Pommel Horse Gymnast at Olympics", "body": "As if the United States' men's gymnastics securing its first Olympic team medal since 2008 wasn't headline-worthy enough, the event's real show-stopping star came in the form of glasses-wearing pommel horse specialist Stephen Nedoroscik. Read to learn more about the 25-year-old who secured the bronze medal at the 2024 Paris Olympics and went viral in one night!\n\nTo anyone watching NBC's live coverage of the gymnastics all-around men team final event on Monday night, the loomingcountdown clock for \"Nedoroscik Pommel\" was contrasted by a calm -- sometimes slumbering -- Nedoroscik, pommel horse specialist for the United States. .\n\nWith the bronze medal in reach for the three different teams going into the gymnastics team final, it came down to Nedoroscik's 45-second routine to endTeam USA's 16-year podium drought.\n\nGlasses off and game face on, Nedoroscik mounted the horizontal bar and delivered thehighest-scoring pommel horse performance of the day, exactly what team needed to hold off Great Britain and Ukraine men's gymnastics teams and win the bronze by a 2.266-point differential to the eventual fourth place finishers.\n\nIn addition to Nedoroscik's clutch pommel horse routine, the USA gymnasts A posted crucial scores on high bar with a 14.833 fromFrederick Richard andAsher Hong's 14.833 on vault to seal their bronze medal fate.\n\nMeet viral gymnastics sensation Stephen Nedoroscik\n\nThe Paris stadium erupted once Nedoroscik stuck the landing and viewers at home took to social media, making Nedoroscik viral not only for his clutch performance but also innocuously 'nerdy' appearance.\n\nBorn and raised in Worcester, Massachusetts , Nedoroscik attendedPenn State where he majored in electrical engineering and became a two-time NCAA national champion on the pommel horse while competing on the gymnastics team.\n\nHe is a four-time pommel horse champion and took home the gold medal on the pommel horse at the 2021 World Artistic Gymnastics Championships. He is tied forthe most U.S. pommel horse titles in U.S. history.\n\nHis signature glasses -- sadly not worn for the purposes of cosplaying as superman's civilian alter ego -- are forstrabismus, or crossed eyes, a condition that can lead to double vision.\n\nNotoriouslythe most technically difficult event in men's artistic gymnastics, pommel horse has been a sore spot on Team USA's lineup for several years.\n\nOriginally hoping for a spot in the Tokyo Olympics in 2020, Nedoroscik missed a place on Team USA's squad after acostly fall during the trials.\n\nNedoroscik had a second chance at his dream during the trials for the 2024 Summer Olympics and realized that dream when he wasnamed to the team in June of this year.\n\nA score of 14.850 on the final day of the trials was enough to punch his ticket to Paris as a pommel horse specialist -- an acquisition that paid off ten-fold for Team USA on Monday night.\n\n\"This feels almost like, you know, my vengeance, right? Coming back swinging,\" Nedoroscik said aboutqualifying for the 2024 Olympic Games.\n\nWhat's next for Stephen Nedoroscik?\n\nThe only member of Team USA to qualify for the final of any individual apparatus, Nedoroscik will compete in the pommel horse final, slated for Saturday, August 3.\n\nKeep scrolling for more 2024 Summer Olympic Game content!\n\nThe Paris Olympics Hijab Ban Has Recently {"uri": "2024-07-438933032", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "02:16:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T02:16:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T02:07:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/world/international/2808248/", "title": "Stephen Nedoroscik sparks viral memes after USA Gymnastics set When to see him compete next", "body": "American gymnast Stephen Nedoroscik, who specializes in the pommel horse event, performed the final routine the U.S. men's gymnasts needed to win their first team medal in 16 years, and his glasses and relaxed demeanor on the competition floor prompted plenty of memes from fans online.\n\nStephen Nedoroscik helped the U.S. men's gymnastics team win a bronze medal. (Photo by Daniela ... [+] (Porcelli/Eurasia Sport Images/Getty Images)\n\nKey information about Getty Images\n\nNedoroscik waited hours to perform on the pommel horse while his teammates went through the other five men's gymnastics events, and his routine was so anticipated that NBC aired an on-screen countdown.\n\nA photo of Nedoroscik waiting for his turn to perform with his glasses on and his eyes closed went viral on social media, with one post on X liked more than 370,000 times indicating that he sat there until he was activated as a sleeper agent, took off his glasses like Clark Kent and did a pommel horse routine that helped give the team its first medal in 16 years.\n\nNedoroscik helped introduce gymnastics to new fans: I've been rooting for this guy ever since I heard about him five minutes ago, one post, featuring a picture of Nedoroscik with his eyes closed, liked 100,000 times, says.\n\nNBC also got in on the memes, referring to Nedoroscik as the Clark Kent of the pommel horse in a post following his performance with side-by-side photos of the gymnast and Kent.\n\nPenn State University, where Nedoroscik attended and competed for the NCAA gymnastics team, posted an image of Nedoroscik with her eyes closed with the text superimposed: 1. Finish, 2. Pommel, 3. Start.\n\nWhen will Stephen Nedoroscik next compete?\n\nNedoroscik will compete in the men's pommel horse final on Saturday at 11:16 a.m. EDT, his final appearance during the Olympics. Nedoroscik is expected to be a medal contender. He advanced to the final with a score tied for the highest 15.200, although Irish gymnast Rhys McClenaghan won the tiebreaker, which is decided by the gymnast with the highest execution score.\n\nKey context\n\nNedoroscik, 25, was born and raised in Worcester, Massachusetts, and began gymnastics in 2003. Nedoroscik's coach, Syque Caesar, told The Washington Post that the gymnast is quirky, funny, goofy and dances to his own beat. Early in his career, Nedoroscik became known for his skills on the pommel horse, but he also gained attention for wearing glasses or goggles while competing. The glasses, which are not prescription, were a Secret Santa gift from his Penn State teammate Ben Cooperman, who joked that Nedoroscik should wear them while competing. \"I started to develop a goofy side when it came to competing and I was like, you know what? It would be fun to wear them. Let's wear them,\" Nedoroscik said. He didn't wear the glasses at the Olympics, telling Olympics.com after the team finals that he hadn't felt like wearing them lately. He's also known for solving Rubik's Cubes. On Monday, before the team finals, Nedoroscik said on Instagram that he had solved a Rubik's Cube in 9.32 seconds, which he considered a good omen. According to his TikTok bio, his Rubik's Cube record is 8.664 seconds. Nedoroscik competed for Penn States' NCAA gymnastics team from 2017 to 2020, where he became a two-time NCAA national champion on the pommel horse. He graduated with a degree in mechanical engineering.\n\nSurprising fact\n\nNedoroscik has competed exclusively on pommel horse for much of his career, unlike his Olympic teammates, who compete in all six men's gymnastics events. Nedoroscik won a gold medal on pommel horse at the 2021 World Gymnastics Championships, a first for the United States and the first gold medal by an American in any event since 2011. He is a four-time national champion on pommel horse.\n\nTangent\n\nNedoroscik scored 14.866 on the pommel horse in the men's team final Monday, the second-highest score on the apparatus that day. His performance helped the U.S. gymnasts claim the bronze medal, the first for the U.S. men's gymnastics team since 2008. Nedoroscik and four other gymnasts Asher Hong, Paul Juda, Frederick Richard and Brody Malone had a total score of 257.793, more than four points higher than their qualifying score of 253.229, where they placed fifth. The U.S. team won bronze behind Japan, the gold medalist, and China, which took silver.\n\nFurther reading\n\nU.S. Men's Gymnastics Team Wins First Olympic Medal in 16 Years (Forbes)\n\nStephen Nedoroscik waited his whole life for a number. The American pommel horse specialist nailed it (Associated Press)\n\nWhat Are The Main Benefits Of Comparing Car Insurance Quotes Online\n\nLOS ANGELES, CA / ACCESSWIRE / June 24, 2020, / Compare-autoinsurance.Org has launched a new blog post that presents the main benefits of comparing multiple car insurance quotes. For more info and free online quotes, please visit https://compare-autoinsurance.Org/the-advantages-of-comparing-prices-with-car-insurance-quotes-online/ The modern society has numerous technological advantages. One important advantage is the speed at which information is sent and received. With the help of the internet, the shopping habits of many persons have drastically changed. The car insurance industry hasn't remained untouched by these changes. On the internet, drivers can compare insurance prices and find out which sellers have the best offers. View photos The advantages of comparing online car insurance quotes are the following: Online quotes can be obtained from anywhere and at any time. Unlike physical insurance agencies, websites don't have a specific schedule and they are available at any time. Drivers that have busy working schedules, can compare quotes from anywhere and at any time, even at midnight. Multiple choices. Almost all insurance providers, no matter if they are well-known brands or just local insurers, have an online presence. Online quotes will allow policyholders the chance to discover multiple insurance companies and check their prices. Drivers are no longer required to get quotes from just a few known insurance companies. Also, local and regional insurers can provide lower insurance rates for the same services. Accurate insurance estimates. Online quotes can only be accurate if the customers provide accurate and real info about their car models and driving history. Lying about past driving incidents can make the price estimates to be lower, but when dealing with an insurance company lying to them is useless. Usually, insurance companies will do research about a potential customer before granting him coverage. Online quotes can be sorted easily. Although drivers are recommended to not choose a policy just based on its price, drivers can easily sort quotes by insurance price. Using brokerage websites will allow drivers to get quotes from multiple insurers, thus making the comparison faster and easier. For additional info, money-saving tips, and free car insurance quotes, visit https://compare-autoinsurance.Org/ Compare-autoinsurance.Org is an online provider of life, home, health, and auto insurance quotes. This website is unique because it does not simply stick to one kind of insurance provider, but brings the clients the best deals from many different online insurance carriers. In this way, clients have access to offers from multiple carriers all in one place: this website. On this site, customers have access to quotes for insurance plans from various agencies, such as local or nationwide agencies, brand names insurance companies, etc. \"Online quotes can easily help drivers obtain better car insurance deals. All they have to do is to complete an online form with accurate and real info, then compare prices\", said Russell Rabichev, Marketing Director of Internet Marketing Company. {"uri": "2024-07-438652182", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "18:14:28", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T18:14:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T18:00:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.cnn.com/2024/07/30/sport/stephen-nedoroscik-pommel-horse-olympics-cec/index.html", "title": "Meet Stephen Nedoroscik, Team USA's 'Clark Kent' pommel horse hero", "body": "Stephen Nedoroscik helped the US men's gymnastics team take home its first medal in 16 years with his near-perfect pommel horse routine.\n\nBefore it was his turn to take center stage at the Paris Olympic Games, Stephen Nedoroscik leaned back and closed his eyes.\n\nBut the bespectacled Olympian wasn't snoozing.\n\nNedoroscik, whose speciality is pommel horse and whose routine would decide whether the US men's artistic gymnastics team would make it to the Olympic podium for the first time in 16 years, was tracing his steps in his head. He breathed slowly to lower his heart rate, he told Today.\n\nWhen it was his turn, Nedoroscik ditched his glasses and Team USA jacket and headed to the pommel horse. And in a near-perfect 40-second routine of quickly swinging both legs around his body and flinging himself into a walking handstand, Nedoroscik secured the team's bronze medal. His teammates' reactions were as euphoric as they might have been if they'd won gold.\n\n\"I don't know what's happening, did we do it?\" he asked his teammates after they hoisted him into the air, triumphant.\n\nThough they won together, it's Nedoroscik who's broken out as the fan favorite, even with his limited performance time. He's earning Clark Kent comparisons for the unassuming demeanor and similar specs he wears before losing both to become a confident pommel horse hero.\n\nNedoroscik, for his part, thinks the memes he's inspired are \"awesome.\"\n\n\"I'm representing people who wear glasses well,\" he said, beaming, in a Tuesday appearance on \"Today.\"\n\nHere's what to know about Nedoroscik, the US men's gymnastics team's very own Superman.\n\nHe's Team USA's pommel horse pro\n\nStephen Nedoroscik defied gravity on the pommel horse at Monday's men's gymnastics team final.\n\nAbbie Parr/AP\n\nWhile teammates like Brody Malone and Fred Richard flit between events like rings and vault, Nedoroscik only performs on one apparatus: pommel horse. He's the first American gymnast to make the Olympic team as a specialist in a single event, according to his training gym, Evo Gymnastics in Sarasota, Florida.\n\nHe dropped the other events in artistic gymnastics seven year ago, he told USA Gymnastics, after winning two Junior Olympic National titles in pommel horse and joining Penn State's men's gymnastics program.\n\nSpecializing has succeeded: Commentators said that he's perhaps the best in the world at what he does.\n\nNedoroscik, it seems, takes himself less seriously than he does his sport.\n\n\"I go internationally and I see all the other (pommel) horse specialists. It seems to be a universal thing that we're quirky people that are kind of just fun,\" he said.\n\nHe was a world champion before Paris\n\nNedoroscik and the US men's gymnastics team earned a bronze medal in Paris, but on another world stage, he's won gold.\n\nAt the 2021 World Artistic Gymnastics Championships in Kitakyushu, Japan, conditions were less than ideal for Nedoroscik to medal at all: The phenom had broken his hand.\n\nIt didn't matter: Nedoroscik still came in first -- the first time the US had ever earned a gold medal for pommel horse at a world championship.\n\nStateside, he's been crowned the US pommel horse champion four times, tying the record for most pommel horse wins, per USA Gymnastics.\n\nThe Paris Games are Nedoroscik's first Olympics -- he missed the chance in 2020 after a disappointing performance in the Olympic trials.\n\n\"I messed up,\" he told CNN affiliate WBBH in Fort Myers, Florida, ahead of this year's Games. \"I felt the pressure and kind of crumbled under it.\"\n\nBut the blow didn't keep him down for long. Nedoroscik decided to \"redirect that energy immediately,\" get back in the gym and keep training. He followed up those disappointing trials with his thrilling performance at the world championships, and since then, he's kept on winning.\n\nHe's a puzzle fiend\n\nAs if competing at the highest level of gymnastics weren't enough, Nedoroscik is also an \u00fcber-competitive puzzler. His personal record for solving a Rubik's Cube is 8.6 seconds.\n\nHe took time off from \"cubing,\" though, after a particularly hard puzzle consumed his downtime. His gymnastics teammate Fred Richard turned him on to \"killer sudoku,\" a version of the puzzle that involves more math. Nedoroscik found a killer sudoku puzzle that claimed to be the \"world's hardest,\" and after 45 hours of puzzling, he became the 43rd person in the world to solve it.\n\nThe experience nearly ruined the Rubik's Cube for him, he said.\n\n\"I tried to get back into cubing, and it wasn't the same,\" he told USA Gymnastics ahead of the Olympics. \"I was kind of lost.\"\n\nHis cubing slump ended along with the US men's gymnastics drought at the Olympics. He brought his trusty cube with him to Paris and solved it on the day of the team final in just over nine seconds.\n\n\"It's stress relief,\" he said on his Tuesday \"Today\" appearance. \"Sometimes I make the excuse that it's good for wrist rehab, too.\"\n\nHe competes with an eye sensitivity\n\nThe specs are cool for Clark Kent comparisons, but without them, Nedoroscik wouldn't be able to see his adoring crowd at the Olympics. Nedoroscik has strabismus, or crossed eyes, and has trouble seeing without them.\n\nOn \"Today,\" while wearing host Hoda Kotb's borrowed Ray-Bans, Nedoroscik said that when he's up on the pommel horse without his glasses, he depends not on sight but feel.\n\n\"I don't even really see when I'm doing my gymnastics,\" he said. \"It's all in the hands. I can feel everything.\"\n\nHe hasn't always competed with limited vision. Nedoroscik used to wear goggles on the pommel horse during his time at Penn State, but he said in June that he \"hadn't really felt like\" wearing them on the Olympic stage.\n\nHe hinted that the new look may have had something to do with testing his own limits.\n\n\"Sometimes, I like to push the boundaries,\" he said.\n\nPushing paid off in Paris. His kryptonite is not, it seems, the pressure of performing on the world's biggest stage in sports.\n\nHe'll have a brief break between the Olympics and his next venture: Swinging around the US with Simone Biles and some of his men's gymnastics teammates on the Gold Over America tour. The pommel horse pro will take the stage beginning in September.", "source": {"uri": "cnn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CNN"}, "authors": [{"uri": "scottie_andrew@cnn.com", "name": "Scottie {"uri": "8250764971", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "13:48:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T13:48:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T13:47:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://hollywoodlife.com/feature/meet-the-pommel-horse-guy-stephen-nedoroscik-5305582/", "title": "Olympics: Meet Stephen Nedoroscik, the 'Pommel Horse Guy'", "body": "Stephen Nedoroscik has now been described as a sleeper agent, akin to Clark Kent with the way he takes off his glasses before swinging into action, but most may refer to him as the 'Pommel Horse Guy'.\n\nWhile most male gymnasts train for multiple routines, Nedoroscik specializes in just one: the pommel horse. Due to his specialty, the U.S. men's gymnastics team walked away from the Olympics with a bronze medal -- the team's first in men's gymnastics since 2008.\n\nMikulak, a three-time Olympian turned coach, told the athlete that he didn't need to go all out. That 80% would be good enough, even though Mikulak knew full well that Nedoroscik never does anything -- whether in his sport or solving a Rubik's Cube -- at 80%.\n\nThe announcers struggled to put into words the pressure Nedoroscik was under as Team USA closed in on its first team medal since 2008. \"You have to trick yourself,\" said Mikulak. \"You've got to make sure you don't let all the noise get into your head.\"\n\nThe pommel horse was the final event for Team USA's rotation, and the Penn State grad was the last member of Team USA to attempt his only routine. The NBC broadcast even included a timer for the lead-up to Nedoroscik's event.\n\nAfter a long wait, the Olympian performed his moves on the pommel horse in just 40 seconds. His score put Team USA ahead of Team Great Britain, which came in fourth place, by two points.\n\nBecause the pommel horse has long been a weakness for the U.S. men's national team program, Nedoroscik essentially decided to dedicate himself to a single pursuit. His attitude of \"there's still something to improve\" paid off for Team USA.\n\n\"Going up to pommel horse, the last guy up in the whole competition, I had a good feeling that our team was in a great spot. I just knew I had to go up there and do my job,\" he told NBC in an interview after the event.\n\nAnd landing the dismount, he said, was the \"best moment of my life.\"\n\nHere's everything you need to know about Team USA's closer ...\n\nNedoroscik is from Worcester, Massachusetts, and majored in electrical engineering at Penn State.\n\nThe 25-year-old competed in college from 2017 to 2019, winning two NCAA titles on the pommel horse in 2017 and 2018 and finishing as the runner-up in 2019.\n\nIn 2014, a coach who had trained the national pommel-horse champion the previous year approached Nedoroscik and told him he could be the national champion one day, Time magazine reported.\n\nHe went on to become the first American to win a gold medal on the pommel horse at the 2021 World Championships.\n\nThe 2024 Olympics marked his first time making Team USA at the Olympic Games.\n\nNedoroscik was just one competitor on one event in the team final for Team USA. To get him in position to perform that routine for the bronze medal were Paul Juda, Fred Richard, Asher Hong, and Brody Malone. Richard and Juda both compete for Michigan, while Hong and Malone competed for Stanford.\n\nTeammates Richard, Malone, Juda, and Hong had completed 17 straight routines without a miss, putting the Americans in position to reach the medal stand for the first time since 2008 in Beijing.", "source": {"uri": "hollywoodlife.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Hollywood Life"}, "authors": [], "https://hollywoodlife.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/GettyImages-2163825873_81433e-e1722343622884.jpg?quality=100&w=1024", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9768598", "eventUri": "eng-9768598", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.1372549019607843, "wgt": 200, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-07-438671402", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "18:37:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T18:37:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T18:32:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/sports/meet-team-usa-s-clark-kent-pommel-horse-hero-1.6983134", "title": "Meet Team USA's 'Clark Kent' pommel horse hero", "body": "Before it was his turn to take center stage at the Paris Olympic Games, Stephen Nedoroscik leaned back and closed his eyes.\n\nBut the bespectacled Olympian wasn't snoozing.\n\nNedoroscik, whose speciality is pommel horse and whose routine would decide whether the US men's artistic gymnastics team would make it to the Olympic podium for the first time in 16 years, was tracing his steps in his head. He breathed slowly to lower his heart rate, he told Today.\n\nWhen it was his turn, Nedoroscik ditched his glasses and Team USA jacket and headed to the pommel horse. And in a near-perfect 40-second routine of quickly swinging both legs around his body and flinging himself into a walking handstand, Nedoroscik secured the team's bronze medal. His teammates' reactions were as euphoric as they might have been if they'd won gold.\n\n\"I don't know what's happening, did we do it?\" he asked his teammates after they hoisted him into the air, triumphant.\n\nThough they won together, it's Nedoroscik who's broken out as the fan favorite, even with his limited performance time. He's earning Clark Kent comparisons for the unassuming demeanor and similar specs he wears before losing both to become a confident pommel horse hero.\n\nNedoroscik, for his part, thinks the memes he's inspired are \"awesome.\"\n\n\"I'm representing people who wear glasses well,\" he said, beaming, in a Tuesday appearance on \"Today.\"\n\nHere's what to know about Nedoroscik, the U.S. men's gymnastics team's very own Superman.\n\nHe's Team USA's pommel horse pro\n\nWhile teammates like Brody Malone and Fred Richard flit between events like rings and vault, Nedoroscik only performs on one apparatus: pommel horse. He's the first American gymnast to make the Olympic team as a specialist in a single event, according to his training gym, Evo Gymnastics in Sarasota, Florida.\n\nHe dropped the other events in artistic gymnastics seven year ago, he told USA Gymnastics, after winning two Junior Olympic National titles in pommel horse and joining Penn State's men's gymnastics program.\n\nSpecializing has succeeded: Commentators said that he's perhaps the best in the world at what he does.\n\nNedoroscik, it seems, takes himself less seriously than he does his sport.\n\n\"I go internationally and I see all the other (pommel) horse specialists. It seems to be a universal thing that we're quirky people that are kind of just fun,\" he said.\n\nHe was a world champion before Paris\n\nNedoroscik and the US men's gymnastics team earned a bronze medal in Paris, but on another world stage, he's won gold.\n\nAt the 2021 World Artistic Gymnastics Championships in Kitakyushu, Japan, conditions were less than ideal for Nedoroscik to medal at all: The phenom had broken his hand.\n\nIt didn't matter: Nedoroscik still came in first -- the first time the U.S. had ever earned a gold medal for pommel horse at a world championship.\n\nStateside, he's been crowned the US pommel horse champion four times, tying the record for most pommel horse wins, per USA Gymnastics.\n\nThe Paris Games are Nedoroscik's first Olympics -- he missed the chance in 2020 after a disappointing performance in the Olympic trials.\n\n\"I messed up,\" he told CNN affiliate WBBH in Fort Myers, Florida, ahead of this year's Games. \"I felt the pressure and kind of crumbled under it.\"\n\nBut the blow didn't keep him down for long. Nedoroscik decided to \"redirect that energy immediately,\" get back in the gym and keep training. He followed up those disappointing trials with his thrilling performance at the world championships, and since then, he's kept on winning.\n\nHe's a puzzle fiend\n\nAs if competing at the highest level of gymnastics weren't enough, Nedoroscik is also an \u00fcber-competitive puzzler. His personal record for solving a Rubik's Cube is 8.6 seconds.\n\nHe took time off from \"cubing,\" though, after a particularly hard puzzle consumed his downtime. His gymnastics teammate Fred Richard turned him on to \"killer sudoku,\" a version of the puzzle that involves more math. Nedoroscik found a killer sudoku puzzle that claimed to be the \"world's hardest,\" and after 45 hours of puzzling, he became the 43rd person in the world to solve it.\n\nThe experience nearly ruined the Rubik's Cube for him, he said.\n\n\"I tried to get back into cubing, and it wasn't the same,\" he told USA Gymnastics ahead of the Olympics. \"I was kind of lost.\"\n\nHis cubing slump ended along with the US men's gymnastics drought at the Olympics. He brought his trusty cube with him to Paris and solved it on the day of the team final in just over nine seconds.\n\n\"It's stress relief,\" he said on his Tuesday \"Today\" appearance. \"Sometimes I make the excuse that it's good for wrist rehab, too.\"\n\nHe competes with an eye sensitivity\n\nThe specs are cool for Clark Kent comparisons, but without them, Nedoroscik wouldn't be able to see his adoring crowd at the Olympics. Nedoroscik has strabismus, or crossed eyes, and has trouble seeing without them.\n\nOn \"Today,\" while wearing host Hoda Kotb's borrowed Ray-Bans, Nedoroscik said that when he's up on the pommel horse without his glasses, he depends not on sight but feel.\n\n\"I don't even really see when I'm doing my gymnastics,\" he said. \"It's all in the hands. I can feel everything.\"\n\nHe hasn't always competed with limited vision. Nedoroscik used to wear goggles on the pommel horse during his time at Penn State, but he said in June that he \"hadn't really felt like\" wearing them on the Olympic stage.\n\nHe hinted that the new look may have had something to do with testing his own limits.\n\n\"Sometimes, I like to push the boundaries,\" he said.\n\nPushing paid off in Paris. His kryptonite is not, it seems, the pressure of performing on the world's biggest stage in sports.\n\nHe'll have a brief break between the Olympics and his next venture: Swinging around the U.S. with Simone Biles and some of his men's gymnastics teammates on the Gold Over America tour. The pommel horse pro will take the stage beginning in September.", "source": {"uri": "ctvnews.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "CTV News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8250832751", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "14:30:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T14:30:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T14:29:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.forbes.com/sites/conormurray/2024/07/30/us-gymnast-stephen-nedoroscik-goes-viral-after-helping-team-secure-bronze-heres-when-hell-compete-next/", "title": "U.S. Gymnast Stephen Nedoroscik Goes Viral After Helping Team Secure Bronze -- Here's When He'll Compete Next", "body": "American gymnast Stephen Nedoroscik, who specializes on the pommel horse event, performed the very last routine that the U.S. men's gymnasts needed to secure their first team medal in 16 years, and his glasses and relaxed demeanor on the competition floor have sparked plenty of internet memes from fans.\n\nNedoroscik will compete in the men's pommel horse final on Saturday at 11:16 a.m. EDT, his last appearance during the Olympics. Nedoroscik is expected to be a contender for a medal. He qualified into the final with a tie for the highest score -- 15.200 -- though Irish gymnast Rhys McClenaghan won the tiebreak, which is decided based on which gymnast has the higher execution score.\n\nNedoroscik, 25, was born and raised in Worcester, Massachusetts, and started gymnastics in 2003. Syque Caesar, Nedoroscik's coach, told the Washington Post the gymnast is \"quirky, funny, goofy\" and \"dances to his own tune.\" Early in his career, Nedoroscik became known for his abilities on the pommel horse -- but he also garnered attention for wearing glasses or goggles during competition. The goggles, which aren't prescription, were a Secret Santa gift from his teammate at Penn State University, Ben Cooperman, who joked that Nedoroscik should wear them during competition. \"I started to form a goofiness when it came to competing and I was like, you know what? It'd be fun to put them on. Let's put 'em on,\" Nedoroscik said. He hasn't worn the goggles at the Olympics, telling Olympics.com after the team finals that he hasn't felt like wearing them lately. He is also known for solving Rubik's Cubes. On Monday, before the team final, Nedoroscik said on Instagram he solved one in 9.32 seconds, which he considered a \"good omen.\" According to his TikTok bio, his Rubik's Cube record is 8.664 seconds. Nedoroscik competed for Penn State's NCAA gymnastics team between 2017 and 2020, where he became a two-time NCAA national champion on the pommel horse. He graduated with a degree in mechanical engineering.\n\nNedoroscik has solely competed on the pommel horse for much of his career -- a contrast to his Olympic teammates, who compete on all six events in men's gymnastics. Nedoroscik won a gold medal on the pommel horse at the 2021 world gymnastics championships, a first for the United States and the first gold medal for an American man in any event since 2011. He is a four-time national champion on the pommel horse.\n\nNedoroscik scored a 14.866 on the pommel horse during the men's team final on Monday, a tie for the second-highest score on the apparatus that day. His performance helped the U.S. men's gymnasts clinch the bronze medal, the first for the American men's gymnastics team since 2008. Nedoroscik and the other four gymnasts -- Asher Hong, Paul Juda, Frederick Richard and Brody Malone -- earned a total team score of 257.793, more than four points higher than their qualification round score of 253.229, where they ranked fifth. The U.S. team won the bronze behind Japan, the gold medal winning team, and China, which took the silver.\n\nU.S. Men's Gymnastics Team Wins First Olympic Medal In 16 Years (Forbes)", "source": {"uri": "8250954433", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "15:52:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T15:52:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T15:51:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.usmagazine.com/entertainment/news/team-usa-gymnast-stephen-nedoroscik-best-memes-of-the-2024-olympics/", "title": "Us Can't Get Enough of Team USA Men's Gymnastics Star Stephen Nedoroscik", "body": "Gymnast Stephen Nedoroscik became a fan favorite as he helped the Team USA men earn their first Olympic medal in 16 years.\n\nThe 25-year-old is a two-time NCAA National Champion and a 2021 World Champion, specializing in the pommel horse. He won the 2024 U.S. National Championships title in the event, leading to his selection to compete in the Olympic Trials. His impressive performance officially earned him a spot on Team USA alongside fellow gymnasts Brody Malone, Fred Richard, Asher Hong and Paul Juda.\n\nWhen the competition began in Paris, Nedoroscik quickly stole viewers' hearts with one crucial accessory: his glasses.\n\n\"Obsessed with this one guy on the US men's gymnastics team who looks like he's getting his phd in anthropology and his only job is pommel horse,\" one viewer tweeted as Nedoroscik prepped for the men's team finals on Monday, July 29.\n\nAnother fan wrote, \"I know nothing about gymnastics and here I am living and dying with whether this nerdy guy in glasses named Steve can pommel that horse. The Olympics are a curse.\"\n\nAs a specialist, Nedoroscik doesn't compete in other events in the rotation, including vault, floor, parallel bars and more. During Monday's team final, Nedoroscik was the last to hit the pommel horse -- and NBC's Olympics broadcast even included a countdown clock to his routine. A pic of Nedoroscik taking a nap (or resting his eyes? meditating?) while waiting for his moment instantly went viral.\n\nWhen it's his time to compete, Nedoroscik takes his glasses off. \"It's not necessarily clear,\" he told Today of his vision. \"But the thing about pommel horse is if I keep [my glasses] on, they're gonna fly somewhere.\"\n\nHe continued, \"When I go up on the pommel horse, it's all about feeling the equipment. I don't even really see when I'm doing my gymnastics. It's all in the hands -- I can feel everything.\"\n\nNedoroscik and his teammates earned the first Olympic medal for the U.S. in men's gymnastics since 2008, taking home the bronze on Monday. He'll compete in the individual pommel horse final on Saturday, August 3.\n\nScroll down to see more of the best memes about Nedoroscik from the 2024 Paris Olympics:", "source": {"uri": "usmagazine.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Us Weekly"}, "authors": [{"uri": "meredith_nardino@usmagazine.com", "name": "Meredith Nardino", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": {"uri": "8250565381", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "11:47:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T11:47:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T11:46:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://dnyuz.com/2024/07/30/us-mens-gymnast-stephen-nedoroscik-goes-viral-as-he-shines-on-pommel-horse-american-icon/", "title": "US men's gymnast Stephen Nedoroscik goes viral as he shines on pommel horse: 'American icon'", "body": "American men's gymnast Stephen Nedoroscik went viral on Monday as he waited around during the team final for his chance to secure a spot on the podium with a pommel horse performance.\n\nThe Paris Olympics broadcast camera kept showing Nedoroscik getting mentally prepared for his event as he watched his other teammates, Frederick Richard, Brody Malone, Paul Juda and Asher Hong, compete in the other disciplines. Nedoroscik was only needed for the pommel horse.\n\nHowever, he caught the eye of social media users who tuned into the event.\n\nNedoroscik got his chance to shine on the pommel horse and he delivered. He scored a 15.166.\n\n\"It went really well today, I handled the nerves very well,\" he said after helping secure the men's gymnastics team's first medal since 2008, a bronze. \"I worked my whole life up to those 45 seconds.\"\n\nNedoroscik will compete again in the pommel horse final next week.\n\n\"This is just another day of doing the gymnastics,\" he said. \"Sure it's the biggest stage in the world. It only happens once every four years, but at the same time I'm putting chalk on my hands and doing the horse for the team, it's nothing different.\"\n\nHe has become the specialist the U.S. men's gymnastics team has needed all along. {"uri": "2024-07-437500389", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "19:27:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T19:27:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T19:16:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://eu.heraldtribune.com/story/sports/olympics/2024/07/29/paris-games-sarasota-mens-gymnasts-lead-us-team-to-first-team-medal-since-2008/74592371007/", "title": "2024 Olympics: Sarasota-based gymnasts lead US men's team to first Olympic medal since 2008", "body": "PARIS - For the first time in 16 years, the U.S. men's gymnastics team has won an Olympic medal.\n\nBuoyed by a resurgent performance from national champion Brody Malone, who competed in five of the six events, Team USA held off Great Britain and Ukraine to win bronze at the 2024 Olympics. Japan surged to gold in the final rotation, while China took silver.\n\nIt's the first time the American men have been on the Olympic podium since 2008, when Jonathan Horton led them to bronze. And ultimately, they finished closer to second-place China (1.3 points off) than they did fourth-place Great Britain (2.2 points).\n\nStephen Nedoroscik, a pommel horse specialist whose only contribution to the team score came on the very last routine of the night, helped clinch the bronze for Team USA with a solid performance. But every member of the team hit clutch routines, including Paul Juda and Asher Hong on vault and Frederick Richard on high bar.\n\nThe Americans finished fifth at each of the previous three Summer Olympics, and they finished fifth again in Saturday's qualifying. The difference on Monday largely revolved around Malone.\n\nMalone, 24, had been expected to qualify for the all-around individual final and perhaps even contend for a medal, but he had a dreadful showing in qualifying - with falls on pommel horse, floor and even high bar, the event in which he won a world championship in 2022. It was such a jarring performance that some of his teammates later said he apologized to them afterwards.\n\n\"I know Brody's a dog and a competitor,\" Hong said. \"So I know he's going to come into team finals and full send.\"\n\nAnd he did. Malone improved upon or matched his performances on every apparatus, including a significantly better showing on high bar that helped keep the U.S. ahead of its bronze rivals. After falling twice on the apparatus in qualifying, he looked much more comfortable - and stuck the landing - for a score that was nearly two full points higher than his score Saturday.\n\nHong, Juda and Richard, meanwhile, each competed in four events - each pumping up their teammates, and the crowd, between routines. Chants of \"U-S-A!\" rang out at Bercy Arena at multiple points over the course of the night.\n\nAlthough China and Japan were long considered the favorites, the U.S. knew for months that it would benefit from the absence of Russia, which is banned from team competitions at these Olympics because of its invasion of Ukraine.\n\nThe Americans knew the bronze medal was there for the taking. And they took it.\n\nStephen Nedoroscik dazzles on pommel horse\n\nStephen Nedoroscik closed out the U.S. men's rotation on pommel horse, nailing his routine and enciting a massive cheer from the crowd, including a chant of \"USA! USA!\" His teammates threw him in the air in celebration. He earned a score of 14.866.\n\nBrody Malone on pommel horse\n\nBrody Malone scored a 13.700 on pommel horse, leaving only Stephen Nedoroscik's turn on the rotation.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8251151696", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "18:25:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T18:25:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T18:19:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://keyt.com/sports/national-sports/cnn-sports/2024/07/30/meet-team-usas-clark-kent-pommel-horse-hero/", "title": "Meet Team USA's 'Clark Kent' pommel horse hero", "body": "(CNN) -- Before it was his turn to take center stage at the Paris Olympic Games, Stephen Nedoroscik leaned back and closed his eyes.\n\nBut the bespectacled Olympian wasn't snoozing.\n\nNedoroscik, whose speciality is pommel horse and whose routine would decide whether the US men's artistic gymnastics team would make it to the Olympic podium for the first time in 16 years, was tracing his steps in his head. He breathed slowly to lower his heart rate, he told Today.\n\nWhen it was his turn, Nedoroscik ditched his glasses and Team USA jacket and headed to the pommel horse. And in a near-perfect 40-second routine of quickly swinging both legs around his body and flinging himself into a walking handstand, Nedoroscik secured the team's bronze medal. His teammates' reactions were as euphoric as they might have been if they'd won gold.\n\n\"I don't know what's happening, did we do it?\" he asked his teammates after they hoisted him into the air, triumphant.\n\nThough they won together, it's Nedoroscik who's broken out as the fan favorite, even with his limited performance time. He's earning Clark Kent comparisons for the unassuming demeanor and similar specs he wears before losing both to become a confident pommel horse hero.\n\nNedoroscik, for his part, thinks the memes he's inspired are \"awesome.\"\n\n\"I'm representing people who wear glasses well,\" he said, beaming, in a Tuesday appearance on \"Today.\"\n\nHere's what to know about Nedoroscik, the US men's gymnastics team's very own Superman.\n\nWhile teammates like Brody Malone and Fred Richard flit between events like rings and vault, Nedoroscik only performs on one apparatus: pommel horse. He's the first American gymnast to make the Olympic team as a specialist in a single event, according to his training gym, Evo Gymnastics in Sarasota, Florida.\n\nHe dropped the other events in artistic gymnastics seven year ago, he told USA Gymnastics, after winning two Junior Olympic National titles in pommel horse and joining Penn State's men's gymnastics program.\n\nSpecializing has succeeded: Commentators said that he's perhaps the best in the world at what he does.\n\nNedoroscik, it seems, takes himself less seriously than he does his sport.\n\n\"I go internationally and I see all the other (pommel) horse specialists. It seems to be a universal thing that we're quirky people that are kind of just fun,\" he said.\n\nNedoroscik and the US men's gymnastics team earned a bronze medal in Paris, but on another world stage, he's won gold.\n\nAt the 2021 World Artistic Gymnastics Championships in Kitakyushu, Japan, conditions were less than ideal for Nedoroscik to medal at all: The phenom had broken his hand.\n\nIt didn't matter: Nedoroscik still came in first -- the first time the US had ever earned a gold medal for pommel horse at a world championship.\n\nStateside, he's been crowned the US pommel horse champion four times, tying the record for most pommel horse wins, per USA Gymnastics.\n\nThe Paris Games are Nedoroscik's first Olympics -- he missed the chance in 2020 after a disappointing performance in the Olympic trials.\n\n\"I messed up,\" he told CNN affiliate WBBH in Fort Myers, Florida, ahead of this year's Games. \"I felt the pressure and kind of crumbled under it.\"\n\nBut the blow didn't keep him down for long. Nedoroscik decided to \"redirect that energy immediately,\" get back in the gym and keep training. He followed up those disappointing trials with his thrilling performance at the world championships, and since then, he's kept on winning.\n\nAs if competing at the highest level of gymnastics weren't enough, Nedoroscik is also an \u00fcber-competitive puzzler. His personal record for solving a Rubik's Cube is 8.6 seconds.\n\nHe took time off from \"cubing,\" though, after a particularly hard puzzle consumed his downtime. His gymnastics teammate Fred Richard turned him on to \"killer sudoku,\" a version of the puzzle that involves more math. Nedoroscik found a killer sudoku puzzle that claimed to be the \"world's hardest,\" and after 45 hours of puzzling, he became the 43rd person in the world to solve it.\n\nThe experience nearly ruined the Rubik's Cube for him, he said.\n\n\"I tried to get back into cubing, and it wasn't the same,\" he told USA Gymnastics ahead of the Olympics. \"I was kind of lost.\"\n\nHis cubing slump ended along with the US men's gymnastics drought at the Olympics. He brought his trusty cube with him to Paris and solved it on the day of the team final in just over nine seconds.\n\n\"It's stress relief,\" he said on his Tuesday \"Today\" appearance. \"Sometimes I make the excuse that it's good for wrist rehab, too.\"\n\nThe specs are cool for Clark Kent comparisons, but without them, Nedoroscik wouldn't be able to see his adoring crowd at the Olympics. Nedoroscik has strabismus, or crossed eyes, and has trouble seeing without them.\n\nOn \"Today,\" while wearing host Hoda Kotb's borrowed Ray-Bans, Nedoroscik said that when he's up on the pommel horse without his glasses, he depends not on sight but feel.\n\n\"I don't even really see when I'm doing my gymnastics,\" he said. \"It's all in the hands. I can feel everything.\"\n\nHe hasn't always competed with limited vision. Nedoroscik used to wear goggles on the pommel horse during his time at Penn State, but he said in June that he \"hadn't really felt like\" wearing them on the Olympic stage.\n\nHe hinted that the new look may have had something to do with testing his own limits.\n\n\"Sometimes, I like to push the boundaries,\" he said.\n\nPushing paid off in Paris. His kryptonite is not, it seems, the pressure of performing on the world's biggest stage in sports.\n\nHe'll have a brief break between the Olympics and his next venture: Swinging around the US with Simone Biles and some of his men's gymnastics teammates on the Gold Over America tour. The pommel horse pro will take the stage beginning in September.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. {"uri": "8251114162", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "17:50:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T17:50:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T17:49:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/pommel-horse-hero-stephen-nedoroscik-174624577.html", "title": "Who Is Pommel Horse Hero Stephen Nedoroscik? Meet the Olympic Gymnast (and Viral Meme!) Capturing Hearts", "body": "U.S. men's gymnast Stephen Nedoroscik helped Team USA secure their first medal in 16 years at the 2024 Olympics\n\nStephen Nedoroscik proved himself to be the Clark Kent of the pommel horse at the 2024 Olympics.\n\nThe Olympic gymnast helped propel his team to win bronze at the men's gymnastics team final at the Paris Olympics -- their first medal in 16 years. While the team is composed of five men -- including Paul Juda, Fred Richard, Brody Malone and Asher Hong -- Nedoroscik was the only member to qualify for a single event -- pommel horse -- at the team final on July 29, whereas his teammates each performed across the other five events. Despite his seemingly smaller role, his high score ultimately clenched the team's bronze win.\n\n\"It was just the greatest moment of my life, I think,\" the athlete told reporters, including PEOPLE, after excelling at his routine. \"[I'm] so happy to have been there.\"\n\nIn addition to being an Olympian, Nedoroscik quickly became an internet sensation thanks to his thick glasses, which social media users likened to Clark Kent. Though he was previously referred to as the \"goggles guy\" for the sports glasses he wore while he competed, Nedoroscik went sans glasses during his performance, explaining that he doesn't need his eyes to see the pommel horse.\n\n\"I don't think I actually use my eyes on pommel horse,\" he told The Washington Post. \"It's all feeling. I see with my hands.\"\n\nSo who is Stephen Nedoroscik? Here's everything to know about the pommel horse hero who helped the U.S. men's gymnastics team secure their first Olympic medal in nearly two decades.\n\nNedoroscik was born on Oct. 28, 1998, and raised in Worcester, Mass. He grew up attending the Sterling Academy of Gymnastics in Sterling, Mass., where he was cheered on during a watch party of the men's team finals.\n\n\"My parents started this business in 1992 with the smallest of dreams,\" owner Matt Carbone told NBC Boston. \"But 32 years later, we now have an Olympic bronze medalist, and he's still going on to compete in event finals on Saturday. It's absolutely incredible.\"\n\nCarbone remembered Nedoroscik as a \"goofy\" boy, whose banner now hangs in the gym for other children in the academy to look up to.\n\n\"He was a typical goofy little boy that would play around on the equipment and get in trouble at times and just had fun with gymnastics,\" Carbone said.\n\nNedoroscik committed to Pennsylvania State University in his senior year of high school to join their gymnastics team, announcing his decision on Instagram in November 2015.\n\n\"It took a long time to decide but I'm excited to announce I've verbally committed to Penn State, and in the process of signing the letter of intent, can't wait for college!\" he wrote in the caption of his announcement.\n\nThe athlete enrolled at Penn State in August 2016 and graduated four years later in December 2020 with a degree in electrical engineering. Since he finished school during the COVID-19 pandemic, Nedoroscik celebrated his graduation at home with a televised commencement.\n\n\"No recruiting trips. Didn't know collegiate gymnastics was an option until junior year,\" he wrote in his graduation post on Instagram. \"Penn State took a serious risk in taking me in, and I will forever be grateful for that opportunity.\"\n\nUnlike the other gymnasts on the U.S. men's team, Nedorocsik is a specialist in just one skill: the pommel horse. His task includes spinning around the figure and performing a 45-second routine filled with skills and tricks that he's trained for years but often may need to improvise in the moment depending on a number of factors.\n\nPicking a specialist for the Olympics was a controversial move. However, the pommel horse is where the U.S. men's team has historically struggled and Nedorocsik was the U.S. selection committee's answer to the problem.\n\n\"I was completely aware of it,\" Nedoroscik told the Post of the criticism he received. \"I really wanted to make the Olympic team, and I knew that there was going to be backlash to it. I do one event compared to these guys that are phenomenal all-arounders. And I am a phenomenal horse guy. But it's hard to fit on a five-guy team.\"\n\nNedoroscik isn't just a one-trick pony -- he can also solve a Rubik's cube at an incredibly fast speed. Before his performance at the finals on July 29, the gymnast posted a photo of his Instagram Stories of himself completing a Rubik's cube in 9.321 seconds, writing \"Good omen\" above the image.\n\nPer his TikTok bio, his personal best is 8.664 seconds.\n\nThe Olympian has made waves on social media not only for his incredible athletic prowess, but also for his thick glasses. Nedoroscik has strabismus, a condition where one eye is turned in a direction that's different from the other. Commonly known as crossed eyes, the athlete has control over which is the dominant eye, demonstrating his ability to switch in an August 2022 TikTok.\n\nAfter his performance, social media users began comparing Nedoroscik's appearance to that of Clark Kent, who also wears thick glasses when he's not his alterego, Superman. Even NBC's official Olympics account shared a post on X comparing a side-by-side photo of Nedoroscik with Christopher Reeves as Kent, calling the gymnast \"the Clark Kent of pommel horse.\"\n\n\"I think they're awesome,\" Nedoroscik said on TODAY of the comparison posts a day after his performance. \"You know, representing the people that wear glasses well.\"\n\nHowever, during competition Nedoroscik takes his glasses off, explaining on the show that he doesn't need them to perform well or see the pommel horse.\n\n\"When I go up on the pommel horse, it's all about feeling the equipment,\" he said. \"I don't even really see when I'm doing my gymnastics. It's all in the hands. I can feel everything.\"\n\nBefore his turn was up at the finals, Nedoroscik was getting himself in the zone, leaving the arena at one point to practice in the warmup gym. Minutes before he was up, a camera captured Nedoroscik leaning his head back and sitting with his eyes closed and glasses on -- a meme that quickly went viral.\n\n\"I'm doing my breathing exercises,\" he shared on TODAY. \"We always try to keep our heart rate down and through that five minutes I'm sitting there, I'm just visualizing my routine over and over ... that's all I'm doing in my head.\"\n\nAfter his teammates performed in the five other events for the artistic gymnastics men's team finals, it was Nedoroscik's turn to secure a medal for the team. He nailed his routine, earning a score of 14.866 and a bronze for Team USA.\n\nThough he was last after a \"long day,\" Nedoroscik told reporters, including PEOPLE, he was happy to go last.\n\n\"I framed that in my head as a positive, like I can be the exclamation point,\" he said.\n\nWith his teammates cheering for him on the sidelines and his coach's pep talk, Nedoroscik knew when he finished his performance that they had found success.\n\n\"I kind of, in that moment, was like, 'Alright, let's run it back, then. Let's go out there and do our thing,' \" he said. \"I have [coach] Sam Mikulak as just like, the greatest coach of all time. He's up there, helping me keep the nerves in check. He knows exactly what to say to me. So when we got that chalk bucket, he kind of just settled me down and said, 'You're ready for this.' I went up there, did my routine and during that dismount, I was just like, already smiling.\"", "source": {"uri": "ca.sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports Canada"}, "authors": {"uri": "2024-07-437453709", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "18:23:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T18:23:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T18:21:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://eu.telegram.com/story/sports/olympics/2024/07/29/olympic-gymnastics-live-results-mens-team/74502516007/", "title": "Olympic gymnastics live updates: US men win bronze in team final, first medal in 16 years", "body": "PARIS - For the first time in 16 years, the U.S. men's gymnastics team has won an Olympic medal.\n\nBuoyed by a resurgent performance from national champion Brody Malone, who competed in five of the six events, Team USA held off Great Britain and Ukraine to win bronze at the 2024 Olympics. Japan surged to gold in the final rotation, while China took silver.\n\nIt's the first time the American men have been on the Olympic podium since 2008, when Jonathan Horton led them to bronze. And ultimately, they finished closer to second-place China (1.3 points off) than they did fourth-place Great Britain (2.2 points).\n\nGet Olympics updates in your texts! Join USA TODAY Sports' WhatsApp Channel\n\nStephen Nedoroscik, a pommel horse specialist whose only contribution to the team score came on the very last routine of the night, helped clinch the bronze for Team USA with a solid performance. But every member of the team hit clutch routines, including Paul Juda and Asher Hong on vault and Frederick Richard on high bar.\n\nThe Americans finished fifth at each of the previous three Summer Olympics, and they finished fifth again in Saturday's qualifying. The difference on Monday largely revolved around Malone.\n\nMalone, 24, had been expected to qualify for the all-around individual final and perhaps even contend for a medal, but he had a dreadful showing in qualifying - with falls on pommel horse, floor and even high bar, the event in which he won a world championship in 2022. It was such a jarring performance that some of his teammates later said he apologized to them afterwards.\n\n\"I know Brody's a dog and a competitor,\" Hong said. \"So I know he's going to come into team finals and full send.\"\n\nAnd he did. Malone improved upon or matched his performances on every apparatus, including a significantly better showing on high bar that helped keep the U.S. ahead of its bronze rivals. After falling twice on the apparatus in qualifying, he looked much more comfortable - and stuck the landing - for a score that was nearly two full points higher than his score Saturday.\n\nHong, Juda and Richard, meanwhile, each competed in four events - each pumping up their teammates, and the crowd, between routines. Chants of \"U-S-A!\" rang out at Bercy Arena at multiple points over the course of the night.\n\nAlthough China and Japan were long considered the favorites, the U.S. knew for months that it would benefit from the absence of Russia, which is banned from team competitions at these Olympics because of its invasion of Ukraine.\n\nThe Americans knew the bronze medal was there for the taking. And they took it.\n\nStephen Nedoroscik closed out the U.S. men's rotation on pommel horse, nailing his routine and enciting a massive cheer from the crowd, including a chant of \"USA! USA!\" His teammates threw him in the air in celebration. He earned a score of 14.866.\n\nBrody Malone on pommel horse\n\nBrody Malone scored a 13.700 on pommel horse, leaving only Stephen Nedoroscik's turn on the rotation left.\n\nPaul Juda on pommel horse\n\nPaul Juda opened the U.S. men's rotation on pommel horse and stuck his landing, drawing a huge roar from the crowd. He scored a 13.900.\n\nU.S. men's gymnastics in medal position entering last rotation\n\nThe U.S. is sitting in third place with just one rotation left to go. Unfortunately, that last rotation is in a notoriously tricky event: Pommel horse.\n\nThe U.S. has a 1.8-point lead over Ukraine, which is in fourth place, after a solid showing on floor exercise. Asher Hong, Paul Juda and Frederick Richard all notched scores about 14.100 on floor, with Richard's routine the highlight.\n\nNow, it just needs to hang on. The U.S. will put up Juda, Brody Malone and Stephen Nedoroscik on pommel horse. Nedoroscik is a one-event specialist whose only routine of the night will be Team USA's last -- with a medal on the line.\n\nU.S. men's gymnastics has monster high bar set\n\nWhat a difference a couple of days make. The U.S. men are in third place with two events to go thanks to a monster performance on high bar.\n\nFrederick Richard and Brody Malone improved their scores from qualifying by nearly three points, including a hit by Malone. The 2022 world champ on high bar has been struggling on his signature event all summe, but he came through when it counted most. And Richard was simply magnificent, his release series setting off chants of \"USA! USA!\" China still has a commanding lead, and Ukraine leapfrogged the Americans. But the Americans are hanging in there.\n\nBrody Malone put up an impressive high bar routine and scored a 14.166.\n\nFrederick Richard on high bar\n\nMonster high bar routine from Frederick Richard. He stuck the landing and scored a 14.833 -- roughly seven-tenths better than his routine in qualifying.\n\nU.S. men's gymnastics in second halfway through Olympic team final\n\nThe U.S. men are still in medal contention halfway through the team final.\n\nThe Americans are 1.201 points behind China after three events, with a score of 130.163. They got a big boost on parallel bars, where Asher Hong improved his score from qualifying by more than a half-point. Frederick Richard also picked up about 1.2 points, offsetting a slightly lower score from Brody Malone.\n\nIt's not just that the Americans are doing their jobs, they're getting help from the other contenders. Japan is probably out of the running for gold after Daiki Hashimoto fell off pommel horse in the second rotation. They're more than three points behind China and are almost two points behind the Americans. Britain had to count a 13.033 on vault and are 1.7 points back from the U.S. But the Americans must now go on high bar, a high-risk, high-reward event.\n\nParallel bars: Brody Malone (14.433), Frederick Richard (14.566), Asher Hong (14.400)\n\nAsher Hong amped after big vault\n\nOne of the keys for Team USA, and every team in this final, is to have its stars on each apparatus put up big scores. And Asher Hong certainly did that on vault, which is one of his best events.\n\nHong took a slight hop on his Ri Se-gwang vault -- a full twisting, double back somersault -- but nevertheless notched a strong score of 14.833, pumping his fist and yelling in celebration as he walked off the podium. Between that vault, Paul Juda's stuck landing, and dramatic improvement on this apparatus by Brody Malone, the U.S. put up another strong showing and moved into first place in the overall team standings -- at least for a brief moment.\n\nIf you're simply comparing Team USA's performance to its performance in the qualifying round, then things are looking good. The Americans improved by four-tenths on still rings and roughly 0.9 points on vault.\n\nThe gold will go to either China or Japan, and Daiki Hashimoto's mistake on pommel horse might loom large.\n\nThe reigning Olympic and world champion wound up on his back on top of the horse midway through his routine and dropped off. The crowd gasped, and Hashimoto put his head in his hands after he finished, knowing what a costly error it was. His score of 13.1 was almost 1.4 points below his score in qualifying. Unlike in qualifying, when teams can drop their lowest score, every score counts tonight.\n\nThe only positive is that the mistake occurred early enough in the competition that Japan has time to make up ground. Still, the reigning world champs are a half-point behind China.\n\nU.S. men's gymnastics on still rings\n\nThere's a lot of gymnastics left to go, but the U.S. got to off to a solid start on still rings. Frederick Richard led off with a 14.033 -- which was a half-point improvement on his rings score in qualifying -- while Brody Malone and Asher Hong finished right around their scores Saturday. The result was a net positive of four-tenths for Team USA over qualifying, where they finished more than three full points behind third-place Great Britain.\n\nIn Monday's eight-team final, the Americans will be rotating from one apparatus to another with Italy and start off on still rings. And they'll end with arguably the trickiest event in men's gymnastics: Pommel horse, which is often compared to balance beam on the women's side.\n\nAfter a rough showing in the qualifying round, reigning U.S. champion Brody Malone will have the busiest night in the final, competing in every event except floor. Asher Hong, Paul Juda and Frederick Richard will have four routines apiece, and Stephen Nedoroscik will wrap up the night with his only event: Pommel horse.\n\nHere's the complete lineup for Team USA in Monday's final, and their order of events:\n\nNBC is airing the men's team final, Peacock is live streaming it.\n\nWhat time is men's gymnastics on today ?\n\nThe men's team final is happening now, after starting at 11:30 a.m. ET. The U.S. men's gymnastics team is vying to win its first medal since 2008. The Simone Biles and the U.S. women's gymnastics team competes in the team final on Tuesday at 12:15 p.m. ET.\n\nStephen Nedoroscik to step into pommel horse pressure-cooker\n\nThere was a bit of controversy over Stephen Nedoroscik's inclusion on Team USA. He only competes in one event -- pommel horse -- but he is one of the best in the world on that apparatus when he hits.\n\nThat means there's a ton of pressure for the Penn State product to nail his routine in the team final Monday.\n\nThe timing, or rather order of events, only further adds to that pressure. The Americans will go last on pommel horse, and Nedoroscik will be the third and final member of the team to compete. Meanwhile, Great Britain and Ukraine, who are expected to be Team USA's biggest rivals for the bronze medal, will be on floor exercise -- where Great Britain recorded the highest score in qualifying.\n\nThe rub: When Nedoroscik steps up to the pommel horse, there could very well be a medal on the line.\n\nA gymnastics routine gets two scores: One for difficulty, also known as the D score or start value, and one for execution. Every gymnastics skill has a numerical value, and the D score is the sum total of the skills in a routine. The execution score, or E score, reflects how well the skills were done. A gymnast starts with a 10.0, and deductions for flaws and form errors are taken from there. Add the D and E scores together, and that's your total for an apparatus. (Vault scores will always be higher because it's a single skill.)\n\nWhy US men's gymnastics team has best shot at an Olympic medal since 2008\n\nWinning an Olympic team medal is difficult. Difficulty doesn't have to be what keeps the U.S. men's gymnastics team from winning one, however. Since the Tokyo Olympics, where they finished fifth for a third straight Games, the Americans have prioritized making their routines harder in hopes of breaking what is now a 16-year medal drought. You can do the most beautiful gymnastics in the world and it won't matter if your skills aren't as difficult as what the top teams are doing.\n\n\"I hate to say that about Tokyo but yeah, that was kind of what that was,\" said Brody Malone, referring to the 7-point gap between the U.S. men and China, the bronze medalists.\n\nIn the gymnastics scoring system, there is one score for the difficulty value of a routine and another for how well it's executed. The Americans still lag well behind Japan and China, perennial favorites in men's gymnastics. But with no Russia, which won the team title both in Tokyo and at the world championships before it, the bronze medal is there for the taking.", "source": {"uri": "eu.telegram.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Telegram & Gazette"}, "authors": [{"uri": "worcester_telegram@eu.telegram.com", "name": "Worcester Telegram", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Juda", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Paul Juda"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asher_Hong", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": {"uri": "8250934883", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "15:42:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T15:42:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T15:37:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/people-obsessed-pommel-horse-guy-153041074.html", "title": "People are obsessed with 'pommel horse guy,' aka USA gymnast Stephen Nedoroscik", "body": "The Paris 2024 Olympics are still underway, but this summer's games have already delivered a number of viral moments. This week, during the US men's gymnastics final, viewers were given yet another breakout star - lovingly nicknamed by the internet as \"pommel horse guy\".\n\nStephen Nedoroscik, a 25-year-old Penn State alum, secured Team USA an Olympic medal in men's gymnastics for the first time in 16 years. While Japan and China finished in first and second place, respectively, Nedoroscik and his teammates received the third place bronze medal.\n\nDuring Monday's final, viewers couldn't take their eyes off Nedoroscik, who waited nearly three hours for his turn to compete in the very last event. With his thick black frame glasses, the gymnast was seen napping, playing charades, solving Rubik's cubes, and cheering on his teammates - Brody Malone, Paul Juda, Frederick Richard, and Asher Hong - until it was time to mount the pommel horse.\n\nNedoroscik, known as the pommel horse \"specialist,\" delivered a nearly perfect routine with a score of 14.866. But it wasn't his impressive skills on the mat that made Nedoroscik into a viral sensation. Rather, it was his unassuming, \"nerdy\" Clark Kent-turned-Superman energy that transformed Nedoroscik into everyone's favorite Olympic athlete.\n\n\"Obsessed with this guy on the US men's gymnastics team who's [sic] only job is pommel horse,\" wrote user Megan on X, formerly Twitter, after Nedoroscik's stunning performance. \"He just sits there until he's activated like a sleeper agent, whips off his glasses like Clark Kent and does a pommel horse routine that helps deliver the team its first medal in 16 years.\"\n\nAcross social media, fans were amazed that Nedoroscik's entire gymnastics career has been focused on perfecting the pommel horse. In fact, he was tapped to join the five-member US men's gymnastics team after he came in first place at the 2024 US pommel horse championship. Much like Ken in the Barbie movie, whose sole job is beach, Nedoroscik's one job at the Olympics is essentially pommel horse.\n\n\"Absolutely sick that America brought Stephen Nedoroscik, some nerd from Massachusetts, to Paris who's [sic] sole purpose in life is to ball out on the pommel horse,\" said user Sam after Monday's final. \"Long live pommel horse guy.\"\n\nMany sports fans admitted that they were unaware of Nedoroscik, or his pommel horse skills, up until his jaw-dropping performance. Now, some have declared him a \"national hero\" and \"American icon\".\n\nOthers made comparisons to Clark Kent, who famously takes off his glasses before transforming into Superman. Nedoroscik was seen wearing his square-framed glasses up until the last men's gymnastics event. When it was finally his turn to take to the pommel horse, Nedoroscik whipped off his frames and balanced himself on the apparatus with near perfection. Although Nedoroscik has previously told fans he suffers from strabismus - a condition also known as crossed eyes - even someone with 20/20 vision wouldn't come close to such a performance.\n\n\"Taking off your glasses to then perform a near perfect routine on the pommel horse is so freaking metal,\" one person said, while the official account for NBC Olympics & Paralympics captioned a side-by-side image of Nedoroscik and Superman actor Christopher Reeve: \"Stephen Nedoroscik, the Clark Kent of pommel horse!\"\n\nThe Massachusetts native, who graduated from Penn State in 2020 with a degree in mechanical engineering, won two NCAA championships during his college career. In 2021, he became the first US gymnast to win a world championship gold medal on pommel horse, according to ABC. After scoring 14.866 during Monday's event, Nedoroscik will be given another chance to score a medal on Saturday, August 3.\n\nIt also seems that Nedoroscik has caught wind of the viral reaction to his pommel horse performance. Speaking to Today co-hosts Hoda Kotb and Savannah Guthrie on Tuesday, the gymnast was asked how he feels about becoming the latest internet meme.\n\n\"I think they're awesome,\" he said. \"I'm {"uri": "8251553714", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "01:11:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T01:11:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T01:10:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.elle.com.au/culture/pommel-horse-guy-olympics/", "title": "Who Is Pommel Horse Guy? The Surprise Heartthrob Of The Olympics", "body": "An unassuming member of the US gymnastics team competing in the Olympics has become a viral sensation overnight. Stephen Nedoroscik is a nerdy Clark Kent type passionate about Rubik's cubes. So why can't the internet get enough of him?\n\nFirstly, 2024 has been the year of the geeky guy with \"Rodent Boy Summer\"; geeky guys with Stewart little vibes are the new heartthrobs. Ironically, the sporting movie Challengers sent the trend viral, with Josh O'Connor and Mike Faist leading the charge. Stephen Nedoroscik, the bespectacled hero of the Olympics who can allegedly solve a Rubik's cube in 10 seconds, fits the bill.\n\nStephen Nedoroscik is a member of the men's artistic gymnastics team. The 25-year-old gymnast specialises in \"the pommel horse\", a part of the gym routine that requires strength, rhythm and precision. It's a move that takes 40 seconds. But Nedoroscik's performance helped the men's Team USA gymnasts break their 16-year medal drought, winning them bronze with his flawless execution of the difficult\"pommel horse\" move.\n\nCompeting in one Olympic event means waiting for three hours on the day (according to NBC News). As the bespectacled hunk sat on the sideline, he caught the attention of X users who wondered what he was up to.\n\nOne user wrote, \"I'm obsessed with this one guy on the US men's gymnastic team who looks like he's getting his PhD in anthropology, and his only job is pommel horse.\"\n\nAt one point, the pommel horse guy seemed to be taking a kip, but apparently, he was meditating. The internet went wild, \"he just sits there until he's activated like a sleeper agent, whips off his glasses like Clark Kent and does a pommel horse routine that helps deliver the team its first medal in 16 years.\" He scored a phenomenal 14.866, helping put them 2 points ahead of team Britain and scraping them a bronze medal. It also cinched his superhero vibes. Nedoroscik told press it was \"just the greatest moment of my life, I think\", the gymnast told People.\n\nThe internet was right; Stephen Nedoroscik is a geek outside of pommel horsing. The pommel horse king is an electrical engineering graduate. He's from Massachusetts and attended the Sterling Academy of Gymnastics in Sterling, Massachusetts. His small-town academy has been cheering him on. The ebullient owner, Matt Carbone, told NBC Boston, \"My parents started this business in 1992 with the smallest of dreams, but 32 years later, we now have an Olympic bronze medalist.\" He remembered Stephen Nedoroscik as a \"goofy boy\" who would \"get into trouble at times\" and.\n\nNedoroscik went to college at Penn State and joined their gymnastics team. He said on Instagram the prestigious Penn State took a \"serious risk\" taking him in, and I will forever be grateful for that opportunity.\"\n\nMen's gymnastics comprises five team members -- Nedorosciks team members are Brody Malone, Asher Hong, Paula Juda, and Fred Richard. These four are all-rounders, but as established, Stephen Nedoroscik focuses only on the pommel horse. According to People, the US has typically lost out on this part of the competition. Bringing someone in solely to execute this routine is not standard. Indeed, there was a backlash when Nedoroscik was selected, given the many \"all-rounder\" gymnasts who wanted to compete in the Olympics.\n\nNedoroscik told the press he was aware of the criticism and came to his own defence in the most charmingly modest way possible. \"I really wanted to make the Olympic team, and I knew there would be backlash to it. I do one event compared to these guys, who are phenomenal all-rounders. And I am a phenomenal horse guy. But it's hard to fit on a five-guy team.\"\n\nThe pommel horse routine involves spinning around the \"horse\" for forty-five seconds with his entire body weight on his arms.\n\nWe don't see many athletes wearing thick frames at the Olympics. But Stephen Nedoroscik wears glasses because he has strabismus, in which one eye turns in a direction different from the other. Nedoroscik isn't self-conscious about it, though. Indeed, he showed his ability to switch \"dominant\" eyes in a TikTok in August 2022.\n\nNedoroscik says he's pleased with the comparisons to Christover Reeves as Clark Kent because he's happy to represent people who \"wear glasses well.\" Indeed.\n\nHe also said that the condition doesn't hold him back when he's on the pommel horse, where he unsurprisingly has to remove his specs. \"I don't even really see when I'm doing my gymnastics. It's all in the hands. I can feel everything.\"\n\nUnfortunately for hopefuls wanting to nab a geeky boyfriend, our Clark Kent of the pommel horse is taken. There, he also met his girlfriend of almost a decade, Tess McCracken, a fellow gymnast.
