{"uri": "2024-07-438955702", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "03:02:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T03:02:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T02:27:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.rnz.co.nz/news/sport/523731/olympics-2024-stephen-nedoroscik-is-america-s-pommel-horse-hero", "title": "Olympics 2024: Stephen Nedoroscik is America's pommel horse hero", "body": "The US gymnastics team has a new breakout star - bespectacled, Rubik's Cube-solving 'pommel horse guy' Stephen Nedoroscik.\n\nThe 25-year-old gymnast specialises in the pommel horse, which demands strength, rhythm, and precision.\n\nWhen he stepped up to the apparatus on Monday night, for the men's artistic gymnastics team final, he delivered a clutch performance, rousing the crowds watching in the arena and at home.\n\nWith one 40-second routine, Nedoroscik helped secure the team a bronze medal - its first since 2008 - and became an overnight internet sensation.\n\nNedoroscik had the final routine in the last rotation of the Olympic final.\n\nHis less than one minute on the apparatus was the only thing standing between the US team and a medal.\n\nAs he hopped off after scoring 14.866, his fist shot straight into the air and the crowd erupted. He did what he had come to Paris to do.\n\nThe internet also took notice of the gymnast from the state of Massachusetts.\n\nSoon, he was being referred to as Mr Pommel Horse. His girlfriend changed her profile on X, formerly Twitter, to \"Ms Pommel Horse\".\n\nFans also discovered one of his hobbies: solving Rubik's Cubes. He finished one in less than 10 seconds the day of the competition.\n\nSocial media users compared him to Clark Kent, Superman's alter-ego who wears glasses.\n\nNedoroscik, waiting for his routine, sat on the sidelines in glasses, before taking them off to compete.\n\n\"Obsessed with this guy on the US men's gymnastics team,\" one user wrote in a viral post.\n\n\"He just sits there until he's activated like a sleeper agent, whips off his glasses like Clark Kent and does a pommel horse routine that helps deliver the team its first medal in 16 years.\"\n\nNBC's Olympics X account called him \"the Clark Kent of pommel horse\".\n\nNedoroscik has strabismus, or crossed eyes, which can cause double vision.\n\nIn a 2022 post on TikTok, he showed his followers how his condition allows him to alternate which eye is the dominant eye.\n\nHe told The Today Show he thought the memes about him are \"awesome\" and represent \"the people that wear glasses well\".\n\nHe was asked how he was able to carry out Monday's routine without his glasses, though he has competed in prescription goggles in the past.\n\n\"It's not necessarily clear,\" he said of his vision.\n\n\"But the thing about pommel horse is if I keep [the glasses] on, they're going to fly somewhere.\"\n\nIn the end, he said, it's \"all about feeling the equipment\".\n\n\"I don't even really see when I'm doing my gymnastics. It's all in the hands. I can feel everything.\"\n\nNedoroscik will compete again in the individual event, the men's pommel horse final, on 3 August.", "source": {"uri": "rnz.co.nz", "dataType": "news", "title": "RNZ"}, "wgt": 47}], "image": "https://media.rnztools.nz/rnz/image/upload/s--yzEKwQQr--/t_tohu-badge-twitter/v1722391872/4KM6F9G_063_2159846380_jpg?_a=BACCd2AD", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9768598", "eventUri": "eng-9768598", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-08-03", "textStart": 2645, "textEnd": 2653}], "sentiment": 0.2392156862745098, "wgt": 175, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8250764896", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "13:48:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T13:48:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T13:47:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://newsadvance.com/sports/other/olympics/pommel-horse-specialist-stephen-nedoroscik-waited-his-whole-life-for-one-routine/article_510db0c8-f31e-5a08-b3b6-dfd1129b6e5f.html", "title": "Pommel horse specialist Stephen Nedoroscik waited his whole life for one routine", "body": "PARIS -- Sam Mikulak pulled Stephen Nedoroscik close and tasked the American pommel horse specialist with the impossible.\n\nThe U.S. men's gymnastics team's first Olympic medal in 16 years a solitary routine away, Mikulak told the pommel horse specialist that he didn't need to go all out. That 80% would be good enough, even though Mikulak knew full well that Nedoroscik never does anything -- from his sport to solving a Rubik's Cube -- at 80%.\n\n\"You have to trick yourself,\" said Mikulak, a three-time Olympian turned coach. \"You've got to make sure you don't let all the noise get into your head.\"\n\nThat usually isn't a problem for the 25-year-old from Worcester, Massachusetts. It takes a certain type of single-mindedness to make the choices Nedoroscik has made for the last decade, when he essentially decided to dedicate himself to a single pursuit, focusing on an event that has long been a weakness for the U.S. men's national team program.\n\nYes, there is monotony involved. How could there not be?\n\n\"I don't know how I don't lose my mind,\" Nedoroscik said before the Games. \"But every day I go into the gym and there's still something to do. There's still something to improve.\"\n\nNot anymore.\n\nProving a point\n\nHe drilled his set during qualifying on Saturday to earn a spot on the event finals later in the Games. But Monday night, things were different. Teammates Frederick Richard, Brody Malone, Paul Juda and Asher Hong had put together 17 straight routines without a miss, putting the Americans in position to reach the medal stand for the first time since 2008 in Beijing.\n\nWhile Nedoroscik had some wiggle room -- the U.S. had a fairly healthy lead after Juda and Malone hit their sets before Nedoroscik saluted the judges -- he also didn't want to merely hold on. He wanted to prove a point.\n\nNot just to himself, but to those who wondered if he deserved to be there in the first place.\n\nWhat followed were 45 seconds of sublime brilliance, with Nedoroscik's hands traveling from one end of the horse to the other, his legs swooping this way, then that.\n\nA few feet away, his four teammates -- and the sizable contingent of US fans inside Bercy Arena -- roared as a medal that seemed distant for a program that had finished a distant fifth in each of its last three trips under the rings -- drew closer.\n\nBy the time Nedoroscik neared his dismount, he knew his job was complete. The celebration began before his feet even hit the mat.\n\nAll those years, all those reps, both physical and mental, all the difficult times when he wondered whether to keep going, all the quirks he's developed along the way -- from the non-prescription goggles he sometimes rocks to the chef's kiss to the camera he occasionally makes -- led up to that moment.\n\nAnd he did not miss, delivering \"the exclamation point\" with a 14.866 to finish off a performance the U.S. men's program hopes provides serious momentum heading into the 2028 Games in Los Angeles.\n\n\"I kind of in that moment was like, 'All right, let's run it back and let's go out there and do our thing,'\" Nedoroscik said.\n\nFilling a critical gap\n\nA \"thing\" that has long been a sore spot for the U.S. in major international competition. The 2012 Olympic team topped qualifying. Then they led off on pommel horse in the finals and saw their medal hopes vanish one mistake at a time.\n\nNedoroscik understood the history. It's one of the reasons he gravitated toward pommels. Another is the fact that it requires many things -- stamina, strength and creativity chief among them -- that he has in spades, particularly that last one.\n\nHe describes himself as a \"late bloomer\" on the event. Those early struggles only helped him press forward.\n\n\"Running into trouble on the apparatus early on taught me how to fight, how to stay on, how to really go for that routine,\" he said. \"And I think that that has stuck with me throughout.\"\n\nUnlike other events, which are painstakingly laid out and practiced on end for months if not years, pommel horse allows gymnasts to color outside the lines and make things up as they go on. Miss an element here? Well, maybe you can make it up trying something else later in the routine.\n\nHe says the end result is the feeling of \"flying through the air,\" though it's more akin to levitation.\n\nMore work to be done\n\nNedoroscik will soar into the event finals Saturday with a chance to put another medal in his carry-on before he heads home. His 15.200 qualifying score tied Ireland's Rhys McClenaghan for the tops among the eight finalists.\n\nHe is ready to ride the wave as far as it will take him. Yet whatever happens on Saturday or for the rest of his life for that matter, it will be difficult to top Monday night, when the guy with the curly hair and the glasses that made him the kind of social media sensation only the Olympics provides struck a blow for his sport, his teammates and himself.\n\n\"I'm really proud of these guys,\" he said while sitting alongside the group that became U.S. men's gymnastics royalty. \"I love you boys.\"\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8249853465", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "03:14:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T03:14:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T03:12:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.news18.com/olympics/8983507-8983507.html", "title": "Paris Olympics 2024: US Men End 16-Year Medal Drought With Team Gymnastics Bronze - News18", "body": "The US team score of 257.793 was 1.801 points behind gold medallists Japan, who snatched the gold from China on their final apparatus, the horizontal bar.\n\nThe United States captured bronze in the men's gymnastics team final at the Paris Games on Monday, ending a 16-year Olympic medal drought thanks to a bounce-back performance from Brody Malone.\n\nMalone, the veteran of a team featuring Paul Juda, Frederick Richard, Asher Hong and Stephen Nedoroscik, endured a horrendous qualifying round, actually apologising to his teammates after they finished fifth.\n\nIt was the USA's first men's team medal since they also took bronze at the 2008 Beijing Olympics.\n\n\"This is incredible,\" said Malone, who just 16 months ago suffered career-threatening knee injuries in a horizontal bar fall at an event in Germany.\n\n\"Coming off the day I had Saturday, that was probably one of my worst competitions I've ever had,\" said Malone, who was still wearing a cumbersome knee brace for some events when he won a third US all-around title in June.\n\n\"But being able to reel it back in for the team when it mattered is just everything.\"\n\nThe US team score of 257.793 was 1.801 points behind gold medallists Japan, who snatched the gold from China on their final apparatus, the horizontal bar.\n\nThe Americans arrived at their final apparatus, pommel horse, with a 1.798-point lead over Ukraine for bronze.\n\nJuda delivered a strong 13.900. Malone, who had scored 12.100 on the horse in qualifying, stepped up to score 13.700.\n\nNedoroscik, a pommel horse specialist who made the Olympic team specifically for the one event, held his nerve to close out the rotation with a score of 14.866 and as he left the podium was hoisted into the air by his jubilant teammates.\n\n\"I had my coach by my side and he does a great job of taking the nerves out of (me),\" the bespectacled Nedoroscik said.\n\n\"But these guys hit every routine before me and I have a statistic: when people hit before me, I also hit (my routine).\n\n\"So I went out {"uri": "8251027890", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "16:43:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T16:43:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T16:43:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.themarysue.com/best-stephen-nedoroscik-memes/", "title": "Stephen Nedoroscik Went Full Clark Kent at the Paris Olympics and the Internet Noticed", "body": "Thanks to an absolutely mesmerizing pommel horse routine that scored Team U.S.A. its first medal in men's gymnastics since 2008, Stephen Nedoroscik is having a major meme moment.\n\nThe 25-year-old glasses-wearing \"pommel horse guy\" first attracted attention during the July 29, 2024 competition, but not (initially) because of his performance. Instead, fans couldn't help but notice that he spent hours that day supporting his teammates by fetching them water and cheering them on. The reason he didn't compete in the earlier events is because Nedoroscik is a member of the team solely because of his prowess at just one event, the pommel horse, and nothing else. He's kind of the \"pro from Dover,\" a weapon that's only deployed when the time is right.\n\nThat time came at the very end of the meet, when it was up to Nedoroscik to beat Great Britain to secure Team U.S.A.'s first medal in 16 years. Right before the event, NBC shared this photo of the athlete seemingly cool, calm, collected, and firmly \"in the zone.\"\n\nLater, Nedoroscik told Today's Savannah Guthrie, \"I'm doing my breathing exercises. We always try to keep our heart rate down and through that five minutes I'm sitting there, I'm just visualizing my routine over and over ... that's all I'm doing in my head.\"\n\nDespite his calm demeanor, when it was his time to shine, he did. And HOW!\n\nNedoroscik crushed it at his one and only event, earning a massive score of 14.866 to bring his team to an overall score of 257.793. His performance in the ninth inning broke the 16-year dry spell while also launching the first official meme rush of the Paris Olympics. People flocked to social media to share images of the bespeckled athlete, whom many dubbed the \"Clark Kent\" of the Games. Here's a sampling of the best Stephen Nedoroscik memes so far.\n\nAs an aside, Nedoroscik also told Today that he always removes his glasses before performing on the pommel horse, stating that his vision is \"not necessarily clear,\" but that they will \"fly somewhere\" if he tries to keep them on. \"When I go up on the pommel horse, it's all about feeling the equipment,\" he said. \"I don't even really see when I'm doing my gymnastics. It's all in the hands -- I can feel everything.\"\n\nAs for Nedoroscik, the athlete seems to be taking the new meme attention in his stride. \"I think they're awesome,\" he told Hoda Kotb. \"I'm representing people that wear glasses well.\"\n\nHe sure is! Congratulations to Stephen Nedoroscik and the entire men's Team U.S.A. gymnastics team on their bronze medal. Since the waning days of his high-school career, he has competed only on pommel horse - emerging as one of the best athletes in the world on this one apparatus, even at the apparent expense of the other five.\n\nIn arguably the most pressure-packed situation that one could imagine in men's gymnastics - the last routine of the last rotation of the Olympic final - Nedoroscik delivered in a big way Monday night, putting together a smooth, confident showing on pommel horse that wrapped up the bronze medal for the U.S. men's gymnastics team.\n\nIt was his only event of the night, on the apparatus he's practiced exclusively for years. And when it was over, his teammates hoisted him into the air, and he raised his hands above his head.\n\n\"It was just the greatest moment of my life, I think,\" Nedoroscik said.\n\nYou can watch his full routine, which earned him a score of 14.866, below.\n\nSocial media reaction to Stephen Nedoroscik\n\nBefore his routine, Nedoroscik was shown with his head resting on a wall and his eyes closed, appearing to take a moment to focus. The image became the source of many jokes on social media.\n\nHis pommel horse routine, and the clinching of the bronze medal for USA Gymnastics, also earned Nedoroscik the admiration of many social {"uri": "8249399196", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "18:29:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T18:29:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T18:27:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://people.com/us-men-gymnastics-team-win-bronze-2024-paris-olympics-8685203", "title": "U.S. Men's Gymnastics Team Take Home Bronze, Their First Olympic Medal in 15 Years", "body": "For the first time in nearly 20 years, the U.S. men's gymnastics team is taking home an Olympic medal.\n\nTeam USA gymnasts Paul Juda, Fred Richard, Brody Malone, Asher Hong and Stephen Nedoroscik were strong and steady throughout the competition to earn bronze, behind gold medalists Japan and second-place China.\n\nThe U.S. finished with a total score of 257.793, just 1.801 points behind Japan.\n\nThe hardware marks the first medal in the team event since 2008 for the American men's gymnastics team, who finished fifth in qualifying rounds on Saturday.\n\nGoing into their final apparatus, the pommel horse, the U.S. sat in third behind China and Japan.\n\nThat's when Nedoroscik, a 25-year-old pommel horse specialist, put up a 14.866 to guarantee the U.S. a medal. The team was seen screaming and cheering on the arena floor with an American flag after the final scores went up.\n\nAfter qualifiers on Saturday, Juda, 23, told reporters that the team was focused on the task ahead, and would pay no mind to numbers and statistics.\n\n\"We didn't watch any scores. We're not going to watch any scores for the next competition,\" he said. \"We're just going to go and do our routines and lay the cards where they fall. I've always just tried to take any competition one event at a time, especially as I've gotten older. But then I just look in the crowd and I see all those people and I go, 'Oh my god, it's just gymnastics!'\"\n\nRichard, 20, previously told PEOPLE earlier this month that heading to his first Olympics is \"really exciting,\"\n\n\"My biggest goal is by the end of this Olympics, number one, I guess everybody starts to know who I am and realize, okay, this kid is the future of gymnastics and for the next coming Olympics he's going to be something big,\" he said. \"It's kind of like my, 'Hello, world.' I got that from Tiger Woods. {"uri": "2024-07-438248547", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "12:00:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T12:00:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T07:50:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.13wmaz.com/article/sports/olympics/stephen-nedoroscik-pommel-horse-specialist/507-5f6aeee6-cb60-4a88-b933-2e3ad0ee0291", "title": "Stephen Nedoroscik waited his whole life for one routine. The US pommel horse specialist nailed it", "body": "PARIS, France -- Sam Mikulak pulled Stephen Nedoroscik close and tasked the American pommel horse specialist with the impossible.\n\nThe U.S. men's gymnastics team's first Olympic medal in 16 years a solitary routine away, Mikulak told the pommel horse specialist that he didn't need to go all out. That 80% would be good enough, even though Mikulak knew full well that Nedoroscik never does anything -- from his sport to solving a Rubik's Cube -- at 80%.\n\n\"You have to trick yourself,\" said Mikulak, a three-time Olympian turned coach. \"You've got to make sure you don't let all the noise get into your head.\"\n\nThat usually isn't a problem for the 25-year-old from Worcester, Massachusetts. It takes a certain type of single-mindedness to make the choices Nedoroscik has made for the last decade, when he essentially decided to dedicate himself to a single pursuit, focusing on an event that has long been a weakness for the U.S. men's national team program.\n\nYes, there is monotony involved. How could there not be?\n\n\"I don't know how I don't lose my mind,\" Nedoroscik said before the Games. \"But every day I go into the gym and there's still something to do. There's still something to improve.\"\n\nNot anymore.\n\nHe drilled his set during qualifying on Saturday to earn a spot on the event finals later in the Games. But Monday night, things were different. Teammates Frederick Richard, Brody Malone, Paul Juda and Asher Hong had put together 17 straight routines without a miss, putting the Americans in position to reach the medal stand for the first time since 2008 in Beijing.\n\nWhile Nedoroscik had some wiggle room -- the U.S. had a fairly healthy lead after Juda and Malone hit their sets before Nedoroscik saluted the judges -- he also didn't want to merely hold on. He wanted to prove a point.\n\nNot just to himself, but to those who wondered if he deserved to be there in the first place.\n\nWhat followed were 45 seconds of sublime brilliance, with Nedoroscik's hands traveling from one end of the horse to the other, his legs swooping this way, then that.\n\nA few feet away, his four teammates -- and the sizable contingent of US fans inside Bercy Arena -- roared as a medal that seemed distant for a program that had finished a distant fifth in each of its last three trips under the rings -- drew closer.\n\nBy the time Nedoroscik neared his dismount, he knew his job was complete. The celebration began before his feet even hit the mat.\n\nAll those years, all those reps, both physical and mental, all the difficult times when he wondered whether to keep going, all the quirks he's developed along the way -- from the non-prescription goggles he sometimes rocks to the chef's kiss to the camera he occasionally makes -- led up to that moment.\n\nAnd he did not miss, delivering \"the exclamation point\" with a 14.866 to finish off a performance the U.S. men's program hopes provides serious momentum heading into the 2028 Games in Los Angeles.\n\n\"I kind of in that moment was like, 'All right, let's run it back and let's go out there and do our thing,'\" Nedoroscik said.\n\nA \"thing\" that has long been a sore spot for the U.S. in major international competition. The 2012 Olympic team topped qualifying. Then they led off on pommel horse in the finals and saw their medal hopes vanish one mistake at a time.\n\nNedoroscik understood the history. It's one of the reasons he gravitated toward pommels. Another is the fact that it requires many things -- stamina, strength and creativity chief among them -- that he has in spades, particularly that last one.\n\nHe describes himself as a \"late bloomer\" on the event. Those early struggles only helped him press forward.\n\n\"Running into trouble on the apparatus early on taught me how to fight, how to stay on, how to really go for that routine,\" he said. \"And I think that that has stuck with me throughout.\"\n\nUnlike other events, which are painstakingly laid out and practiced on end for months if not years, pommel horse allows gymnasts to color outside the lines and make things up as they go on. Miss an element here? Well, maybe you can make it up trying something else later in the routine.\n\nHe says the end result is the feeling of \"flying through the air,\" though it's more akin to levitation.\n\nNedoroscik will soar into the event finals Saturday with a chance to put another medal in his carry-on before he heads home. His 15.200 qualifying score tied Ireland's Rhys McClenaghan for the tops among the eight finalists.\n\nHe is ready to ride the wave as far as it will take him. Yet whatever happens on Saturday or for the rest of his life for that matter, it will be difficult to top Monday night, when the guy with the curly hair and the glasses that made him the kind of social media sensation only the Olympics provides struck a blow for his sport, his teammates and himself.\n\n\"I'm really proud of these guys,\" he said while sitting alongside the group that became U.S. men's gymnastics royalty. \"I love you boys.\"", "source": {"uri": "13wmaz.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WMAZ"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": After that they invited me to join the gymnastics team. It can lead to double vision but the gymnast was not wearing glasses when he scored 14.866 on the pommel horse on Monday.\n\nHe had already become the first American gymnast in history to make the Olympic team as a specialist in a single event.\n\nIt was around a decade ago that the Massachusetts native decided to dedicate himself to the pommel horse, an event that has long been a weakness for the US men's national team program.\n\nNedoroscik has become an internet sensation, with fans likening the gymnast to Clark Kent\n\nNedoroscik's girlfriend Tess McCracken posted throwback pictures alongside the gymnast\n\n'I don\u00b4t know how I don't lose my mind,' Nedoroscik admitted before the Games. {"uri": "2024-07-438588615", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "17:02:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T17:02:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T16:13:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.aol.com/olympic-gymnast-stephen-nedoroscik-embraces-161306310.html", "title": "Olympic Gymnast Stephen Nedoroscik Embraces Clark Kent Comparison Memes: 'They're Awesome'", "body": "Olympic Gymnast Stephen Nedoroscik Embraces Clark Kent Comparison Memes: 'They're Awesome'\n\nKimberlee Speakman\n\nJuly 30, 2024 at 6:13 PM\n\nThe 25-year-old athlete's pommel horse routine helped Team USA win bronze at the Paris 2024 Olympics\n\nStephen Nedoroscik is having one super Summer Olympics, alright.\n\nThe 25-year-old gymnast helped Team USA take home an Olympic bronze medal on Monday, July 29 with his incredible pommel horse routine. But while his performance earned plenty of praise online, fans were equally vocal about the glasses-wearing Massachusetts native's resemblance to Clark Kent, Superman's alter ego.\n\nWrote one fan on X: \"Stephen Nedoroscik is like Clark Kent, but when he takes off his glasses, he's Superman on the pommel horse.\"\n\n\"All I'm saying is we've never seen Stephen Nedoroscik and Clark Kent in the same room...\" said another.\n\nEven NBC's official Olympics account got in on the action, calling Nedoroscik \"the Clark Kent of pommel horse\" on X and sharing a side-by-side photo of him and of the late Christopher Reeve playing Kent in one of the Superman films.\n\nAsked about the memes during an interview on the Today show on Tuesday, July 30, Nedoroscik embraced them, saying he's seen them and finds them humorous.\n\n\"I think they're awesome,\" said Nedoroscik. \"You know, representing the people that wear glasses well.\"\n\nHosts Hoda Kotb and Savannah Guthrie then asked whether he has been stopped yet as he \"walks down the streets\" because of the memes.\n\n\"Oh, not quite yet,\" he said -- though Kotb and Guthrie teased it'd be happening soon enough.\n\nNedoroscik wears glasses because he has strabismus, a condition where one eye is turned in a direction that's different from the other. More commonly known as crossed eyes, it can lead to double vision -- though, as Nedoroscik demonstrated in an August 2022 TikTok, he can alternate which eye is the dominant eye.\n\nAsked on Today by Kotb, 59, and Guthrie, 52, about how he was able to carry out his pommel horse routine without the use of his glasses, Nedoroscik admitted he doesn't see.\n\n\"It's not necessarily clear,\" the gymnast said. \"But the thing about pommel horse is if I keep [the glasses] on, they're going to fly somewhere.\"\n\nInstead, Nedoroscik relies on his intuition. \"When I go up on the pommel horse, it's all about feeling the equipment,\" he explained. \"I don't even really see when I'm doing my gymnastics. It's all in the hands. I can feel everything.\"\n\nRelated: Gymnast Stephen Nedoroscik Says Nailing Pommel Horse Routine Ahead of U.S. Bronze Medal Was 'the Greatest Moment of My Life'\n\nRelated: U.S. Men's Gymnastics Team Take Home Bronze, Their First Olympic Medal in 16 Years\n\nFollowing Nedoroscik's display on the pommel horse, which helped the U.S. men's gymnastic team win their first Olympic medal in 16 years, the athelete spoke with reporters about what it felt like to have succeeded in garnering a high score on the apparatus.\n\n\"It was just the greatest moment of my life, I think,\" the athlete told reporters, including PEOPLE, in Paris of acing his routine with a 14.866. \"[I'm] so happy to have been there.\"\n\nThe sportsman said it'd been a \"really long day\" leading up to his moment in the spotlight, but that he completed his breathing exercises to stay calm. He said he heard big cheers for Brody Malone and Paul Juda, who were set to go up before him, and knew that they were setting him up for success.\n\nNever miss a story -- sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer, from juicy celebrity news to compelling human interest stories.\n\n\"I kind of, in that moment, was like, 'Alright, let's run it back, then. Let's go out there and do our thing,' \" he said. \"I have [coach] Sam Mikulak as just like, the greatest coach of all time. He's up there, helping me keep the nerves in check. He knows exactly what to say to me.\"\n\n\"So when we got that chalk bucket, he kind of just settled me down and said, 'You're ready for this.' I went up there, did my routine and during that dismount, I was just like, already smiling,\" he added.\n\nTo learn more about all the Olympic and Paralympic hopefuls, come to people.com to check out ongoing coverage before, during and after the games. And sign up for Going for Gold, our Olympics newsletter, to get the biggest stories from the Games delivered straight to your inbox. He is also a four-time US champion, which ties him for the most in history.He was a unique Olympic selection because he does only one of six events. High-level gymnasts are typically expected to be compete in several, if not all, events.Nedoroscik has a chance for an individual medal in pommel horse. He is also a four-time US champion, which ties him for the most in history.\n\nHe was a unique Olympic selection because he does only one of six events. {"uri": "2024-07-438167460", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "10:50:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T10:50:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T09:21:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.aol.com/sports/paris-olympics-know-stephen-nedoroscik-092126004.html", "title": "Paris Olympics: Get to know Stephen Nedoroscik, the glasses-wearing pommel horse hero of USA men's gymnastics", "body": "The U.S. men jumped from fifth in qualifying to secure the bronze medal in the men's team gymnastics final on Monday, a landmark result for a program that hadn't medaled in the Olympics since 2008.\n\nStephen Nedoroscik is a big reason why. The pommel horse specialist took his turn with USA sitting in bronze-medal position in the team's final rotation of the competition. He delivered a nearly flawless routine that secured USA's highest score on the apparatus and ensured that the bronze was theirs.\n\nNedoroscik recounted the moment while rewatching his routine with NBC's Mike Tirico alongside his teammates Brody Malone, Asher Hong, Paul Juda and Frederick Richard.\n\nBetween that routine and that interview, Nedoroscik made his imprint as a U.S. hero of the Paris Olympics.\n\nPommel Horse is Stephen Nedoroscik's thing\n\nNedoroscik didn't make Team USA because of his abilities on the vault, the rings, the parallel bar, the high bar or in the floor routine. He was selected because he's one of the best in the world at doing one thing -- perform on the pommel horse.\n\nNedoroscik won two NCAA championships and a silver medal on pommel horse while competing for Penn State. He won a gold medal for Team USA in the event at the 2021 World Championships. His 14.866 score on Tuesday was tied for the second best of the day in the team finals behind Great Britain's Max Whitlock.\n\nIt was the only event in which he competed. He waited through the entire competition for his turn in USA's final rotation. There, he delivered. He'll have a chance to do so again in the pommel horse event final after finishing second in qualifying with a 15.200.\n\nNedoroscik relaxes by solving Rubik's Cubes. Like any Rubik's Cube savant, it's not a matter for Nedoroscik of if he solves it, but how long it takes him to do so. He's very fast.\n\nPrior to Monday's gymnastics final, Nedoroscik posted an image of a Rubik's Cube on Instagram next to a tablet with a time displayed: 9.321 seconds.\n\nAccording to his TikTok bio, Nedoroscik's personal best time at Rubik's Cube is 8.664 seconds. Just in case you were wondering.\n\nNedoroscik has strabismus\n\nNedoroscik became quickly known on Monday not just because of his gymnastics routine -- but because of his distinct look featuring fashionable glasses.\n\nHe revealed a potential reason for those glasses on Tiktok. He has strabismus, which is basically medical terminology for having crossed eyes. He sent a call out for doctors on Tiktok asking for information on the diagnosis and demonstrated his experience of the condition for his followers.\n\nIt's not clear if he received any satisfying responses.\n\nThe strabismus doesn't appear to bother him too much. It certainly didn't hinder him on Monday when he competed without the use of goggles or glasses. But he proudly rocked his glasses on the podium and while celebrating with his teammates.\n\nNedoroscik's selection to Team USA came with criticism\n\nTo a lot of gymnastics observers, Nedoroscik didn't belong on USA's Olympics team.\n\nTo be fair, a one-event specialist in a six-event competition with five-man teams doesn't sound at a glance like the best fit. Nedoroscik has heard the criticism of the decision.\n\n\"I was completely aware of it,\" Nedoroscik told the Washington Post of the criticism. \"I really wanted to make the Olympic team, and I knew that there was going to be backlash to it. I do one event compared to these guys that are phenomenal all-arounders. And I am a phenomenal horse guy. But it's hard to fit on a five-guy team.\"\n\nBut Nedoroscik's strength is a relative weakness of the rest of Team USA. In a competition where Nedoroscik wasn't required to compete on any of his weaker events, the math added up. Nedoroscik's pommel horse score had the potential to raise the U.S. men onto the podium. It was a situation that required his teammates to consistently do their jobs on the other events.\n\nThey all met the moment and have the hardware now to show for it. And on Saturday, Nedoroscik's a favorite to pick up additional hardware in the pommel horse final.", "source": {"uri": "aol.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Aol"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8250554829", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "11:55:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T11:55:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T11:39:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13688233/Stephen-Nedoroscik-waited-life-one-routine-The-US-pommel-horse-specialist-nailed-it.html", "title": "Stephen Nedoroscik waited his whole life for one routine. The US...", "body": "PARIS (AP) - Sam Mikulak pulled Stephen Nedoroscik close and tasked the American pommel horse specialist with the impossible.\n\nThe U.S. men's gymnastics team's first Olympic medal in 16 years a solitary routine away, Mikulak told the pommel horse specialist that he didn't need to go all out. That 80% would be good enough, even though Mikulak knew full well that Nedoroscik never does anything - from his sport to solving a Rubik's Cube - at 80%.\n\n\"You have to trick yourself,\" said Mikulak, a three-time Olympian turned coach. \"You've got to make sure you don't let all the noise get into your head.\"\n\nThat usually isn't a problem for the 25-year-old from Worcester, Massachusetts. It takes a certain type of single-mindedness to make the choices Nedoroscik has made for the last decade, when he essentially decided to dedicate himself to a single pursuit, focusing on an event that has long been a weakness for the U.S. men's national team program.\n\nYes, there is monotony involved. How could there not be?\n\n\"I don\u00b4t know how I don\u00b4t lose my mind,\" Nedoroscik said before the Games. \"But every day I go into the gym and there\u00b4s still something to do. There\u00b4s still something to improve.\"\n\nStephen Nedoroscik, of United States, gets a hug from Paul Juda after last rotation during the men's artistic gymnastics team finals round at Bercy Arena at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Monday, July 29, 2024, in Paris, France. (AP Photo/Abbie Parr)\n\nNot anymore.\n\nHe drilled his set during qualifying on Saturday to earn a spot on the event finals later in the Games. But Monday night, things were different. Teammates Frederick Richard, Brody Malone, Paul Juda and Asher Hong had put together 17 straight routines without a miss, putting the Americans in position to reach the medal stand for the first time since 2008 in Beijing.\n\nWhile Nedoroscik had some wiggle room - the U.S. had a fairly healthy lead after Juda and Malone hit their sets before Nedoroscik saluted the judges - he also didn't want to merely hold on. He wanted to prove a point.\n\nNot just to himself, but to those who wondered if he deserved to be there in the first place.\n\nWhat followed were 45 seconds of sublime brilliance, with Nedoroscik's hands traveling from one end of the horse to the other, his legs swooping this way, then that.\n\nA few feet away, his four teammates - and the sizable contingent of US fans inside Bercy Arena - roared as a medal that seemed distant for a program that had finished a distant fifth in each of its last three trips under the rings - drew closer.\n\nBy the time Nedoroscik neared his dismount, he knew his job was complete. The celebration began before his feet even hit the mat.\n\nAll those years, all those reps, both physical and mental, all the difficult times when he wondered whether to keep going, all the quirks he's developed along the way - from the non-prescription goggles he sometimes rocks to the chef's kiss to the camera he occasionally makes - led up to that moment.\n\nAnd he did not miss, delivering \"the exclamation point\" with a 14.866 to finish off a performance the U.S. men's program hopes provides serious momentum heading into the 2028 Games in Los Angeles.\n\n\"I kind of in that moment was like, 'All right, let\u00b4s run it back and let\u00b4s go out there and do our thing,\u00b4\" Nedoroscik said.\n\nA \"thing\" that has long been a sore spot for the U.S. in major international competition. The 2012 Olympic team topped qualifying. Then they led off on pommel horse in the finals and saw their medal hopes vanish one mistake at a time.\n\nNedoroscik understood the history. It's one of the reasons he gravitated toward pommels. Another is the fact that it requires many things - stamina, strength and creativity chief among them - that he has in spades, particularly that last one.\n\nHe describes himself as a \"late bloomer\" on the event. Those early struggles only helped him press forward.\n\n\"Running into trouble on the apparatus early on taught me how to fight, how to stay on, how to really go for that routine,\" he said. \"And I think that that has stuck with me throughout.\"\n\nUnlike other events, which are painstakingly laid out and practiced on end for months if not years, pommel horse allows gymnasts to color outside the lines and make things up as they go on. Miss an element here? Well, maybe you can make it up trying something else later in the routine.\n\nHe says the end result is the feeling of \"flying through the air,\" though it's more akin to levitation.\n\nNedoroscik will soar into the event finals Saturday with a chance to put another medal in his carry-on before he heads home. His 15.200 qualifying score tied Ireland's Rhys McClenaghan for the tops among the eight finalists.\n\nHe is ready to ride the wave as far as it will take him. Yet whatever happens on Saturday or for the rest of his life for that matter, it will be difficult to top Monday night, when the guy with the curly hair and the glasses that made him the kind of social media sensation only the Olympics provides struck a blow for his sport, his teammates and himself.\n\n\"I'm really proud of these guys,\" he said while sitting alongside the group that became U.S. men's gymnastics royalty. \"I love you boys.\"\n\nAP Summer Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games\n\nStephen Nedoroscik, of United States, reacts after the pommel horse during the men's artistic gymnastics team finals round at Bercy Arena at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Monday, July 29, 2024, in Paris, France. (AP Photo/Abbie Parr)\n\nStephen Nedoroscik, of United States, performs on the pommel during the men's artistic gymnastics team finals round at Bercy Arena at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Monday, July 29, 2024, in Paris, France. (AP Photo/Abbie Parr)\n\nStephen Nedoroscik, of United States, pommel during the men's artistic gymnastics team finals round at Bercy Arena at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Monday, July 29, 2024, in Paris, France. (AP Photo/Abbie Parr)\n\nStephen Nedoroscik, of United States, pommel during the men's artistic gymnastics team finals round at Bercy Arena at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Monday, July 29, 2024, in Paris, France. (AP Photo/Abbie Parr)\n\nTeam USA celebrate after last rotation as they lift Stephen Nedoroscik, of United States, during the men's artistic gymnastics team finals round at Bercy Arena at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Monday, July 29, 2024, in Paris, France. {"uri": "2024-07-437536368", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "20:21:01", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T20:21:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T19:37:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.aol.com/u-men-win-first-olympic-182600248.html", "title": "U.S. men win their first Olympic gymnastics team medal in 16 years", "body": "U.S. men win their first Olympic gymnastics team medal in 16 years\n\nStephen Smith, Wendy Gillette\n\nUpdated July 29, 2024 at 9:37 PM\n\nTeam USA's men gymnasts captured their first Olympic medal in the team event in 16 years, capturing a bronze with consistent performances from all five members. Japan won gold and China won silver.\n\nLed by star Frederick Richard, the team of Asher Hong, Paul Juda, Brody Malone and pommel horse specialist Stephen Nedoroscik are the first American men to win a team gymnastics event at the Games since the 2008 Beijing Olympics.\n\nJapan captured its eighth team gold medal -- winning by just 0.532 points -- after China's Su Weide fell twice off the horizontal bar, the Associated Press reported.\n\nTeam USA Gymnastics posted a celebratory message on social media after the men's team won the bronze.\n\n\"For the first time since 2008, the U.S. Men are taking home hardware in the Olympic Team Competition!\" USA Gymnastics wrote. \"Congratulations to Asher, Paul, Brody, Stephen & Frederick -- you are Olympic Medalists!\"\n\nChants of \"U-S-A! U-S-A!\" from flag-waving Americans rang out in Bercy Arena throughout the competition as the men's team hit routine after routine to win the bronze.\n\nHigh scores included a 14.866 for Nedoroscik on the pommel horse and 14.833 for Hong on the vault, and a monster routine for Richard on the high bar.\n\n\"It's so powerful,\" Angie Tyler from Louisville, Kentucky, told CBS News after Richard's performance. \"His release moves are super exciting. He has a lot of combinations that he puts together, as well.\"\n\nThe team ranked fifth after a much rougher qualifying round on Saturday, beating out Ukraine and Great Britian in the finals.\n\n\"We were cheering 'U-S-A,' we were getting a little hoarse in our voice,\" said Philadelphia resident Wally Orlov. \"It's nice to see the boys catching up with the girls again.\"\n\nRichard and Paul will next compete in the all-around final while Nedoroscik -- who has been dubbed \"Clark Kent\" for the thick glasses he wears -- will vie for a medal in the pommel horse final.\n\nGreat Britain came in fourth place and Ukraine took fifth place. Russia, which won a gold medal at the Tokyo Olympics, is not competing in Paris because of its role in the war against Ukraine.\n\nHarris ramps up campaign as Trump remarks to Christian voters {"uri": "8250674174", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "12:53:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T12:53:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T12:52:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/boston/news/stephen-nedoroscik-pommel-horse-olympics-gymnastics/", "title": "Worcester's Stephen Nedoroscik proves he belongs at Olympics with U.S. men's gymnastics team", "body": "PARIS - Sam Mikulak pulled Stephen Nedoroscik close and tasked the American pommel horse specialist with the impossible.\n\nThe U.S. men's gymnastics team's first Olympic medal in 16 years a solitary routine away, Mikulak told the pommel horse specialist that he didn't need to go all out. That 80% would be good enough, even though Mikulak knew full well that Nedoroscik never does anything - from his sport to solving a Rubik's Cube - at 80%.\n\n\"You have to trick yourself,\" said Mikulak, a three-time Olympian turned coach. \"You've got to make sure you don't let all the noise get into your head.\"\n\nThat usually isn't a problem for the 25-year-old from Worcester, Massachusetts. It takes a certain type of single-mindedness to make the choices Nedoroscik has made for the last decade, when he essentially decided to dedicate himself to a single pursuit, focusing on an event that has long been a weakness for the U.S. men's national team program.\n\nYes, there is monotony involved. How could there not be?\n\n\"I don't know how I don't lose my mind,\" Nedoroscik said before the Games. \"But every day I go into the gym and there's still something to do. There's still something to improve.\"\n\nNot anymore.\n\nHe drilled his set during qualifying on Saturday to earn a spot on the event finals later in the Games. But Monday night, things were different. Teammates Frederick Richard, Brody Malone, Paul Juda and Asher Hong had put together 17 straight routines without a miss, putting the Americans in position to reach the medal stand for the first time since 2008 in Beijing.\n\nWhile Nedoroscik had some wiggle room - the U.S. had a fairly healthy lead after Juda and Malone hit their sets before Nedoroscik saluted the judges - he also didn't want to merely hold on. He wanted to prove a point.\n\nNot just to himself, but to those who wondered if he deserved to be there in the first place.\n\nWhat followed were 45 seconds of sublime brilliance, with Nedoroscik's hands traveling from one end of the horse to the other, his legs swooping this way, then that.\n\nA few feet away, his four teammates - and the sizable contingent of US fans inside Bercy Arena - roared as a medal that seemed distant for a program that had finished a distant fifth in each of its last three trips under the rings - drew closer.\n\nBy the time Nedoroscik neared his dismount, he knew his job was complete. The celebration began before his feet even hit the mat.\n\nAll those years, all those reps, both physical and mental, all the difficult times when he wondered whether to keep going, all the quirks he's developed along the way - from the non-prescription goggles he sometimes rocks to the chef's kiss to the camera he occasionally makes - led up to that moment.\n\nAnd he did not miss, delivering \"the exclamation point\" with a 14.866 to finish off a performance the U.S. men's program hopes provides serious momentum heading into the 2028 Games in Los Angeles.\n\n\"I kind of in that moment was like, 'All right, let's run it back and let's go out there and do our thing,'\" Nedoroscik said.\n\nA \"thing\" that has long been a sore spot for the U.S. in major international competition. The 2012 Olympic team topped qualifying.\n\nThen they led off on pommel horse in the finals and saw their medal hopes vanish one mistake at a time.\n\nNedoroscik understood the history. It's one of the reasons he gravitated toward pommels. Another is the fact that it requires many things - stamina, strength and creativity chief among them - that he has in spades, particularly that last one.\n\nHe describes himself as a \"late bloomer\" on the event. Those early struggles only helped him press forward.\n\n\"Running into trouble on the apparatus early on taught me how to fight, how to stay on, how to really go for that routine,\" he said. \"And I think that that has stuck with me throughout.\"\n\nUnlike other events, which are painstakingly laid out and practiced on end for months if not years, pommel horse allows gymnasts to color outside the lines and make things up as they go on. Miss an element here? Well, maybe you can make it up trying something else later in the routine.\n\nHe says the end result is the feeling of \"flying through the air,\" though it's more akin to levitation.\n\nNedoroscik will soar into the event finals Saturday with a chance to put another medal in his carry-on before he heads home. His 15.200 qualifying score tied Ireland's Rhys McClenaghan for the tops among the eight finalists.\n\nHe is ready to ride the wave as far as it will take him. Yet whatever happens on Saturday or for the rest of his life for that matter, it will be difficult to top Monday night, when the guy with the curly hair and the glasses that made him the kind of social media sensation only the Olympics provides struck a blow for his sport, his teammates and himself.\n\n\"I'm really proud of these guys,\" he said while sitting alongside the group that became U.S. men's gymnastics royalty. \"I love you boys.\"", "source": {"uri": "cbsnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBS News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-437494821", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "19:19:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T19:19:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T19:15:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.bradenton.com/sports/article290542054.html", "title": "Stephen Nedoroscik Hailed As American Hero After U.S. Men's Gymnastics Wins Bronze", "body": "U.S. gymnast Stephen Nedoroscik, a Penn State alum born in Worcester, Mass., became the Americans' unassuming savior in the men's team gymnastics final on Monday.\n\nWhat makes the 25-year-old athlete stand out is that he only performs one of six events: the pommel horse. Nedoroscik was selected to the U.S. men's Olympic gymnastics squad earlier this summer solely because of his pommel horse talents, and the gamble ultimately paid off.\n\nAfter compatriots Paul Juda and Brody Malone logged solid scores with their respective pommel horse routines, Nedoroscik came up last in the rotation and stuck the landing, literally and metaphorically.\n\nIn an all-time clutch performance, Nedoroscik scored 14.866 to help Team USA clinch bronze, their first Olympic team medal since the 2008 Beijing Olympics. He exited the stage and was immediately bear-hugged by his teammates, who were excitedly jumping up and down in anticipation of their bronze finish.\n\nFans on social media quickly came together in support of the nerdy-looking gymnast who delivered for Team USA when they needed it most.\n\nThis article was originally published on www.si.com as Stephen Nedoroscik Hailed As American Hero After {"uri": "8249878580", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "03:42:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T03:42:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T03:41:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.latimes.com/sports/olympics/story/2024-07-29/team-usa-gymnast-stephen-nedoroscik-new-hero-glasses", "title": "Meet Team USA gymnast Stephen Nedoroscik: A new hero in glasses", "body": "Stephen Nedoroscik's clutch pommel horse routine during Monday's team final clinched the United States' first Olympic medal since 2008 and, in the process, launched a thousand internet memes.\n\nThe bespectacled Olympic bronze medalist has been compared to Clark Kent, a Ken whose job is \"horse,\" and Steve Rogers before and after being injected with the super serum that turned him into Captain America.\n\nA pommel horse specialist, Nedoroscik cheered on his teammates for two hours during a tense competition at Bercy Arena, carried bags and got water. NBC flashed a countdown clock to his performance. Then on the final routine of the final rotation, he stepped up for a 38-second performance that helped the team make history.\n\n\"It was a really long day, and I sat in our room and thought about how I get to be the last person [to compete],\" said Nedoroscik, who will compete in the pommel horse final on Saturday. \"And I framed that in my head as a positive -- that I can be the exclamation point.\"\n\nHe was an emphatic punctuation mark on a night full of highlights for the United States. The team hit 18 for 18 routines, including stuck vaults from Paul Juda and Brody Malone. Asher Hong's complicated double-flipping, single-twisting vault anchored the rotation and briefly pushed the United States into first place. Frederick Richard, the reigning world bronze medalist, avenged a lackluster high bar routine in the qualifying rounds by showing off upgraded difficulty and scoring the highest mark on the event during Sunday's competition.\n\nWith the table set for a perfect ending, Nedoroscik knew that he was going to deliver. He said he's never missed a routine if all of his teammates hit before him.\n\n\"I had no doubt in my mind that we could just go out there and just hit a massive set,\" Hong said.\n\nThe 2021 world pommel horse champion has been specializing in his signature event for eight years. Although he grew up practicing all six events, he noticed around high school that he was only progressing on pommel horse, the trickiest event in men's gymnastics that is often compared to the women's balance beam. As a one-routine wonder, Nedoroscik collected junior Olympic national titles in 2015 and 2016. People told him early on that he would be in the Olympics one day.\n\n\"Back then I was just dorky little kid,\" Nedoroscik said during the U.S. Olympic trials, where he hit both of his routines to punch his ticket to Paris. \"And now look at me. I'm a dorky adult going to the Olympics.\"\n\nOn the second day of Olympic trials, the two-time NCAA pommel horse champion from Penn State also had to wait until the final rotation to compete. Just like he would do one month later at Bercy Arena, Nedoroscik delivered the routine he needed.\n\nAlthough Nedoroscik earned his position by delivering four strong performances during the U.S. championships and the Olympic trials to swing the formula used to predict the top team scoring scenarios in his favor, some critics still wondered whether he belonged or whether an event specialist would hurt the team by limiting lineup flexibility.\n\nInstead he helped with the highest U.S. score on any event on Monday.\n\n\"It's like a Cinderella story, fairy tale ending,\" said Sam Mikulak, a three-time Olympian turned coach who trains Nedoroscik. \"I just hope everyone starts believing and gives him the credit that's due -- especially Team USA, for creating the procedures that got him on the team.\"\n\nIn the media mixed zone after the meet, Mikulak hadn't realized that the specialist who once drew side eyes had become the latest American cult hero. It was about time that the shift happened.\n\n\"He deserves to be recognized for his individuality,\" Mikulak said.\n\nNedoroscik's \"nerd credentials,\" as described on X, are nearly unmatched in sports. The night before the team final, he posted on his Instagram story that he solved a Rubik's cube in 9.695 seconds. He said the anxiety he feels when solving a cube is similar to the feeling he gets when working through a pommel horse set.\n\n\"When you're on a really good pace, really good solve, you feel the anxiety, your fingers start slipping,\" Nedoroscik said last month, \"and in a weird way, it kind of helps you stay in the zone as you're doing it.\"\n\nAnd then there's the glasses.\n\nHe broke through with the national team while wearing goggles he received as a joke from a Penn State teammate, and now takes his black rimmed glasses off for competition. He reaches for them immediately after his routine, but he said can see the equipment without them.\n\n\"It's all feeling,\" Nedoroscik said with a chuckle. \"I see with my hands.\"", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8249450448", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "19:15:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T19:15:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T19:14:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.nbcnews.com/news/sports/us-mens-gymnastics-team-wins-bronze-earning-first-olympic-team-medal-1-rcna164103", "title": "U.S. men's gymnastics team wins bronze, earning first Olympic team medal in 16 years", "body": "Team USA poses with their bronze medal during the podium ceremony for the artistic gymnastics men's team final during the Paris 2024 Olympic Games at the Bercy Arena in Paris, on Monday.Paul Ellis / AFP - Getty Images\n\nFrederick Richard, Brody Malone, Paul Juda, Asher Hong and Stephen Nedoroscik etched their names in gymnastics history books Monday.\n\nThe U.S. men won their first Olympic team medal in gymnastics since 2008, earning a bronze. They edged out Great Britain for the third podium spot, while Japan and China won the gold and silver medals, respectively.\n\nThe U.S. team's celebrations rivaled the rowdiest of college gymnastics meets, with the athletes cheering each other on through every twist and flip.\n\nWhen they earned the bronze, many on the team broke down in tears. While the American women are accustomed to podium finishes, it is only the third team medal in the last 20 years for the U.S. men.\n\nThe bronze was in their grasp after a consummate performance in the first five rotations, but they had to get through the pommel horse first, which is never an easy task. It is comparable to the balance beam on the women's side, which can vanquish even the best in the world.\n\nNedoroscik made the Olympic team based solely on the strength of his routine on the event. He faced an agonizing two-and-a-half hour wait on the sidelines during the final, going up last for the U.S. in the final rotation. His effort clinched the bronze medal.\n\nThey built early momentum with stellar rotations on still rings and vault, making significant improvements to their scores from the qualifying round, where they finished fifth.\n\n\"I was completely blacked out while I was running down the runway,\" Juda said of his flawless vault. \"I hit the table, and I just said, 'Alright, just hold it, just don't fall. Just please don't fall.'\"\n\n\"Next thing I know, the ground's at my feet, and I stuck it at the Olympic Games,\" he said.\n\nAfter competing in two of the six events, the U.S. occupied the top spot on the leaderboard.\n\nChants of \"USA\" erupted in Paris' Bercy Arena after Hong became the third American to sail through parallel bars. He earned a 14.400, putting the U.S. in the second spot as they headed to high bar.\n\nRichard was a star throughout the final for Team USA. He performed a monstrously difficult routine on high bar, sticking his dismount and posting a score that would have won a silver medal last year's world championships.\n\nAs the U.S. anchor on floor, Richard delivered a clutch routine to wrap up the penultimate rotation. One of his skills on floor stems from breakdancing, a sport that is making its Olympic debut in Paris.\n\nHe will compete alongside Juda in the all-around final on Wednesday. Nedoroscik is eyeing gold in the pommel horse final, which is slated for Saturday.", "source": {"uri": "nbcnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBC News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-438453894", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "14:57:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T14:57:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T14:07:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://wgntv.com/2024-olympics/meet-stephen-nedoroscik-the-clark-kent-of-pommel-horse/", "title": "Meet Stephen Nedoroscik, the Clark Kent of pommel horse", "body": "(NEXSTAR) -- Social media is in love with Stephen Nedoroscik. With a medal on the line Monday in Paris, the American gymnast removed his glasses, jumped up on the pommel horse, and secured a bronze medal for Team USA. He put his glasses back on before celebrating.\n\nThat was his only event in the team competition. Nedoroscik did his job. You can call him the Clark Kent of pommel horse.\n\nThe memes started almost instantly with social media users making the super hero comparisons.\n\n\"Obsessed with this guy on the US men's gymnastics team who's only job is pommel horse, so he just sits there until he's activated like a sleeper agent, whips off his glasses like Clark Kent and does a pommel horse routine that helps deliver the team its first medal in 16 years,\" @MegWritesBooks posted to X.\n\n\"While the pressure kept building in the gym, he meditated. A slight smile crept onto his face when he heard the cheers for his teammate's score,\" Whitney Fleming wrote in a viral post on Facebook. \"And then, like Clark Kent turning into Superman, he took off his jacket, removed his glasses, and puffed out his chest-and HE KILLED IT!\"\n\nNedoroscik is a 25-year-old pommel horse specialist from Worcester, Massachusetts. It takes a certain type of single-mindedness to make the choices Nedoroscik has made for the last decade, when he essentially decided to dedicate himself to a single pursuit, focusing on an event that has long been a weakness for the U.S. men's national team program.\n\nThe 2012 Olympic team topped qualifying. Then they led off on pommel horse in the finals and saw their medal hopes vanish one mistake at a time.\n\nNedoroscik understood the history. It's one of the reasons he gravitated toward pommels. Another is the fact that it requires many things -- stamina, strength and creativity chief among them -- that he has in spades, particularly that last one.\n\nHe describes himself as a \"late bloomer\" on the event. Those early struggles only helped him press forward.\n\n\"Running into trouble on the apparatus early on taught me how to fight, how to stay on, how to really go for that routine,\" Nedoroscik said. \"And I think that that has stuck with me throughout.\"\n\nUnlike other events, which are painstakingly laid out and practiced on end for months if not years, pommel horse allows gymnasts to color outside the lines and make things up as they go on. Miss an element here? Well, maybe you can make it up trying something else later in the routine.\n\nHe says the end result is the feeling of \"flying through the air,\" though it's more akin to levitation.\n\nNedoroscik will soar into the event finals Saturday with a chance to put another medal in his carry-on before he heads home. His 15.200 qualifying score tied Ireland's Rhys McClenaghan for the tops among the eight finalists.", "source": {"uri": "wgntv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WGN-TV"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "2024-07-437488565", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "19:11:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T19:11:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T19:03:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://eu.telegram.com/story/sports/2024/07/29/worcesters-nedoroscik-helps-u-s-to-first-gymnastics-medal-since-2008/74591401007/", "title": "Worcester's Stephen Nedoroscik's clutch performance helps United States to first gymnastics medal since 2008", "body": "Worcester's Stephen Nedoroscik made the U.S. Olympic gymnastics team because of his specialization in the pommel horse.\n\nOn Monday the 2016 Worcester Tech graduate rewarded that faith with the performance of a lifetime at the 2024 Olympics in Paris.\n\nAfter waiting through five rotations of Monday's team final - nearly three hours - Nedoroczik's performance on his specialty event provided the final push to clinch a bronze medal for the United States, giving the team their first medal since 2008.\n\nMore: Worcester's Stephen Nedoroscik and Team USA gymnastics compete today for first medal since 2008\n\nNedoroczik, who qualified in second place to the pommel horse final with a stellar score of 15.200 on Saturday, notched a score of 14.866 to push the United States ahead of Great Britain and Ukraine and clinch the bronze medal. Japan took gold, while China claimed silver.\n\nAfter a near flawless routine of twists, turns and spins, Nedoroscik leapt off the apparatus on his dismount and seemed to know he did his job well, clinching his first and yelling in celebration once he hit the mat as his teammates ran out to meet him and members in the crowd - including his parents Cheryl and John - chanted \"U-S-A!\" throughout Bercy Arena.\n\nWith their arms around one another, the men's gymnastics team waited anxiously for Nedoroscik's score to be announced and for the final competitor, China's Zhang Boheng, to finish his horizontal bar routine.\n\nBoheng's score gave China the points needed to secure second, while Nedoroscik's score gave the United States enough to hold off Great Britain and Ukraine for a medal of their own and start the celebration.\n\nMore: 'That is what he was here to do for Team USA': Worcester's Stephen Nedoroscik shines in Olympic debut\n\nThree gymnastics from each team perform in six events for the men's team final, competing on the floor, pommel horse, vault, rings and bar. A gymnast can perform in any event as long as all six events get three performances from each team and all scores count. Nedoroscik was only competing in the pommel horse, which was seen as a weakness for the U.S. squad and the reason he was brought on board, as Nedoroscik was the 2021 world champion on that apparatus.\n\nThe experience isn't over for Nedoroscik, as the Penn State graduate who got his start at the Sterling Academy of Gymnastics advanced to the pommel horse final after both he and Ireland's Rhys McClenaghan notched matching scores of 15.200 in qualifications last Saturday. McClenaghan posted the higher execution score, earning a mark of 8.900 to Nedoroscik's 8.800 to earn the top spot. {"uri": "8250682930", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "12:58:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T12:58:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T12:57:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.wbur.org/news/2024/07/30/stephen-nedoroscik-worcester-pommel-horse", "title": "Worcester's Stephen Nedoroscik waited his whole life for one routine. The pommel horse specialist nailed it", "body": "Sam Mikulak pulled Stephen Nedoroscik close and tasked the American pommel horse specialist with the impossible.\n\nThe U.S. men's gymnastics team's first Olympic medal in 16 years a solitary routine away, Mikulak told the pommel horse specialist that he didn't need to go all out. That 80% would be good enough, even though Mikulak knew full well that Nedoroscik never does anything -- from his sport to solving a Rubik's Cube -- at 80%.\n\n\"You have to trick yourself,\" said Mikulak, a three-time Olympian turned coach. \"You've got to make sure you don't let all the noise get into your head.\"\n\nThat usually isn't a problem for the 25-year-old from Worcester, Massachusetts. It takes a certain type of single-mindedness to make the choices Nedoroscik has made for the last decade, when he essentially decided to dedicate himself to a single pursuit, focusing on an event that has long been a weakness for the U.S. men's national team program.\n\nYes, there is monotony involved. How could there not be?\n\n\"I don't know how I don't lose my mind,\" Nedoroscik said before the Games. \"But every day I go into the gym and there's still something to do. There's still something to improve.\"\n\nNot anymore.\n\nHe drilled his set during qualifying on Saturday to earn a spot on the event finals later in the Games. But Monday night, things were different. Teammates Frederick Richard, Brody Malone, Paul Juda and Asher Hong had put together 17 straight routines without a miss, putting the Americans in position to reach the medal stand for the first time since 2008 in Beijing.\n\nWhile Nedoroscik had some wiggle room -- the U.S. had a fairly healthy lead after Juda and Malone hit their sets before Nedoroscik saluted the judges -- he also didn't want to merely hold on. He wanted to prove a point.\n\nNot just to himself, but to those who wondered if he deserved to be there in the first place.\n\nWhat followed were 45 seconds of sublime brilliance, with Nedoroscik's hands traveling from one end of the horse to the other, his legs swooping this way, then that.\n\nA few feet away, his four teammates -- and the sizable contingent of U.S. fans inside Bercy Arena -- roared as a medal that seemed distant for a program that had finished a distant fifth in each of its last three trips under the rings -- drew closer.\n\nBy the time Nedoroscik neared his dismount, he knew his job was complete. The celebration began before his feet even hit the mat.\n\nAll those years, all those reps, both physical and mental, all the difficult times when he wondered whether to keep going, all the quirks he's developed along the way -- from the non-prescription goggles he sometimes rocks to the chef's kiss to the camera he occasionally makes -- led up to that moment.\n\nAnd he did not miss, delivering \"the exclamation point\" with a 14.866 to finish off a performance the U.S. men's program hopes provides serious momentum heading into the 2028 Games in Los Angeles.\n\n\"I kind of in that moment was like, 'All right, let's run it back and let's go out there and do our thing,'\" Nedoroscik said.\n\nA \"thing\" that has long been a sore spot for the U.S. in major international competition. The 2012 Olympic team topped qualifying. Then they led off on pommel horse in the finals and saw their medal hopes vanish one mistake at a time.\n\nNedoroscik understood the history. It's one of the reasons he gravitated toward pommels. Another is the fact that it requires many things -- stamina, strength and creativity chief among them -- that he has in spades, particularly that last one.\n\nHe describes himself as a \"late bloomer\" on the event. Those early struggles only helped him press forward.\n\n\"Running into trouble on the apparatus early on taught me how to fight, how to stay on, how to really go for that routine,\" he said. \"And I think that that has stuck with me throughout.\"\n\nUnlike other events, which are painstakingly laid out and practiced on end for months if not years, pommel horse allows gymnasts to color outside the lines and make things up as they go on. Miss an element here? Well, maybe you can make it up trying something else later in the routine.\n\nHe says the end result is the feeling of \"flying through the air,\" though it's more akin to levitation.\n\nNedoroscik will soar into the event finals Saturday with a chance to put another medal in his carry-on before he heads home. His 15.200 qualifying score tied Ireland's Rhys McClenaghan for the tops among the eight finalists.\n\nHe is ready to ride the wave as far as it will take him. Yet whatever happens on Saturday or for the rest of his life for that matter, it will be difficult to top Monday night, when the guy with the curly hair and the glasses that made him the kind of social media sensation only the Olympics provides struck a blow for his sport, his teammates and himself. (Scroll down for more social media reactions to Nedoroscik's performance.)\n\n\"I'm really proud of these guys,\" he said while sitting alongside the group that became U.S. men's gymnastics royalty. \"I love you boys.\"\n\nNedoroscik's Olympic prep and performance created instant social media fervor. {"uri": "8250925127", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "15:32:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T15:32:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T15:31:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.today.com/parents/family/stephen-nedorosciks-ear-tug-dziadziu-rcna164234", "title": "Pommel horse specialist Stephen Nedoroscik reveals the meaning of his secret on-air signal", "body": "\"When I was at Penn State, that was the thing that I did whenever I was on TV.\"\n\nTeam USA gymnast Stephen Nedoroscik gave his ear a little tug while waving hello on the TODAY broadcast from Paris -- and there's a special reason why.\n\nNedoroscik, a breakout star of this year's Olympic Games, told TODAY that the ear pull was always his signal to his \"dziadziu,\" which means grandfather in Polish.\n\nGrandpa Stephen John Nedoroscik, the man for whom the 25-year-old athlete is named, passed away last year at age 94.\n\n\"I've kept the tradition up and now it always means, 'Hey,' to everyone that I love,\" the pommel horse specialist explained in a behind-the-scenes video.\n\n\"He's a World War II vet and my idol,\" Nedoroscik told a TODAY producer backstge at the 2024 Paris Olympics. \"When I was at Penn State, that was the thing that I did whenever I was on TV to say, 'Hey Dziadziu.'\" (It's pronounced DJAH-djoo.)\n\nNedoroscik became an American hero -- and viral meme -- after helping the men's gymnastic team win the bronze medal with a seamless pommel horse routine on July 29. It was the team's first Olympic medal in 16 years.\n\nPommel horse is Nedoroscik's specialty, and the sole reason he was tapped for Team USA. On July 29, the Worcester, Massachusetts native sat on the sideline for almost three hours as his teammates performed routines for the first five events of the competition.\n\nAccording to NBC News, Nedoroscik place on the team was considered \"somewhat controversial\" because, unlike most high-level gymnasts who compete in multiple events such as parallel bars and vault, he performed in just one.\n\nWhile waiting for his turn to shine, a bespectacled Nedoroscik was seen with his eyes closed, and he quickly became a viral meme. Sample tweet: \"Obsessed with this guy on the US men's gymnastics team who's only job is pommel horse, so he just sits there until he's activated like a sleeper agent, whips off his glasses like Clark Kent and does a pommel horse routine that helps deliver the team its first medal in 16 years.\"\n\nSome people wondered if Nedoroscik was napping.\n\n\"I'm doing my breathing exercises,\" Nedoroscik told Hoda Kotb and Savannah Guthrie on July 30. \"We always try to keep our heart rate down and through that five minutes I'm sitting there, I'm just visualizing my routine over and over ... that's all I'm doing in my head.\"\n\nNedoroscik has a good sense of humor about the memes.\n\n\"I think they're awesome,\" he said on TODAY. \"I'm representing people that wear glasses well.\"", "source": {"uri": "8249576654", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "21:21:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T21:21:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T21:19:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/u-mens-gymnastics-team-wins-211106306.html", "title": "U.S. men's gymnastics team wins bronze, earning first Olympic team medal in 16 years", "body": "Frederick Richard, Brody Malone, Paul Juda, Asher Hong and Stephen Nedoroscik etched their names in gymnastics history books Monday.\n\nThe U.S. men won their first Olympic team medal in gymnastics since 2008, earning a bronze. They edged out Great Britain for the third podium spot, while Japan and China won the gold and silver medals, respectively.\n\nThe U.S. team's celebrations rivaled the rowdiest of college gymnastics meets, with the athletes cheering each other on through every twist and flip.\n\nWhen they earned the bronze, many on the team broke down in tears. While the American women are accustomed to podium finishes, it is only the third team medal in the last 20 years for the U.S. men.\n\nThe bronze was in their grasp after a consummate performance in the first five rotations, but they had to get through the pommel horse first, which is never an easy task. It is comparable to the balance beam on the women's side, which can vanquish even the best in the world.\n\nNedoroscik made the Olympic team based solely on the strength of his routine on the event. He faced an agonizing two-and-a-half hour wait on the sidelines during the final, going up last for the U.S. in the final rotation. His effort clinched the bronze medal.\n\nThey built early momentum with stellar rotations on still rings and vault, making significant improvements to their scores from the qualifying round, where they finished fifth.\n\n\"I was completely blacked out while I was running down the runway,\" Juda said of his flawless vault. \"I hit the table, and I just said, 'Alright, just hold it, just don't fall. Just please don't fall.'\"\n\n\"Next thing I know, the ground's at my feet, and I stuck it at the Olympic Games,\" he said.\n\nAfter competing in two of the six events, the U.S. occupied the top spot on the leaderboard.\n\nChants of \"USA\" erupted in Paris' Bercy Arena after Hong became the third American to sail through parallel bars. He earned a 14.400, putting the U.S. in the second spot as they headed to high bar.\n\nRichard was a star throughout the final for Team USA. He performed a monstrously difficult routine on high bar, sticking his dismount and posting a score that would have won a silver medal last year's world championships.\n\n\"I knew I had the whole U.S. behind me,\" Richard said. \"I knew I had these five guys cheering me on and I knew I wanted to do the best routine possible for them. When you feel that deep in your heart, it happens, and you stick that landing.\"\n\nAs the U.S. anchor on floor, Richard delivered a clutch routine to wrap up the penultimate rotation. One of his skills on floor stems from breakdancing, a sport that is making its Olympic debut in Paris.\n\nHe will compete alongside Juda in the all-around final on Wednesday. Nedoroscik is eyeing gold in the pommel horse final, which is slated for Saturday.\n\n\"We're out here representing the best country in the world,\" said U.S. national all-around champion Malone. \"It's just an incredible feeling anytime you get to wear USA on your chest, but especially at the Olympic Games.\"", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo
