{"uri": "8249642095", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "22:42:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T22:42:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T22:36:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13686185/The-U-S-mens-gymnastics-team-ended-lengthy-Olympic-medal-drought-They-hope-NCAA-notices.html", "title": "The U.S. men's gymnastics team ended a lengthy Olympic medal...", "body": "PARIS (AP) - Before they stood with their arms wrapped around each other in a brotherhood forever etched into U.S. Olympic lore, Brody Malone, Frederick Richard, Asher Hong, Paul Juda and Stephen Nedoroscik were collegians.\n\nYes, the dreams the members of the U.S. men's gymnastics team had fostered since childhood began in small gyms scattered across the country. But they became tangible at Stanford, Michigan and Penn State.\n\nSo when it was time for those dreams to become fully, vividly realized inside a raucous Bercy Arena on Monday night, they leaned on the experiences they gained during all those meets in all those sometimes sparsely filled gyms that taught them about pressure and teamwork and belief.\n\nYes, the bronze medal the Americans so emphatically earned ended a 16-year drought on the sport's biggest stage.\n\nYet it was also a message to athletic directors at the dozen schools that still have Division I gymnastics - and to be honest, to the ones that don't, too - that the sport is worth saving.\n\n\"If you want to keep seeing USA Gymnastics and Team USA on a gymnastics podium, at least on the men\u00b4s side, you\u00b4re going to have to give us more opportunities to compete in college,\" said Juda, who is in graduate school at Michigan.\n\nTeam USA from left to right Brody Malone, Asher Hong, Fred Richard, Paul Juda and Stephen Nedoroscik, of United States, celebrate their bronze medal during the men's artistic gymnastics team finals round at Bercy Arena at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Monday, July 29, 2024, in Paris, France. (AP Photo/Abbie Parr)\n\nOpportunities that are in danger of vanishing quickly thanks to a rapidly evolving college sports landscape. It's a reality the five men who stood on the podium with their arms around each other are only too aware of.\n\nRichard, a rising junior at Michigan, has made it his life's mission to bring more people to a side of the sport that - at least in the U.S. anyway - has long plugged along anonymously.\n\nAnd while he's carved out a rapidly expanding niche on social media, Richard is savvy enough to understand the one thing guaranteed to attract people to men's gymnastics isn't a viral video, but hardware like the medal he kept grabbing in the giddy aftermath.\n\n\"My goal even here was to make a statement that the U.S. is getting stronger and stronger and we're only (going up),\" Richard said. \"And I think we did that today. I think a lot of young boys watching are inspired by us.\"\n\nThat's the way it was for Richard as a kid in the Boston suburbs. There were pictures on the wall at the gym of the medal-winning 2004 and 2008 U.S. men's Olympic teams. Richard would stare at the pictures and wonder how those teams put all the pieces together.\n\n\"It looks like they all came together on the same day and just did like these perfect routines,\" Richard said. \"And you\u00b4re like, how is that possible?\"\n\nRichard found out firsthand.\n\nThe Americans didn't record a major fall during any of their 18 routines in the final and finished closer to second-place China than fourth-place Britain. They leaned into the energy from a vocal contingent of U.S. fans that offered a hint of what it might look like in Los Angeles four years from now.\n\nMostly, however, they leaned on each other and their experiences to shake off an iffy qualifying session on Saturday in which they finished a sloppy fifth.\n\n\"We just told each other we were gonna treat it like an NCAA championships because we\u00b4ve all been there,\" Malone said. \"And it\u00b4s high pressure competing for a team. And it\u00b4s no different this competition. I mean yeah, this one\u00b4s a little bit different, a little bit bigger. But same concept.\"\n\nWith perhaps a much more impactful result.\n\nNedoroscik is 26. Malone is 24. Juda is 23. Hong and Richard are 20. There is a feeling of real momentum within the U.S. men's program for the first time in a while. Yet to keep it going, the pipeline behind them needs to keep churning.\n\nThere was a sense in the 2010s that the U.S. had grown stale in part because those at the core group at the top grew a little too comfortable due in part to a lack of competition from those trying to catch them.\n\nSam Mikulak went to three Olympics with teams that had considerable talent. He never came home with a medal, though on Monday night he was chatting with Nedoroscik as he prepared for his pommel horse set that served as the exclamation point.\n\nWhile they talked, Mikulak told Nedoroscik to stay calm, that 80 percent of his best would be good enough. To soak in a moment Mikulak dreamed of but never quite grasped.\n\nAnd when Nedoroscik gracefully swooped from one end of the horse to the other, his hands working dutifully in tandem on an event that has given the Americans fits for years, the bronze that felt in some ways like gold was won.\n\nStanding there in the aftermath, Mikulak couldn't help but speculate about what might lie ahead.\n\n\"I think the guys are going to be hungry for more,\" he said. \"And hopefully this spurs men\u00b4s gymnastics in the US like never before.\"\n\nAP Summer Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games\n\nTeam USA from left to right Brody Malone, Asher Hong, Fred Richard, and Stephen Nedoroscik, of United States, celebrates bronze medal during the men's artistic gymnastics team finals round at Bercy Arena at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Monday, July 29, 2024, in Paris, France. (AP Photo/Abbie Parr)\n\nFred Richard, Asher Hong, Brody Malone, and Stephen Nedoroscik, of United States, celebrates bronze medal during the men's artistic gymnastics team finals round at Bercy Arena at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Monday, July 29, 2024, in Paris, France. (AP Photo/Abbie Parr)\n\nFred Richard, Asher Hong, Brody Malone, and Stephen Nedoroscik, of the United States, celebrate after winning the bronze medal during the men's artistic gymnastics team finals round at Bercy Arena at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Monday, July 29, 2024, in Paris, France. (AP Photo/Abbie Parr)\n\nFred Richard, of the United States, reacts after performing on the rings during the men's artistic gymnastics team finals round at Bercy Arena at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Monday, July 29, 2024, in Paris, France. (AP Photo/Abbie Parr)\n\nTeam USA from left to right Brody Malone, Asher Hong, Fred Richard, Paul Juda and Stephen Nedoroscik, of the United States, celebrate after winning the bronze medal during the men's artistic gymnastics team finals round at Bercy Arena at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Monday, July 29, 2024, in Paris, France. (AP Photo/Abbie Parr)\n\nBrody Malone, of United States, performs on the pommel during the men's artistic gymnastics team finals round at Bercy Arena at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Monday, July 29, 2024, in Paris, France. (AP Photo/Abbie Parr)\n\nAsher Hong, of United States, Brody Malone, of United States, and Stephen Nedoroscik, of United States, Team USA celebrate after last rotation during the men's artistic gymnastics team finals round at Bercy Arena at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Monday, July 29, 2024, in Paris, France. (AP Photo/Abbie Parr)\n\nStephen Nedoroscik, of United States, is lifted by teammates after pommel horse during the men's artistic gymnastics team finals round at Bercy Arena at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Monday, July 29, 2024, in Paris, France. {"uri": "8250773012", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "13:54:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T13:54:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T13:53:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.stltoday.com/sports/other/olympics/pommel-horse-specialist-stephen-nedoroscik-waited-his-whole-life-for-one-routine/article_a6085d24-a2d5-5028-a98a-a52e9c908b9c.html", "title": "Pommel horse specialist Stephen Nedoroscik waited his whole life for one routine", "body": "PARIS -- Sam Mikulak pulled Stephen Nedoroscik close and tasked the American pommel horse specialist with the impossible.\n\nThe U.S. men's gymnastics team's first Olympic medal in 16 years a solitary routine away, Mikulak told the pommel horse specialist that he didn't need to go all out. That 80% would be good enough, even though Mikulak knew full well that Nedoroscik never does anything -- from his sport to solving a Rubik's Cube -- at 80%.\n\n\"You have to trick yourself,\" said Mikulak, a three-time Olympian turned coach. \"You've got to make sure you don't let all the noise get into your head.\"\n\nWho's Donald Trump's pick for Missouri governor? He's got three. Inside the ouster: Why the St. Louis Public Schools leader was pushed out after 1 year St. Louis Public Schools superintendent Keisha Scarlett is out, replaced with interim chief Ranch in Wildwood is sanctuary for abused miniature horses Cardinals land starter Erick Fedde and Tommy Pham, but trade Tommy Edman in 3-team deal Mercy paid former exec $1 million in wake of 'sexual exploitation' allegations Lawsuit accuses Archdiocese of St. Louis of allowing clergy to abuse children Messenger: He fixed up his mobile home. He made it too nice. The city wants him out. Hair relaxer ingredients tied to cancer risk, say lawsuits and FDA. St. Louis stylists offer options. St. Louis County lawsuit names Omaha archbishop among sexual abusers. He denies the claim. Editorial: Bell has our enthusiastic endorsement for Missouri's 1st Congressional District 'He outlasted all of them': How 13-year-old gelding succeeds as one of nation's oldest racehorses Mine collapse leaves Alton golf course shut down, paying six figures a month Goold's chat: What 3 ways could Cardinals assert themselves as contenders? Is trade only 1? Woman from Valley Park drowns in Big River trying to help another canoeist\n\nThat usually isn't a problem for the 25-year-old from Worcester, Massachusetts. It takes a certain type of single-mindedness to make the choices Nedoroscik has made for the last decade, when he essentially decided to dedicate himself to a single pursuit, focusing on an event that has long been a weakness for the U.S. men's national team program.\n\nYes, there is monotony involved. How could there not be?\n\n\"I don't know how I don't lose my mind,\" Nedoroscik said before the Games. \"But every day I go into the gym and there's still something to do. There's still something to improve.\"\n\nNot anymore.\n\nProving a point\n\nHe drilled his set during qualifying on Saturday to earn a spot on the event finals later in the Games. But Monday night, things were different. Teammates Frederick Richard, Brody Malone, Paul Juda and Asher Hong had put together 17 straight routines without a miss, putting the Americans in position to reach the medal stand for the first time since 2008 in Beijing.\n\nWhile Nedoroscik had some wiggle room -- the U.S. had a fairly healthy lead after Juda and Malone hit their sets before Nedoroscik saluted the judges -- he also didn't want to merely hold on. He wanted to prove a point.\n\nNot just to himself, but to those who wondered if he deserved to be there in the first place.\n\nWhat followed were 45 seconds of sublime brilliance, with Nedoroscik's hands traveling from one end of the horse to the other, his legs swooping this way, then that.\n\nA few feet away, his four teammates -- and the sizable contingent of US fans inside Bercy Arena -- roared as a medal that seemed distant for a program that had finished a distant fifth in each of its last three trips under the rings -- drew closer.\n\nBy the time Nedoroscik neared his dismount, he knew his job was complete. The celebration began before his feet even hit the mat.\n\nAll those years, all those reps, both physical and mental, all the difficult times when he wondered whether to keep going, all the quirks he's developed along the way -- from the non-prescription goggles he sometimes rocks to the chef's kiss to the camera he occasionally makes -- led up to that moment.\n\nAnd he did not miss, delivering \"the exclamation point\" with a 14.866 to finish off a performance the U.S. men's program hopes provides serious momentum heading into the 2028 Games in Los Angeles.\n\n\"I kind of in that moment was like, 'All right, let's run it back and let's go out there and do our thing,'\" Nedoroscik said.\n\nFilling a critical gap\n\nA \"thing\" that has long been a sore spot for the U.S. in major international competition. The 2012 Olympic team topped qualifying. Then they led off on pommel horse in the finals and saw their medal hopes vanish one mistake at a time.\n\nNedoroscik understood the history. It's one of the reasons he gravitated toward pommels. Another is the fact that it requires many things -- stamina, strength and creativity chief among them -- that he has in spades, particularly that last one.\n\nHe describes himself as a \"late bloomer\" on the event. Those early struggles only helped him press forward.\n\n\"Running into trouble on the apparatus early on taught me how to fight, how to stay on, how to really go for that routine,\" he said. \"And I think that that has stuck with me throughout.\"\n\nUnlike other events, which are painstakingly laid out and practiced on end for months if not years, pommel horse allows gymnasts to color outside the lines and make things up as they go on. Miss an element here? Well, maybe you can make it up trying something else later in the routine.\n\nHe says the end result is the feeling of \"flying through the air,\" though it's more akin to levitation.\n\nMore work to be done\n\nNedoroscik will soar into the event finals Saturday with a chance to put another medal in his carry-on before he heads home. His 15.200 qualifying score tied Ireland's Rhys McClenaghan for the tops among the eight finalists.\n\nHe is ready to ride the wave as far as it will take him. Yet whatever happens on Saturday or for the rest of his life for that matter, it will be difficult to top Monday night, when the guy with the curly hair and the glasses that made him the kind of social media sensation only the Olympics provides struck a blow for his sport, his teammates and himself.\n\n\"I'm really proud of these guys,\" he said while sitting alongside the group that became U.S. men's gymnastics royalty. \"I love you boys.\"\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. The NBC Olympics camera crew captured him having a little shuteye before his turn on the pommel horse --- Nedoroscik's only specialty out of all six apparatus that include floor, vault, rings, high bar and parallel bars.\n\nThe 25-year-old from Worcester, Massachusetts, may seem like a one-trick pony to non-gymastics fans but he sure knows his way around the pommel horse. He helped the men's team end a 16-year-long medal drought at the Olympics with a major score of 15.200.\n\nHe typically competes with a pair of goggles designed to stay on as he swings around the apparatus. Fans have dubbed him the Clark Kent of pommel horse because he takes off his thick-rimmed eyeglasses off before his routine, and puts them immediately back on to see.\n\nSeveral X users have called the Penn State graduate \"nerdy\" but it's all extremely well-intentioned. Nedoroscik not only studied electrical engineering, he regularly boasts about the time it takes him to solve a Rubik's cube. His personal best? It's 8.664 seconds, according to his TikTok profile.\n\nHe even posted on his Instagram story about solving a cube at the Paris Olympics.\n\nIf you missed the men's artistic gymnastics team event, you It's their first time on the podium in 16 years.\n\nThe team came to Monday's event in a close race with Great Britain for the bronze. Nedoroscik would be the team's last hope to hold on to that medal.\n\nIn 45 seconds, the 25-year-old Worcester Tech graduate electrified the crowd at Bercy Arena, culminating with a perfect dismount to rapturous applause and chants of 'USA, USA.\" His teammates lifted him as he walked off the mat to a team-best score of 14.866.\n\nNBC Olympics posted the routine on social media with the simple caption, \"Moment = Met.\"\n\nJapan took home gold in the all-around competition, and China earned silver.\n\nDespite being a US and world champion, Nedoroscik was considered a controversial pick for the Paris Olympics because he only competed in the pommel horse, according to The Athletic. Most of the US men's gymnastics team performed in all or most of the six events.\n\nThat meant he spent hours on the sidelines Monday waiting for his chance to prove he deserved his spot. And he did just that, turning in one of the most memorable moments for the US team of the Paris Games thus far.\n\nIt's fitting that the glasses-wearing Nedoroscik drew comparisons to Clark Kent as he {"uri": "8249003666", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "13:40:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T13:40:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T13:39:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/07/29/sports/olympics-mens-gymnastics-live/", "title": "The US men are trying for their first team gymnastics medal in 16 years, and two Mass. natives are leading the way. Follow live updates. - The Boston Globe", "body": "Stephen Nedoroscik does one thing very well. And he crushed it on Saturday. -- 9:30 a.m.\n\nMount the pommel horse. Compete at his highest level. Score well. Help Team USA.\n\nAt Saturday's men's gymnastics team qualification inside Bercy Arena, the Worcester native did his job very, very well.\n\n\"He killed it,\" said teammate Frederick Richard, the other half of Team USA's Massachusetts contingent as well as the squad's top all-around threat. \"I mean, that's his event. He knows he has a very important role to play on that event but he handles it like a king.\"\n\nOn Saturday, that meant anchoring the American's first rotation on pommel horse, where Nedoroscik's daring routine carries the highest difficulty score of all five gymnasts, filled as it is with one-handed spins, amazingly consistent movements, and impressive body control. But even if Nedoroscik has become well-accustomed to doing his one event and being finished, watching as his four other teammates compete at rings, vault, parallel bars, high bar and floor, helping them with their bags, making sure they have water, cheering them on, this day was different.\n\nThat's because Brody Malone, the team's most veteran gymnast and the only one back from Tokyo in 2021, came off the pommel horse when he went up first, a mistake that resulted in a disappointing 12.1. That meant Nedoroscik's score had to count toward the Americans' team total. In other words, the pressure was on.\n\n\"It definitely did get in my head a little bit,\" he said. \"You know, but at the same time the goal was the same. I wanted to hit a good routine. So whether or not someone fell before me didn't necessarily impact me. Obviously, as I was waiting there, I did see Brody's score come up. I didn't know that he made a mistake but mistakes happen. I'm not going to get mad at him or anything like that and [it] didn't really put any pressure on me.\"\n\nOverall, as an Olympic newbie, having just missed out on being a specialist on the Tokyo team, Nedoroscik was delighted with how his first attempt went. His 15.2 was the highest single score for any American routine.\n\n\"As soon as I got down, and I was giving all the guys high fives, Paul [Juda] literally pointed to my arm and said, 'You have goosebumps, man.' The moment was surreal. I'm so proud of what I did in that moment, I was like, Okay, I think I made the horse final and I think that now as well. I'm very happy.'\"\n\nBy Adam Himmelsbach\n\nPARIS -- As Frederick Richard discusses his place as an elite gymnast, he is asked to name other athletes who inspired his journey. For the first time in this conversation, the 20-year-old Stoughton, Mass., native sounds stumped.\n\nThen his voice begins to rise with confidence.\n\n\"I always just imagined myself doing all of these crazy skills,\" he says. \"I imagined myself going to the Olympics and doing all of this stuff that I'd invented, things that had never been done before. That was the person I was always chasing.\"\n\nRichard could become one of the faces of the Paris Olympics for the US as men's gymnastics qualifying begins Saturday. He is young and energetic and personable, with more than 680,000 TikTok followers and a burning desire to show the world what it has been missing.\n\nAsher Hong's gold (all-around) and silver (still rings) medals at the 2023 US Championships increase the chance the US will win its first Olympic team medal since 2008. Competing at Stanford, he won six gold medals in the last 2 years, and was an all-around bronze medalist in the NCAA championships in 2023. He finished first in the still rings at the team trials in June, and fourth in floor and parallel bars.\n\nAge: 23 | Hometown: Deerfield, Ill.\n\nPaul Juda was 19 when he became the youngest national team member after he competed in the 2020 Winter Cup. He won eight medals in three NCAA championships at Michigan. Juda was forced to miss the 2023 season due to an injury but still received the Nissen-Emery Award, given to the best senior collegiate male gymnast. Juda helped Michigan win its first floor title since 1992 at the 2024 NCAA men's gymnastics championship with his first-place finish. He competes in Ann Arbor alongside Stoughton's Frederick Richard.\n\nAge: 24 | Hometown: Summerville, Ga.\n\nBrody Malone wasn't expected to participate in this Olympics after suffering a knee injury at the 2023 DTB Cup. A year later, he managed to defy the odds to earn his second Olympic team berth. Malone finished fourth in horizontal bar in Tokyo in 2021 and advanced to the all-around final. He was a seven-time NCAA champion at Stanford and placed first in horizontal bar at the 2022 world championships. Malone and Asher Hong were teammates during their time at Stanford. He won the Nissen-Emery Award the year before Juda.\n\nAge: 25 | Hometown: Worcester\n\nNedoroscik grew up in Worcester and attended Worcester Technical High School before matriculating to Penn State in 2017. He is a specialist, competing only in pommel horse. Nedoroscik's focus makes him a not-so-secret weapon for the Americans. He won a gold medal at the 2021 world championships, and he is tied for the most titles in US history with four. He took home gold in the 2024 World Cup.\n\nAge: 20 | Hometown: Stoughton\n\nRichard trains at the Massachusetts Elite Gymnastics Academy in Millis and competes for Michigan, where he was named Big Ten gymnast of the year in April. He became a junior national team member in 2019, which helped boost his social media presence -- he has more than 670,000 followers and 30.5 million likes on TikTok and another 310,000 followers on Instagram. Richard won a bronze medal in the team and all-around at the 2023 world championships when he was 19, making him the youngest individual medalist in men's US history. He won the NCAA team, all-around, and still rings silver medals with Michigan in 2024. At the US championships this year, he placed first in floor, second in all-around and horizontal bars, and sixth in still rings.", "source": {"uri": "bostonglobe.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8246117942", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-27", "time": "11:51:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-27T11:51:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-27T11:47:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/u-gymnastics-brody-malone-misses-113416878.html", "title": "U.S. gymnastics' Brody Malone misses out on Olympic all-around final in a big surprise", "body": "PARIS -- Brody Malone had at one point been considered the best chance for the U.S. men's gymnastics team to win an individual all-around medal at the 2024 Paris Olympics.\n\nBut after a few critical mistakes on the first day of competition at Bercy Arena, including on his signature event, he will miss out on the individual all-around final altogether.\n\nMalone, the reigning U.S. national champion and only returning member of the 2021 Olympic team, finished third among the U.S. all-arounders, and only two gymnasts per country are allowed to advance to the 24-person final, which is Wednesday.\n\nPaul Juda and Frederick Richard will represent Team USA in the final instead, though it remains to be seen which American men will for apparatus finals. Only the top eight qualifying scores in each event advance to the final.\n\nGet Olympics updates in your texts! Join USA TODAY Sports' WhatsApp Channel\n\nMeanwhile, from a team standpoint, the American men finished second in their qualification group. They were more than three points behind Great Britain but appear safely on track to qualify for Monday's team final - when the scores will reset and medals will be at stake.\n\nTwo more subdivisions of competition are still to come later Saturday, with dominant forces China and Japan still among the teams that are yet to compete.\n\nMalone's day got off to a bad start, with a fall on pommel horse, and only got worse from there. The nail in the metaphorical coffin was his performance on high bar, the event in which he won world championship medals in both 2021 and 2022. Malone missed the bar on one aerial element, then slipped off again a few minutes later - a devastating routine that effectively knocked him out of individual medal contention at these Games.\n\nThe two biggest stars on the men's team heading into Paris were Frederick Richard and Brody Malone. The former won the U.S. Olympic trials and has a massive following on social media. The latter returned from a gruesome knee injury to win his third U.S. all-around title earlier in the year.\n\nYet at Bercy Arena on Saturday, the most impressive performer of the day might have been a guy who was not considered a lock to even make the team: Paul Juda.\n\nThe Michigan product started off the day with a terrific routine on pommel horse - which is historically one of the Americans' worst events - and put up another big score on vault. Through four rotations, he was actually ahead of both Malone and Richard in the all-around standings.\n\nPommel horse specialist Stephen Nedoroscik also had an impressive and vital performance in his only event of the day, notching a score of 15.200 that will boost him into the individual final on that the apparatus.\n\nSaturday's competition served as the qualifying round for both the team and individual finals.\n\nThere are 12 national teams, spaced out across three subdivisions over the course of the day. The eight teams make the finals. China, Great Britain, Japan and Ukraine are among those expected to join the U.S. there.\n\nIndividually, the top 24 finishers in qualifying make the all-around final - but with the important caveat that there can be no more than two all-around finalists per country. It's this rule that essentially eliminated Malone. In apparatus-specific competition, like vault or pommel horse, the top eight qualifiers from Saturday advance.\n\nContact Tom Schad at tschad@usatoday.com or on social media @Tom_Schad.", "source": {"uri": "2024-07-437632983", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "23:11:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T23:11:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T00:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://m.arcamax.com/sports/olympics/s-3348126", "title": "How the US men's gymnastics team won its first medal since 2008", "body": "PARIS -- Frederick Richard, Brody Malone, Paul Juda and Asher Hong stood shoulder to shoulder. Their arms were draped across each other's backs in a tight line as Stephen Nedoroscik mounted the pommel horse.\n\nWhen Nedoroscik's feet touched the mat again, they were all Olympic medalists.\n\nThe United States ended a 16-year Olympic medal drought, claiming bronze in the team final on Monday in Bercy Arena. Japan overcame a shocking fall by reigning Olympic all-around champion Hashimoto Daiki on pommel horse to edge out China, which suffered three falls on high bar in the final rotation.\n\nNedoroscik had waited two hours to perform his single routine of the day. The pommel horse specialist didn't look fazed, working through efficiently and sending his teammates into a euphoric celebration when he landed his dismount. He raised both fists in the air and wrapped coach Sam Mikulak in a hug. Mikulak lifted Nedoroscik in the air.\n\nJapan won with 259.594 points, 0.532 points ahead of China. The United States finished with 257.793 points.\n\nThe tight race at the top came from a three-year process that started when the Americans returned home from a third consecutive fifth-place Olympic finish in Tokyo. The United States was already out of medal contention when the Americans entered the arena three years ago. Their difficulty score during the team final was five points behind the top team Japan, a chasm even perfect execution could not close.\n\nThey needed to tip the math in their favor.\n\nIn an effort to boost the team's difficulty score, USA Gymnastics used a complicated bonus system that encouraged athletes to demonstrate upgraded skills. Typically, a fall while attempting a difficult element would decide an athlete's standing on the national team and the financial and marketing opportunities that come with the designation. But the bonus system, which began in 2022, offered a safety net of additional points at domestic competitions for more difficult skills that would have offset a fall.\n\nWhen Richard had just learned a tricky full-twisting high bar release in 2022, he took the risk of adding it to his competitive routine for the U.S. championship with assurance that even if he didn't catch the bar, the bonus system could provide a safety net. He aced the skill both days of competition and it's been in his routine since. He used it to become the youngest American man to win an all-around medal at the world championships when he took bronze in 2023 while helping the United States to team gold.\n\nThe Americans ended a nearly 10-year world championship drought by finishing third last year in Belgium. From a five-point difficulty gap at the 2021 Olympics, the United States was 2.1 points behind first-place Japan at the world championships and 0.7 point behind second-place China.\n\nThe math, as they say, was mathing.\n\n\"We're going to be able to control our own destiny [at the Olympics],\" U.S. high performance director Brett McClure said after the team was announced at U.S. Olympic trials.\n\nWhen the Americans were safely in medal position following Nedoroscik's hit routine, McClure handed an American flag to Malone. The 24-year-old was the only member of the U.S. team with prior Olympic experience. He didn't look the part during qualifications when he began the competition with a fall on pommel horse and fell twice on his signature event high bar.\n\nHe apologized to teammates after the competition. But Richard remained confident Malone would bounce back when the team needed him.\n\nThe three-time U.S. champion did just that. He stuck his dismount on high bar to anchor the United States' fourth rotation and keep the team in third place. He followed up on pommel horse in the final rotation with another hit routine and he finally let his emotions show.\n\nHe shouted, \"Let's go!\" In the celebration, he wrapped the flag around his broad shoulders as a smile overtook his face.", "source": {"uri": "m.arcamax.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "m.arcamax.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": "arcamax_publishing@m.arcamax.com", "name": "ArcaMax Publishing", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pommel_horse", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Pommel horse"}}, {"uri": {"uri": "8249498160", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "20:03:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T20:03:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T20:02:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://ftw.usatoday.com/2024/07/stephen-nedoroscik-olympics-usa-mens-gymnastics-pommel-horse-bronze-medal", "title": "Team USA gymnast Stephen Nedoroscik inspired so many memes after winning an Olympic bronze medal", "body": "Stephen Nedoroscik is an ABSOLUTE DAWG, and as an unofficial card-holding member of the glasses-wearers coalition, I salute him.\n\nIt's been so long since the U.S. won a medal in any team event for men's gymnastics (Here's exactly how long it's been), and to win one during this year's Paris Games, it was all down to one event: the pommel horse.\n\nThe U.S. is not exactly a powerhouse on the pommel, and they needed big performances from Paul Juda and Brody Malone to boost Team USA's chances of winning a medal before Steve Nedoroscik took the floor. Both Juda and Malone came through with clutch scoring, setting the stage for Steve to go big or go home. AND HE DELIVERED.\n\nHis performance -- sans glasses -- was so good that Olympics fans had a field day. {"uri": "2024-07-438376641", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "13:46:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T13:46:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T13:30:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://siouxcityjournal.com/sports/other/olympics/pommel-horse-specialist-stephen-nedoroscik-waited-his-whole-life-for-one-routine/article_f0b0702f-626c-5d81-aeaa-587b8542e116.html", "title": "Pommel horse specialist Stephen Nedoroscik waited his whole life for one routine", "body": "The numbers behind day 3 as the Australians dominated the pool and Tom Daley grabbed his fifth Olympic medal.\n\nPARIS -- Sam Mikulak pulled Stephen Nedoroscik close and tasked the American pommel horse specialist with the impossible.\n\nThe U.S. men's gymnastics team's first Olympic medal in 16 years a solitary routine away, Mikulak told the pommel horse specialist that he didn't need to go all out. That 80% would be good enough, even though Mikulak knew full well that Nedoroscik never does anything -- from his sport to solving a Rubik's Cube -- at 80%.\n\n\"You have to trick yourself,\" said Mikulak, a three-time Olympian turned coach. \"You've got to make sure you don't let all the noise get into your head.\"\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nSierra signage going up at former Sioux City Bed Bath & Beyond North Sioux City crash kills one 4-year-old boy escaped from cage in Iowa home; deputies found him covered in feces on street Now streaming and on DVD: 'The Richmond Way' gives us the whole 'Ted Lasso' story BNSF Railway wants to remove collapsed Big Sioux River train bridge Sioux City's Lyons Park getting $1.22 million in upgrades Jason's Frozen Treats open second dine-in ice cream parlor Sioux City driver charged with vehicular homicide from weekend crash Body found in Floyd River in Sioux City Elk Point man killed in North Sioux City crash Wife of Dakota Dunes fatal stabbing suspect charged as an accessory Financial situation for McCook Lake residents still murky a month after flood State baseball: Scrapy dynamic duo sends Crusaders to state title game, down top seed Wahlert Woodbury County Court Report for July 22, 2024 Two dead following Sunday night two-vehicle accident in Sioux City's westside\n\nThat usually isn't a problem for the 25-year-old from Worcester, Massachusetts. It takes a certain type of single-mindedness to make the choices Nedoroscik has made for the last decade, when he essentially decided to dedicate himself to a single pursuit, focusing on an event that has long been a weakness for the U.S. men's national team program.\n\nYes, there is monotony involved. How could there not be?\n\n\"I don't know how I don't lose my mind,\" Nedoroscik said before the Games. \"But every day I go into the gym and there's still something to do. There's still something to improve.\"\n\nNot anymore.\n\nProving a point\n\nHe drilled his set during qualifying on Saturday to earn a spot on the event finals later in the Games. But Monday night, things were different. Teammates Frederick Richard, Brody Malone, Paul Juda and Asher Hong had put together 17 straight routines without a miss, putting the Americans in position to reach the medal stand for the first time since 2008 in Beijing.\n\nWhile Nedoroscik had some wiggle room -- the U.S. had a fairly healthy lead after Juda and Malone hit their sets before Nedoroscik saluted the judges -- he also didn't want to merely hold on. He wanted to prove a point.\n\nNot just to himself, but to those who wondered if he deserved to be there in the first place.\n\nWhat followed were 45 seconds of sublime brilliance, with Nedoroscik's hands traveling from one end of the horse to the other, his legs swooping this way, then that.\n\nA few feet away, his four teammates -- and the sizable contingent of US fans inside Bercy Arena -- roared as a medal that seemed distant for a program that had finished a distant fifth in each of its last three trips under the rings -- drew closer.\n\nBy the time Nedoroscik neared his dismount, he knew his job was complete. The celebration began before his feet even hit the mat.\n\nAll those years, all those reps, both physical and mental, all the difficult times when he wondered whether to keep going, all the quirks he's developed along the way -- from the non-prescription goggles he sometimes rocks to the chef's kiss to the camera he occasionally makes -- led up to that moment.\n\nAnd he did not miss, delivering \"the exclamation point\" with a 14.866 to finish off a performance the U.S. men's program hopes provides serious momentum heading into the 2028 Games in Los Angeles.\n\n\"I kind of in that moment was like, 'All right, let's run it back and let's go out there and do our thing,'\" Nedoroscik said.\n\nFilling a critical gap\n\nA \"thing\" that has long been a sore spot for the U.S. in major international competition. The 2012 Olympic team topped qualifying. Then they led off on pommel horse in the finals and saw their medal hopes vanish one mistake at a time.\n\nNedoroscik understood the history. It's one of the reasons he gravitated toward pommels. Another is the fact that it requires many things -- stamina, strength and creativity chief among them -- that he has in spades, particularly that last one.\n\nHe describes himself as a \"late bloomer\" on the event. Those early struggles only helped him press forward.\n\n\"Running into trouble on the apparatus early on taught me how to fight, how to stay on, how to really go for that routine,\" he said. \"And I think that that has stuck with me throughout.\"\n\nUnlike other events, which are painstakingly laid out and practiced on end for months if not years, pommel horse allows gymnasts to color outside the lines and make things up as they go on. Miss an element here? Well, maybe you can make it up trying something else later in the routine.\n\nHe says the end result is the feeling of \"flying through the air,\" though it's more akin to levitation.\n\nMore work to be done\n\nNedoroscik will soar into the event finals Saturday with a chance to put another medal in his carry-on before he heads home. His 15.200 qualifying score tied Ireland's Rhys McClenaghan for the tops among the eight finalists.\n\nHe is ready to ride the wave as far as it will take him. Yet whatever happens on Saturday or for the rest of his life for that matter, it will be difficult to top Monday night, when the guy with the curly hair and the glasses that made him the kind of social media sensation only the Olympics provides struck a blow for his sport, his teammates and himself.\n\n\"I'm really proud of these guys,\" he said while sitting alongside the group that became U.S. men's gymnastics royalty. \"I love you boys.\"\n\nOlympic Games Paris 2024: Scenes from the opening ceremony\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8249446949", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "19:13:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T19:13:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T19:11:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/arena/the-spun/u-s-mens-gymnastics-medals-in-team-competition-for-first-time-since-2008/article_fd061e8e-128b-5994-a369-365c07caeedf.html", "title": "U.S. Men's Gymnastics Medals In Team Competition For First Time Since 2008", "body": "The United States men's gymnastics team has medaled in the team competition at the Summer Olympics for the first time since 2008.\n\nThe Americans needed to come through on the pommel horse in order to secure a medal and they did just that. It came down to Stephen Nedoroscik, the \"pommel horse specialist,\" who nailed his routine - and most importantly, his dismount - to secure a bronze medal for the United States.\n\n\"OLYMPIC BRONZE MEDALISTS! For the first time since 2008, the U.S. Men are taking home hardware in the Olympic Team Competition! Congratulations to Asher, Paul, Brody, Stephen & Frederick - you are Olympic Medalists!\" Team USA announced on Monday afternoon.\n\nNedoroscik, who is competing in his first Summer Olympics, handled the nerves well in the qualifiers on Saturday. He then came through when it mattered most on Monday.\n\n\"It went really well today, I handled the nerves very well,\" Nedoroscik said on Saturday. \"I worked my whole life up to those 45 seconds.\"\n\nHe's had a good mindset throughout.\n\n\"This is just another day of doing the gymnastics,\" Nedoroscik joked. \"Sure it's the biggest stage in the world. It only happens once every four years, but at the same time I'm putting chalk on my hands and doing the horse for the team, it's nothing different.\"\n\nThe individual all-around and the apparatus competitions will take place later this week.\n\nRelated: Danica Patrick Was Furious With The Summer Olympics Opening Ceremony", "source": {"uri": "postandcourier.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8246103397", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-27", "time": "11:35:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-27T11:35:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-27T11:34:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.nbcolympics.com/news/mens-gymnastics-recap-july-27-richard-juda-edge-out-malone-great-britain-tops-us", "title": "Men's gymnastics recap, July 27: Richard, Juda edge out Malone; Great Britain tops U.S.", "body": "Subdivision 1: United States, Great Britain, Germany and Canada\n\nOne of the biggest storylines following the United States men's gymnastics team into Paris is whether or not the team is capable of bringing home an Olympic medal, which hasn't happened since the team won bronze in 2008. Japan and China are the heavy favorites to battle for gold, but there are a handful of teams who are capable of challenging for a spot on the medal podium alongside them.\n\nThe U.S. and Great Britain are two of those teams.\n\nAfter the first subdivision of the qualification round, Great Britain (256.561) edged out the U.S. (253.229), with Canada finishing third (247.794) and Germany finishing fourth (245.395).\n\nJake Jarman of Great Britain leads the all-around (84.897), but perhaps the story of the day is 2023 World all-around bronze medalist Frederick Richard and 2022 NCAA all-around champion Paul Juda (82.865), advancing to the all-around final - knocking out three-time all-around national champion Brody Malone.\n\nMalone fell on pommel horse in the first rotation and had two falls on high bar, ending his chances before the competition even concluded. Malone will also miss the high bar final, an event where he is a world champion from 2022.\n\nComing into the competition, Malone and Richard were favored to advance as the top all-around gymnasts. However, Juda was undeniable today. Showing confidence and precision on every single event to qualify to his first major all-around final in his Olympic debut.\n\nGreat Britain took the lead over the United States early on with a 44.299 on vault, thanks to a couple of huge vaults from Harry Hepworth and 2023 World vault champion Jake Jarman. Both gymnasts performed two vaults, hoping to land a spot in the event final. Hepworth posted the highest average on vault with a 14.766, but Jarman wasn't too far behind with a 14.699.\n\nMeanwhile, the U.S. got off to a strong start (42.433) on the pommel horse - an event that historically has been one of the team's weaker events.\n\nJuda started the competition, showing clean circles and setting the U.S. team off on the right foot. The routine was so good, Juda couldn't help but let out a victorious scream after sticking his dismount; soaking in every moment of his first routine on the Olympic stage. Richard followed with a strong routine of his own, however the U.S. ran into a hiccup in the third spot when Malone fell off midway through his pommel horse routine, posting just a 12.100.\n\nFollowing a long wait for Malone's score, 2021 pommel horse world champion Stephen Nedoroscik rounded out the rotation with a superb set, doing exactly what he brought to Paris to do. Nedoroscik hasn't always performed his highest level of difficulty in competition this year but performed a 6.4 difficulty routine to set the benchmark for event qualification with a massive 15.200.\n\nOver on rings in the second rotation, Juda and Richard nailed their routines with Richard capping things off with a stuck double double. Malone rebounded well from his fall in the first rotation to put up a clean rings routine. Asher Hong posted the highest score of the rotation for Team USA (14.633). He'll be targeting a spot in the event finals with that score.\n\nGreat Britain maintained the lead after two rotations, led by Joe Fraser's 14.933 on parallel bars.\n\nIn the third rotation, the U.S. was a little conservative on vault and wasn't able to get any stuck landings. The highlight of the rotation was Hong's incredibly difficult Ri Se-Gwang, which he landed with a step back for a 14.700.\n\nIn the fourth rotation, Juda kept his momentum rolling with a 14.033 on parallel bars. Malone posted a 14.533, his highest score of the day.\n\nGreat Britain went big on the floor, with Jarman (14.766), Luke Whitehouse (14.544) and Hepworth (14.166) posting some of the highest scores of the first subdivision.\n\nOn high bar in the fifth rotation, Hong went the wrong way on his Tak full but recovered well for a 12.600. Next up, Malone fell on his Liukin and again on his Kolman - a devastating ending for his all-around and event final chances. His final score was 12.233. Richard rounded out the rotation with a stellar routine, good for a 14.166.\n\nOver on pommel horse for Great Britain, two-time Olympic champion Max Whitlock delivered a huge routine. His 15.166 puts him behind Nedoroscik by just .034.\n\nIn the final rotation, Richard went out of bounds on his opening tumbling pass on floor, but his 13.833 was enough to lock in his spot in the all-around final for Team USA, along with Juda, who went 13.966 on floor. Hong posted the highest score for the Americans on floor with a 14.100.\n\nOther notable performances from individuals competing in the first subdivision included Mahdi Olfati of Iran, who vaulted an impressive Yurchenko double pike just hours after serving as the flag bearer for his country. Israel's Artem Dolgopyat posted a 14.466 on floor, the event where he is the reigning Olympic champion.\n\nAhmad Abu Al Soud of Jordan, who also was a flag bearer, fell on the pommel horse (12.466). Abu Al Soud, who is a world silver and bronze medalist on the event, will miss the event finals.", "source": {"uri": "nbcolympics.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "nbcolympics.com"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8249471485", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "19:38:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T19:38:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T19:36:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://dailyvoice.com/massachusetts/worcester/moment-met-worcester-gymnast-helps-us-men-claim-first-olympic-medal-in-16-years/", "title": "'Moment = Met': Worcester Gymnast Helps US Men Claim First Olympic Medal In 16 Years", "body": "Stephen Nedoroscik had only one event to make his mark on the 2024 Paris Olympics, and he did not disappoint.\n\nNedoroscik, a Worcester, Massachusetts, gymnast and Pennsylvania State University alum, nailed his pommel horse routine on Monday, July 29, to lift the team US men's gymnastic team to a bronze medal in the all-around competition. It's their first time on the podium in 16 years.\n\nThe team came to Monday's event in a close race with Great Britain for the bronze. Nedoroscik would be the team's last hope to hold on to that medal.\n\nIn 45 seconds, the 25-year-old Worcester Tech graduate electrified the crowd at Bercy Arena, culminating with a perfect dismount to rapturous applause and chants of 'USA, USA.\" His teammates lifted him as he walked off the mat to a team-best score of 14.866.\n\nNBC Olympics posted the routine on social media with the simple caption, \"Moment = Met.\"\n\nJapan took home gold in the all-around competition, and China earned silver.\n\nDespite being a US and world champion, Nedoroscik was considered a controversial pick for the Paris Olympics because he only competed in the pommel horse, according to The Athletic. Most of the US men's gymnastics team performed in all or most of the six events.\n\nThat meant he spent hours on the sidelines Monday waiting for his chance to prove he deserved his spot. And he did just that, turning in one of the most memorable moments for the US team of the Paris Games thus far.\n\nIt's fitting that the glasses-wearing Nedoroscik drew comparisons to Clark Kent as he is now being called the Superman of these games.\n\nThe US men's gymnastics team also won a bronze medal in the 2008 Beijing Olympics.\n\nClick here to follow Daily Voice Worcester and receive free China will take home the silver and the U.S. will win the bronze.\n\nFrom the very moment Frederick Richard drilled his dismount on rings, the energy was palpable. It was clear that the momentum was on Team USA's side.\n\nRotation after rotation, routine after routine - Frederick Richard, Brody Malone, Asher Hong, Paul Juda and Stephen Nedoroscik delivered without a waiver.\n\nNedoroscik, who had to wait over two hours to compete in his one and only event, sealed the deal on pommel horse. The 25 year old from Worcester, MA went lights out on the event where he is a four-time national champion and a world champion from 2021.\n\nIt's a storybook ending for Malone, who battled back from a rough day of competition during the qualification round to contribute critical routines for his team when it mattered most. It happened that the Worcester, Massachusetts, native's moment on the floor was the U.S. team's last.\n\nFollowing solid performances from teammates Paul Juda and Brody Malone, Nedoroscik posted a 14.866, one of the best pommel horse scores of the day, and secured Team USA the bronze medal behind Japan and China.\n\nWhile the U.S. women's gymnastics team has dominated the sport in the last decade, this was the men's squad's first spot on the podium since 2008.\n\nAnother Massachusetts gymnast provided more points to Team USA's total of 257.793 -- Frederick Richard earned cheers from a watch party back in Stoughton as performed in four different events: floor, rings, parallel bars and horizontal bars.\n\n\"We've been giving it everything and today it all came together,\" Richard told NBC10 Boston after the win. \"The universe, you know, it works in crazy ways.\"\n\nWhile the rest of the squad kept the team in touching distance, Nedoroscik kept warm in a separate gym area, and only came back out near the end of the meet.\n\nAn NBC analyst even compared him to legendary New England Patriot Adam Vinatieri, the kicker who just about everyone back in Massachusetts will know Only two American men have ever claimed gold in the event.\n\nCoverage of Nedoroscik's attempt to become the third will be featured on Peacock this Saturday, Aug. 3 at 11:10 a.m. ET.\n\nHe is among the favorites to win the gold. {"uri": "8249503968", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "20:08:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T20:08:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T20:07:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://bleacherreport.com/articles/10130047-medal-count-2024-olympics-updated-standings-highlights-after-day-3", "title": "Medal Count 2024 Olympics: Updated Standings, Highlights After Day 3", "body": "Frederick Richard of the U.S. men's gymnastics teamNaomi Baker/Getty Images\n\nAs previously noted, the U.S. men's gymnastics team hadn't won a team medal since the 2008 Olympics -- and hasn't won a gold medal since the 1984 games. In each of the past three Summer Olympics, the Americans have finished fifth.\n\nWhile women's gymnastics remains a marquee sport in the U.S., things have waned on the men's side of things. That's why taking home any medal in Paris was big for the men's team.\n\nLed by national champion Brody Malone, Stephen Nedoroscik, Frederick Richard, Paul Juda and Asher Hong, the Americans had a terrific group performance, ultimately edging out Great Britain for third place.\n\nMalone competed in five of six events, while Nedoroscik delivered a clutch performance on pommel horse to secure a trip to the podium.\n\nThe bronze win was largely the result of a change in approach by USA Gymnastics coaches. In previous years, Team USA's routines simply weren't difficult enough, and coaches looked to change that.\n\n\"In an effort to boost the team's difficulty score, USA Gymnastics used a complicated bonus system that encouraged athletes to demonstrate upgraded skills,\" Thuc Nhi Nguyen of the Los Angeles Times wrote.\n\nBy offering a bonus system that rewarded more difficult skills and helped offset falls during the team-selection process, they found a squad that could truly compete on the biggest stage. Fortunately, it executed.\n\nAnd while winning a bronze during an Olympics that features 329 medal events might not seem like a big deal, it's huge for the American men's gymnastics landscape.\n\nJapan took gold in the event, while China won silver. If Team USA uses its third-place performance as a springboard to the 2028 Olympics, perhaps it will have a shot at its first gold in more than four decades.", "source": {"uri": "bleacherreport.com", He helped the men's team end a 16-year-long medal drought at the Paris Olympics with a major score of 15.200.\n\nHe typically competes with a pair of goggles designed to stay on as he swings around the apparatus. Fans have dubbed him the Clark Kent of pommel horse because he takes off his thick-rimmed eyeglasses before his routine, and puts them immediately back on to see.\n\nSeveral X users have called the Penn State graduate \"nerdy\" but it's all extremely well-intentioned. He did just that via his stellar performance on the pommel horse on Monday, but he also did something else along the way. He captured the fascination of the internet.\n\nNedoroscik, 25, attended the Olympics only to compete on the pommel horse, working as a specialist designed to propel Team USA to a medal. Thanks in part to his performance, they won the bronze in the team final on July 29, marking their first medal since 2008. But only competing in one Olympic event means a lot of waiting (about three hours, according to NBC News), and during his wait time is when Nedoroscik won over the internet. {"uri": "8246104174", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-27", "time": "11:38:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-27T11:38:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-27T11:35:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/sports-games/3032073-great-britain-leads-mens-gymnastics-qualifying-at-paris", "title": "Great Britain Leads Men's Gymnastics Qualifying at Paris | Sports-Games", "body": "Great Britain surged ahead in men's gymnastics qualifying with a team score of 256.561, outperforming the United States. The Americans, struggling with high bar and pommel horse issues, finished second. Jake Jarman and Joe Fraser led with top all-around scores, while Max Whitlock boosted his team with a stellar pommel horse routine.\n\nGreat Britain surged to an early lead during men's gymnastics qualifying, posting a team total of 256.561 to finish ahead of the United States in the first of three subdivisions Saturday.\n\nThe Americans, who finished third at the 2023 world championships ahead of Great Britain, dealt with issues on the high bar and pommel horse to finish second at 253.229.\n\nThere is work to be done after the British put on a largely mistake-free clinic across six rotations. Jake Jarman and Joe Fraser posted top all-around scores, while six-time Olympic medalist Max Whitlock provided momentum with an electric pommel horse routine, his signature event.\n\nWhitlock's 15.166 trailed only American Stephen Nedoroscik, a specialist whose 15.200 likely secured him a spot in the event finals. However, the US team's momentum was halted when Brody Malone fell multiple times. Frederick Richard and Paul Juda will represent the Americans in the all-around finals, with Richard being a bronze medalist at the 2023 world championships.\n\nQualifying continues later today with rivals Japan and China competing. {"uri": "8249391492", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "18:20:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T18:20:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T18:19:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/07/29/sports/stephen-nedoroscik-olympics/", "title": "Four things to know about Stephen Nedoroscik, the Worcester gymnast who helped Team USA win bronze - The Boston Globe", "body": "Here's what to know about Nedoroscik, who is from Massachusetts.\n\nA 2016 graduate of Worcester Tech, Nedoroscik trains at Sterling Academy of Gymnastics in Worcester. Nedoroscik, 25, he began his gymnastics journey in 2003. Gymnastics was the only sport he played in high school and decided to focus solely on pommel horse after winning the Junior Olympic Nationals in 2015 and 2016, his only times competing in the event.\n\nUnlike some other gymnasts who learn all six disciplines (floor, vault, parallel bars, horizontal bar, pommel horse, and still rings), Nedoroscik stars on just one: pommel horse.\n\nHe is appearing in his first Olympics after narrowly missing out on being a part of the 2021 Tokyo roster. At the team qualification on Saturday, Nedoroscik scored a 15.2, the highest score for any American gymnast through the qualification.\n\nJoining the Nittany Lions in college, Nedoroscik instantly made an impact, securing the 2017 and 2018 pommel horse titles at the national championships.\n\nNedoroscik won the Nissen Emery Award in 2020, given to the nation's most outstanding senior college gymnast. He continued his success after graduating with a degree in electrical engineering, winning United State pommel horse championships in four consecutive years, from 2021-24. His four US pommel horse titles are the tied for the most in American history.\n\nHave you seen his goggles? They are not prescribed, yet play an integral role in his look and his confidence. A secret Santa gift in 2017 while at Penn State from teammate Ben Cooperman, Nedoroscik began to wear them as a joke. When he continued to excel, he decided to keep them and has not broken the superstition since. Now, the goggles have become indelibly linked with the pommel horse specialist.", "source": {"uri": "bostonglobe.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Boston Globe"}, "authors": [], "concepts": "https://bostonglobe-prod.cdn.arcpublishing.com/resizer/vq91hkSAr9vDOzx0I5hr1LnCS6U=/506x0/cloudfront-us-east-1.images.arcpublishing.com/bostonglobe/2YH47PHMASCL5I65QADLVDX4LI.jpg", "originalArticle": {"uri": "8250768660", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "13:50:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T13:50:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T13:49:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/sports/other/olympics/pommel-horse-specialist-stephen-nedoroscik-waited-his-whole-life-for-one-routine/article_317c92a8-4c00-5cd4-8fc6-415d2532ea41.html", "title": "Pommel horse specialist Stephen Nedoroscik waited his whole life for one routine", "body": "PARIS -- Sam Mikulak pulled Stephen Nedoroscik close and tasked the American pommel horse specialist with the impossible.\n\nThe U.S. men's gymnastics team's first Olympic medal in 16 years a solitary routine away, Mikulak told the pommel horse specialist that he didn't need to go all out. That 80% would be good enough, even though Mikulak knew full well that Nedoroscik never does anything -- from his sport to solving a Rubik's Cube -- at 80%.\n\n\"You have to trick yourself,\" said Mikulak, a three-time Olympian turned coach. \"You've got to make sure you don't let all the noise get into your head.\"\n\nPeople are also reading... Bloomington approves $6.8M contract for roadwork McLean County Fair selects 2024 royalty Bloomington man denied release from treatment center 15 years after infant daughter's death Bear seen in Illinois likely swam across Ohio River from Kentucky, wildlife official says 2 suspects arrested after shots fired on Morris Avenue in Bloomington Bloomington businessman giving backpacks to families in need Bloomington woman pleads guilty to burglary charge in McLean County Normal police investigating shots fired Tuesday night Records show deputy's behavior, integrity questioned years before shooting of Sonya Massey UPDATE: Missing teen from Normal found safe Riverdale man gets 123 years for 2020 murder in Bloomington Normal man pleads guilty, sentenced for reckless driving in crash that injured 2 students Funerals pending for July 27 McLean County pathologist recognized for death investigation, tissue donation work Bloomington native, trick rider Lindy Lica performs hometown show at McLean County Fair\n\nThat usually isn't a problem for the 25-year-old from Worcester, Massachusetts. It takes a certain type of single-mindedness to make the choices Nedoroscik has made for the last decade, when he essentially decided to dedicate himself to a single pursuit, focusing on an event that has long been a weakness for the U.S. men's national team program.\n\nYes, there is monotony involved. How could there not be?\n\n\"I don't know how I don't lose my mind,\" Nedoroscik said before the Games. \"But every day I go into the gym and there's still something to do. There's still something to improve.\"\n\nNot anymore.\n\nProving a point\n\nHe drilled his set during qualifying on Saturday to earn a spot on the event finals later in the Games. But Monday night, things were different. Teammates Frederick Richard, Brody Malone, Paul Juda and Asher Hong had put together 17 straight routines without a miss, putting the Americans in position to reach the medal stand for the first time since 2008 in Beijing.\n\nWhile Nedoroscik had some wiggle room -- the U.S. had a fairly healthy lead after Juda and Malone hit their sets before Nedoroscik saluted the judges -- he also didn't want to merely hold on. He wanted to prove a point.\n\nNot just to himself, but to those who wondered if he deserved to be there in the first place.\n\nWhat followed were 45 seconds of sublime brilliance, with Nedoroscik's hands traveling from one end of the horse to the other, his legs swooping this way, then that.\n\nA few feet away, his four teammates -- and the sizable contingent of US fans inside Bercy Arena -- roared as a medal that seemed distant for a program that had finished a distant fifth in each of its last three trips under the rings -- drew closer.\n\nBy the time Nedoroscik neared his dismount, he knew his job was complete. The celebration began before his feet even hit the mat.\n\nAll those years, all those reps, both physical and mental, all the difficult times when he wondered whether to keep going, all the quirks he's developed along the way -- from the non-prescription goggles he sometimes rocks to the chef's kiss to the camera he occasionally makes -- led up to that moment.\n\nAnd he did not miss, delivering \"the exclamation point\" with a 14.866 to finish off a performance the U.S. men's program hopes provides serious momentum heading into the 2028 Games in Los Angeles.\n\n\"I kind of in that moment was like, 'All right, let's run it back and let's go out there and do our thing,'\" Nedoroscik said.\n\nFilling a critical gap\n\nA \"thing\" that has long been a sore spot for the U.S. in major international competition. The 2012 Olympic team topped qualifying. Then they led off on pommel horse in the finals and saw their medal hopes vanish one mistake at a time.\n\nNedoroscik understood the history. It's one of the reasons he gravitated toward pommels. Another is the fact that it requires many things -- stamina, strength and creativity chief among them -- that he has in spades, particularly that last one.\n\nHe describes himself as a \"late bloomer\" on the event. Those early struggles only helped him press forward.\n\n\"Running into trouble on the apparatus early on taught me how to fight, how to stay on, how to really go for that routine,\" he said. \"And I think that that has stuck with me throughout.\"\n\nUnlike other events, which are painstakingly laid out and practiced on end for months if not years, pommel horse allows gymnasts to color outside the lines and make things up as they go on. Miss an element here? Well, maybe you can make it up trying something else later in the routine.\n\nHe says the end result is the feeling of \"flying through the air,\" though it's more akin to levitation.\n\nMore work to be done\n\nNedoroscik will soar into the event finals Saturday with a chance to put another medal in his carry-on before he heads home. His 15.200 qualifying score tied Ireland's Rhys McClenaghan for the tops among the eight finalists.\n\nHe is ready to ride the wave as far as it will take him. Yet whatever happens on Saturday or for the rest of his life for that matter, it will be difficult to top Monday night, when the guy with the curly hair and the glasses that made him the kind of social media sensation only the Olympics provides struck a blow for his sport, his teammates and himself.\n\n\"I'm really proud of these guys,\" he said while sitting alongside the group that became U.S. men's gymnastics royalty. \"I love you boys.\"\n\nOlympic Games Paris 2024: Scenes from the opening ceremony\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. Jake Jarman (84.897) and Joe Fraser (84.666) posted the top all-around scores and six-time Olympic medalist Max Whitlock provided a jolt with an electric pommel horse routine - his signature event - that left the 31-year-old looking relieved.\n\nWhitlock's 15.166 trailed only American Stephen Nedoroscik, a specialist whose 15.200 likely earned him a spot in the event finals and gave his teammates some early momentum.\n\nIt didn't last. Brody Malone, who came back from a horrific leg injury to win his third U.S. championship in June, fell twice on high bar and once on pommel horse to scuttle his chances of returning to the all-around finals.\n\nPHOTOS: Great Britain rides strong effort of Olympic veterans to early lead in men's gymnastics qualifying\n\nInstead, Frederick Richard and Paul Juda will represent the Americans. His all-around total of 82.865 was fourth among early qualifiers, trailing only Richard (83.498), Jarman and Fraser.\n\nQualifying continues later Saturday, with longtime rivals and gold medal favorites Japan and China competing in the second of three subdivisions. {"uri": "8251326807", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "20:50:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T20:50:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T20:49:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://thesportsgrail.com/why-does-stephen-nedoroscik-wear-glasses-for-his-eyesight-and-what-happened-to-his-eyes-explained/", "title": "Why does Stephen Nedoroscik wear glasses for his eyesight and what happened to his eyes explained", "body": "Find out the reason behind why the American Olympian, Stephen Nedoroscik wears glasses for his eyesight as a video of him addressing the matter went viral across social media platforms following his stellar performance at the Paris Olympics 2024\n\nFor the unfamiliar, the 25-year-old U.S. gymnast, a rarity among Olympic athletes, wears glasses. Competing in the 2024 Paris Olympics, he removes them for his sole event, the pommel horse, a dazzling routine that helped Team USA's men's gymnastics team win bronze on Monday, July 29.\n\nNedoroscik's transformation from a mild-mannered, bespectacled mechanical engineer to a powerful athlete defying gravity on the pommel horse draws comparisons to Clark Kent turning into Superman.\n\nIn an interview earlier today on July 30, Nedoroscik could be heard saying, \"I think they're awesome,\" adding \"I'm representing people that wear glasses well.\"\n\nDuring the interview with co-anchor Hoda Kotb, he revealed that he wore his sunglasses due to his eye sensitivity, a condition that he previously discussed on social media.\n\n\"It's not necessarily clear, but the thing about pommel horse is if I keep them on, they're gonna fly somewhere,\" Nedoroscik explained.\n\nHe further added, \"When I go up on the pommel horse, it's all about feeling the equipment. I don't even really see when I'm doing my gymnastics. It's all in the hands -- I can feel everything.\"\n\nNedoroscik has strabismus, or crossed eyes, a condition he revealed on TikTok. Strabismus, caused by issues with eye muscles, leads to misaligned eyes, resulting in depth perception loss, blurry, or double vision.\n\nGlasses or contacts can help, and other treatments include surgery, eye muscle exercises, and prism lenses. Additionally, Nedoroscik has coloboma, a genetic condition where part of the eye tissue is missing at birth, making him photophobic, or light-sensitive.\n\nThis explains why he borrowed Hoda's sunglasses. Symptoms include vision loss and blindness in specific areas. There's no cure, but glasses, contact lenses, low vision aids, or surgery can help.\n\nHe has also revealed that sometimes he just wears glasses for good luck as a superstition.\n\nFor the unfamiliar, Born on October 28, 1998, Stephen John Nedoroscik is an American artistic gymnast specializing in the pommel horse. {"uri": "8249814894", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "02:26:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T02:26:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T02:24:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/stephen-nedoroscik-internet-gymnastics-hero-013236085.html", "title": "Stephen Nedoroscik Is an Internet -- and Gymnastics -- Hero", "body": "U.S. gymnast Stephen Nedoroscik at the Bercy Arena in Paris on July 27, 2024. Credit - Gabriel Bouys -- AFP/Getty Images\n\nThe name doesn't exactly roll off the tongue -- Stephen Nedoroscik -- but you can just call him The Pommel Horse guy.\n\nThat's what social media is dubbing their newly minted star.\n\nIt's Nedoroscik's specialty in gymnastics, and the sole reason he was put on the U.S. men's team. The Massachusetts native now trains in Florida, and is a four-time U.S., two-time NCAA, and 2021 world champion on the event.\n\nPommel horse? What's that? That's the event in which gymnasts mount -- yes, mount -- what's called a horse that is 160-cm. long and 135-cm. wide with two handles on top. You grab the handles and swing your legs around in creative ways -- around, above, and next to the horse. You can even move from one end of the horse to the other -- a move that Nedoroscik does especially well.\n\nRead More: How the U.S. Men's Gymnastics Team Won Their First Medal in 16 Years\n\nNedoroscik was put on the five-member U.S. Olympic team because he's so good on that event. His selection came as a surprise to many gymnastics fans, who questioned the sanity of USA Gymnastics in banking on a specialist who only competes on one of the six events in men's gymnastics. What if he makes a mistake? What if other gymnasts on the team get injured and you run out of alternates to replace them? A specialist, in the gymnastics world, is therefore a very risky thing to be.\n\nBut all the chatter didn't seem to bother the bespectacled Nedoroscik, who, as luck would have it, was scheduled to compete in the last of six rotations, and last in the lineup. That meant he waited for 2.5 hours before it was his turn to mount that pommel.\n\nWhat Nedoroscik did to while away the time is now stuff of internet legend. Snaps of him with his head back, eyes closed, and seemingly dozing have become a meme. But Nedoroscik was just in full preparation mode.\n\n\"I did my breathing exercises, and I could hear all the guys cheering for [teammates] Brody [Malone] and Paul [Juda], and I thought, 'Sounds like everything is going well,'\" he said. \"I knew at that moment that every guy hit every single routine. And I have this thing, if everybody hits [their routines] before me, then I never miss. So I thought 'let's go out there and do our thing.'\"\n\nAnd do his thing he did, swinging, and swinging, and swinging some more to put, as he called it, \"an exclamation point\" on the competition.\n\nIt will surprise absolutely no one that Nedoroscik, an electrical engineering graduate from Penn State, is highly superstitious. He used to wear goggles that were part of a competition superstition after a friend gifted them and he wore them as a prank -- but successfully completed a hard routine. He steers clear of songs that he's listened to before having a bad routine -- \"Thunder\" and \"Riptide\" are big ones (sorry, Imagine Dragons and Vance Joy). Since the 2021 world championships, however, he's been trying to rid himself of those rituals by indulging in them to \"break the curses.\"\n\nIronically, when it comes to his career, Nedoroscik has been more laissez-faire. He concentrated on pommel horse after 2014, when a coach who had trained the national pommel horse champion the previous year came to his club gym in Worcester and told him he could also be a national champion one day.\n\n\"I figured, this guy has seen a national champion so he must see something in me,\" Nedoroscik said. \"That year I won my first ever junior national title. I had no idea how gymnastics worked and didn't even know that college was a thing for gymnasts. So I started talking to coaches and ended up at Penn State. I didn't know how to get on the national team, but won the Winter Cup one year and then made the national team. I thought, 'dude [being a specialist] is awesome'!\"\n\nIt's taken him from recreational gymnast to national and world champion to, now, an Olympic medalist.
