{"uri": "8249802696", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "02:10:22", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T02:10:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T02:09:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.dallasnews.com/sports/other-sports/2024/07/29/2024-paris-olympics-us-mens-gymnastics-bronze-medal-asher-hong-stephen-nedoroscik/", "title": "On triumphant day for U.S. men, Plano gymnast Asher Hong was the juice behind bronze medal", "body": "PARIS - On the first U.S. men's gymnastics team to win an Olympic medal in 16 years, which only feels more like 60, Frederick Richard is its star; Brody Malone, the captain; Paul Juda, the stabilizer; Stephen Nedoroscik, the closer.\n\nAsher Hong?\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe juice.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nOn Monday at Bercy Arena in the team finals, when the momentum finally turned in the men's favor after all these years in the shadow of a women's program that drew stars to Sunday's qualifying like it was the Oscars, the Plano native was the one who lit it up.\n\nSports Roundup\n\nGet the latest D-FW sports news, analysis, scores and more.\n\nSIGN UP\n\nOr with:\n\nGoogleFacebook\n\nBy signing up you agree to our Terms of Service and Privacy Policy\n\nAll five did their jobs, no question. That was the plan. It wasn't take-no-prisoners; it was take-no-risks. Brett McClure, the high performance director, harbored no delusions that they might beat Japan and China, historic programs and rivals that finished 1-2 in an epic photo-finish. The U.S.' conservative approach enabled the team to finish only a point-and-a-half out of second and two ahead of Great Britain.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nFor instance: Before clinching bronze with a score nearly .4 less than the 15.200 he posted in qualifying, Nedoroscik, a pommel horse specialist who sat around two hours waiting for something to do, got his marching orders from his coach.\n\n\"Eighty percent,\" Sam Mikulak told him, \"is all you need.\"\n\nNot what you'd read on Alabama's locker room wall, but, hey, it worked. He knew it's not good to get Nedoroscik too geeked. He's geeky enough as it is, which you'd know if you'd seen him in his black horn-rimmed glasses underneath the pile of backpacks he schlepped around for teammates at qualifying. His peers are built like fire hydrants. Nedoroscik looks like he should haunt a chemistry lab, not swing gracefully around and over a pommel horse. If they make this story into a movie, Michael Cera is a lock for the part.\n\nThe point is, Nedoroscik had one job to do, and if he wasn't exactly magnificent at it Monday, he was plenty good enough. Same with Malone. The squad's only two-time Olympian, a medal hopeful, he'd been a flop in qualifying. Literally. Fell four times across three apparatuses.\n\nLike Nedoroscik, he didn't put on a show Monday, but he didn't wobble once. In qualifying, the '22 world champ on the high bar needed three starts on the apparatus, ending up with just 10 points. When his score Sunday came up 14.166, his coaches protested, but their hearts weren't in it. They were just happy he didn't end up face-first on his finely chiseled chin.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nIn fact, the U.S. went 18-for-18 on six apparatuses, meaning no one slipped, fell or landed on his derriere. Might not sound like much to you, but Japan couldn't say that. Neither could China, whose Su Weide fell twice from the high bar in the final rotation, costing China two points and effectively the gold.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nJuda would be hard-pressed to make the starting lineups of either of the gold or silver medalists, but he set the tone for the U.S. on all four apparatuses he competed on Monday. Stuck the landing and turned it over to the next guy.\n\nWhen he volunteered to go first on the pommel horse in the final rotation, Hong could tell Juda's nerves were frayed. They were this close to a medal. They knew it, even if they refused to look at the scores. Stayed in their \"bubble,\" as they called it. But they had an idea the bronze was in hand after going 15-for-15.\n\nWhen Juda raised his hand and tentatively said he'd go first one more time, Hong moved in.\n\n\"Paul, you're the man for the job,\" he said.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"You earned this moment.\"\n\nThe sense of belief was all Juda needed to hear.\n\n\"I went up there,\" he said, \"and I was light as a feather.\"\n\nFunny thing is, Hong believes he just as easily could have handled the horse in the Olympics. It's his weakest, which is why Nedoroscik took his place, denying Hong an opportunity to compete for the all-around Thursday. But he's getting better on the horse. He was a half-point better on the bars Monday than he'd been in qualifying, and his 14.533 on the rings led the Americans, as did his spectacular 14.833 on the vault.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nGoing into the second rotation, the U.S. was in fifth place overall. Once Hong, a 5-foot-1 blur, landed his twisting, double-back somersault in the vault, the U.S. was in first.\n\n\"That,\" Mikulak said, \"was when then momentum was heating up, and that's Asher's M.O. He's gonna rise to the occasion. There's no way he's missing this. This is, like, his moment.\n\n\"This is what he's been dreaming of, and he finally got it.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\nWhen not giving the team a shot of adrenaline on an apparatus, Hong is its head cheerleader. He and Richard, both still just 20, represent the high-wire future of the men's team. At one point it was hard to tell who'd expended more energy: Richard, a crowd-pleaser who added a gadget to his high bar routine, improving his qualifying score by .7; or Hong, who did everything but climb up on the bar with him.\n\nWeren't you afraid of wearing yourself out?\n\n\"Oh, no,\" Hong said, smiling. \"Hyping everybody gets me more hyped, too.\"\n\nOnce Nedoroscik landed, the rest of the U.S. team members let out everything they'd held in reserve all day. Next thing you knew, the closer, who called it \"the greatest moment of my life,\" was crowd-surfing his teammates. Malone, whose face is a mask in competition, looked like a kid at Christmas. They had a right to party. The men's team had waited 16 long years for this, since Richard and Hong were only 4 years old. The boys are all grown up.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nTwitter/X: @KSherringtonDMN\n\nRelated StoriesView MoreCoppell's Chiaka Ogbogu, U.S. women's volleyball avoid worst vs. China in Olympic openerU.S. women beat Japan to open campaign for 8th straight Olympic gold medalWhy Olympic gold would be a nice addition to Scottie Scheffler's expanding trophy caseTexas ex Ryan Crouser says he's 'as good as I ever {"uri": "2024-07-435852870", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-28", "time": "05:11:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-28T05:11:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-27T20:52:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/olympics/2024/07/27/us-mens-gymnastics-olympics-qualifying-results/74569291007/", "title": "U.S. gymnastics' Brody Malone misses out on Olympic all-around final in a big surprise", "body": "But after a shocking performance on his signature event Saturday, that chance is already gone.\n\nMalone, the only returning member of the 2021 Olympic team, failed to qualify for the individual all-around final by finishing third among the U.S. athletes on the first day of competition at Bercy Arena. Mistakes on pommel horse, floor exercise and, most surprisingly, high bar left him trailing both Frederick Richard and Paul Juda in the all-around standings, while wiping away any chance he had of reaching an individual final in Paris.\n\nOnly two gymnasts per country are allowed to advance to the 24-person all-around final, which is July 31.\n\n\"Just silly mistakes that I don't usually make,\" said Malone, who finished 30th overall. \"But I mean, it happens. It's sports. You'll not always be perfect. So I'm just going to go reset tomorrow in the gym, reset my foundation with some basics and then just be ready for team finals.\"\n\n2024 Olympic medals: Who is leading the medal count? Follow along as we track the medals for every sport.\n\nGet Olympics updates in your texts! Join USA TODAY Sports' WhatsApp Channel\n\nThe first round of competition at elite gymnastics competitions serves as a catch-all qualifier, used to determine both the individuals who make all-around and apparatus-specific finals as well as the teams that will compete in the team final. Only eight individuals make the final for each apparatus, and only eight nations reach the team final on July 29.\n\nThe American men finished second in their four-team qualification group, significantly behind Great Britain. But they placed fifth overall to advance to the final, when the scores will reset and medals will be at stake.\n\n\"It answered a lot of questions for us,\" high-performance director Brett McClure said of Great Britain's performance. \"Our strategy is to go out there and do everything we can, because I think if we put it all together, we're right there with them.\"\n\nPart of that gap between Great Britain and the U.S. can be traced back, unfortunately, to Malone's uncharacteristically rough day.\n\nUsually one of Team USA's most steady and consistent performers, he started off the competition with a fall in the first rotation, pommel horse. And he ended it with a slip in the last rotation, floor exercise. He received scores in the 12s for both routines - well below his usual marks and below par for a team, and athlete, with medal aspirations. In a format where teams drop their lowest score on each event, the U.S. men counted only two of Malone's.\n\nThe nail in the metaphorical coffin, however, was Malone's performance on high bar, the event in which he won a world championship in 2022. He missed the bar on one release move, then stalled after catching the bar too close on another release and had to drop off - a devastating sequence that effectively knocked him out of individual medal contention at these Games.\n\nRichard and Juda said Malone apologized to the team shortly after leaving the floor.\n\n\"We all have bad days,\" Richard said. \"I lost the NCAA championships in April. I came back stronger for (U.S.) championships. I know what it's like to not perform as well as you can, but that's part of the sport.\n\n\"Looking at the full picture, today is not the day we needed him.\"\n\nMalone's loss will likely prove to be Juda's gain. The Michigan product was not considered a lock to even make the Olympic team a few months ago, but he started off the day with a terrific routine on pommel horse - which is historically one of the Americans' worst events - and put up another big score on vault.\n\nPommel horse specialist Stephen Nedoroscik also had an impressive and vital performance in his only event of the day, notching a score of 15.200 that was tied for the best of the day. He will be the only American man to compete in an apparatus final.\n\n\"I don't think that our performance today is going to be concerning,\" Nedoroscik said. \"... I still think we have a fantastic chance to medal.\"\n\nThe U.S. men are attempting to win their first team medal at the Olympics since 2008 - and, at least entering Saturday, they appeared to have solid odds. Team USA doesn't have the difficulty required to keep pace with China or Japan. But with perennial medal contender Russia out of the picture - the result of a team sports suspension levied by the International Olympic Committee - they are expected to be in the mix with Great Britain and Ukraine for the bronze.\n\n\"We didn't watch any scores. We're not going to watch any scores,\" Juda said. \"We're just going to go into our routines and lay the cards where they fall.\"", "source": {"uri": "usatoday.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "USA {"uri": "8249410609", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "18:39:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T18:39:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T18:37:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.sportingnews.com/us/olympics/news/stephen-nedoroscik-glasses-usa-gymnastics-olympics/9b07b6712a8bbe4a1329d55c", "title": "Who is Stephen Nedoroscik? Glasses-wearing pommel horse specialist leads USA gymnastics to bronze medal at Olympics", "body": "Stephen Nedoroscik is giving off a Clark Kent look and is the USA's superhero at the 2024 Paris Olympics.\n\nThe 25-year-old is a pommel horse specialist for the United States gymnastics team and his performance in the all-around finals was the difference in the country medaling for the first time since 2008.\n\nNedoroscik wears glasses that have gotten some Clark Kent comparisons at the Olympic Games. It's fitting that he was in a position to be Superman for Team USA on Monday.\n\nHere's all you need to know about Nedoroscik and his Olympic routine.\n\n2024 PARIS OLYMPICS\n\nFull Olympics schedule | How to watch in USA | Meet NBC's broadcasters\n\nNedoroscik is a pommel horse specialist for Team USA, who is going viral for both his look and his Olympic routine.\n\nThe 25-year-old wears glasses around the mat, giving off a Clark Kent look. He doesn't, however, wear the glasses during his pommel horse routine.\n\nIf you're wondering why he doesn't wear contact lenses, Nedoroscik wears glasses for comfort and superstitious reasons, according to the Olympics. He is said to have gotten glasses as a gift from a friend.\n\nNedoroscik played a major role for the United States during Day 3 of the 2024 Summer Games. His performance put the men's gymnastics team on the podium for the first time since 2008.\n\nNedoroscik scored a 14.866 in his pommel horse routine during the men's artistic gymnastics all-around final. It lifted Team USA onto the podium, winning bronze at the 2024 Paris Olympics.\n\nHe was the anchor for Team USA, sealing the deal for the medal-winning team. He was in the same position that Sasha Artemev was in during the 2008 Olympics.\n\nNedoroscik has been referred to as Clark Kent recently, but his nickname growing up was much different. {"uri": "2024-07-437578149", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "21:27:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T21:27:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T21:22:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://eu.usatoday.com/story/sports/olympics/2024/07/29/stephen-nedoroscik-pommel-horse-team-usa-gymnastics-olympics-paris-2024-bronze-medal-social-media/74594761007/", "title": "Stephen Nedoroscik pommel horse: Social media reacts to American gymnast's bronze medal-clinching routine", "body": "For all the thoughts that could have been flowing through his head, it's unlikely that the American gymnast was pondering how he was about to become a meme.\n\nThe 25-year-old Worcester, Massachusetts native had the unenviable, pressure-filled task Monday of competing in just a single rotation -- the pommel horse -- that wouldn't take place until the end of the team final.\n\nAfter the long, mentally taxing wait, he rose to the occasion, scoring a 14.866 on his routine to secure a medal (ultimately, a bronze) for his team. It was the first time the American men medaled in the team final since 2008.\n\nREQUIRED READING: How Stephen Nedoroscik's pommel horse specialty carried him to Paris Olympics\n\nThough it took the United States several brilliantly executed moves and routines to earn that place on the podium, social media users fixated primarily on Nedoroscik, the bespeckled pommel horse specialist whose moment of contemplation and focus captured by the NBC cameras became a source of inspiration, admiration and, of course, some jokes.\n\nHere's a sampling of how social media reacted to Nedoroscik and, specifically, the image of him sitting intently with his eyes shut:\n\nSocial media reaction to Stephen Nedoroscik and his pommel horse gymnastics routine\n\nChatter about Nedoroscik went beyond just that television screenshot.\n\nThe former Penn State standout and his outstanding pommel horse routine earned the affection of many Americans watching the competition. In that way, Nedoroscik embodied what's so captivating about the Olympics -- a previously little-known athlete is now a viral internet sensation and a national hero.", "source": {"uri": "usatoday.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "USA Today"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pommel_horse", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Pommel horse"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gymnastics", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Gymnastics"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States", "type": "loc", "score": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Paris"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "France"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pennsylvania_State_University", "type": "org", "score": "storyUri": "eng-9768598", "eventUri": "eng-9768598", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.2549019607843137, "wgt": 151, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-07-437706009", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "02:00:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T02:00:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T01:57:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.bnd.com/sports/article290555404.html", "title": "Risky Strategy, Fearless Execution Brings U.S. Men's Gymnastics Back to the Podium", "body": "For two hours and 24 minutes, Stephen Nedoroscik waited. He watched as his teammates hit routine after routine, and he warmed up and tried not to think about what he'd understood since he saw the start list: He would decide whether the U.S. earned its first Olympic medal in the men's gymnastics team event in 16 years.\n\nThirty-eight seconds later, as he flung himself off the pommel horse, he let himself think it: Bro, if you hit this dismount, your team wins a medal.\n\n\"And I stuck it!\" he said afterward, the bronze dangling around his neck, a grin stretched across his face.\n\n\"There's gonna be no pressure that matches that,\" said U.S. teammate Asher Hong.\n\nThe gymnasts insisted later that they had abided by the rule they set for themselves not to watch the scoreboard. \"We make jokes about it, when [the PA announces] the place we're in, we're like, 'We don't want to know that information! Stop telling us!'\" said Paul Juda. But they could tell.\n\n\"It wasn't a matter of knowing,\" he said. \"It was a matter of feeling.\"\n\nThey felt good all day, which was a welcome change from a qualifying round that went so poorly that de facto team captain Brody Malone apologized to his teammates afterward. The Americans finished Saturday's qualifiers ranked fifth and seemed to be a world away from top contenders Japan, who would win gold, and China who would take silver. They made only three individual finals: Frederick Richard and Juda in the all-around, and Nedoroscik in the pommel horse. But they reminded themselves that Monday's final \"was the day that mattered,\" Hong said. \"We got 18 routines to hit, and that's our goal.\"\n\nThe same four gymnasts-Hong, Juda, Malone and Richard-hit the first 17. Then came Nedoroscik.\n\nBy literal luck of the draw, the Americans would begin on the still rings, which meant they would end on the pommel horse, historically their most challenging event. Its mix of balance and movement has bedeviled generations of gymnasts. But not Nedoroscik, who loves it so much he decided in high school to specialize in it. And he has been so successful-in 2021 he became the first American to win gold in the event at the world championships-that the U.S. coaches decided their team should be four all-arounders and one man who can do only one thing.\n\nIt was a risky decision. But this U.S. team does not just tolerate risk. It embraces it. After a decade of frustrating results, the coaches decided heading into Paris to reshape the program, implementing a program that incentivizes athletes to attempt more difficult skills.\n\n\"We took a lot of hits on that, because not a lot of people believed in it,\" said Syque Caesar, the coach who devised the system. \"I even was critical of it, and I helped put it together. But I think tonight proved that it can work.\"\n\nGymnastics scores comprise two elements: an execution score, which starts at 10 and decreases with mistakes, and a difficulty-score, which is open-ended. The Americans had been prioritizing consistency, which led athletes to choose easier routines that they were sure they could stick. This made for clean meets but meant that realistically they never had a shot at the podium, not when their opponents began with such higher potential values. So in 2022, the coaching staff instituted a bonus system that awarded gymnasts extra tenths of a point-sometimes even more than a point-in domestic competitions for attempting difficult skills.\n\nIt was a controversial change. Many athletes balked at first. Even high performance director Brett McClure-the official responsible for implementing the system-needed the hard sell. \"Very hard,\" he said. \"But if it's what the coaches and athletes want, to have that buffer to make mistakes and still make national teams, still get funding, do all of these things, then I support it, 100%.\"\n\nIt's just math, said Caesar. He likens it to another sport, baseball, that underwent a shift toward analytics two decades ago: \"We Moneyballed the sport,\" he said.\n\nOn Friday, they looked more like the Oakland A's of 2024 than of 2002. But on Monday, they showed up ready to go, charging through the practice area while the other athletes looked on, bemused. Leading off the event, Richard stuck the landing on his rings routine and set off a U-S-A chant in the stands.\n\nThat became a trend as they hit routine after routine. The gymnasts began to feel as if the whole arena was behind them.\n\n\"Instead of trying to prove people wrong,\" Richard says, \"You're proving them right.\"\n\nThe Americans slowly built their advantage, improving their scores from qualifying on each apparatus.\n\n\"Every routine is an opportunity to build momentum,\" Richard had told his teammates.\n\nAs they continued to perform flawlessly, their joy became almost desperate. Hong and Juda may have expended more energy cheering than they did competing. But after Malone-the 2022 high bar world champion who fell twice on the apparatus in qualifying and missed the event final-nailed his high bar routine, they huddled and reminded one another not to get too far ahead of themselves.\n\nMeanwhile, Caesar was doing no such thing. He knew exactly where the team stood and exactly what it had to do. The margin over Great Britain and Ukraine was large enough that the U.S. needed only to avoid mistakes.\n\n\"We started crunching the numbers, and we're like, 'Just stay on the horse,'\" Caesar said.\n\nNedoroscik did one better. He all but floated through his routine, reminding himself only to think about the next skill. And then, suddenly, there was no next skill. His teammates grabbed him and tossed him into the air. They draped themselves in the American flag and laughed and cried. Nedoroscik came to Paris for 38 seconds. The celebration will last much longer.\n\nThis article was originally published on www.si.com as Risky Strategy, Fearless Execution Brings U.S. Men's Gymnastics Back to the Podium.", "source": {"uri": "bnd.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Belleville News-Democrat"}, "authors": [{"uri": "stephanie_apstein@bnd.com", "name": "Stephanie Apstein", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": {"uri": "news/Sports", "label": "news/Sports", "wgt": 97}], "image": "https://www.mcclatchy-wires.com/incoming/xsu98q/picture290555219/alternates/LANDSCAPE_1140/96b3b47d-6cf6-469c-8ebe-da374b7d1dc4", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9768598", "eventUri": "eng-9768598", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.1529411764705881, "wgt": 151, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8250763222", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "13:47:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T13:47:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T13:46:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://mcdowellnews.com/sports/other/olympics/pommel-horse-specialist-stephen-nedoroscik-waited-his-whole-life-for-one-routine/article_a6782cae-d193-54ba-a7d2-dad080367457.html", "title": "Pommel horse specialist Stephen Nedoroscik waited his whole life for one routine", "body": "PARIS -- Sam Mikulak pulled Stephen Nedoroscik close and tasked the American pommel horse specialist with the impossible.\n\nThe U.S. men's gymnastics team's first Olympic medal in 16 years a solitary routine away, Mikulak told the pommel horse specialist that he didn't need to go all out. That 80% would be good enough, even though Mikulak knew full well that Nedoroscik never does anything -- from his sport to solving a Rubik's Cube -- at 80%.\n\n\"You have to trick yourself,\" said Mikulak, a three-time Olympian turned coach. \"You've got to make sure you don't let all the noise get into your head.\"\n\nPeople are also reading... Roses Discount Store in Marion set to close in August McDowell calendar: Trump Road Rally goes from Morganton to Marion, and more events Two Marion women charged with drug crimes Young child found wandering on road in Morganton alone; mother charged Sheriff: Marion man intentionally hit pedestrian with car McDowell girls basketball coach Zack McCartha to coach in 2025 East-West All-Star game Hickory law firm partner disbarred for taking $55,000 for personal use McDowell native wants to create Marion walk of fame Play by McDowell 14-year-old centers on Marion water treatment Family of missing Burke woman pleads for her return; $1K reward offered Drag queens help open Olympics but 'Last Supper' tableau draws criticism Three polling places changing in McDowell County Catawba County mother charged in death of 9-month-old appears in court McDowell Titans wrapping up summer camp as 2024 football season nears Thousands came to Marion for summer events\n\nThat usually isn't a problem for the 25-year-old from Worcester, Massachusetts. It takes a certain type of single-mindedness to make the choices Nedoroscik has made for the last decade, when he essentially decided to dedicate himself to a single pursuit, focusing on an event that has long been a weakness for the U.S. men's national team program.\n\nYes, there is monotony involved. How could there not be?\n\n\"I don't know how I don't lose my mind,\" Nedoroscik said before the Games. \"But every day I go into the gym and there's still something to do. There's still something to improve.\"\n\nNot anymore.\n\nProving a point\n\nHe drilled his set during qualifying on Saturday to earn a spot on the event finals later in the Games. But Monday night, things were different. Teammates Frederick Richard, Brody Malone, Paul Juda and Asher Hong had put together 17 straight routines without a miss, putting the Americans in position to reach the medal stand for the first time since 2008 in Beijing.\n\nWhile Nedoroscik had some wiggle room -- the U.S. had a fairly healthy lead after Juda and Malone hit their sets before Nedoroscik saluted the judges -- he also didn't want to merely hold on. He wanted to prove a point.\n\nNot just to himself, but to those who wondered if he deserved to be there in the first place.\n\nWhat followed were 45 seconds of sublime brilliance, with Nedoroscik's hands traveling from one end of the horse to the other, his legs swooping this way, then that.\n\nA few feet away, his four teammates -- and the sizable contingent of US fans inside Bercy Arena -- roared as a medal that seemed distant for a program that had finished a distant fifth in each of its last three trips under the rings -- drew closer.\n\nBy the time Nedoroscik neared his dismount, he knew his job was complete. The celebration began before his feet even hit the mat.\n\nAll those years, all those reps, both physical and mental, all the difficult times when he wondered whether to keep going, all the quirks he's developed along the way -- from the non-prescription goggles he sometimes rocks to the chef's kiss to the camera he occasionally makes -- led up to that moment.\n\nAnd he did not miss, delivering \"the exclamation point\" with a 14.866 to finish off a performance the U.S. men's program hopes provides serious momentum heading into the 2028 Games in Los Angeles.\n\n\"I kind of in that moment was like, 'All right, let's run it back and let's go out there and do our thing,'\" Nedoroscik said.\n\nFilling a critical gap\n\nA \"thing\" that has long been a sore spot for the U.S. in major international competition. The 2012 Olympic team topped qualifying. Then they led off on pommel horse in the finals and saw their medal hopes vanish one mistake at a time.\n\nNedoroscik understood the history. It's one of the reasons he gravitated toward pommels. Another is the fact that it requires many things -- stamina, strength and creativity chief among them -- that he has in spades, particularly that last one.\n\nHe describes himself as a \"late bloomer\" on the event. Those early struggles only helped him press forward.\n\n\"Running into trouble on the apparatus early on taught me how to fight, how to stay on, how to really go for that routine,\" he said. \"And I think that that has stuck with me throughout.\"\n\nUnlike other events, which are painstakingly laid out and practiced on end for months if not years, pommel horse allows gymnasts to color outside the lines and make things up as they go on. Miss an element here? Well, maybe you can make it up trying something else later in the routine.\n\nHe says the end result is the feeling of \"flying through the air,\" though it's more akin to levitation.\n\nMore work to be done\n\nNedoroscik will soar into the event finals Saturday with a chance to put another medal in his carry-on before he heads home. His 15.200 qualifying score tied Ireland's Rhys McClenaghan for the tops among the eight finalists.\n\nHe is ready to ride the wave as far as it will take him. Yet whatever happens on Saturday or for the rest of his life for that matter, it will be difficult to top Monday night, when the guy with the curly hair and the glasses that made him the kind of social media sensation only the Olympics provides struck a blow for his sport, his teammates and himself.\n\n\"I'm really proud of these guys,\" he said while sitting alongside the group that became U.S. men's gymnastics royalty. \"I love you boys.\"\n\nOlympic Games Paris 2024: Scenes from the opening ceremony\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@mcdowellnews.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sam_Mikulak", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Sam Mikulak"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pommel_horse", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Pommel horse"}}, {"uri": {"uri": "8251189957", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "18:54:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T18:54:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T18:53:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/clly5d02d3ro", "title": "Who is Stephen Nedoroscik, the pommel horse guy?", "body": "With one 40 second routine, Mr Nedoroscik helped secure the team a bronze medal - its first since 2008 - and became an overnight internet sensation.\n\nMr Nedoroscik had the final routine in the last rotation of the Olympic final.\n\nHis less than one minute on the apparatus was the only thing standing between the US team and a medal.\n\nAs he hopped off after scoring 14.866, his fist shot straight into the air and the crowd erupted. He did what he had come to Paris to do.\n\nThe internet also took notice of the gymnast from the state of Massachusetts.\n\nSoon, he was being referred to as Mr Pommel Horse. His girlfriend changed her profile on X, formerly Twitter, to \"Ms Pommel Horse\".\n\nFans also discovered one of his hobbies: solving Rubik's cubes. He finished one in less than 10 seconds the day of the competition.\n\nIn a interview on Tuesday, Mr Nedoroscik told NBC's The Today Show that solving the puzzle is \"stress relief\".\n\n\"I love to solve it - it's just fun,\" he said.\n\nSocial media users compared him to Clark Kent, Superman's alter-ego who wears glasses.\n\nMr Nedoroscik, waiting for his routine, sat on the sidelines in glasses, before taking them off to compete.\n\n\"Obsessed with this guy on the US men's gymnastics team,\" one user wrote in a viral post.\n\n\"He just sits there until he's activated like a sleeper agent, whips off his glasses like Clark Kent and does a pommel horse routine that helps deliver the team its first medal in 16 years.\"\n\nNBC's Olympics X account called him \"the Clark Kent of pommel horse\".\n\nMr Nedoroscik has strabismus, or crossed eyes, which can cause double vision.\n\nIn a 2022 post on TikTok, he showed his followers how his condition allows him to alternate which eye is the dominant eye.\n\nHe told The Today Show he thought the memes about him are \"awesome\" and represent \"the people that wear glasses well\".\n\nHe was asked how he was able to carry out Monday's routine without his glasses, though he has competed in prescription goggles in the past.\n\n\"It's not necessarily clear,\" he said of his vision.\n\n\"But the thing about pommel horse is if I keep [the glasses] on, they're going to fly somewhere.\".\n\nIn the end, he said, it's \"all about feeling the equipment\".\n\n\"I don't even really see when I'm doing my gymnastics. It's all in the hands. I can feel everything.\"\n\nMr Nedoroscik will compete again in the individual event, the men's pommel horse final, on 3 August.", "source": {"uri": "bbc.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "BBC"}, {"uri": "2024-07-438680391", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "18:49:04", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T18:49:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T18:19:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.upworthy.com/team-usa-nerdy-pommel-horse-guy-success-holds-a-key-life-lesson-to-share-with-our-kids", "title": "'Nerdy pommel horse guy' success story holds a key life lesson to share with our kids", "body": "Stephen Nedoroscik clinched the bronze medal for Team USA at the Paris 2024 Olympics.\n\nOnce in a while, an unlikely American hero emerges from an Olympic games, and that hero at the 2024 Paris Olympics might just be Team USA's glasses-wearing pommel horse specialist, Stephen Nedoroscik.\n\nThe 25-year-old gymnast from Worcester, Massachusetts, helped break Team USA's 16-year Olympic medal drought, clinching the bronze and launching him to viral fame with his epic team final performance.\n\nIt's not just that he delivered when it counted most; it's the unexpectedness of his story. Nedoroscik showed up to the Olympics looking less like an elite gymnast and more like a guy getting a PhD in astrophysics. He had one job, and he cheered for his teammates while waiting for his big moment. And then, in true hero fashion, he took of his thick, wide-rimmed glasses and performed superhuman feats on the pommel horse.\n\nBut that's not all. As writer Whitney Fleming pointed out, there's an important life lesson buried in Nedoroscik's story that shouldn't get lost in the celebration.\n\n\"Sometimes, the world needs a Simone Biles to blow us away with raw talent, and sometimes, we need someone like Stephen Nedoroscik to remind us that a nerdy (his words), bespectacled engineer who can solve a Rubik's Cube in under 10 seconds can be a hero,\" Fleming wrote on Facebook before sharing why she loves his story.\n\n\"When he didn't progress in gymnastics like he wanted to, he threw himself into the one event he excelled at: the pommel horse. He's won all sorts of competitions as an event specialist, and literally was put on the team because he scores so big on this one apparatus.\n\nDuring today's team finals, he spent the day bringing his teammates water, giving high fives, and cheering on every performance with incredible enthusiasm. And then it was his turn.\n\nNedoroscik was the last athlete to compete on the team's last rotation. He needed to hit his routine for the Americans to end a 16-year medal drought. No pressure.\n\nIt was a build-up right out of an iconic sports movie (Do you believe in miracles?)\n\nWhile the pressure kept building in the gym, he meditated. A slight smile crept onto his face when he heard the cheers for his teammate's score. And then, like Clark Kent turning into Superman, he took off his jacket, removed his glasses, and puffed out his chest--and HE KILLED IT!\"\n\nFleming shared the lesson we can all take from Nedoroscik's unusual success story:\n\n\"Nedoroscik took an untraditional path to get to the pinnacle of his sport and it paid off with an Olympic Bronze medal.\n\nThere is no one way to success, there is no one way to do this life, and there is no one way to find your purpose.\n\nBe unapologetically and unabashedly you in every way possible, and you might end up the hero of your story as well.\"\n\nThat's such an important lesson to share with our kids, who may look at big name athletes and start believing there are limited ways to find success. The reality is every story is unique, every person has their own way of doing things, and there's no \"right\" path to achieve your goals, whatever they may be.\n\nThank you, Stephen Nedoroscik, for being a delightful example and the hero we didn't know we needed.\n\nYou can follow Whitney Fleming on Facebook and Instagram, and find her upcoming book, \"You're Not a Failure: My Teen Doesn't Like Me Either,\" here.\n\n(And in case you missed Stephen Nedoroscik's team final pommel horse routine, here you go.)", "source": {"uri": "upworthy.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Upworthy"}, {"uri": "8249546931", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "20:49:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T20:49:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T20:48:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.ctpublic.org/2024-07-29/pair-of-massachusetts-olympians-lead-u-s-mens-gymnastics-team-to-a-bronze-medal", "title": "Pair of Massachusetts Olympians lead U.S. men's gymnastics team to a bronze medal", "body": "Monday at the Summer Olympics in Paris, the United States won the bronze medal in the men's gymnastics team competition. That's largely due to the performances of two athletes from Massachusetts.\n\nThis is the first time since 2008 the men's team won a medal. Stoughton's Frederick Richard was a standout for the U.S. He earned the squad's top scores in the floor exercise (14.466), parallel bars (14.566) and the horizontal bar (14.833).\n\nWith the competition winding down, the hopes for a medal for the U.S. all came down to Worcester's Stephen Nedoroscik. Prior to the Olympics, he told NEPM, \"I never like to say that we're definitely going to medal. But I'll tell you what -- we have a very good chance of medaling.\"\n\nAnd he turned out to be right.\n\nNedoroscik turned in a clutch performance, scoring 14.866 -- which was tied for the second-best score registered by any athlete Monday in Paris in the pommel horse.\n\nNedoroscik is a former world champion in the event, but he missed out on making the U.S. team for the previous Olympics in Tokyo three years ago. He said before the games he tried to learn from that disappointment.\n\n\"I'm just so honored and proud to be representing Team USA. It is a dream come true, but I feel like these last three years have taught me so much about staying with the sport, staying motivated, and, you know, it's all worth it in the end,\" Nedoroscik said.\n\nIt is also the first Olympic appearance for Stoughton's Frederick, who has immerged as something of the face of the U.S. men's Olympic contingent.\n\nBy about a half point, Japan ended up winning the gold medal Monday, edging China, which picked up the silver.\n\nThere are still more opportunities for the U.S. men to earn medals in gymnastics. The all-around competition and the individual finals for each discipline are still to come over the next week.", "source": {"uri": "ctpublic.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "Connecticut Public"}, {"uri": "8249779966", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "01:40:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T01:40:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T01:39:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://time.com/7005192/stephen-nedoroscik-usa-gymnastics-pommel-horse-guy-olympics-memes-medalist/", "title": "Stephen Nedoroscik Is an Internet -- and Gymnastics -- Hero", "body": "The name doesn't exactly roll off the tongue -- Stephen Nedoroscik -- but you can just call him The Pommel Horse guy.\n\nThat's what social media is dubbing their newly minted star.\n\nIt's Nedoroscik's specialty in gymnastics, and the sole reason he was put on the U.S. men's team. The Massachusetts native now trains in Florida, and is a four-time U.S., two-time NCAA, and 2021 world champion on the event.\n\nPommel horse? What's that? That's the event in which gymnasts mount -- yes, mount -- what's called a horse that is 160-cm. long and 135-cm. wide with two handles on top. You grab the handles and swing your legs around in creative ways -- around, above, and next to the horse. You can even move from one end of the horse to the other -- a move that Nedoroscik does especially well.\n\nNedoroscik was put on the five-member U.S. Olympic team because he's so good on that event. His selection came as a surprise to many gymnastics fans, who questioned the sanity of USA Gymnastics in banking on a specialist who only competes on one of the six events in men's gymnastics. What if he makes a mistake? What if other gymnasts on the team get injured and you run out of alternates to replace them? A specialist, in the gymnastics world, is therefore a very risky thing to be.\n\nBut all the chatter didn't seem to bother the bespectacled Nedoroscik, who, as luck would have it, was scheduled to compete in the last of six rotations, and last in the lineup. That meant he waited for 2.5 hours before it was his turn to mount that pommel.\n\nWhat Nedoroscik did to while away the time is now stuff of internet legend. Snaps of him with his head back, eyes closed, and seemingly dozing have become a meme. But Nedoroscik was just in full preparation mode.\n\n\"I did my breathing exercises, and I could hear all the guys cheering for [teammates] Brody [Malone] and Paul [Juda], and I thought, 'Sounds like everything is going well,'\" he said. \"I knew at that moment that every guy hit every single routine. And I have this thing, if everybody hits [their routines] before me, then I never miss. So I thought 'let's go out there and do our thing.'\"\n\nAnd do his thing he did, swinging, and swinging, and swinging some more to put, as he called it, \"an exclamation point\" on the competition.\n\nIt will surprise absolutely no one that Nedoroscik, an electrical engineering graduate from Penn State, is highly superstitious. He used to wear goggles that were part of a competition superstition after a friend gifted them and he wore them as a prank -- but successfully completed a hard routine. He steers clear of songs that he's listened to before having a bad routine -- \"Thunder\" and \"Riptide\" are big ones (sorry, Imagine Dragons and Vance Joy). Since the 2021 world championships, however, he's been trying to rid himself of those rituals by indulging in them to \"break the curses.\"\n\nIronically, when it comes to his career, Nedoroscik has been more laissez-faire. He concentrated on pommel horse after 2014, when a coach who had trained the national pommel horse champion the previous year came to his club gym in Worcester and told him he could also be a national champion one day.\n\n\"I figured, this guy has seen a national champion so he must see something in me,\" Nedoroscik said. \"That year I won my first ever junior national title. I had no idea how gymnastics worked and didn't even know that college was a thing for gymnasts. So I started talking to coaches and ended up at Penn State. I didn't know how to get on the national team, but won the Winter Cup one year and then made the national team. I thought, 'dude [being a specialist] is awesome'!\"\n\nIt's taken him from recreational gymnast to national and world champion to, now, an Olympic medalist. {"uri": "8250869480", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "14:55:08", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T14:55:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T14:54:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://92moose.fm/ixp/696/p/frederick-richard-stephen-nedoroscik-new-england-bronze-medal-olympics/", "title": "Frederick Richard, Stephen Nedoroscik Become First New Englanders to Medal for Team USA in 2024 Olympics", "body": "As of the end of Monday, July 29, Team USA continued to lead the pack in most medals earned for the 2024 Paris Olympics at 20.\n\nAnd capping off the day was the men's gymnastic team scoring a bronze medal, their first in over 16 years, according to Time Magazine. U-S-A! U-S-A!\n\nBut what makes that historic moment even more amazing is the fact that two of the members marked the first earned medals for New Englanders in the 2024 Paris Olympics: Stephen Nedoroscik of Worcester, Massachusetts, and Frederick Richard of Stoughton, Massachusetts.\n\nTheir win with their teammates Paul Juda, Brody Malone and Asher Hong is a testament to their dedication, perseverance, and exceptional skill.\n\nNo surprise that USA Gymnastics would give them a shout out on X either.\n\nAnd did you know that, according to NBC, Nedoroscik \"qualified for the Olympic team solely on the strength of his pommel horse routine\"?\n\nYou can watch his incredible routine that helped win the bronze medal here.\n\nThe 25-year-old Massachusetts native said after his routine, according to PEOPLE, \"It was just the greatest moment of my life, I think. [I'm] so happy to have been there.\"\n\nAnd Nedoroscik certainly has become a fan favorite and the face of a bunch of memes comparing him to Clark Kent thanks to his glasses. If you've been following the games, you've probably seen some of them.\n\nThe other Massachusetts native making a name for himself, 20-year-old Richard, according to USA TODAY, \"delivered team-best performances in the floor, parallel bars and horizontal bar,\" which helped the USA to its bronze win.\n\nAdditionally, Boston.com stated that he is the youngest male American gymnast to win an individual all-around medal at the 2023 World Artistic Gymnastics Championship.\n\nHow amazing is that?\n\nTheir hard work paid off on the world's biggest stage, likely inspiring future generations of athletes from New England and beyond, but it's only the beginning.\n\n\"We're told all our lives the American dream, you have a dream and you give everything every day towards it and eventually it comes true,\" Richard said, according to USA Today. \"And we all are always waiting to see if that's really true, but I'm standing here with a medal around my neck after going to the gym every day, hours and hours and giving everything. It's like the universe paid you back, so I'm living the American dream. That's what it feels like.\"\n\nBut don't worry, those two aren't done for the games quite yet. Nedoroscik will be in the individual pommel horse finals on Saturday, August 3, and Richard will be in the all-around final on Wednesday, July 31.\n\nCongrats to Frederick Richard and Stephen Nedoroscik for making history and bringing Olympic glory to New England! {"uri": "8246434464", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-27", "time": "16:47:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-27T16:47:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-27T16:46:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/world/international/2805481/", "title": "Richard and Judah edge Malone; Britain edges US in first subdivision - ExBulletin", "body": "One of the biggest talking points after the U.S. men's gymnastics team arrives in Paris is whether or not the team can bring home an Olympic medal, something they haven't done since winning bronze in 2008. Japan and China are the heavy favorites to battle for gold, but there are a handful of teams that can challenge for a spot on the medal podium alongside them.\n\nThe United States and Great Britain are among these teams.\n\nAfter the first subdivision of the qualifying round, Great Britain (256.561) was ahead of the United States (253.229), with Canada finishing third (247.794) and Germany finishing fourth (245.395).\n\nGreat Britain's Jake Jarman leads the all-around (84.897), but the story of the day may be 2023 world all-around bronze medalist Frederick Richard and 2022 NCAA all-around champion Paul Juda (82.865), who advanced to the all-around final and knocked off three-time national all-around champion Brody Malone.\n\nMalone fell on the pommel horse in the first rotation and had two falls on the high bar, ending his chances before the competition even ended. As a result, Malone will also miss the high bar final, an event on which he is the world champion as of 2022.\n\nConsidering Malone's performance in training, high performance director Brett McClure said his performance today had come as a surprise.\n\n\"He didn't have a good day,\" McClure said. \"I hope he can recover and refocus for the team final.\"\n\nHeading into the competition, Malone and Richard were favored to qualify as the top all-around gymnasts. However, Judah was undeniable today, displaying confidence and precision on every event to advance to his first all-around grand final in his Olympic debut.\n\nJudah performed well under pressure and was the United States' best player for most of the competition.\n\n\"A few months ago or maybe even a few years ago, I don't think I would have been able to do this,\" Judah said after the competition. \"I've worked really hard on the sports psychology side of things, my mental health, my athletic performance, etc. and it was those rehearsals that really allowed me to do what I did today. Over the last couple of weeks, I felt like I could be first on a few events and probably on pommel horse. As most gymnasts know, it's one of the toughest events to compete in, but I knew if I was put first, I would earn it myself... and I was ready for it.\"\n\nGreat Britain took the lead over the United States early on with a 44.299 on vault, thanks to two huge vaults from Harry Hepworth and Jarman, the 2023 world vault champion. Both gymnasts landed two vaults, hoping to secure a spot in the apparatus final. Hepworth posted the highest average on vault with a 14.766, but Jarman wasn't too far behind with a 14.699.\n\nMeanwhile, the United States got off to a good start (42.433) on pommel horse, an event that has historically been one of the team's weakest.\n\nJudah opened the competition by performing clean circles and giving the U.S. team the lead. The routine was so good that Judah couldn't help but let out a victory cry after nailing his dismount, enjoying every moment of his first routine on the Olympic stage. Richard followed with a solid routine, but the U.S. ran into trouble in third place when Malone fell midway through his pommel horse routine, scoring just 12.100.\n\nAfter a long wait to hear Malones' score, 2021 pommel horse world champion Stephen Nedoroscik rounded out the rotation with a superb routine, doing exactly what he came to Paris to do. Nedoroscik hasn't always performed at his highest level of difficulty in competition this year, but delivered a 6.4 difficulty routine to set the benchmark for qualifying for the event with a massive {"uri": "8249859637", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "03:20:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T03:20:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T03:19:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://www.wdef.com/trions-brody-malone-wins-bronze-medal-with-u-s-gymnastics-team/", "title": "Trion's Brody Malone Wins Bronze Medal With U.S. Gymnastics Team - WDEF", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- Before they stood with their arms wrapped around each other in a brotherhood forever etched into U.S. Olympic lore, Brody Malone, Frederick Richard, Asher Hong, Paul Juda and Stephen Nedoroscik were collegians.\n\nYes, the dreams the members of the U.S. men's gymnastics team had fostered since childhood began in small gyms scattered across the country. But they became tangible at Stanford, Michigan and Penn State.\n\nSo when it was time for those dreams to become fully, vividly realized inside a raucous Bercy Arena on Monday night, they leaned on the experiences they gained during all those meets in all those sometimes sparsely filled gyms that taught them about pressure and teamwork and belief.\n\nYes, the bronze medal the Americans so emphatically earned ended a 16-year drought on the sport's biggest stage.\n\nYet it was also a message to athletic directors at the dozen schools that still have Division I gymnastics -- and to be honest, to the ones that don't, too -- that the sport is worth saving.\n\n\"If you want to keep seeing USA Gymnastics and Team USA on a gymnastics podium, at least on the men's side, you're going to have to give us more opportunities to compete in college,\" said Juda, who is in graduate school at Michigan.\n\n\"My goal even here was to make a statement that the U.S. is getting stronger and stronger and we're only (going up),\" Richard said. \"And I think we did that today. I think a lot of young boys watching are inspired by us.\"\n\nThat's the way it was for Richard as a kid in the Boston suburbs. There were pictures on the wall at the gym of the medal-winning 2004 and 2008 U.S. men's Olympic teams. Richard would stare at the pictures and wonder how those teams put all the pieces together.\n\n\"It looks like they all came together on the same day and just did like these perfect routines,\" Richard said. \"And you're like, how is that possible?\"\n\nRichard found out firsthand.\n\nThe Americans didn't record a major fall during any of their 18 routines in the final and finished closer to second-place China than fourth-place Britain. They leaned into the energy from a vocal contingent of U.S. fans that offered a hint of what it might look like in Los Angeles four years from now.\n\nMostly, however, they leaned on each other and their experiences to shake off an iffy qualifying session on Saturday in which they finished a sloppy fifth.\n\n\"We just told each other we were gonna treat it like an NCAA championships because we've all been there,\" Malone said. \"And it's high pressure competing for a team. And it's no different this competition. I mean yeah, this one's a little bit different, a little bit bigger. But same concept.\"\n\nWith perhaps a much more impactful result.\n\nNedoroscik is 26. Malone is 24. Juda is 23. Hong and Richard are 20. There is a feeling of real momentum within the U.S. men's program for the first time in a while. Yet to keep it going, the pipeline behind them needs to keep churning.\n\nThere was a sense in the 2010s that the U.S. had grown stale in part because those at the core group at the top grew a little too comfortable due in part to a lack of competition from those trying to catch them.\n\nSam Mikulak went to three Olympics with teams that had considerable talent. He never came home with a medal, though on Monday night he was chatting with Nedoroscik as he prepared for his pommel horse set that served as the exclamation point.\n\nWhile they talked, Mikulak told Nedoroscik to stay calm, that 80 percent of his best would be good enough. To soak in a moment Mikulak dreamed of but never quite grasped.\n\nAnd when Nedoroscik gracefully swooped from one end of the horse to the other, his hands working dutifully in tandem on an event that has given the Americans fits for years, the bronze that felt in some ways like gold was won.\n\nStanding there in the aftermath, Mikulak couldn't help but speculate about what might lie ahead.\n\n\"I think the guys are going to be hungry for more,\" he said. \"And hopefully this spurs men's gymnastics in the US like never before.\"", "source": {"uri": "wdef.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "News {"uri": "8249740101", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "00:47:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T00:47:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T00:46:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.today.com/popculture/stephen-nedoroscik-gymnastics-meme-paris-olympics-2024-rcna164161", "title": "US gymnast Stephen Nedoroscik getting in the zone is a whole vibe in viral meme", "body": "The 25-year-old with glasses and a love for Rubik's cubes is being called the Clark Kent of gymnastics by users online.\n\nStephen Nedoroscik is the internet's new meme for \"Beast mode activated.\"\n\nOn X, Instagram and TikTok, users can't get enough of the glasses-wearing, Rubik's cube-solving athlete who has become the hometown hero of the U.S. men's gymnastics team. Across the platforms, users have circulated an image of the 25-year-old American gymnast looking calm, cool and in mediation just before he helped score the bronze medal for the U.S. at the July 29 final.\n\n\"Clark Kent while sitting on the sidelines -- Superman on the pommel horse,\" one user commented on a viral photo of the athlete resting up and seated on the sidelines. He could be seen wearing glasses with his eyes shut, appearing to be calm.\n\n\"Nerves of steel!\" another chimed in.\n\n\"Stephen Nedoroscik had to score big on pommel horse for Team USA in the last rotation,\" @NBCOlympics wrote in a July 28 post on TikTok. \"AND HE DID.\"\n\nThe Nedoroscik mania comes as he dismounted from his July 29 pommel horse routine with a score of 14.866, according to NBC Sports.\n\nOn July 29, Nedoroscik sat on the sideline for almost three hours as his teammates performed routines for the first five events of the competition before his bottom-of-the-ninth moment. According to NBC News, Nedoroscik's place on the team has been considered \"somewhat controversial\" because, unlike most high-level gymnasts who compete in multiple events, he performed just one.\n\nHis only event for the games boosted Team USA's Men's Artistic Team All-Around overall score to 257.793, clinching them the bronze.\n\nAccording to NBC News, the team won its last medal in 2008, toward the tail end of the George W. Bush administration. The team's 16-year dry spell prompted USA Gymnastics to tap him in hopes that he would deliver on his specialty, the pommel horse.\n\nIn the comments section of a post by @NBCOlympics on X about how he was \"getting in the zone,\" users called the viral image of Nedoroscik an \"iconic picture.\"\n\nIn the comments section of a post by @NBCOlympics on X about how he was \"getting in the zone,\" users called the viral image of Nedoroscik an \"iconic picture.\"\n\n\"That's the new Superman,\" a user by the name@Yankees44Giants wrote.\n\n\"I love this nerdy kid from Worcester who's at the Olympics just to do pommel horse and only pommel horse and he is literally Team USA's best chance at Olympic gold for just pommel horse. And today he's literally just hanging out until it's time for pommel horse. LOVE HIM.\" a user by the name @megsokay wrote.\n\n\"To truly understand Stephen Nedoroscik's nerd credentials, you need to know that he is in Paris for the Olympics and posting to his insta story about solving a Rubik's cube in under 10 seconds,\" author John Green said in a post.\n\nIn an interview with NBC News, Nedoroscik gave some insight into what's been going on in his head as he prepares to compete.\n\n\"I didn't know what we needed, but I knew I needed to do a good job,\" Nedoroscik said. \"I was feeling the nerves, but right before I went, these guys told me, 'We trust you. We got your back.' {"uri": "8250293857", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "09:04:08", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T09:04:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T09:02:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/world/international/2807634/", "title": "The U.S. men's gymnastics team ended a long Olympic medal drought. They hope the NCAA will take notice - ExBulletin", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- Before they found themselves together, arms crossed, in a brotherhood forever etched in American Olympic legend, Brody Malone, Frederick Richard, Asher Hong, Paul Juda and Stephen Nedoroscik were middle schoolers.\n\nSure, the childhood dreams the members of the U.S. men's gymnastics team have had began in small gyms scattered across the country. But they've become tangible at Stanford, Michigan and Penn State.\n\nSo when it came time to fully and vividly realize those dreams in a noisy Bercy Arena on Monday night, they drew on the experiences they gained from all those encounters in all those sometimes sparsely-filled gyms that taught them about pressure, teamwork and confidence.\n\nYes, the bronze medal won with such brilliance by the Americans put an end to 16 years of drought on the biggest sporting stage.\n\nBut it was also a message to the athletic directors at the dozen schools that still have Division I gymnastics classes, and, to be fair, to those that don't, that the sport is worth saving.\n\nIf you want to continue to see USA Gymnastics and Team USA on the podium in gymnastics, at least on the men's side, you're going to have to give us more opportunities to compete in college, said Juda, who is a graduate student at Michigan.\n\nOpportunities that are likely to disappear quickly due to a changing college sports landscape. It's a reality the five men standing on the podium with their arms around each other are all too aware of.\n\nRichard, a rising junior at Michigan, is on a mission to introduce more people to a side of the sport that, at least in the United States, has long been pursued anonymously.\n\nAnd while he's carved out a growing niche on social media, Richard is savvy enough to understand that the only thing guaranteed to draw people to men's gymnastics isn't a viral video, but hardware like the medal he kept grabbing in the aftermath.\n\nMy goal here was to show that the United States is getting stronger and stronger and we're just going from strength to strength, Richard said. And I think we did that today. I think a lot of young guys that are watching are inspired by us.\n\nThat's how Richard lived as a kid growing up in suburban Boston. On the gym walls were pictures of the 2004 and 2008 U.S. men's Olympic medal-winning teams. Richard would look at the pictures and wonder how those teams put all the pieces together.\n\n\"It seems like they all got together on the same day and did like perfect routines,\" Richard said. And you wonder how that's possible?\n\nRichard discovered it with his own eyes.\n\nThe Americans didn't have a major fall in their 18 routines in the final and finished closer to second-place China than fourth-place Great Britain. They were buoyed by the energy of a contingent of American fans who gave a glimpse of what the competition might look like in Los Angeles four years from now.\n\nBut they relied on each other and their experiences to recover from a difficult qualifying session on Saturday, in which they finished a poor fifth.\n\n\"We figured we'd treat this like an NCAA championship because we've all been there,\" Malone said. \"And it's a lot of pressure to compete for a team. And this competition is no different. I mean, yeah, this one is a little different, a little bigger. But the concept is the same.\"\n\nWith perhaps a much more impactful result.\n\nNedoroscik is 26, Malone is 24, Judah is 23, Hong and Richard are 20. For the first time in a long time, there is a real sense of momentum within the U.S. men's program. But for that to continue, the pipeline that supports them needs to keep churning.\n\nBy the 2010s, there was a sense that the United States had become obsolete, partly because those at the top of the core group had become a little too comfortable, partly because of the lack of competition from those trying to catch up.\n\nSam Mikulak has competed in three Olympics with teams that featured considerable talent. He has never gone home with a medal, though Monday night he was chatting with Nedoroscik as he prepared for his pommel horse that served as an exclamation point.\n\nAs they talked, Mikulak told Nedoroscik to stay calm, that 80 percent of his effort would be enough. To enjoy a moment Mikulak had dreamed of but never quite grasped.\n\nAnd when Nedoroscik gracefully glided from one end of the horse to the other, his hands working dutifully in tandem on an event that has given Americans fits for years, the bronze that somehow felt like gold was won.\n\nStanding there after the events, Mikulak couldn't help but speculate about what might happen.\n\n\"I think the guys are going to want more,\" he said. \"And hopefully it'll boost men's gymnastics in the United States like never before.\"\n\n___\n\nAP Summer Olympics: "dmoz/Sports/Gymnastics/Artistic", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Shopping/Sports/Olympics", "label": "dmoz/Shopping/Sports/Olympics", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Sports", "label": "news/Sports", "wgt": "https://dims.apnews.com/dims4/default/3c359af/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4630x2604+0+241/resize/1440x810!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fassets.apnews.com%2F%5B7%2F%2C%20%2F81%2C%20-101%2C%20-56%2C%20-107%2C%20100%2C%205%2C%20103%2C%2024%2C%2039%2C%20-66%2C%20-127%2C%20108%2C%20-101%2C%2094%2C%20-106%2C%2016%2C%2038%2C%2086%2C%20106%2C%20-78%2C%203%2C%20-51%2C%20-30%2C%20-61%2C%2092%2C%2026%2C%20-101%5D%2Ff9f1982e1f234dcba0c6cce35db21199", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9768598", "eventUri": "eng-9768598", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Paris"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "France"}}}, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.3411764705882352, "wgt": 147, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-07-437676421", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "00:52:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T00:52:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T00:45:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://time.com/7005170/mens-gymnastics-team-usa-bronze-paris-olympics/", "title": "How the U.S. Men's Gymnastics Team Won Their First Olympic Medal in 16 Years", "body": "The U.S. men's gymnastics team had high hopes for the Paris Olympics. After finishing fifth in the team event at the last three Olympic Games, it was time for a change. This time the team had its sights set on a medal -- something they hadn't achieved since the 2008 Olympics in Beijing.\n\nOn July 29, the U.S. men's team of Asher Hong, Paul Juda, Brody Malone, Stephen Nedoroscik, and Frederick Richard got it done and earned bronze behind Japan and China.\n\n\"We ended the medal drought that was 16 years in the making and I couldn't be happier for everybody,\" said Paul Juda, a University of Michigan gymnast.\n\nGetting to the podium wasn't just a matter of hitting every routine. The work began after the Tokyo Games, with some very deliberate strategizing. Under the current scoring system, athletes don't start with the same score, such as a 10.0, but instead have varying start values, depending on the difficulty of the elements they perform in their routines. Those scores are added to a score that encapsulates how well they perform those skills for the total score. So the more difficult the routines are, the more likely gymnasts are to earn higher scores overall.\n\nRead More: 'There's Actually Something Wrong.' Jade Carey Explains Why She Fell During Her Floor Routine\n\nUSA Gymnastics men's high-performance director Brett McClure knew that the U.S.'s difficulty scores, or start values, put them out of medal contention before they even hit the mats. No amount of perfect performances could change that. So he and his team focused heavily on incorporating more challenging skills in the gymnasts' routines.\n\nAt the U.S. Olympic trials in June to determine the team for Paris, McClure rattled off the average difficulty of each of the top teams and calculated what the U.S. would need to make the podium -- namely, outscoring squads such as Great Britain and Ukraine that have consistently surpassed the U.S. at recent world and Olympic events. In Tokyo, McClure said, the U.S. lagged about six points behind the bronze-medal finishers in difficulty scores, but by last year's world championships, that gap had narrowed to about two points -- easily bridged with stronger execution scores. \"Japan's difficulty right now is around 110, and China 108. Our difficulty scores are about 106 and Ukraine is 104 and Great Britain around 102. So we're great considering where we were in Tokyo, when we were already six points behind. We're in a much different position now.\"\n\nIndeed they were. Shaky performances during the qualification round in Paris, however, put the U.S. men back in their familiar position -- fifth -- coming into the team event. But in the team competition, qualification scores are scratched and scoring starts anew.\n\n\"You take it, you seize the moment,\" said Richard, Juda's teammate at Michigan. \"After day one [qualification], I was the one who was saying, 'It's all part of the process, trust in the end goal.' You don't have to win every single competition; you have to win the ones that matter. I knew that the day-one goal was to qualify and get the nerves out. Going into day two, we needed to capitalize on all the hard work we've done and it showed. We didn't wait to become the medalists. We decided we were going to do it. And every routine, we gave everything.\"\n\nThat included Nedoroscik, who was controversially the only specialist on the team, selected for his high scoring ability on pommel horse. He competed only on pommel horse, and none of the other five events, and the competition order put the U.S. on pommel horse in the last of six rotations, with Nedoroscik the last U.S. gymnast to compete, meaning he waited two and a half hours before he was called up. When he was, he electrified the crowd with his impressive and smooth swings and helped the U.S. clinch the bronze. But until then, his meditating and visualization techniques inspired the internet, turning him into a social media sensation as everyone speculated about how he managed to make the trip to Paris to perform on one event and one event only, and how he was occupying himself while waiting his turn.\n\nRead More: All About Jordan Chiles' Beyonce-Inspired Routine\n\nRichard had not only his family from Stoughton, Mass. in Bercy Arena, but his first coach Tom Fontecchio, who saw potential in young Richard when he followed his older sister to Fontecchio's gym in Massachusetts. The two remained close even after Richard left for college, and Fontecchio still watches every one of his former student's meets and regularly texts him with words of encouragement. \"He did a fantastic job,\" Fontecchio told TIME. \"In junior high, he had a goal listed in superlatives, and his superlative was, 'I want to be an Olympian.' He already knew that was going to be his goal and he just kept going with it.\"\n\nThe U.S. got off to a strong start on the rings, with Richard, the current world all-around bronze medalist, breaking the ice with a solid routine that set the stage for Malone, the national champion, and Hong, six-time NCAA champion who, along with Richard, was part of the U.S. bronze-medal-winning team at world championships in 2023.\n\nDuring Olympic trials, McClure's priority was to find the combination of athletes whose scores, when combined, would give the U.S. the highest number of starting value points when the team competed in Paris. \"The plan worked,\" Jordan Gaarenstroom, one of Juda's and Richard's coaches at Michigan, told TIME. \"It worked exactly how it should have worked. It was great to watch it.\"\n\nUnder the Olympic format, three athletes compete on six apparatus and all three scores count (unlike during the qualification, in which four gymnasts compete on each event and the top three scores are used). Richard competed in five of the six events, as did Malone. Malone was more consistent than he was during the qualification round, in which he made mistakes on the high bar, floor, and pommel horse.\n\n\"It's about having a short memory and putting it behind me,\" Malone said. \"Once it's done and over with, it's done and over with. I just had to reset my mind and get ready for the next competition, and that's what I did.\"\n\n\"Every single routine just kept getting better and better,\" McClure said of the 18 solid performances the gymnasts executed. Juda said the team agreed ahead of time not to look at the scoreboard, which kept track of where they stood after each rotation. Whenever the placements were announced in the arena, \"We joked, 'We don't want to know what place we are - stop telling us,'\" he said. \"It wasn't a matter of knowing, but a matter of feeling [that we would earn a medal].\"\n\nPreparing the men included ensuring that they conserved their strength and energy for the multiple days of performance ahead. For Richard, who was expecting to compete in the all-around event, that meant building up gradually, especially in the high-bar event, one of his strengths. His routine in qualification was less difficult than the one he performed in the team competition. \"This is a marathon, from two weeks ago when we got [to France], to training camp and then you come to Paris,\" said Gaarenstroom. \"And every day they are reminded they are Olympians. So it's high and low and high and low -- you've got to keep their energy in check so you just make small changes to give them a little less pressure.\"\n\nBut Richard's score in the qualification round, which determines who competes in the event finals, wasn't high enough to qualify him for the high-bar final, after judges scored his routine lower than he and his coaches expected, so he knew he would get only one shot to do the more challenging routine. \"I knew this would be my high-bar final,\" he said of the team event. \"It's the routine I train every single day in the gym, and I'm one of the best high-bar gymnasts in the world, so I wanted to show that today, to my brothers and to my country, and that's what I did.\"\n\nRichard and Juda will be competing in the all-around competition on July 31. Juda jokes that Richard is always looking ahead and striving for more, saying there is always something \"cooler\" to be experienced, or accomplished. That will certainly be the case in Paris now that the team medal is around their necks. And it's clear where that ambition comes from. When TIME asked Richard's father Carl what he would say to his son, now an Olympic medalist, he said, \"We love you and you're the best. And you have one more achievement [left] here; bring another medal.\" An Olympian's job, it seems, is never done.\n\nThe gymnasts hope that the medal will reignite interest in men's gymnastics in the U.S., at a time when many colleges are shutting down their programs and limiting funding for the sport. \"Every single one of us came from an NCAA program,\" Juda said. \"If you want to keep seeing USA Gymnastics on the podium on the men's side, you have to give us more opportunities to compete in college.\"\n\nMcClure, for his part, is already looking ahead to 2028, when the Olympics will be held in Los Angeles. \"We are trending in the right direction,\" he said. \"Obviously Japan and China are still in another category. But if we want to get better and push for first place in L.A., then this [bronze] is going to be extremely motivating.\"", "source": {"uri": "time.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "TIME"}, "authors": [{"uri": "alice_park@time.com", "name": "Alice Park", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Juda", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Paul Juda"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brett_McClure", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Brett McClure"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pommel_horse", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Pommel horse"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bronze_medal", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label":
