{"uri": "8249662287", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "23:03:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T23:03:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T23:02:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/07/29/sports/olympics-usa-men-gymnastics-bronze/", "title": "US men end finally get back on the podium - The Boston Globe", "body": "What the Worcester native and his four teammates did on Monday night, though, hadn't been achieved by an American squad since the 2008 Olympics.\n\nWhen the chalk dust settled inside Bercy Arena and the final standings went up the US had clinched the bronze medal in the team competition, joining superpowers Japan and China on the podium.\n\n\"We ended the drought 16 years in the making,\" said Paul Juda, the team's table-setter on four of the six events.\n\nThree straight times after their Beijing bronze the US had finished fifth at the Games. And after also placing fifth in Saturday's qualifying competition it appeared that the Yanks would fall short again.\n\nBut with team leader Brody Malone rebounding from a dreadful first night to set the tone his colleagues turned the page and never looked back.\n\n\"Every single routine just kept getting better and better and better,\" said Brett McClure, the men's high performance director. \"This team deserved it and they absolutely earned it tonight.\"\n\nThis was the medal that meant the most to the US males especially since there won't be many more here.\n\nRichard, the world bronze medalist from Stoughton, has a chance in Wednesday's all-around. But Nedoroscik, the bespectacled pommel specialist, is the only one who qualified for an apparatus final.\n\nThe Americans won the team bronze medal at last year's world championships without Malone, who was recovering from a ghastly knee injury.\n\nSo they were positioned to finally cash in, especially with the Russians banned from the Games because of their country's invasion of Ukraine.\n\nAll the Americans needed to do was what historically has been beyond their ability -- to hit all 18 routines with authority. No pratfalls, no stumbles. And the man most under the spotlight was Malone, the only holdover from the Tokyo team from three years ago.\n\nHe'd fallen twice from the horizontal bar and come off the horse in qualifying, missing the all-around. But this was a different day, a different challenge, a different opportunity.\n\n\"It's about having a short memory and putting it behind me,\" Malone said. \"Once it was done and over with, it's done and over with. You can't do anything about it. I just had to reset my mind and get ready for the next competition. and that's what I did.\"\n\nAfter starting off strong on still rings and vault the Americans were first among the eight teams, more than a point ahead of the Japanese.\n\n\"You take it. You seize the moment,\" said Richard. \"We didn't wait to become the medalists. We decided we were going to do it. And every routine we gave everything.\"\n\nStill ahead, though, were the horizontal bar and the horse, two treacherous events where medals can vanish with a slip of the hand. \"Staying on the high bar is always Priority No. 1,\" said Juda.\n\nNot only did his colleagues stay on, they finished second to Japan. When it came down to the horse, the final event, the Yanks had what they knew they had to have -- a nearly two-point cushion over the British, who'd been in their way ever since Beijing.\n\nAnd they had the man they wanted going up last -- Nedoroscik, the former world champion on the apparatus. \"My teammates did every single routine before me,\" he said. \"I've never fallen when everyone did it before me.\"\n\nAfter Nedoroscik went crisp and clean and their podium finish was secure, his teammates hoisted him like a hero and passed around the Stars and Stripes to drape across their shoulders.\n\n\"Tonight we celebrate,\" declared McClure, who was on the 2004 squad that won a breakthrough silver in Athens. \"We did what we haven't done in so long.\"\n\nIt was a bronze that felt like gold after 16 years off the medal stand. \"We're trending in the right direction,\" said McClure. \"Obviously Japan and China are still in another category. If we want to get better and push for first place in LA (in 2028) then this is going to be extremely motivating.\"\n\nWhat the federation hopes is that boys watching at home on TV will decide to chalk up and go after an Olympic medal of their own in a decade or so.\n\nUnlike the American women, who have an unparalleled pipeline from the toddler level upward, the men come out of a diminishing development pool.\n\nIn the late 1960s more than 200 Div. 1 colleges had teams. Now only a dozen do, most of them in the Big 10 and the service academies. Relatively few high schools offer boys squads and the club system overwhelmingly attracts girls.\n\nBut USA Gymnastics produced five guys who envisioned five rings in their future and they mined precious metal here.", "source": {"uri": "bostonglobe.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Boston Globe"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karl_Malone", "type": {"uri": "8246907551", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-28", "time": "03:28:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-28T03:28:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-28T03:23:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/sports-games/3032647-olympic-gymnast-showdown-china-vs-japan", "title": "Olympic Gymnast Showdown: China vs. Japan | Sports-Games", "body": "Longtime gymnastics rivals China and Japan are set for another close finish at the Olympics. China leads qualifying with 263.028 points, followed by Japan with 260.594. Japan's Daiki Hashimoto is aiming to defend his all-around title despite some setbacks. Other teams, including Britain and the U.S., vie for medals.\n\nLongtime men's gymnastics rivals China and Japan appear headed for another tight finish at the Olympics.\n\nThe sport's two superpowers surged to the top of qualifying at Bercy Arena on Saturday. China, seeking its fourth Olympic team title, posted a team total of 263.028. Japan, a seven-time Olympic champion, finished second at 260.594.\n\nThe five-man Chinese team, missing veteran Sun Wei after he was injured during training Thursday, used a series of spectacular routines on rings and parallel bars to stamp itself as the favorite heading into Monday's final.\n\nJapan, the reigning world champion, dealt with a couple of uncharacteristic mistakes by current world and Olympic gold medalist Daiki Hashimoto but still finished well clear of third-place Britain.\n\nWhile the 22-year-old Hashimoto will get a chance to defend his title in the all-around, he won't on high bar -- his signature event -- after stumbling during his dismount. Hashimoto appeared to be dealing with right shoulder discomfort for much of the afternoon and was tended to by a Team Japan trainer shortly after finishing up on still rings though he said afterward he was not hurt. Hashimoto is currently third in the all-around through two subdivisions at 85.064, behind teammate Shinnousuke Oka (86.865) and China's Zhang Boheng (88.597).\n\nThe scores will reset for the team finals, though the only real question is who will join China and Japan on the podium with defending champion Russia ineligible due to the war in Ukraine.\n\nThe Japanese settled for silver at home in Tokyo in 2021, losing to the Russians by just over a tenth of a point in a close final while China took bronze a little further back.\n\n\"It was frustrating,\" Japan's Kazuma Kaya said. ''But we kept practicing every day for success today. Next time, in (the team final), I want the gold medal.\" The gold isn't the only medal in question. Bronze is a toss-up, too, though Britain made a strong case by topping the first subdivision, a group that included the U.S. Ukraine overcame a nightmarish set on high bar to slip past the U.S. and into fourth at 253.893, dropping the Americans into fifth at 253.229.\n\nItaly, Switzerland and Canada also advanced to the finals, with the Canadians claiming the eighth and final spot by less than a quarter of a point over Turkey.\n\nThe British insist they don't have any sort of rivalry with the U.S., even if the two programs have spent the better part of a decade jockeying for position at nearly every major international event.\n\nBritain sent a very real if unspoken message: it is more than capable of grabbing a bronze to go with the one it somewhat unexpectedly won in London a dozen years ago.\n\nJake Jarman's 84.897 all-around total was just ahead of teammate Joe Fraser while Max Whitlock -- in his fourth and final Games -- fought off the jitters he knew would come to score a 15.133 on pommel horse and give Britain plenty of momentum.\n\n''A lot of people have asked me that question in terms of How's it feel to be above the U.S.?''' Whitlock said. \"To be honest, you take it with a pinch of salt. I think it's really important to kind of just think about our job.\" Russia's absence creates a medal opportunity for the U.S., Britain and Ukraine behind another duel between China and Japan for gold. Still, Whitlock downplayed the idea that if Russia was involved, a team medal for anyone outside the sport's Big Three would be out of the question.\n\n\"If they were in, you'd like to think that they'd be up near the top,\" Whitlock said. \"So with them not, of course, there's a little bit of (a better opportunity to medal), but only a little bit.\" The American men -- hoping to repeat the bronze they won at the world championships last fall -- weren't nearly as sharp in front of an audience that included U.S. First Lady Jill Biden, who clapped along with American star Frederick Richard's floor routine and posed for pictures with a somewhat subdued team afterward.\n\nWhile Richard called the experience \"pretty sick,\" he regretted not being able to show Biden a \"cooler\" routine after he scored a 13.833, a bit below what he knows he'll need to medal in the all-around finals next week.\n\nRichard wasn't the only one. The U.S. arrived in Paris hoping to earn a team medal at the Olympics for the first time since a bronze in Beijing 16 years ago. While that certainly remains on the table, Richard & Co. will need to be significantly better going forward after pommel horse specialist Stephen Nedoroscik became the only American to make an apparatus final.\n\nBrody Malone, who returned from a catastrophic leg injury in March 2023 to win the U.S. Championships in early June and make his second Olympic team, fell once on pommel horse and twice on high bar.\n\nHis second miscue on high bar -- a high-risk, high-reward event in which Malone won gold at the 2022 world championships -- forced the Americans to use Asher Hong's 12.600, one of the reasons the U.S. ended up 3.322 behind Britain.\n\n\"It was definitely not perfect,\" U.S. high-performance director Brett McClure said. \"And it was a few too many mistakes. I feel leading into team finals we need to clean some things up.\"", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Devdiscourse"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Longtime men's gymnastics rivals China and Japan appear headed for another tight finish at the Olympics.\n\nParis, Jul 28 (AP) Longtime men's gymnastics rivals China and Japan appear headed for another tight finish at the Olympics.\n\nThe sport's two superpowers surged to the top of qualifying at Bercy Arena on Saturday. China, seeking its fourth Olympic team title, posted a team total of 263.028. Japan, a seven-time Olympic champion, finished second at 260.594.\n\nAlso Read | IND vs SL 2nd T20I 2024, Kandy Weather, Rain Forecast and Pitch Report: Here's How Weather Will Behave for India vs Sri Lanka Match at Pallekele International Cricket Stadium.\n\nThe five-man Chinese team, missing veteran Sun Wei after he was injured during training Thursday, used a series of spectacular routines on rings and parallel bars to stamp itself as the favorite heading into Monday's final.\n\nJapan, the reigning world champion, dealt with a couple of uncharacteristic mistakes by current world and Olympic gold medalist Daiki Hashimoto but still finished well clear of third-place Britain.\n\nAlso Read | Paris Olympics 2024: Canada Women's Football Team Docked Six Points for Spying Scandal; Three Coaches Banned.\n\nWhile the 22-year-old Hashimoto will get a chance to defend his title in the all-around, he won't on high bar -- his signature event -- after stumbling during his dismount. Hashimoto appeared to be dealing with right shoulder discomfort for much of the afternoon and was tended to by a Team Japan trainer shortly after finishing up on still rings though he said afterward he was not hurt.\n\nHashimoto is currently third in the all-around through two subdivisions at 85.064, behind teammate Shinnousuke Oka (86.865) and China's Zhang Boheng (88.597).\n\nThe scores will reset for the team finals, though the only real question is who will join China and Japan on the podium with defending champion Russia ineligible due to the war in Ukraine.\n\nThe Japanese settled for silver at home in Tokyo in 2021, losing to the Russians by just over a tenth of a point in a close final while China took bronze a little further back.\n\n\"It was frustrating,\" Japan's Kazuma Kaya said. \"But we kept practicing every day for success today. Next time, in (the team final), I want the gold medal.\"\n\nThe gold isn't the only medal in question. Bronze is a toss-up, too, though Britain made a strong case by topping the first subdivision, a group that included the U.S. Ukraine overcame a nightmarish set on high bar to slip past the U.S. and into fourth at 253.893, dropping the Americans into fifth at 253.229.\n\nItaly, Switzerland and Canada also advanced to the finals, with the Canadians claiming the eighth and final spot by less than a quarter of a point over Turkey.\n\nThe British insist they don't have any sort of rivalry with the U.S., even if the two programs have spent the better part of a decade jockeying for position at nearly every major international event.\n\nBritain sent a very real if unspoken message: it is more than capable of grabbing a bronze to go with the one it somewhat unexpectedly won in London a dozen years ago.\n\nJake Jarman's 84.897 all-around total was just ahead of teammate Joe Fraser while Max Whitlock -- in his fourth and final Games -- fought off the jitters he knew would come to score a 15.133 on pommel horse and give Britain plenty of momentum.\n\n\"A lot of people have asked me that question in terms of How's it feel to be above the U.S.?'\" Whitlock said. \"To be honest, you take it with a pinch of salt. I think it's really important to kind of just think about our job.\"\n\nRussia's absence creates a medal opportunity for the U.S., Britain and Ukraine behind another duel between China and Japan for gold. Still, Whitlock downplayed the idea that if Russia was involved, a team medal for anyone outside the sport's Big Three would be out of the question.\n\n\"If they were in, you'd like to think that they'd be up near the top,\" Whitlock said. \"So with them not, of course, there's a little bit of (a better opportunity to medal), but only a little bit.\"\n\nThe American men -- hoping to repeat the bronze they won at the world championships last fall -- weren't nearly as sharp in front of an audience that included U.S. First Lady Jill Biden, who clapped along with American star Frederick Richard's floor routine and posed for pictures with a somewhat subdued team afterward.\n\nWhile Richard called the experience \"pretty sick,\" he regretted not being able to show Biden a \"cooler\" routine after he scored a 13.833, a bit below what he knows he'll need to medal in the all-around finals next week.\n\nRichard wasn't the only one. The U.S. arrived in Paris hoping to earn a team medal at the Olympics for the first time since a bronze in Beijing 16 years ago. {"uri": "2024-07-437620861", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "22:45:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T22:45:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T18:31:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/us/articles/2024-07-29/olympics-gymnastics-underdogs-no-more-u-s-men-nab-bronze-in-olympic-resurgence", "title": "Olympics-Gymnastics-Underdogs No More, U.S. Men Nab Bronze in Olympic Resurgence", "body": "PARIS (Reuters) - The U.S. men's gymnastics squad made a huge statement in Paris on Monday as they put together a stunning third-place performance to end their 16-year Olympic medal drought, announcing themselves as a force in the gymnastics world.\n\nThe energy inside Bercy Arena was electric heading into the sixth and final rotation with the Americans battling Ukraine and Britain for the bronze medal, while favourites Japan and China were squaring off for gold.\n\nThe Americans appeared in position to secure bronze but they had to end on the ever-treacherous pommel horse, where Japanese ace Daiki Hashimoto had faltered earlier.\n\nAmericans Paul Juda and Brody Malone hit two strong routines to start, placing the U.S. fate squarely on anchor and pommel horse specialist Stephen Nedoroscik, who had waited the entire evening for his sole performance.\n\nNedoroscik's teammates fiercely hyped him through the whole routine, which he nailed with ease. The whole team erupted into celebration as if they had just won gold despite Japan being the true victors, surging back from fifth place at the halfway point to deliver heartbreak to China.\n\n\"I was like, five feet in the air jumping,\" U.S. gymnast Frederick Richard exclaimed as he described the moment.\n\nThat energy had been building throughout the event as the Americans stuck landing after landing, igniting belief they could stand on the team medals podium for the first time since the 2008 Beijing Games.\n\n\"Every stick builds the momentum,\" Richard said.\n\nThe Americans opened Monday's team final on still rings, a great place to start according to the U.S. men's high performance director.\n\n\"We knew we could go three-for-three easily,\" Brett McClure told reporters, before explaining that Asher Hong's massive vault in the next rotation kicked the guys into gear.\n\n\"Once he put that on his feet I was like, now we're rolling,\" McClure said.\n\nThe Americans then worked through parallel bars, horizontal bar and floor exercise, besting their scores from qualifications on each apparatus.\n\nMalone's horizontal bar effort marked redemption after suffering two uncharacteristic falls during qualifying, but a focused mindset was the key to success on Monday.\n\n\"(The team) made it a very strong point before going into the competition that we were going to make sure to stay in our bubble,\" Malone told reporters.\n\nRichard hopes the Americans' clutch performance in Paris has made an impact on the next generation.\n\n\"I think a lot of young boys watching are inspired by us, and that makes me really happy.\"\n\n(Additional reporting by Gabrielle T\u00e9trault-Farber)", "source": {"uri": "usnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "U.S. News & {"uri": "8246571048", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-27", "time": "19:13:29", "dateTime": "2024-07-27T19:13:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-27T19:12:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.dallasnews.com/sports/other-sports/2024/07/27/planos-asher-hong-helps-keep-gymnastic-medal-hopes-alive-but-us-faces-tough-situation/", "title": "Plano's Asher Hong helps keep gymnastic medal hopes alive, but U.S. men are in tough spot", "body": "PARIS -- On a day when the U.S. men's most decorated gymnast and unquestioned leader flamed out in the all-around, the littlest and least members came up big in qualifying Saturday, preserving their medal hopes a couple more days, anyway.\n\nPlano native Asher Hong, tiny even for a gymnast at 5-1, and Paul Juda, another Olympic newbie, joined Frederick Richard and pommel horse specialist Stephen Nedoroscik in picking up the pieces after Brody Malone flopped on two of the six apparatuses.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nConsolation prize: The U.S. men got an audience afterward with Jill Biden, so they had that going for them.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"That was pretty sick,\" said Richard, who, along with Juda, qualified for Monday's all-around titles. \"I mean, I did not expect today that I would meet the First Lady, but I'm very thankful for the opportunity, and I'm glad they're watching.\"\n\nSports Roundup\n\nGet the latest D-FW sports news, analysis, scores and more.\n\nSIGN UP\n\nOr with:\n\nGoogleFacebook\n\nBy signing up you agree to our Terms of Service and Privacy Policy\n\nBy \"they\" he meant Olympic legends Bart Conner, Brian Boitano and Dawn Staley, now coach of South Carolina's women's basketball team.\n\nRichard -- a crowd favorite who goes by Frederick Flip on TikTok -- said he wished he'd given the celebrities a better show on his floor routine, but otherwise he was happy with his performance.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nMalone? Not so much. Coming off his third national all-around title in Fort Worth last month, he looked more like the gymnast still rehabbing from a horrific knee/leg injury last year that required three surgeries. He misfired once on the pommel horse Saturday and needed three starts on the high bar, his specialty.\n\nPraised by his teammates for his unflappable nature, he nevertheless apologized to them after the U.S. finished second in its subdivision Saturday to Great Britain, 256.561 to 253.229.\n\nHere's why that's problematic: China, with its 13 world championships and bronze from Tokyo, and Japan, defending silver medalist and last year's world champs, are overwhelming favorites for the top two spots in Monday's finals. Third place is probably up for grabs between the U.S. and Great Britain, which took third and fourth, respectively, at last year's worlds.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe U.S. men will need a rebound by Malone to have any shot at their first medal since 2008.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nHong is counting on it.\n\nPhotos: Highs and lows for Team USA in men's gymnastics qualifying at the 2024 Summer Olympics in Paris 22 imagesView Gallery\n\n\"Some days you're gonna be off and some days you're gonna be on,\" said Hong, who grew up in Plano and now lives outside Houston. \"But, I mean, you know, Brody's a dog and a competitor, so I know he's gonna give it his all in the team finals.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\nLike Richards, Juda and Nedoroscik, top scorer of the subdivision in the pommel horse, Hong didn't hold back. His scores led the U.S. in rings (14.633), floor (14.100) and vault (14.566, his average on the two attempts required of contenders for the vault finals). He's third overall in rings, fifth on vault and sixth on floor.\n\nBecause Nedoroscik competes on the pommel horse in Hong's place, the latter is ineligible for the all-around, which requires points from all six events.\n\nHong said he tried to treat the qualifier as if it were any old meet, but it was hard to tell by his results and reactions. During Richard's floor routine, you could hear Hong's screams in the upper regions of Bercy Arena.\n\n\"I wanted to tone it down a little bit because it's not team finals,\" he said. \"And, you know, it's not a marathon, it's a sprint.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"We've got a long week ahead of us.\"\n\nMalone made it a little bit longer Saturday. Brett McClure, the men's high-performance director, said he was \"surprised\" by the two-time Olympian's day. He conceded they must get him right for Monday in order to have a shot at a team medal. Finishing fifth, as they have in the last three Olympics, is getting a little stale. They'd looked ready for something better after finishing third at the World Championships, when McClure called the goal of a medal \"attainable.\"\n\nThey can still win one, but it looks harder from here.\n\n\"We can't hold anything back in the team finals,\" McClure said Saturday. \"Great Britain looks amazing.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\nJust like the future looks for Hong, only 20. His family -- father, Rick; mother, Karen; and brothers Xander, 18, and Kiefer, 16 -- got a close-up view of his Olympic coming-out party Saturday, though Asher couldn't exactly pinpoint where they were. He thought he could hear his mother, which is saying something, given the racket the crowd made for the Americans.\n\nPretty soon the family will take its act on the road, when Xander joins Asher this fall at Stanford. He'll get to see his big brother as BMOC.\n\nNot a little ironic, too, seeing as how both Xander and Kiefer are each at least a head taller. Asked if they give him a hard time about being the shortest of the Brothers Hong, Asher smiled and said, \"Sometimes.\"\n\nHe said it over his shoulder, as a team official whisked him off to a meeting with the First Lady. Not a bad day at all. They'll just need a better one Monday.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nTwitter/X: @KSherringtonDMN\n\nRelated StoriesView MoreRussian media throw shade at Paris Olympics, which TV won't showOlympic medal tracker: {"uri": "8249878589", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "03:42:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T03:42:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T03:41:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/sports/us-mens-gymnastics-team-ends-lengthy-olympic-medal-drought-hopes-ncaa-notices-5696169", "title": "US Men's Gymnastics Team Ends Lengthy Olympic Medal Drought, Hopes NCAA Notices", "body": "PARIS -- Before they stood with their arms wrapped around each other in a brotherhood forever etched into U.S. Olympic lore, Brody Malone, Frederick Richard, Asher Hong, Paul Juda, and Stephen Nedoroscik were collegians.\n\nYes, the dreams the members of the U.S. men's gymnastics team had fostered since childhood began in small gyms scattered across the country. But they became tangible at Stanford, Michigan, and Penn State.\n\nSo, when it was time for those dreams to become fully, vividly realized inside a raucous Bercy Arena on Monday night, they leaned on the experiences they gained during all those meets in all those sometimes sparsely filled gyms that taught them about pressure and teamwork and belief.\n\nYes, the bronze medal the Americans so emphatically earned ended a 16-year drought on the sport's biggest stage.\n\nYet it was also a message to athletic directors at the dozen schools that still have Division I gymnastics -- and to be honest, to the ones that don't, too -- that the sport is worth saving.\n\n\"If you want to keep seeing USA Gymnastics and Team USA on a gymnastics podium, at least on the men's side, you're going to have to give us more opportunities to compete in college,\" said Juda, who is in graduate school at Michigan.\n\nThose opportunities are in danger of vanishing quickly, thanks to a rapidly evolving college sports landscape. It's a reality the five men who stood on the podium with their arms around each other are only too aware of.\n\nRichard, a rising junior at Michigan, has made it his life's mission to bring more people to a side of the sport that -- at least in the U.S. -- has long plugged along anonymously.\n\nAnd while he's carved out a rapidly expanding niche on social media, Richard is savvy enough to understand the one thing guaranteed to attract people to men's gymnastics isn't a viral video, but hardware like the medal he kept grabbing in the giddy aftermath.\n\n\"My goal even here was to make a statement that the U.S. is getting stronger and stronger, and we're only [going up],\" Richard said. \"And I think we did that today. I think a lot of young boys watching are inspired by us.\"\n\nThat's the way it was for Richard as a kid in the Boston suburbs. There were pictures on the wall at the gym of the medal-winning 2004 and 2008 U.S. men's Olympic teams. Richard would stare at the pictures and wonder how those teams put all the pieces together.\n\n\"It looks like they all came together on the same day and just did like these perfect routines,\" Richard said. \"And you're like, how is that possible?\"\n\nRichard found out firsthand.\n\nThe Americans didn't record a major fall during any of their 18 routines in the final and finished closer to second-place China than fourth-place Britain. They leaned into the energy from a vocal contingent of U.S. fans that offered a hint of what it might look like in Los Angeles four years from now.\n\nMostly, however, they leaned on each other and their experiences to shake off an iffy qualifying session on Saturday in which they finished a sloppy fifth.\n\n\"We just told each other we were gonna treat it like an NCAA championships because we've all been there,\" Malone said. \"And it's high pressure competing for a team. And it's no different [in] this competition. I mean, yeah, this one's a little bit different, a little bit bigger. But same concept.\"\n\nWith perhaps a much more impactful result.\n\nNedoroscik is 26. Malone is 24. Juda is 23. Hong and Richard are 20. There is a feeling of real momentum within the U.S. men's program for the first time in a while. Yet to keep it going, the pipeline behind them needs to keep churning.\n\nThere was a sense in the 2010s that the U.S. had grown stale in part because those at the core group at the top grew a little too comfortable, due in part to a lack of competition from those trying to catch them.\n\nSam Mikulak went to three Olympics with teams that had considerable talent. He never came home with a medal, though on Monday night he was chatting with Nedoroscik as he prepared for his pommel-horse set that served as the exclamation point.\n\nWhile they talked, Mikulak told Nedoroscik to stay calm, that 80 percent of his best would be good enough. To soak in a moment Mikulak dreamed of, but never quite grasped.\n\nAnd when Nedoroscik gracefully swooped from one end of the horse to the other, his hands working dutifully in tandem on an event that has given the Americans fits for years, the bronze that felt in some ways like gold was won.\n\nStanding there in the aftermath, Mikulak couldn't help but speculate about what might lie ahead.\n\n\"I think the guys are going to be hungry for more,\" he said. \"And hopefully this spurs men's gymnastics in the U.S. like never before.\"", "source": {"uri": "theepochtimes.com", {"uri": "2024-07-437576709", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "21:24:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T21:24:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T20:33:12Z", "dataType": "title": "US men end Olympic medal drought with team gymnastics bronze", "body": "The United States captured bronze in the men's gymnastics team final at the Paris Games on Monday, ending a 16-year Olympic medal drought thanks to a bounce-back performance from Brody Malone.\n\nMalone, the veteran of a team featuring Paul Juda, Frederick Richard, Asher Hong and Stephen Nedoroscik, endured a horrendous qualifying round, actually apologising to his teammates after they finished fifth.\n\nNewsletters", "source": {"uri": "djournal.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Journal"}, "authors": [{"uri": "agence_france_presse@djournal.com", "name": "Agence France-Presse", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olympic_Games", {"uri": "8249653930", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "22:53:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T22:53:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T22:51:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/athletic/5666950/2024/07/29/stephen-nedoroscik-pommel-horse-gymnastics-olympics-paris-2024/", "title": "Stephen Nedoroscik beat the odds to earn an Olympic moment, and then he nailed it", "body": "PARIS -- Somewhere after his dismount from the pommel horse and the celebration with his teammates, Stephen Nedoroscik did what he always does after competing: He grabbed for his glasses. In the span of one Olympic moment, those specs have become something of an internet sensation. They are not, however, some prop a la Miranda Priestly in \"The Devil Wears Prada,\" tossed on and off for effect; Nedoroscik has a disease that renders his eyes permanently dilated.\n\n\"But I don't need to see when I do pommel horse,\" Nedoroscik said, a bronze medal draped around his neck and a grin spread across his face. \"It's all by feel.\"\n\nNedoroscik felt his way through a two-minute set and into Olympic lore. A pommel horse specialist in Paris to do one thing exceptionally well, he was the last man to compete in Monday's men's gymnastics team final. His team in contention but not yet assured of its first medal of any kind in 16 years, Nedoroscik discarded his glasses, walked up to the horse and started swinging.\n\nThousands of miles and an ocean away, Randy Jepson watched and knew Nedoroscik was going to clinch the medal. Some eight years ago, Nedoroscik sent him the equivalent of a cold call, emailing the Penn State gymnastics coach a video of him from high school. Though a junior Olympic champion, Nedoroscik didn't have a single college offer. His singularity of gymnastics purpose understandably made him less appealing in a sport in which few schools sponsor the sport and there are even fewer scholarships to offer. But Penn State and Jepson long have liked their pommel horse specialists; the school has produced 12 national champions in the event. He was intrigued, but Nedoroscik hadn't been to campus -- or at least Jepson didn't think he had.\n\nThen one day, scrolling through social media, the coach spied a picture on Nedoroscik's feed of some very familiar squirrels hanging around a very familiar spot.\n\n\"It was Penn State squirrels in the Penn State parking garage,\" Jepson said with a laugh. Nedoroscik had come to State College to check out Penn State and its facilities, but never told Jepson he was coming. Eventually, Jepson learned that was part of Nedoroscik's quirky charm.\n\nHe is a delightful analytical nerd, an electrical engineering major who enjoys solving (not attempting, but solving) a Rubik's Cube in his spare time. He gets ticked if it takes under 10 seconds. Yet he's also hilariously goofy, quick to poke fun at himself and the best sort of teammate. Accustomed to waiting around to do his thing, Nedoroscik pours his spare time and all of his energy into cheering on his teammates.\n\nHe did it at Penn State, where he eventually won two national titles, and he does it now, on the senior circuit. As Team USA made its way around the other five rotations in the team final, Nedoroscik could be found in full warmups, cupping his hands over his mouth and barking cheers to his teammates.\n\n\"It's not easy being a specialist,\" Jepson said. \"You have to wait around, and there's a lot of pressure to perform. But Stephen is such a joy to be around. He's an amazing, amazing teammate.\"\n\nHe also is exceptionally good at the one thing he does, though his path here has been bumpy. His last collegiate season was canceled by COVID, and his first shot at an Olympic berth ended disastrously. He fell on the first day of competition at trials, finishing third and failing to make the team. He rebounded after Tokyo to win the 2021 world championship in pommel horse, but 2022 and 2023 was pockmarked with as many lows and highs.\n\nThe analyst in Nedoroscik considered his circumstances, realizing he was more hellbent on winning than simply doing his routine. That wasn't how Jepson taught him to do things.\n\n\"One thing at a time, that's it,\" Jepson said. So Nedoroscik went back to his roots, worrying only about finishing his first Russian flop, an incredibly difficult skill but the first in his routine. From there he went to the second and so forth, solving the pommel horse with the same diligence he took to the Rubik's Cube.\n\nThe result is a man who manages to stay calm in the face of inordinate pressure. What Nedoroscik had to go through during the team final is not nice. The luck of the draw -- bad in this case -- put the U.S. on the rings to start, which means, as you roll around the competition floor in a counterclockwise direction, pommel horse would be last. The lineups are stacked as well. Three athletes compete on each apparatus, and all three scores count. They go worst to best, which means Nedoroscik would be the last man on the last apparatus for the U.S.\n\nThe men's team does not score-watch. When the public address announcers share the standings after each rotation, Frederick Richard and Nedoroscik cover their ears and yell, \"La la la la,\" to block out the information. But the crowd tells you what you don't want to know, and so do the routines. The United States hit one routine after another -- eventually going a perfect 18 for 18 -- and the noise in a very heavily pro-U.S. crowd picked up like a steady crescendo. Chants of \"U-S-A\" filled Bercy Arena, and even if you didn't know what exactly was going on, it was impossible to not know what was actually going on.\n\nBy the time they rolled around to the last rotation, they were poised to medal. But they had to hit the routines to ensure it. Paul Juda nailed his, as did Brody Malone, and then came Nedoroscik. The morning of the competition, he posted a video of a solved Rubik's Cube on his Instagram. Done in 9.321 seconds.\n\n\"Good omen,\" he wrote.\n\nBack in State College, Jepson saw the video and thought the same. Then he sat down in his house, flipped on the TV and watched Nedoroscik begin to swing.\n\n\"He did that first Russian flop, and I said, 'Oh, he's got this,\" Jepson said. \"He absolutely has this.\"\n\nNedoroscik kept swinging, dismounted, and grabbed his glasses. He could see clearly, all the way to the bronze medal that eventually hung around his neck.", "source": {"uri": "nytimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The New York Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-438919788", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "01:48:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T01:48:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T01:47:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://whdh.com/news/olympic-gymnasts-from-massachusetts-boost-team-usa-to-grab-bronze-medal/", "title": "Olympic gymnasts from Massachusetts boost Team USA to grab bronze medal", "body": "STERLING, MASS. (WHDH) - Massachusetts Olympic gymnasts Stephen Nedoroscik and Frederick Richard helped clinch the bronze medal for Team USA Monday, with the moment making its rounds online and across TV channels.\n\nNow, Nedoroscik, 25, of Worcester, and Richard, 20, of Stoughton, will be returning to the state as hometown heroes.\n\nAs soon as Nedoroscik dismounted from the pommel horse -- his specialty -- during the men's gymnastics team final at the Paris 2024 Olympics, his teammates hugged him with great fervor.\n\nSome are calling the Worcester gymnast Clark Kent, because he took off his glasses and became a hero up there on the gym floor.\n\n\"He just fell in love with the pommel horse and kind of just became obsessed,\" said Jon Rydzefski, who trained with him at Sterling Gym, north of Worcester. \"And that was his thing, that's what he only wanted to do, all the time. He'd get pried away to do the other events, because you had to at that age.\"\n\n\"But, his heart, that's what he wanted to go to and all that work paid off,\" Rydzefski continued.\n\nAlso making his mark, Richard competed in the floor exercise, parallel bars, horizontal bar, and still rings events, pushing his team to a solid bronze medal -- the first U.S. men's gymnastics team medal since 2008.\n\nStoughton Public Schools hosted an Olympics watch party Monday night, with Richard's family members, former teachers, and local community members in attendance. On the district's Facebook page, Richard's headshot sits front and center as the account's cover photo.\n\nStoughton High School Principal Juliette Miller couldn't be prouder.\n\n\"He met with me around his sophomore year or late freshman year, told me that he was going to be in the Olympics. That's what his goal was. He was striving for that. We've known all along to expect great things from him,\" Miller said.\n\nBack at the Sterling gym, young gymnasts said they were determined to follow in the Olympians' footsteps.\n\n\"It's pretty crazy to think about an Olympian doing gymnastics where I'm doing gymnastics,\" said Jacob Jones.\n\nRichard is scheduled to compete again Wednesday, and Nedoroscik will be back on the pommel horse Saturday.\n\n(Copyright (c) 2024 Sunbeam Television. {"uri": "2024-07-435486652", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-27", "time": "14:58:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-27T14:58:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-27T10:47:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5333333611488342, "url": "https://www.wnewsj.com/2024/07/27/britain-rides-strong-effort-of-olympic-veterans-to-early-lead-in-mens-gymnastics-qualifying/", "title": "Britain rides strong effort of Olympic veterans to early lead in men's gymnastics qualifying", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- Britain insists it doesn't have any sort of rivalry with the U.S. in men's gymnastics, even if the two programs have spent the better part of a decade jockeying for position at every major international event right behind superpowers China and Japan.\n\nMaybe, but during Olympic qualifying on Saturday, the British sent a very real if unspoken message: They are not ready to cede a podium spot in Paris to the Americans, or just about anybody else for that matter, either.\n\nPowered by newcomer Jake Jarman and steadied by six-time Olympic medalist Max Whitlock, Britain surged to the lead in the first subdivision inside Bercy Arena, posting a team total of 256.561 to finish well ahead of the somewhat sloppy Americans.\n\nJarman's 84.897 all-around total was just ahead of teammate Joe Fraser while Whitlock -- in his fourth and final Games -- fought off the jitters he knew would come to score a 15.133 on pommel horse and give Britain momentum heading into Monday night's team final.\n\n\"A lot of people have asked me that question in terms of 'How's it feel to be above the U.S.?'\" Whitlock said. \"To be honest, you take it with a pinch of salt. I think it's really important to kind of just think about our job.\"\n\nOne that Whitlock and his four teammates did extremely well over two-plus hours in front of an audience that included U.S. first lady Jill Biden, who clapped along with American star Frederick Richard's floor routine and posed for pictures with a somewhat subdued team afterward.\n\nWhile Richard called the experience \"pretty sick,\" he regretted not being able to show Biden a \"cooler\" routine after he scored a 13.833, a bit below what he knows he'll need in order to medal in the all-around finals next week.\n\nRichard wasn't the only one. The U.S. arrived in Paris hoping to earn a team medal for the first time since a bronze in Beijing 16 years ago. While that certainly remains on the table, Richard & Co. will need to be sharper on Monday night.\n\nBrody Malone, who returned from a catastrophic leg injury in March 2023 to make his second Olympic team, fell once on pommel horse and twice on high bar and likely will miss all-around and event finals.\n\nThe second miscue on high bar -- a high-risk, high-reward event in which Malone won gold at the 2022 world championships -- forced the Americans to use Asher Hong's 12.600, one of the reasons the U.S. ended up 3.322 behind Britain.\n\n\"It was definitely not perfect,\" U.S. high performance director Brett McClure said. \"And it was a few too many mistakes. I feel leading into team finals we need to clean some things up.\"\n\nMalone's miscues opened the door for Paul Juda. The 23-year-old doesn't do the most difficult gymnastics, focusing more on execution to stay competitive. McClure put Juda up first on five of the six events, a position that requires more than a little mental toughness because it can set the tone for an entire rotation.\n\nJuda seems uniquely suited for the position.\n\n\"I just knew that if they put me first, that I earned that myself,\" said Juda, a Michigan student who says he has worked extensively with a sports psychologist over the last couple of years. \"And with my team behind me ... I was ready for it.\"\n\nWhen Malone faltered, it created an opportunity to compete in the all-around finals that few -- perhaps Juda himself at some point -- saw coming.\n\n\"I think today would have been one of those things where I got to say I did all-around at the Olympics, but then to hopefully be making an all-around final, I think that's the cooler thing,\" Juda said. \"And, you know, the coolest thing is yet to come.\"\n\nQualifying continues later Saturday, with longtime rivals and gold medal favorites Japan and China competing in the second of three subdivisions. The top eight team finishers advance to the team finals on Monday.\n\nThe one superpower that won't be in the mix is Russia. The defending Olympic champions will miss the Paris Games as part of the fallout of the war with Ukraine. Russia's absence creates an opportunity for the U.S., Britain and perhaps Ukraine to reach the podium.\n\n\"If they were in, you'd like to think that they'd be up near the top,\" Whitlock said. \"So with them not, of course, there's a little bit of (a better opportunity to medal) but only a little bit.\"\n\n___\n\nAP Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8246125511", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-27", "time": "11:57:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-27T11:57:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-27T11:54:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5333333611488342, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/sports-news-great-britain-rides-strong-effort-of-olympic-veterans-to-early-lead-in-mens-gymnastics-qualifying-6142321.html", "title": "Sports News | Great Britain Rides Strong Effort of Olympic Veterans to Early Lead in Men''s Gymnastics Qualifying | LatestLY", "body": "Get latest articles and stories on Sports at LatestLY. Great Britain surged to an early lead during men's gymnastics qualifying, posting a team total of 256.561 to finish ahead of the United States in the first of three subdivisions Saturday.\n\nParis, Jul 27 (AP) Great Britain surged to an early lead during men's gymnastics qualifying, posting a team total of 256.561 to finish ahead of the United States in the first of three subdivisions Saturday.\n\nThe Americans, who finished third at the 2023 world championships ahead of Great Britain, dealt with issues on the high bar and pommel horse to finish second at 253.229.\n\nAlso Read | Paris Olympics 2024: Major Highlights From Gliterring XXXIII Olympic Games Opening Ceremony.\n\nThe US arrived in Paris believing it had a legitimate chance to medal in the team competition for the first time since earning a bronze in Beijing 16 years ago.\n\nThere is work to be done after the British put on a largely mistake-free clinic across six rotations.\n\nAlso Read | Kangana Ranaut Slams Paris Olympics 2024 Opening for 'Controversial' Last Supper Depiction, Questions 'Why Can't Sex Stay in the Bedroom?' (View Pics).\n\nJake Jarman (84.897) and Joe Fraser (84.666) posted the top all-around scores and six-time Olympic medalist Max Whitlock provided a jolt with an electric pommel horse routine -- his signature event -- that left the 31-year-old looking relieved.\n\nWhitlock's 15.166 trailed only American Stephen Nedoroscik, a specialist whose 15.200 likely earned him a spot in the event finals and gave his teammates some early momentum.\n\nIt didn't last. Brody Malone, who returned from a horrific leg injury to win his third US championship in June, fell twice on a high bar and once on a pommel horse to scuttle his chances of returning to the all-around finals.\n\nInstead, Frederick Richard and Paul Juda will represent the Americans. While Richard -- who earned bronze in the all-around at the 2023 world championships -- is expected to advance, Juda's performance is a bit of a surprise.\n\nThe 23-year-old -- who unabashedly broke down in tears after being named to the five-man Olympic squad -- thrust his arms into the air after his dismount on floor exercise.\n\nHis all-around total of 82.865 was fourth among early qualifiers, trailing only Richard (83.498), Jarman and Fraser.\n\nQualifying continues later Saturday, with longtime rivals and gold medal favourites Japan and China competing in the second of three subdivisions. The top eight team finishers advance to the team finals on Monday. {"uri": "8251896544", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "06:48:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T06:48:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T06:47:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "url": "https://www.justjared.com/2024/07/31/team-usas-pommel-horse-star-stephen-nedoroscik-reacts-to-viral-fame-gushes-over-girlfriend-tess-mccracken/", "title": "Team USA's Pommel Horse Star Stephen Nedoroscik Reacts to Viral Fame, Gushes Over Girlfriend Tess McCracken | Just Jared: Celebrity News and Gossip | Entertainment", "body": "Stephen Nedoroscik has become quite the viral star on the internet lately!\n\nThe 25-year-old Team USA gymnast only competes in one event - pommel horse, and he helped bring the men's gymnastics team to a bronze medal victory, their first metal in 16 years.\n\nWhen he goes up to do his routine, he takes off his glasses, and many have made him a meme, with many viral posts about him being the Clark Kent of the men's gymnastics team.\n\n\"Obsessed with this guy on the US men's gymnastics team who's only job is pommel horse, so he just sits there until he's activated like a sleeper agent, whips off his glasses like Clark Kent and does a pommel horse routine that helps deliver the team its first medal in 16 years,\" one post on X (formerly Twitter) reads. The post, at the time of this article, has over 31k retweets and 534k likes!\n\nNow, Stephen is sharing his thoughts on going viral and while the internet loves him, he has one person who has always been cheering him on - his girlfriend Tess McCracken, who is also a gymnast.\n\nKeep reading to find out more...\n\n\"It is awesome,\" he tells ET of the love he's been getting online. \"I didn't have my phone for a couple hours after the competition and I was like, 'Ah, it's gonna be so fun to see all my friends that have messaged me.' [When] I looked at it, I was like, 'What is going on?'\"\n\n\"I mean, there's so many memes out there about me being a sleeper agent who wakes up and turns into Clark Kent Superman on the pommel horse,\" he added. \"They are hilarious. It is such an honor to be in that position. I'm glad the people are enjoying the show that us men put out last night.\"\n\nStephen also took a moment to gush over his girlfriend Tess, who at one point changed her bio on X to read, \"Ms. Pommel Horse.\"\n\n\"Tess is the absolute best,\" he said. \"First of all, [she is] beautiful. She is so smart. We met eight years ago at Penn State when we were both coming in as freshmen on our respective gymnastics teams. The first time I ever met her she was cracking her back. I thought it was kind of funny, so I introduced myself. We sat there and took an ADHD test or some baseline thing... Right away there was chemistry. It didn't take long for us to start dating.\"\n\n\"She's just been my number one cheerleader for the last eight years. I'm so honored to have her.\"\n\nStephen and the men's gymnastics team may have already picked up a bronze metal in the team event, but he still has another round of competing in the pommel horse {"uri": "2024-07-435644437", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-27", "time": "19:33:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-27T19:33:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-27T19:26:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5215686559677124, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/world/international/2805623/", "title": "American gymnast Brody Malone eliminated from all-around competition at Paris Olympics", "body": "Brody Malone, who returned from a leg injury to win his third U.S. championship in June, fell twice on the high bar and once on the pommel horse, ruining his chances of returning to the all-around final as the United States fell to fifth in men's gymnastics qualifying after two rounds of play Saturday.\n\nChina topped the second subdivision with a team total of 263.028 points, while competing with rivals Japan, the reigning world champion, who had to deal with some uncharacteristic errors from current world and Olympic champion Daiki Hashimoto and finished on 260.594 points.\n\nGreat Britain earned a team total of 256.561 points, the best score in the first of three subdivisions, and sit third overall. Ukraine overcame a high-bar nightmare to overtake the United States and move into fourth place with 253.893 points, with the Americans fifth with 253.229 points.\n\nThe United States, which finished third at the 2023 world championships, arrived in Paris confident it had a legitimate chance of winning a medal in the team competition for the first time since winning bronze in Beijing 16 years ago.\n\nThree-time U.S. champion Brody Malone fell twice on the high bar and once on the pommel horse during men's gymnastics qualifying and will not advance to the all-around final. AP Photo/Morry Gash\n\nMalone's second error on the high bar - a high-risk, high-reward event on which he won gold at the 2022 world championships - forced the Americans to use Asher Hong's 12.600, one of the reasons the United States fell 3.322 behind Great Britain in the first subdivision.\n\n\"It definitely wasn't perfect,\" U.S. high performance director Brett McClure said. \"And there were a few too many mistakes. I think going into the team finals, we need to improve on some things.\"\n\nFrederick Richard and Paul Juda will represent the Americans in the all-around final.\n\nChina's five-man team, without veteran Sun Wei after he was injured during training on Thursday, used a series of spectacular routines on the rings and parallel bars to establish themselves as favourites heading into Monday's final.\n\nJapan's Hashimoto will have a chance to defend his all-around title, but he won't be able to do so on the high bar, his favourite event, after stumbling on his dismount. He appeared to be suffering from discomfort in his right shoulder for much of the afternoon and was treated by a Japanese team coach shortly after finishing on the high bars.\n\nHashimoto finished third overall after two subdivisions with a score of 85.064, behind teammate Shinnosuke Oka (86.865) and China's Zhang Boheng (88.597).\n\nThe scores will be reset for the team finals, although the only real question is who will join Japan and China on the podium, with defending champions Russia ineligible due to the war in Ukraine.\n\nThe British put on a flawless display over six rounds. Jake Jarman (84.897) and Joe Fraser (84.666) posted the best all-around scores, and six-time Olympic medallist Max Whitlock, 31, provided a boost with an electric pommel horse routine - his favourite event - that took the pressure off him.\n\n\"A lot of people have asked me this question: 'How does it feel to be above the United States?'\" said Whitlock, who is competing in his fourth and final Games. \"To be honest, you have to take it with a grain of salt. I think it's really important to think about our job.\"\n\nWith a time of 15.133, Whitlock was trailed only by American Stephen Nedoroscik, a 25-year-old specialist whose time of 15.200 likely earned him a spot in the final and gave his teammates an early boost.\n\n\"It went really well today. I handled my nerves really well,\" Nedoroscik said. \"I worked my whole life to get to those 45 seconds.\"\n\n\"It's the biggest stage in the world for sure. It only happens once every four years, but at the same time, I'm putting chalk on my hands and doing the horse for the team, it's nothing different.\"\n\nRichard scored 13.833 on floor for the Americans, just below what he knows he'll need to medal in the all-around final next week.\n\nWhile Richard, who won bronze in the all-around at the 2023 world championships, was expected to lead, Judah's performance was somewhat surprising.\n\nJuda, 23, who broke down in tears after being selected for the five-man Olympic team, raised his arms in the air after his floor walk. His overall total of 82.865 points puts him fourth among the early qualifiers, behind Richard (83.498), Jarman and Fraser.\n\n\"I think today I could have said I did the all-around at the Olympics, but I also hope to be able to make the all-around final, I think that's the coolest part,\" Judah said. \"And you know, the coolest thing is yet to come.\"\n\nNedoroscik will also compete in the team final, where three men per country will compete on each apparatus and all three scores will count.\n\nThe third subdivision will end later Saturday. The top eight teams will advance to the team final on Monday.\n\nThe Associated Press contributed to this report.\n\nWhat Are The Main Benefits Of Comparing Car Insurance Quotes Online\n\nLOS ANGELES, CA / ACCESSWIRE / June 24, 2020, / Compare-autoinsurance.Org has launched a new blog post that presents the main benefits of comparing multiple car insurance quotes. One important advantage is the speed at which information is sent and received. With the help of the internet, the shopping habits of many persons have drastically changed. The car insurance industry hasn't remained untouched by these changes. On the internet, drivers can compare insurance prices and find out which sellers have the best offers. View photos The advantages of comparing online car insurance quotes are the following: Online quotes can be obtained from anywhere and at any time. Unlike physical insurance agencies, websites don't have a specific schedule and they are available at any time. Drivers that have busy working schedules, can compare quotes from anywhere and at any time, even at midnight. Multiple choices. Almost all insurance providers, no matter if they are well-known brands or just local insurers, have an online presence. Online quotes will allow policyholders the chance to discover multiple insurance companies and check their prices. Drivers are no longer required to get quotes from just a few known insurance companies. Also, local and regional insurers can provide lower insurance rates for the same services. Accurate insurance estimates. Online quotes can only be accurate if the customers provide accurate and real info about their car models and driving history. Lying about past driving incidents can make the price estimates to be lower, but when dealing with an insurance company lying to them is useless. Usually, insurance companies will do research about a potential customer before granting him coverage. Online quotes can be sorted easily. Although drivers are recommended to not choose a policy just based on its price, drivers can easily sort quotes by insurance price. Using brokerage websites will allow drivers to get quotes from multiple insurers, thus making the comparison faster and easier. {"uri": "2024-07-437743629", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "03:17:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T03:17:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T03:13:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5215686559677124, "url": "https://heavy.com/sports/olympics/stephen-nedoroscik-girlfriend-reaction-paris-olympics-performance/", "title": "Stephen Nedoroscik's Girlfriend Sends Two-Word Reaction to Paris Olympics Performance", "body": "Stephen Nedoroscik helped Team USA make history in the men's gymnastics competition on July 29, then got a big message of support from his girlfriend.\n\nThe men's gymnastics star turned in a performance on the pommel horse -- his only event -- that helped Team USA break a 16-year medal drought and earn the bronze at the Paris Olympics. After his big night, Nedoroscik got a two-word message from girlfriend Tess McCracken on Instagram.\n\n\"History = Made,\" McCracken wrote on Instagram.\n\nMcCracken, who posted Instagram stories throughout the day cheering on her boyfriend, went on to say how proud she was of his accomplishment.\n\n\"The most insane, magical day watching you close it out to bring home the first team medal for USA in sixteen years\ud83c\uddfa\ud83c\uddf8. Words can't capture how proud I am of you.\"\n\nStephen Nedoroscik's Girlfriend a Star in Her Own Right\n\nMcCracken and Nedoroscik were both collegiate gymnasts at Penn State. In her senior season, McCracken was nominated for the AAI Award, an award given to the nation's most outstanding senior. She also earned a spot on the Academic All-Big Ten selection and was named a Big Ten Distinguished Scholar.\n\nThe couple met on campus before their freshmen year started and dated all four years. When they graduated in 2020, Nedoroscik took to Instagram to share his love for McCracken.\n\n\"Four years ago I had my entire collegiate experience ahead of me. Little did I know I had already found my favorite part about college. I love you @tess.mccracken and happy four years.\"\n\nStephen Nedoroscik's Big Night in Paris\n\nNedoroscik has been something of a specialist for Team USA, competing exclusively on the pommel horse dating back to his high school days, USA Today's Tom Schad reported.\n\nHeading into Monday's team competition, Nedoroscik admitted that he felt some pressure, especially because of his long wait to compete.\n\n\"(But) I thought about it before, about how I get to be the last person that goes in the Olympics,\" Nedoroscik said. \"I put that in my head as a positive. Like, I can be the exclamation point.\"\n\nBut Nedoroscik's unusual preparation gained some viral interest, with television cameras catching his meditative moments on the sidelines as he waited for his turn to compete. He delivered when it mattered, turning in a show-stopping performance on the pommel horse and earning a score of 14.866, good enough to earn the United States its first medal in the team all-around since 2008.\n\nNedoroscik struggled at times before Paris, falling in the 2021 Olympic trials and ultimately being replaced on Team USA. He also missed the final at the world championships in 2022, where the American team finished fifth, Schad noted.\n\nBut when it mattered the most at the Paris Olympics, Nedoroscik delivered.\n\n\"It's like a Cinderella story, fairy tale ending,\" said Sam Mikulak, one of Nedoroscik's coaches. \"I just hope everyone starts believing and gives him the credit that's due - especially Team USA, for creating the procedures that got him on the team.\"\n\nAfter his performance helped secure a medal for the United States, Nedoroscik took a moment to soak it all in.\n\n\"It was just the greatest moment of my life, I think,\" Nedoroscik said.", "source": {"uri": "heavy.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Heavy"}, "authors": [{"uri": "nathan_dougherty@heavy.com", "name": {"uri": "2024-07-435544007", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-27", "time": "16:29:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-27T16:29:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-27T16:15:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5215686559677124, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/sports/national_sports/china-surges-past-rival-japan-during-mens-olympic-gymnastics-qualifying/article_15ac5749-e714-5fb3-ad46-05aa9cc20944.html", "title": "China surges past rival Japan during men's Olympic gymnastics qualifying", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- China surged to the top of Olympic men's gymnastics qualifying Saturday, putting together a team total of 263.028 while competing next to rival Japan.\n\nThe five-man Chinese team, missing veteran Sun Wei after he was injured during training Thursday, used a series of spectacular routines on rings and parallel bars to stamp itself as the favorite heading into Monday's final.\n\nJapan, the reigning world champion, dealt with a couple of uncharacteristic mistakes by current world and Olympic champion Daiki Hashimoto and finished at 260.594.\n\nWhile the 22-year-old will get a chance to defend his title in the all-around, he won't on high bar -- his signature event -- after stumbling during his dismount. Hashimoto appeared to be dealing with right shoulder discomfort for much of the afternoon and was tended to by a Team Japan trainer shortly after finishing up on still rings.\n\nHashimoto is currently third in the all-around through two subdivisions at 85.064, behind teammate Shinnousuke Oka (86.865) and China's Zhang Boheng (88.597).\n\nThe scores will reset for in the team finals, though the only real question is who will join them on the podium with defending champion Russia ineligible due to the war in Ukraine.\n\nBritain is in third after topping the first subdivision with 256.561. Ukraine overcame a nightmarish set on high bar to slip past the U.S. and into fourth at 253.893, with the Americans fifth at 253.229.\n\nThe British insist they don't have any sort of rivalry with the U.S., even if the two programs have spent the better part of a decade jockeying for position at nearly every major international event.\n\nBritain sent a very real if unspoken message: it is more than capable of grabbing a bronze to go with the one it somewhat unexpectedly won in London a dozen years ago.\n\nJake Jarman's 84.897 all-around total was just ahead of teammate Joe Fraser while Max Whitlock -- in his fourth and final Games -- fought off the jitters he knew would come to score a 15.133 on pommel horse and give Britain plenty of momentum.\n\n\"A lot of people have asked me that question in terms of 'How's it feel to be above the U.S.?'\" Whitlock said. \"To be honest, you take it with a pinch of salt. I think it's really important to kind of just think about our job.\"\n\nOne that Whitlock and his four teammates did extremely well over two-plus hours in front of an audience that included U.S. first lady Jill Biden, who clapped along with American star Frederick Richard's floor routine and posed for pictures with a somewhat subdued team afterward.\n\nWhile Richard called the experience \"pretty sick,\" he regretted not being able to show Biden a \"cooler\" routine after he scored a 13.833, a bit below what he knows he'll need in order to medal in the all-around finals next week.\n\nRichard wasn't the only one. The U.S. arrived in Paris hoping to earn a team medal for the first time since a bronze in Beijing 16 years ago. While that certainly remains on the table, Richard & Co. will need to be sharper in the finals.\n\nBrody Malone, who returned from a catastrophic leg injury in March 2023 to make his second Olympic team, fell once on pommel horse and twice on high bar and likely will miss all-around and event finals.\n\nThe second miscue on high bar -- a high-risk, high-reward event in which Malone won gold at the 2022 world championships -- forced the Americans to use Asher Hong's 12.600, one of the reasons the U.S. ended up 3.322 behind Britain.\n\n\"It was definitely not perfect,\" U.S. high performance director Brett McClure said. \"And it was a few too many mistakes. I feel leading into team finals we need to clean some things up.\"\n\nMalone's miscues opened the door for Paul Juda. The 23-year-old doesn't do the most difficult gymnastics, focusing more on execution to stay competitive. McClure put Juda up first on five of the six events, a position that requires more than a little mental toughness because it can set the tone for an entire rotation.\n\nJuda seems uniquely suited for the position.\n\n\"I just knew that if they put me first, that I earned that myself,\" said Juda, a Michigan student who says he has worked extensively with a sports psychologist over the last couple of years. \"And with my team behind me ... I was ready for it.\"\n\nWhen Malone faltered, it created an opportunity to compete in the all-around finals that few -- perhaps Juda himself at some point -- saw coming.\n\n\"I think today would have been one of those things where I got to say I did all-around at the Olympics, but then to hopefully be making an all-around final, I think that's the cooler thing,\" Juda said. \"And, you know, the coolest thing is yet to come.\"\n\nRussia's absence creates an opportunity for the U.S., Britain and Ukraine to reach the podium in the finals, which figures to be another duel between China and Japan.\n\nStill, Whitlock downplayed the idea that if Russia was involved, a team medal would be out of the question.\n\n\"If they were in, you'd like to think that they'd be up near the top,\" Whitlock said. \"So with them not, of course, there's a little bit of (a better opportunity to medal), but only a little bit.\"\n\nAP Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games", {"uri": "8249722465", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "00:23:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T00:23:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T00:22:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5137255191802979, "url": "https://www.newser.com/story/353632/us-male-gymnasts-win-first-medal-in-16-years.html", "title": "US Male Gymnasts End Long Medal Drought", "body": "The American men's gymnastic team earned bronze in Paris on Monday for its first medal since 2008. After qualifying in fifth place, the US men ended a 16-year drought to the delight of the dozens of fans waving American flags who chanted \"USA! USA!\" throughout the evening, the AP reports. The Americans posted a total of 257.793 points to edge Britain for the bronze. Frederick Richard and Brody Malone were at the top of their game, and every member of the US team contributed. Stephen Nedoroscik, the pommel horse specialist, joined his teammates on the final rotation.\n\nThe Japanese men's gymnastics team claimed gold with an epic comeback over its top rival. With China poised to claim its first Olympic title in 12 years with one rotation to go, Japan surged ahead to win the men's team competition Monday after an intense and nail-biting duel. The Japanese team, which trailed by more than three points going into the last apparatus, overtook its rivals after China's Su Weide fell twice off the horizontal bar and Xiao Ruoteng underperformed under pressure. Russia, which won gold at the Tokyo Games, is not competing in Paris because of its invasion of Ukraine.\n\nThe women's final, featuring seven-time Olympic medalist Simone Biles, takes place on Tuesday. Dana O'Neil at the Athletic writes that while the men's team was a \"model of consistency\" on Monday, \"maybe no one, however, earned the medal draped around his neck more than Brody Malone.\" Malone suffered what SI calls a \"devastating knee injury\" in March last year and had to relearn how to walk after several surgeries. {"uri": "8250414447", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "10:17:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T10:17:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T10:16:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5098039507865906, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/world/international/2807673/", "title": "Team USA | U.S. men's gymnastics team wins first team medal since 2008 - ExBulletin", "body": "After a comeback by China and Japan, the Americans rank third with two events to go. Their goal of a podium is within reach, we could see them sticking together after having successfully completed this rotation on the high bar.\n\n\"We wanted to make sure we didn't get sidetracked by the moment,\" Judah said. \"We were definitely in a kind of flow and the last thing we wanted to do was rush. There were still two critical events left and without successful events, there was no way this was going to happen. So this was a turning point.\"\n\nJudah, Hong and Richard gave the team exactly what they needed during the floor rotation, with the highlight being the crowd's reaction to Richard's blocked landings in the second half of his routine. The U.S. team remained third overall after floor, leaving three pommel horse routines between them and an Olympic medal.\n\nJudah and Malone both posted higher scores than they had in qualifying in first and second place, leaving Nedoroscik, the pommel horse specialist, to close out the round for the United States. In an effort to prepare and remain oblivious to the scores, both from other countries and his own team, Nedoroscik had taken the high bar and floor rotations off the competition floor in the warm-up room. As Nedoroscik prepared to compete, he said he wasn't aware that his routine would decide whether his country would win a team medal. He was only aware of the energy coming from his teammates ahead of him.\n\n\"I could hear all the guys cheering, it seemed to be going really well,\" Nedoroscik said. \"At that point, I knew all the guys had nailed all the routines. I have this thing where if everyone else does it before me, I never fail.\"\n\nThat tradition continued for Nedoroscik. Before his feet even touched the mat on his downhill run, the arena was filled with thunderous applause and collective cheers. His teammates wasted no time as he was greeted with a series of bear hugs on the floor. Once the scores were finalized and the number 3 was displayed on the screen next to USA, it took only moments for American flags to be draped across the backs of each team member. A series of American chants began again, this time a little louder.\n\n\"It's surreal,\" Richard said. \"We're all going to make history.\"\n\nWhat Are The Main Benefits Of Comparing Car Insurance
