{"uri": "8249757723", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "01:10:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T01:10:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T01:09:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5098039507865906, "url": "https://heraldcourier.com/sports/college/olympics-johnson-city-born-brody-malone-helps-u-s-get-bronze-in-mens-gymnastics-team/article_05b68846-4e0e-11ef-83a8-b72bffb97440.html", "title": "OLYMPICS: Johnson City-born Brody Malone helps U.S. get bronze in men's gymnastics team competition", "body": "The Associated Press\n\nPARIS -- Before they stood with their arms wrapped around each other in a brotherhood forever etched into U.S. Olympic lore, Brody Malone, Frederick Richard, Asher Hong, Paul Juda and Stephen Nedoroscik were collegians.\n\nYes, the dreams the members of the U.S. men's gymnastics team had fostered since childhood began in small gyms scattered across the country. But they became tangible at Stanford, Michigan and Penn State.\n\nSo when it was time for those dreams to become fully, vividly realized inside a raucous Bercy Arena on Monday night, they leaned on the experiences they gained during all those meets in all those sometimes sparsely filled gyms that taught them about pressure and teamwork and belief.\n\nYes, the bronze medal the Americans so emphatically earned ended a 16-year drought on the sport's biggest stage.\n\nPeople are also reading... The Big Tri City Fair looks to bring fun and entertainment HIGH SCHOOL BASKETBALL: Hart steps down at Honaker, not seeing commitment in offseason PREP SPORTS: VHSL leaders hold public meeting in Abingdon Only the name has changed; 'The Classic' expected to become bigger and better HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: Versatile Elliott to see plenty of the field for Vikings Owens will be missed at annual Creeper Trail Ride to End Cancer Campus keeps tradition strong This theater season brings friendship, camaraderie and nostalgia to the stage BHC SOFTBALL PLAYER OF YEAR: Muncy completes stellar career with state title at Rye Cove HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: All Wolves now playing at West Ridge PREP FOOTBALL: Marquee games await Northeast Tennessee teams Drug probe leads to arrests, seizure of $1.9M of meth, fentanyl Herald Courier receives awards from Tennessee Press Association Southwest Virginia economy resilient in face of population declines Candidate Cao meets with Republicans in Abingdon\n\nYet it was also a message to athletic directors at the dozen schools that still have Division I gymnastics -- and to be honest, to the ones that don't, too -- that the sport is worth saving.\n\n\"If you want to keep seeing USA Gymnastics and Team USA on a gymnastics podium, at least on the men's side, you're going to have to give us more opportunities to compete in college,\" said Juda, who is in graduate school at Michigan.\n\nOpportunities that are in danger of vanishing quickly thanks to a rapidly evolving college sports landscape. It's a reality the five men who stood on the podium with their arms around each other are only too aware of.\n\nRichard, a rising junior at Michigan, has made it his life's mission to bring more people to a side of the sport that -- at least in the U.S. anyway -- has long plugged along anonymously.\n\nAnd while he's carved out a rapidly expanding niche on social media, Richard is savvy enough to understand the one thing guaranteed to attract people to men's gymnastics isn't a viral video, but hardware like the medal he kept grabbing in the giddy aftermath.\n\n\"My goal even here was to make a statement that the U.S. is getting stronger and stronger and we're only (going up),\" Richard said. \"And I think we did that today. I think a lot of young boys watching are inspired by us.\"\n\nThat's the way it was for Richard as a kid in the Boston suburbs. There were pictures on the wall at the gym of the medal-winning 2004 and 2008 U.S. men's Olympic teams. Richard would stare at the pictures and wonder how those teams put all the pieces together.\n\n\"It looks like they all came together on the same day and just did like these perfect routines,\" Richard said. \"And you're like, how is that possible?\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | Omny Studio\n\nRichard found out firsthand.\n\nThe Americans didn't record a major fall during any of their 18 routines in the final and finished closer to second-place China than fourth-place Britain. They leaned into the energy from a vocal contingent of U.S. fans that offered a hint of what it might look like in Los Angeles four years from now.\n\nMostly, however, they leaned on each other and their experiences to shake off an iffy qualifying session on Saturday in which they finished a sloppy fifth.\n\n\"We just told each other we were gonna treat it like an NCAA championships because we've all been there,\" Malone said. \"And it's high pressure competing for a team. And it's no different this competition. I mean yeah, this one's a little bit different, a little bit bigger. But same concept.\"\n\nWith perhaps a much more impactful result.\n\nNedoroscik is 26. Malone is 24. Juda is 23. Hong and Richard are 20. There is a feeling of real momentum within the U.S. men's program for the first time in a while. Yet to keep it going, the pipeline behind them needs to keep churning.\n\nMalone was born in 2000 in Johnson City, Tennessee, before his family moved to Georgia.\n\nThere was a sense in the 2010s that the U.S. had grown stale in part because those at the core group at the top grew a little too comfortable due in part to a lack of competition from those trying to catch them.\n\nSam Mikulak went to three Olympics with teams that had considerable talent. He never came home with a medal, though on Monday night he was chatting with Nedoroscik as he prepared for his pommel horse set that served as the exclamation point.\n\nWhile they talked, Mikulak told Nedoroscik to stay calm, that 80 percent of his best would be good enough. To soak in a moment Mikulak dreamed of but never quite grasped.\n\nAnd when Nedoroscik gracefully swooped from one end of the horse to the other, his hands working dutifully in tandem on an event that has given the Americans fits for years, the bronze that felt in some ways like gold was won.\n\nStanding there in the aftermath, Mikulak couldn't help but speculate about what might lie ahead.\n\n\"I think the guys are going to be hungry for more,\" he said. \"And hopefully this spurs men's gymnastics in the US like never before.\"\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your {"uri": "8251076643", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "17:20:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T17:20:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T17:19:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5058823823928833, "url": "https://www.today.com/health/men-s-health/stephen-nedoroscik-eyesight-rcna164245", "title": "Why gymnast Stephen Nedoroscik wears glasses: What to know about his eyesight", "body": "The gymnast stands out for wearing thick-rimmed glasses when he's not competing. Here's what Stephen Nedoroscik has shared about his eye conditions.\n\nU.S. gymnast Stephen Nedoroscik wears glasses, which seems to be a rarity among athletes going for the gold at the 2024 Paris Olympics.\n\nHe takes them off when he competes on the pommel horse -- his only event and a dazzling routine that helped Team USA's men's gymnastics team win the bronze medal in the team final on Monday, July 29.\n\nNedoroscik's transformation from a mild-mannered bespectacled mechanical engineer on the sidelines to powerful athlete defying gravity on the pommel horse is drawing comparisons to Clark Kent turning into Superman when he removes his glasses.\n\nThe gymnast talked with TODAY co-anchor Hoda Kotb while wearing her sunglasses because of an eye sensitivity -- a condition he's talked about on social media.\n\nHere's what Nedoroscik has shared about his eyesight:\n\n\"It's not necessarily clear, but the thing about pommel horse is if I keep them on, they're gonna fly somewhere,\" Nedoroscik told TODAY about his preference to take off his glasses.\n\n\"When I go up on the pommel horse, it's all about feeling the equipment. I don't even really see when I'm doing my gymnastics. It's all in the hands -- I can feel everything.\"\n\nNedoroscik has crossed eyes -- or strabismus, the medical term for the condition, he revealed on TikTok.\n\nIt happens when a problem affects eye muscles, causing the eyes to not line up properly and point in different directions, according to the American Academy of Ophthalmology.\n\nStrabismus usually develops in infants and kids under 3, but it can also start later in life, the American Optometric Association notes.\n\nPeople with strabismus can lose depth perception, or develop blurry or double vision. Glasses or contacts can help patients see better. Other treatment options include surgery, eye muscle exercises and prism lenses that help manage the misalignment of the eyes.\n\nThis genetic condition happens when some of the tissue that makes up the eye is missing at birth, according to the National Eye Institute. One or both eyes could be affected.\n\nThere are different types of coloboma depending on which part of the eye is impacted. The missing tissue could involve the eyelid, lens, macula, optic nerve, retina or middle layer of the eye, the American Academy of Ophthalmology notes.\n\nNedoroscik has talked about living with coloboma on TikTok, explaining he's photophobic, or light sensitive, because of it -- perhaps why he borrowed Hoda's sunglasses.\n\nOther symptoms include vision loss; not being able to see in a specific location, such as the upper part of the field of vision; or blindness.\n\nThere's no cure, but glasses or contact lenses can help. Some patients may need low vision aids or surgery.\n\nThey haven't made an appearance at the Olympics yet, but Nedoroscik began wearing the sports goggles his freshman year at Penn State. His college teammates called them \"The Specs,\" noting they were a Secret Santa gift that had no prescription lenses.\n\n\"They are simply for fun, kind of my trademark. I like to have fun out there,\" Nedoroscik said in a 2022 video profile, adding he considers them a good luck charm. \"From day one of competing with them, they had a little bit of magic to them.\"\n\nHe sometimes uses them for comfort and \"superstitious reasons,\" rather than improving his eyesight, according to his official Olympics profile.", "source": {"uri": "today.com", Please don't fall. Please don't fall,'\" Judah said. \"In an instant, the floor was at my feet and I hit the Olympics.\"\n\nHe said he hoped his near-perfect routine \"created the momentum we needed... of course it looked like it.\"\n\nFrom the jump to the finish, \"it was just altitude and cruise, baby,\" Judah said.\n\nThe crowd erupted when Frederick Richard nailed the landing of a risky high bar routine full of tricks. He said it was the people around him who helped him pull off the routine, one of the most remarkable of the night.\n\n\"I think about everybody that's behind me. I knew I had the whole of America behind me. I knew those five guys were cheering me on. And I knew I wanted to do the best routine I could for them,\" Richard told NBC News. \"And when you feel that in your heart, it happens and you get through it.\"\n\nRichard will join Judah in the individual all-around final.\n\nStephen Nedoroscik anchored his team on his famous single event, the pommel horse, earning a score that earned the United States third place. He will compete for Team USA in the individual event final.\n\n\"I didn't know what we needed, but I knew I had to do a good job,\" Nedoroscik said. \"I was nervous, but right before I left, these guys told me, 'We trust you. We support you.' Online", "body": "Watch: 2024 Olympics: Gymnast Jade Carey Shares Why She Fell During Floor Routine\n\nAfter all, the member of the U.S. men's Olympic gymnastics team stayed backstage for almost three hours during the medal round until he was brought out for a single event: the pommel horse.\n\nIt's an unusual move for a gymnastics squad. While his teammates Brody Malone, Fred Richard, Asher Hong and Paul Juda competed in five of the six events -- the horizontal high bar, the parallel bars, the vault, the still rings and the floor -- Stephen, 25, was sequestered away before being brought out for the final event of the evening.\n\nBut however unusual, it's a move that made sense given Stephen's history. {"uri": "8250797594", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "14:08:28", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T14:08:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T14:07:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5058823823928833, "url": "https://thetab.com/uk/2024/07/30/grab-your-glasses-and-laugh-at-the-best-memes-about-steve-the-nerdy-pommel-horse-hero-377440", "title": "Grab your glasses and laugh at the best memes about Steve the nerdy pommel horse hero", "body": "Did any of us know anything about gymnastics or the pommel horse yesterday? No. Would we all now die for Steve the nerdy Pommel Horse hero? Absolutely. The men's gymnastics was on at the Olympics yesterday and the whole world is obsessed with pommel horse guy and pommel horse guy alone. He came, took his glasses off, ATE on that pommel horse, nagged a medal and then left.\n\nSteve Nedoroscik is an American gymnast from Worcester, Massachusetts. He's a member of the United States men's national gymnastics team and specialises on the pommel horse.\n\nSteve said he used to always be climbing walls and furniture when he was a kid so they decided to take him to a local gymnastics centre. He went on to compete on all six apparatuses as a child. But when he was in high school he noticed he was only improving on the pommel horse so he decided to just specialise in that and the rest is history!\n\nYou just know that pommel horse is terrified of him\n\n* Give yourself a medal if you can solve this Olympics optical illusion in less than 52 secs\n\n* Fancy yourself as an Olympian? {"uri": "8249784276", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "01:46:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T01:46:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T01:45:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "url": "https://slate.com/culture/2024/07/olympics-gymnastics-usa-men-medal-nedoroscik-glasses-pommel-horse.html", "title": "Holy Smokes, the U.S. Men's Gymnastics Team Finally Won a Medal!", "body": "And the cool dude in glasses had to sit around for three hours before he clinched it.\n\nYou know he's about to stand on business when Stephen Nedoroscik takes off his glasses. The 25-year-old American gymnast, who trains and competes in precisely one of the six events in the sport of men's artistic gymnastics, is in some ways the male answer to 2017 world champion Morgan Hurd, a bespectacled, chalk-covered hero. Unlike Hurd, however, who famously competes glasses-on, these days Nederoscik pulls a full Kent-to-Superman: competing on muscle memory, instinct, feel, and pure unadulterated American-grade will to power -- vision be damned!\n\nIf this sounds abjectly bananas, you should probably know that Nedoroscik is one of the best pommel horse workers in the world. He also just helped put the stars and stripes on the medal podium in men's gymnastics for the first time since Sarah Palin said she could see Russia from her house.\n\nTo appreciate the full extent of Nedoroscik's most recent triumph -- and that of his four teammates, Fred Richard, Paul Juda, Asher Hong, and Brody Malone -- you should probably also understand the U.S. men's program's fraught history with this sport, given that it receives markedly less media attention than women's artistic gymnastics does. (Yes, a sport where the \"default\" is the women's version!)\n\nMuch like on the women's side, the U.S. really didn't have a medal-contending program (or any medal-contending athletes) until the late 1970s, when Kurt Thomas established himself as a one-man Uncle Sam juggernaut, walking away from the 1979 world championships with six medals. Thomas also pioneered three skills, including a rollout tumbling skill that is now effectively banned across the sport (for falling-on-head reasons) and, most historically, what was once called the Thomas Flare and is now so standard across the repertoire that it's just a flare:\n\nHowever, the Olympics in which Thomas had his best shot to medal were the 1980 Moscow Games, which the U.S. famously boycotted. And indeed, the first time in modern history the U.S. men ever did win a team medal was their gold in 1984. However, this was a gold-with-an-asterisk: The Los Angeles Games were revenge-boycotted by the USSR, whose program would have decimated anyone in their vicinity. Nevertheless, the Reagan-era Wheaties industrial complex managed to gloss over this fact enough to rocket the men to stardom (as it did on the women's side with Mary Lou Retton's success). In some cases that stardom has lasted: '84 stars Bart Conner and Tim Daggett have both been successful commentators for decades. (In the short term, both Conner and certified team hot guy Mitch Gaylord also parlayed their golden fame into brief, campy, but honestly delightful movie roles.)\n\nBy the 1988 Seoul Games, though, the U.S. resumed its usual place in the men's canon: off the podium. In fact, between 1984 and 2001, not a single American man graced a world or Olympic medal stand. Between 2001 and 2008, it appeared the drought was over; this became especially true when Paul Hamm won all-around gold in Athens in 2004, and the team took away silver that year and bronze in Beijing four years later. But then, the drought resumed.\n\nYes, there were numerous individual stars, a few individual medals, and team bronzes at world championships in 2011 and 2014. But for the past three Olympics, the top three men's teams (always Japan, China, and either Russia or Great Britain) have been untouchably good. In 2024, however, with even Shein Russia banned for who knows how long -- a ban helped, in no small part, by the odious behavior of the team's gymnasts -- there has been a possible medal spot with the U.S.'s name on it. Not only that, but since 2020, the men's program has been in an aggressive rebuilding phase, and currently boasts a plethora of young talent. The program built this year's Olympic team with a bronze medal in sight -- and with some help from a disquieting if unsurprising source.\n\nJust like for our undergraduates writing papers, and I guess someone's daughter writing a \"heartfelt\" fan letter to her favorite hurdler, they let A.I. do it. All right, that's an oversimplification, but the program did run all possible score scenarios (based on performance at Olympic Trials) through an algorithm, and the team the algorithm picked was Malone, Juda, Hong, Richard, and Nedoroscik. Was it a good idea? When the U.S. team sustained numerous mistakes in qualifying last Saturday, I had my doubts. But when it came to Monday's team finals, the numbers, in the end, didn't lie.\n\nAnd that brings us back to Nedoroscik and his one event. Using a precious five-man team slot for a single event specialist would, in most configurations, seems like a bad idea. And it would be a bad idea, except for the fact that Nedoroscik's difficulty on pommels is very high. A difficulty value that high (in recent competitions his start value can near the mid-to-high 16s, depending on what he decides to do) means a final score in or near those rare 15s -- unless, of course, he falls. And I cannot emphasize enough how easy it is to fall off his event.\n\nThat possibility was at the heart of this meet's heart-pounding puzzle. I will admit that I had my doubts about this ChatGPT squad until the very last event they competed. Their placement in qualifying meant that they would end team finals on the single most brutal and nerve-destroying apparatus across all versions of gymnastics for time immemorial: that accursed pommel horse.\n\nDo you get nervous watching gymnasts on the balance beam? Sure you do! But despite the beam's formidable specs -- four inches wide; four feet off the ground -- gymnasts at least get to pause in cute little poses between physics-defying acrobatic and dance elements, to gather themselves and right small wrongs. (When these cute little poses look a little wonky, they are usually unplanned; these are what your commentators will call a \"wobble,\" \"bobble,\" or \"correction.\") So on beam, despite the terror-inducing flips and leaps, gymnasts are able to largely stop moving without technically stopping moving.\n\nDo you know what you cannot do for a single microsecond on the pommel horse? Stop moving. In addition to the general coordination all gymnastics apparatus require, this event demands simultaneous abdominal and upper body might, massive cardio stamina, intricate rhythm, and total precision of hand placement. If a gymnast goes even the slightest bit off rhythm while circling or flaring around this Kafkan torture apparatus, he's cooked. In every other event in both men's and women's gymnastics, it is not only possible but an everyday occurrence to use muscle to make a \"save\" (or prevent a fall). In pommels this is straight-up impossible. I hate this event so much! Set it on fire!\n\nOf course, if we set the pommel horse ablaze, that would mean there would be no Stephen Nedoroscik, and all timelines in this story lead back to this magnificent Weezer's IT guy-looking dude. His four teammates all did more than their part on the first five events in the final: stuck vaults! Solid rings! Great floor! Staying on the godforsaken high bar (second only to pommels on my kill list)! The bronze medal was suddenly very literally the U.S. team's to lose -- on the event where the literal best gymnasts the world has ever seen have choked.\n\nWorse yet, because the U.S. went last on pommels, and also because Nedoroscik was in the anchor spot, in order for the U.S. to clinch the bronze medal, he had to first sit in the arena with his glasses on and wait for almost three damn hours. (He was able to warm up a bit in the adjacent practice gym, but he did not get more than the usual 30-second \"touch\" on the actual podium equipment.) As my colleague Dvora Meyers put it: \"Watching the U.S. men on pommel horse in their final rotation may cause dry mouth, heart palpitations and sweaty palms. Speak to your doctor to see if watching pommels is right for you.\" I can tell you: It is not.\n\nBut then, my friends! This happened.\n\nHe did it! They did it! Sixteen-year medal drought over! Shitty qualifying meet forgotten! United States of Beyonc\u00e9 forever and ever -- amen! The much more famous women's team has called 2024 their \"redemption tour,\" but they are not alone in their redemption. The men's team final didn't just redeem (for now) the use of A.I. in sports, or the gamble of putting a one-event specialist on an Olympic team, or even glasses wearers such as myself who are unable to use contacts (represent!). Most importantly, this medal has redeemed the U.S. men's gymnastics program as world-class, because many of these guys are young and, health willing, you will see them on a medal podium again. Is it even possible that this team bronze will cause someone to, when I say I love \"gymnastics,\" ask Which gymnastics, men's or women's? Well, hold on there, Bucko. I'm all for equal rights between the sexes, but let's not get carried away.", "source": {"uri": "slate.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Slate Magazine"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8246508632", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-27", "time": "18:05:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-27T18:05:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-27T18:03:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "url": "https://www.idahostatejournal.com/2024olympics/china-surges-past-rival-japan-during-mens-olympic-gymnastics-qualifying/article_687d00d9-a921-53aa-84a4-c98caecfd5a3.html", "title": "China surges past rival Japan during men's Olympic gymnastics qualifying", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- Longtime men's gymnastics rivals China and Japan could be on their way to another tight finish at the Olympics.\n\nThe sport's two superpowers surged to the top of qualifying at Bercy Arena on Saturday. China posted a team total of 263.028, with Japan right behind in at 260.594.\n\nThe five-man Chinese team, missing veteran Sun Wei after he was injured during training Thursday, used a series of spectacular routines on rings and parallel bars to stamp itself as the favorite heading into Monday's final.\n\nJapan, the reigning world champion, dealt with a couple of uncharacteristic mistakes by current world and Olympic gold medalist Daiki Hashimoto but still finished well clear of third-place Great Britain.\n\nWhile the 22-year-old Hashimoto will get a chance to defend his title in the all-around, he won't on high bar -- his signature event -- after stumbling during his dismount. Hashimoto appeared to be dealing with right shoulder discomfort for much of the afternoon and was tended to by a Team Japan trainer shortly after finishing up on still rings though he said afterward he was not hurt.\n\nHashimoto is currently third in the all-around through two subdivisions at 85.064, behind teammate Shinnousuke Oka (86.865) and China's Zhang Boheng (88.597).\n\nThe scores will reset for the team finals, though the only real question is who will join China and Japan on the podium with defending champion Russia ineligible due to the war in Ukraine.\n\nThe Japanese settled for silver at home in Tokyo in 2021, losing to the Russians by just over a tenth of a point in a close final while China took bronze a little further back.\n\n\"It was frustrating,\" Japan's Kazuma Kaya said. \"But we kept practicing every day for success today. Next time, in (the team final), I want the gold medal.\"\n\nThe gold isn't the only medal in question. Bronze is a toss-up, too, though Britain made a strong case by topping the first subdivision, a group that included the U.S. Ukraine overcame a nightmarish set on high bar to slip past the U.S. and into fourth at 253.893, dropping the Americans into fifth at 253.229.\n\nThe British insist they don't have any sort of rivalry with the U.S., even if the two programs have spent the better part of a decade jockeying for position at nearly every major international event.\n\nBritain sent a very real if unspoken message: it is more than capable of grabbing a bronze to go with the one it somewhat unexpectedly won in London a dozen years ago.\n\nJake Jarman's 84.897 all-around total was just ahead of teammate Joe Fraser while Max Whitlock -- in his fourth and final Games -- fought off the jitters he knew would come to score a 15.133 on pommel horse and give Britain plenty of momentum.\n\n\"A lot of people have asked me that question in terms of 'How's it feel to be above the U.S.?'\" Whitlock said. \"To be honest, you take it with a pinch of salt. I think it's really important to kind of just think about our job.\"\n\nRussia's absence creates a medal opportunity for the U.S., Britain and Ukraine behind another duel between China and Japan for gold. Still, Whitlock downplayed the idea that if Russia was involved, a team medal for anyone outside the sport's Big Three would be out of the question.\n\n\"If they were in, you'd like to think that they'd be up near the top,\" Whitlock said. \"So with them not, of course, there's a little bit of (a better opportunity to medal), but only a little bit.\"\n\nThe American men -- hoping to repeat the bronze they won at the world championships last fall -- weren't nearly as sharp in front of an audience that included U.S. First Lady Jill Biden, who clapped along with American star Frederick Richard's floor routine and posed for pictures with a somewhat subdued team afterward.\n\nWhile Richard called the experience \"pretty sick,\" he regretted not being able to show Biden a \"cooler\" routine after he scored a 13.833, a bit below what he knows he'll need to medal in the all-around finals next week.\n\nRichard wasn't the only one. The U.S. arrived in Paris hoping to earn a team medal at the Olympics for the first time since a bronze in Beijing 16 years ago. While that certainly remains on the table, Richard & Co. will need to be significantly better going forward.\n\nBrody Malone, who returned from a catastrophic leg injury in March 2023 to win the U.S. Championships in early June and make his second Olympic team, fell once on pommel horse and twice on high bar.\n\nHis second miscue on high bar -- a high-risk, high-reward event in which Malone won gold at the 2022 world championships -- forced the Americans to use Asher Hong's 12.600, one of the reasons the U.S. ended up 3.322 behind Britain.\n\n\"It was definitely not perfect,\" U.S. high-performance director Brett McClure said. \"And it was a few too many mistakes. I feel leading into team finals we need to clean some things up.\"\n\nAP Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games", "source": {"uri": "idahostatejournal.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Idaho State Journal"}, "authors": [{"uri": "will_graves@idahostatejournal.com", "name": "Will Graves", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daiki_Hashimoto", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Daiki Hashimoto"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Britain", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Great Britain"}, "location": null}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russia", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Russia"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"uri": "8249561653", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "21:05:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T21:05:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T21:04:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "url": "https://mashable.com/article/stephen-nedoroscik-olympics-pommel-horse-guy", "title": "Stephen Nedoroscik's pommel horse performance for Team USA gymnastics generates online buzz", "body": "Pommel Horse Guy in action. Credit: Tim Clayton/Corbis via Getty Images\n\nStephen Nedoroscik, aka Pommel Horse Guy, proved to be an early Team USA standout in the 2024 Paris Olympics on Monday, delivering a medal-winning performance.\n\nHowever, it wasn't just Nedoroscik's stunning performance on the pommel horse for the U.S. men's gymnastics team that had folks talking. Like a cheesy scene from She's All That, parts of the internet couldn't quite believe a dude with glasses -- gasp -- could also be a world-class gymnast. Nedoroscik also got the requisite Clark Kent comparisons, considering he has dark hair and specs.\n\nTo be clear, Nedoroscik is a world-class gymnast. He specializes in the pommel horse event -- like, that's all he does -- and he absolutely crushed his routine to secure Team USA a bronze medal, the team's first medal since 2008. The team even lifted him in triumph after his performance.\n\nThe internet was chock full of memes, praise, and, to be honest, a bit of thirst for Nedoroscik. It was pretty cool to see someone who had one job freaking nail it for the team.\n\nThe Olympics typically produce celebrities out of nowhere. Athletes who train in relative obscurity get their shot at being heroes for a day. {"uri": "8249698603", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "23:51:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T23:51:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T23:50:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "url": "https://www.nbcchicago.com/paris-2024-summer-olympics/top-moments-day-3/3504636/", "title": "Watch the top moments from Day 3 of the Paris Olympics", "body": "In another exciting day at the Paris Olympics, the United States broke a 16-year medal drought in men's gymnastics, made it to a rugby semifinal round for the first time in Olympic history and racked up medal wins in swimming, skating and more.\n\nThe competition continues on Tuesday and runs until Aug. 11.\n\nFrom hard-fought victories to devastating defeats and more, here's a look back at Monday's highlights:\n\nTeam USA men's gymnastics made it on the podium in the team final for the first time since 2008, ending the 16-year drought in the team competition with the bronze.\n\nThe Americans posted a total of 257.793 points to edge Britain. The Japanese men's team claimed gold with an epic comeback over its top rival China, who took the silver.\n\nTeam USA's stellar showing was a welcome improvement from Saturday's qualifying round, with the mostly green Olympic team of Frederick Richard, Paul Juda, Brody Malone, Asher Hong and pommel horse \"secret weapon\" Stephen Nedoroscik hitting all of their routines.\n\nNext up, Richard and Juda will compete in the all-around final and Nedoroscik in the pommel horse final.\n\nYuto Horigome of Japan successfully defended his Olympic gold medal in Paris after a gnarly final in which he earned the highest single-trick score. Americans Jagger Eaton and Nyjah Huston won silver and bronze.\n\nIn an all-North American podium, Katie Grimes and Emma Weyant of Team USA finished silver-bronze in women's 400m individual medley behind Summer McIntosh, the 17-year-old Canadian phenom and now first-time Olympic gold medalist.\n\nAmerican swimmers won four medals at the Olympics Monday, but none of them gold. Besides Grimes and Weyant, Ryan Murphy took a bronze in the 100-meter backstroke, and Luke Hobson earned a bronze of his own in the 200 freestyle.\n\nAmerican backstroke great Ryan Murphy hung on for a bronze medal in the men's 100m backstroke final, behind Thomas Ceccon of Italy and Xu Jiayu of China.\n\nOn the clay court where he won 14 French Open titles, Rafael Nadal likely bid adieu to Roland Garros on Day 3 of the Paris Olympics. First seed Novak Djokovic bested Nadal 6-1, 6-4 to punch his ticket to Round 3.\n\nAfter the defeat, the two-time Olympic champion was weary of being asked about his future. And he's still playing at the Olympics, pairing with Carlos Alcaraz in doubles for Spain.\n\nA'ja Wilson and Breanna Stewart were dominant down low for the U.S. women's basketball team, which ran its Olympic winning streak to 56 games with a 102-76 win over Japan in its Paris debut. The U.S. women are pursuing an unprecedented 8th straight Olympic basketball gold in Paris.\n\nIlona Maher created a try and almost scored another as the U.S. women's rugby sevens team reached the Olympic semifinals for the first time with a 17-7 win over Britain on Monday.\n\nThey'll face the defending champs, New Zealand, for a spot in the gold-medal match.\n\nConcerns about the water quality in the Seine River led officials to call off the swimming portion of an Olympic triathlon training session for a second straight day.\n\nOrganizers overseeing the event at the Paris Games are optimistic that triathletes will be able to swim in the city's famed waterway when the competition starts Tuesday.\n\nThe sport's governing body, World Triathlon, its medical team and city officials are banking on sunny weather and higher temperatures to bring levels of E. coli and other bacteria below the necessary limits to stage the swim portion of the race, which also includes biking and running.\n\nWorld Triathlon made the decision to cancel the swim workout early Monday following a meeting over water quality in the Seine, which is closely linked to the weather. {"uri": "2024-07-435517221", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-27", "time": "15:45:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-27T15:45:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-27T15:45:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4980392158031464, "url": "https://deadspin.com/us-gymnastics-star-brody-malone-out-of-all-around-after-struggles/", "title": "Deadspin | U.S. gymnastics star Brody Malone out of all-around after struggles", "body": "American gymnast Brody Malone was expected to continue his extraordinary comeback from a serious leg injury suffered in March 2023 by competing for an all-around medal at the Paris Olympics.\n\nInstead, after falling twice on the high bar -- his specialty -- and once on the pommel horse in the qualifying round, Malone won't be competing in the all-around final.\n\nHe is a three-time all-around U.S. champion.\n\n\"What happened here today is done and over,\" Malone said, per The Washington Post. \"There's nothing I can do about it now. Just do the best I can to be ready for team finals.\"\n\nFrederick Richard and Paul Juda will be the two athletes competing in the all-around final for the United States, which finished behind Great Britain in the first of three subdivisions Saturday in the qualifying.\n\nRichard, who finished first all-around in the U.S. Olympic trials and earned a bronze in the 2023 world all-around competition, was no surprise to finish well enough for the all-around, but Juda's presence in the final is unexpected.\n\n\"A couple of months ago or maybe even a couple of years ago, I don't think I would have been able to do that,\" said Juda after the competition, per NBC. \"I've been working super hard on the sport psychology side of the sport, my mental health, sports performance, etc., and those are the reps that really allowed me to do what I did today.\"\n\nRichard finished third among early qualifiers with 83.498, and Juda finished at 82.865. Malone was well back at 79.598, far below his 86.350 score at nationals\n\n\"In the last couple of weeks I had a feeling I might be going first on a couple of events and probably most likely pommel horse,\" said Juda. \"As most gymnasts know it's one of the trickier events to go on but I knew if they put me first, that I earned that myself ... and I was ready for it.\"\n\nGreat Britian finished with a team total 256.561, ahead of the Americans with 253.229, a flip from last year's world championship when the U.S. team finished third in front of Great Britain.\n\nEight teams advance to the team final, and the top 24 individual gymnasts qualify for the all-around finals, with a limit of two per country.\n\nThe qualifying competition will be completed later Saturday.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8250813442", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "14:18:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T14:18:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T14:17:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4980392158031464, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/sport/article/2024/jul/30/stephen-nedoroscik-usa-gymnastics-olympics-paris-glasses", "title": "Stephen Nedoroscik: USA's bespectacled, Rubik's Cube-solving gymnastics hero", "body": "Nearly 167 million American adults wear prescription glasses. Only one is a pommel horse hero.\n\nStephen Nedoroscik, a 25-year-old from Worcester, Massachusetts, has strabismus, more commonly known as crossed eyes, which can lead to double vision. He won gold on the pommel horse at the 2021 World Artistic Gymnastics Championships but was not wearing glasses when scoring 14.866 on the pommel horse in Paris on Monday, a performance that secured a bronze, the first gymnastics men's team medal for the US since 2008.\n\nAll the same, Nedoroscik donned his spectacles to celebrate on the podium and while resting his eyes beforehand, an embodiment of the ordinary and the extraordinary that sparked an avalanche of memes and Clark Kent/Superman comparisons that even the most myopic social media users would find hard to miss, and which he declared \"awesome\".\n\nHe told the Today programme that he is \"representing people that wear glasses well\" - striking a blow for a segment of society that is often mocked as being more likely to be found in the library than the gym, and underlining that a physical imperfection need not preclude an athlete from producing a superlative performance.\n\nHis vision, he added, is \"not necessarily clear, but the thing about pommel horse is if I keep [my glasses] on, they're gonna fly somewhere. When I go up on the pommel horse, it's all about feeling the equipment. I don't even really see when I'm doing my gymnastics. It's all in the hands - I can feel everything.\"\n\nNedoroscik was a college star at Penn State, winning two NCAA pommel horse titles and graduating with a bachelor's degree in electrical engineering.\n\nAs a pommel horse specialist selected ahead of all-arounders in the six-apparatus, five team-member event, the onus was on Nedoroscik to excel in his single area of expertise, the expectations comparable to that faced by an NFL kicker with the Super Bowl on the line. He also had the added strain of going last, having to wait for nearly three hours, and \"probably had the most pressure than any other athlete tonight on the competition floor,\" Brett McClure, the US high performance director, told the Washington Post.\n\n\"I really wanted to make the Olympic team, and I knew that there was going to be backlash to it. I do one event compared to these guys that are phenomenal all-arounders. And I am a phenomenal horse guy. But it's hard to fit on a five-guy team,\" he told the Post.\n\nBut he delivered his 40-second routine with aplomb, reclaimed his glasses and held them aloft as his teammates mobbed him, becoming the newest visually impaired sporting hero.\n\nThe American world champion artistic gymnast Morgan Hurd competed triumphantly in spectacles, using a strap to keep them in place after she decided that contact lenses made her eyes dry. Rebeca Andrade, the Brazilian 2020 Olympic and multiple world champion gymnast, has myopia and astigmatism. She struggles to see the vault as she sprints towards it and cannot read the big screens that flash up her scores, but chooses to compete without contacts as she feels that she performs better with blurry vision, believing that it sharpens her instincts.\n\nMartina Navratilova, Billie Jean King, Eric Dickerson, Edgar Davids and Kareem Abdul-Jabbar are among the famous athletes who played at the highest level in glasses or goggles, but they are outliers despite the large percentage of people with less-than-perfect sight. Contact lenses offer obvious advantages and many professional teams have turned to vision science in a bid to improve performances, both to correct individual defects and to alter the sporting environment, for example by changing kit colours. Nike hired an eye expert, Dr Alan Reichow, who designed tinted glare-reducing contact lenses, a green golf putter and a ball that would be easier for Premier League players to spot during murky winter light.\n\nThe focus will be on Nedoroscik again on Saturday as he targets an individual gold. But the bronze is not his only impressive feat in France. Before the final, the Killer Sudoku fan, who said he spent 45 hours solving one puzzle, posted an image of a Rubik's cube on social media which he appears to have finished in 9.3 seconds - about half a second below his personal best.", "source": {"uri": "theguardian.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Guardian"}, "authors": [{"uri": "tom_dart@theguardian.com", "name": "Tom Dart", "type": {"uri": "8249687040", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "23:40:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T23:40:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T23:35:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4980392158031464, "url": "https://theprint.in/sport/olympics-gymnastics-underdogs-no-more-u-s-men-nab-bronze-in-olympic-resurgence/2197688/", "title": "Olympics-Gymnastics-Underdogs no more, U.S. men nab bronze in Olympic resurgence", "body": "The Americans appeared in position to secure bronze but they had to end on the ever-treacherous pommel horse, where Japanese ace Daiki Hashimoto had faltered earlier.\n\nAmericans Paul Juda and Brody Malone hit two strong routines to start, placing the U.S. fate squarely on anchor and pommel horse specialist Stephen Nedoroscik, who had waited the entire evening for his sole performance.\n\nNedoroscik's teammates fiercely hyped him through the whole routine, which he nailed with ease. The whole team erupted into celebration as if they had just won gold despite Japan being the true victors, surging back from fifth place at the halfway point to deliver heartbreak to China.\n\n\"I was like, five feet in the air jumping,\" U.S. gymnast Frederick Richard exclaimed as he described the moment.\n\nThat energy had been building throughout the event as the Americans stuck landing after landing, igniting belief they could stand on the team medals podium for the first time since the 2008 Beijing Games.\n\nThe Americans opened Monday's team final on still rings, a great place to start according to the U.S. men's high performance director.\n\n\"We knew we could go three-for-three easily,\" Brett McClure told reporters, before explaining that Asher Hong's massive vault in the next rotation kicked the guys into gear.\n\n\"Once he put that on his feet I was like, now we're rolling,\" McClure said.\n\nThe Americans then worked through parallel bars, horizontal bar and floor exercise, besting their scores from qualifications on each apparatus.\n\nMalone's horizontal bar effort marked redemption after suffering two uncharacteristic falls during qualifying, but a focused mindset was the key to success on Monday.\n\n\"(The team) made it a very strong point before going into the competition that we were going to make sure to stay in our bubble,\" Malone told reporters.\n\nRichard hopes the Americans' clutch performance in Paris has made an impact on the next generation.\n\n\"I think a lot of young boys watching are inspired by us, and that makes me really happy.\"\n\n(Additional reporting by Gabrielle T\u00e9trault-Farber)", "source": {"uri": "theprint.in", "dataType": "news", "title": "ThePrint"}, "authors": [{"uri": "reuters@theprint.in", "name": {"uri": "2024-07-438898447", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "01:03:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T01:03:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T01:02:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4980392158031464, "url": "https://www.nbcnewyork.com/paris-2024-summer-olympics/what-to-know-about-stephen-nedorosciks-eyesight-gymnast-reveals-eye-conditions/5651018/", "title": "What to know about Stephen Nedoroscik's eyesight: Gymnast reveals eye conditions", "body": "The gymnast stands out for wearing thick-rimmed glasses when he's not competing. Here's what Stephen Nedoroscik has shared about his eye condition.\n\nU.S. gymnast Stephen Nedoroscik wears glasses, which seems to be a rarity among athletes going for the gold at the 2024 Paris Olympics.\n\nHe takes them off when he competes on the pommel horse -- his only event and a dazzling routine that helped Team USA's men's gymnastics team win the bronze medal in the team final on Monday, July 29.\n\nNedoroscik's transformation from a mild-mannered bespectacled mechanical engineer on the sidelines to powerful athlete defying gravity on the pommel horse is drawing comparisons to Clark Kent turning into Superman when he removes his glasses.\n\nThe gymnast talked with TODAY co-anchor Hoda Kotb while wearing her sunglasses because of an eye sensitivity -- a condition he's talked about on social media.\n\nHere's what Nedoroscik has shared about his eyesight:\n\nWhat he sees when he competes without glasses\n\n\"It's not necessarily clear, but the thing about pommel horse is if I keep them on, they're gonna fly somewhere,\" Nedoroscik told TODAY about his preference to take off his glasses.\n\n\"When I go up on the pommel horse, it's all about feeling the equipment. I don't even really see when I'm doing my gymnastics. It's all in the hands -- I can feel everything.\"\n\nHe has strabismus\n\nNedoroscik has crossed eyes -- or strabismus, the medical term for the condition, he revealed on TikTok.\n\nIt happens when a problem affects eye muscles, causing the eyes to not line up properly and point in different directions, according to the American Academy of Ophthalmology.\n\nStrabismus usually develops in infants and kids under 3, but it can also start later in life, the American Optometric Association notes.\n\nPeople with strabismus can lose depth perception, or develop blurry or double vision. Glasses or contacts can help patients see better. Other treatment options include surgery, eye muscle exercises and prism lenses that help manage the misalignment of the eyes.\n\nHe has coloboma\n\nThis genetic condition happens when some of the tissue that makes up the eye is missing at birth, according to the National Eye Institute. One or both eyes could be affected.\n\nThere are different types of coloboma depending on which part of the eye is impacted. The missing tissue could involve the eyelid, lens, macula, optic nerve, retina or middle layer of the eye, the American Academy of Ophthalmology notes.\n\nNedoroscik has talked about living with coloboma on TikTok, explaining he's photophobic, or light sensitive, because of it -- perhaps why he borrowed Hoda's sunglasses.\n\nOther symptoms include vision loss; not being able to see in a specific location, such as the upper part of the field of vision; or blindness.\n\nThere's no cure, but glasses or contact lenses can help. Some patients may need low vision aids or surgery.\n\nHe sometimes wears sports goggles for 'superstitious reasons'\n\nThey haven't made an appearance at the Olympics yet, but Nedoroscik began wearing the sports goggles his freshman year at Penn State. His college teammates called them \"The Specs,\" noting they were a Secret Santa gift that had no prescription lenses.\n\n\"They are simply for fun, kind of my trademark. I like to have fun out there,\" Nedoroscik said in a 2022 video profile, adding he considers them a good luck charm. \"From day one of competing with them, they had a little bit of magic to them.\"\n\nHe sometimes uses them for comfort and \"superstitious reasons,\" rather than improving his eyesight, according to his official Olympics profile.\n\nThis story first appeared on TODAY.com. The two athletes make up 2/5 of the men's gymnastics olympic team and proved their worth in yesterday's men's team final competition. For the first time in 16 years, Team USA made the podium and took home the bronze at the olympics in large part to these two hometown athletes.\n\nFrederick Richard is from Stoughton\n\nFred was born in 2004 and is from Stoughton, MA. He competed at Michigan and went on to compete in several NCAA and world championships. But it's his social media presence that has introduced Fred to both gymnastics fans and non gymnastics fans alike. Fred has 769.3k followers on TikTok where he has hundreds of millions of views.\n\nStephen Nedoroscik is from Worcester\n\nStephen is quirky, glasses wearing pommel horse specialist that has a Worcester backround. Stephen was chosen for Team USA for one rotation only. He competed on the pommel horse dead last and his essential hit of his routine gave Team USA their first medal in 16 years. {"uri": "8246342835", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-27", "time": "15:15:22", "dateTime": "2024-07-27T15:15:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-27T15:14:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4941176474094391, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/07/27/sports/frederick-richard-gymnastics-olympics/", "title": "In his Olympic debut, Frederick Richard brought his confidence  --  and carried the US into the team final - The Boston Globe", "body": "Related'That's the person I was always chasing:' Boston gymnast Frederick Richard is in Paris to introduce himself to the world\n\nRichard, the tumbling phenom from Stoughton barely past his 20th birthday, knew early on that he was destined for a life on high bars and parallel bars, of one filled with aerial flips and pommel spins, one aiming for rings, both the still kind hanging above him on the mat and the five interlocking ones looming over every Olympic event. He was a natural gymnast with the work ethic and drive to reach the elite.\n\nSo as he stood before that pommel horse, on the precipice of making his lifelong dream a reality, a moment of self-awareness held no risk of interrupting his concentration.\n\n\"I touched my hands on the pommel and I'm thinking, 'Now this feels like every other pommel. Now it's time for me to listen to my breath,'\" he said.\n\nIt held no risk of interrupting his joy.\n\n\"But then, it's funny, like halfway through the routine, I'm like, 'OK, I kind of got this, I can definitely do this,\" he said, \"'and I'm really up here right now.\"\n\nIt held no risk of interrupting his skills. When his feet hit the ground and it was official: Frederick Richard, Olympian?\n\n\"I thought, 'OK, I did it. I'm that guy.\"\n\nAs it turns out, after one day of qualifiers for the men's gymnastic event, Richard is more \"the guy\" for Team USA than anyone even anticipated here in Paris. He was the highest all-around scorer on the US team, which was expected. But it will be his Michigan teammate Paul Juda who will join him in the individual all-around final and not Brody Malone, the lone Olympic veteran on the team, who struggled on every rotation.\n\nMalone, fresh off the triumphant return from a devastating knee injury that didn't stop him from making the team, came off the pommel, fell twice from the high bar (on which he is the reigning world champion), put his hands down on a double-double move on floor and failed to completely stick his landings on the three other events.\n\nRichard had no such issues, seemingly gaining confidence with each pass, from a penultimate routine on his best event, the high bar, when his turn as the team anchor had First Lady Jill Biden clapping animatedly in the crowd, to his final pass on the floor, which while not as smooth, capped an overall successful day.\n\nRichard intends to perform even better during team finals on Monday, and better again at the individual all-around finals on Wednesday. If he's holding nothing back, he hopes to be the best in the world by the time the Olympics hits home shores in Los Angeles in 2028. Such is his personal mandate for these next two weeks, by the end of which he wants the world to know what Frederick Richard (not Fred, s'il vous pla\u00eet) and the rest of his teammates are busy building in their gyms.\n\n\"I want to say Team USA made a statement to the world that we're getting better and better on the men's side and we represented the country well,\" he said. \"And I want to say that the world knows Frederick Richards's name and that he's, he's going to keep getting stronger and stronger and in 2028 he'll probably be the greatest gymnast in the world.\"\n\nStanding beneath the stands of the Bercy Arena speaking to reporters after competing, Richard finishes his bold statement with a laugh. He is serious about his goals, but he is far from an overly serious personality. He is the very definition of joie de vivre, smiling as he pronounces his full name with a lovely French accent, lauding his teammates like Malone, who apologized to the team after his rough day but whom Richard adamantly defended from needing to make such amends, and pommel horse specialist and fellow Massachusetts native Stephen Nedoroscik, whose 15.2 on his only event was the USA's highest single score of the day.\n\nMalone's foibles were more than enough to remind us how quickly it can all unravel, and by contrast, how much Richard accomplished in his first-ever Olympic experience. From that little boy who bounced out of his crib and drove his parents crazy with his tumbling antics, he set his goal early in life.\n\n\"You know, I've grown up my whole life wishing there were some Black gymnasts dominating the sport on the men's side, that I can look up to, wishing that the sport was 20 times bigger,\" he said. \"Now I have an opportunity to contribute to that and make that happen. So I just view it as an opportunity now, every day is an opportunity to compete to make the sport bigger to make my dreams happen.\"", "source": {"uri": "bostonglobe.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8251017357", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "16:36:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T16:36:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T16:35:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4941176474094391, "url": "https://www.cinemablend.com/television/mens-gymnastics-my-number-1-event-2024-olympics-how-it-happened", "title": "I Wasn't Expecting Men's Gymnastics To Be My Number 1 Event Of The 2024 Olympics (So Far). Let's Talk About How It Happened", "body": "Getting pumped for the bronze, the U.S. Men's gymnastics team won our hearts and our attention at the 2024 Olympics.\n\nUntil last night, the U.S. Men's gymnastics team hadn't earned a team medal since 2008. It might not feel that long ago, until you realize the oldest competitor on this team, viral pommel horse master Stephen Nedoroscik, was only 9 years old the last time it happened. Then time, and emotion, hits you like a ton of bricks. This is the story of how a bronze medal five men shared has totally captured the zeitgeist of the 2024 Olympics (so far).\n\nAt the time of this writing, the United States has the most medals so far per country, at 20, and has already earned three gold medals in the men's swimming 400-m relay, the 100-m women's butterfly, which went to Torri Huske, and women's individual foil, which went to Kiefer Lee. A lot of the big US success stories have been silver and bronze medals this year, with Luke Hobson swimming the men's freestyle faster then he'd ever swum it and Gretchen Walsh coming in a close second behind Huske in the butterfly.\n\nBut it was the men's all-around gymnastics events that really had me on the edge of my seat this week. Notwithstanding viral pommel horse guy, Brody Malone sticking with his journey for a second Olympics to try and win a medal for his mom, who died of cancer in 2012, really stuck with me. His teammates include the talkative and talented Fred Richard, whose goal is to grow his TikTok following and bring more eyeballs to the sport. There's Asher Hong, whose spry athletics make him one of the most identifiable of the teammates, and Paul Juda, who made sticking every routine with minimal mistakes look effortless and graceful.\n\nThe aforementioned Nedorosck was a viral meme all night, as the camera kept cutting to him sitting on the sidelines and staying calm by keeping his eyes closed leading up to his one event. He didn't wear his glasses on the pommel horse, telling the NY Times later that he needs to wear them to see normally, given his eyes are permanently dilated, but he doesn't require them when he's competing; he'd rather go in blind.\n\nThey were trying for a bronze. They took fewer risks than they might have, and the effort in restraint paid off: they did exactly what they needed to do to land the third place medal for the first time in 16 years. It wasn't a gold, but it was still really, really compelling TV.\n\nIt was Frederick Richard - who runs a TikTok account called FrederickFlips - who spent a considerable amount of time during his Olympics spotlight trying to explain that it's time the world sees men's gymnastics as a viable sport. He noted in his interview there was a point where he was \"winning all my competitions but no one knows because men's gymnastics doesn't get any attention.\" His goal for the 2024 Olympics team is to use the platform to change that:\n\nI think they've managed it quite well. And as we head into more from women's gymnastics and the men's individual events, they've certainly captured my attention in a sea of viral Olympics moments from Michael Jordan, Hoda Kotb (living her best life with Tom Cruise) and more. Not bad company to be in.\n\nThe Olympics continues on NBC with performances from women's gymnastics and the men's individual events on the 2024 TV schedule. {"uri": "2024-07-437656312", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "00:06:29", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T00:06:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T23:59:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4941176474094391, "url": "https://gephardtdaily.com/sports/team-usa-wins-first-mens-team-gymnastics-medal-since-2008/", "title": "Team USA wins first men's team gymnastics medal since 2008", "body": "July 29 (UPI) -- Paul Juda, Brody Malone, Stephen Nedoroscik, Asher Hong and Frederick Richard ended Team USA's gymnastics drought Monday, winning the Americans' first Olympic medal in a men's team final since 2008.\n\nThe Americans totaled 257.793 points to earn bronze medals at Bercy Arena in Paris.\n\nJapan's Daiki Hashimoto, Kazuma Kaya, Shinnosuke Oka, Takaaki Sugino and Wataru Tanigawa teamed up to earn gold with 259.594 points. China's Liu Yang, Su Weide, Xiao Ruoteng, Zhang Boheng and Zou Jingyuan posted the second-best score (259.062) to win the silver medal.\n\nThe Americans posted the second-best score on vault, horizontal bars and rings. They were third in floor and fourth on the pommel horse and parallel bars.\n\nRichard's 14.833 was the highest score of any athlete on horizontal bars. Nedoroscik's 14.866 on pommel horse was tied for the second-best score. Hong's 14.833 was the fifth-highest score on vault.\n\nThe victory gave the Americans their first team final medal in the event since Raj Bhavsar, Joe Hagerty, Jonathan Horton, Justin Spring, Kai Wen Tan and Alexander Artemev won the bronze at Beijing 2008. China won that event, while Japan won silver.\n\nThe men's gymnastics tournament will continue with the all-around final at 9:30 a.m. MDT Wednesday at Bercy Arena. The women's gymnastics team final will be at 10:15 a.m. Tuesday in Paris. {"uri": "8249688428", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "23:39:05", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T23:39:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T23:37:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4862745106220245, "url": "https://www.thecut.com/article/who-is-pommel-horse-guy.html", "title": "His Job Is Pommel Horse", "body": "For many fledgling Olympians, this year's Olympic Games mark a once-in-a-lifetime shot at glory, rendering most athletes a ball of nerves, grit, and focus. Except, apparently, if you're the internet's beloved \"Pommel Horse Guy,\" otherwise known as Team USA's Stephen Nedoroscik. The gymnast and pommel horse specialist has won over audiences not so much for his flawless execution on his preferred apparatus, but his willingness to nap, chill, and appear pretty bored for three or more hours while waiting for his time to shine: that is, the moment he mounts the pommel horse. Energetically, Nedoroscik seems like the quiet quitter of Olympians; people, in particular, love his \"nerdy kid\" glasses. Technically, he is the sole reason that Team USA's men's gymnastics team broke its 16-year medal drought on Monday, according to NBC News. In other words, he is so much more than just Pommel Horse Guy.\n\nThe 25-year-old Penn State alum was tapped for Team USA to fill a very specific need, NBC reports. The men's gymnastics team hadn't won any medals since Bush was still in office, and naturally has had to contend with the charm and unfettered greatness of the women's team. While gymnasts often have a specialty apparatus or performance, they typically need to be able to participate in multiple events to make the Olympic squad. Not so for Pommel Horse Guy. Nedoroscik is apparently so good at pommel horse and pommel horse only that the team made an exception for him, banking on the man appearing to fall asleep on their sidelines (NBC claims he was just meditating, okay) to bring home the gold ... or whatever he could manage. Sure enough, with Nedoroscik's help, they scored a bronze medal in the team final on Monday. Big ups to Pommel Horse Guy.\n\nWinning team spirit aside, Pommel Horse Guy feels like the perfect Olympic answer to our country's general online absurdism as of late. The juxtaposition of this guy who seems extremely bored at a high-intensity event like the Paris Games feels so goofy. Also, it's not like Nedoroscik is a specialist in floor or parallel bars, but in an apparatus as niche and silly-sounding as the pommel horse. It's perfect internet catnip, really. It certainly doesn't hurt that he was also the only American man to qualify for an individual apparatus final in Paris. Whatever the vibes may be, they are working. {"uri": "2024-07-438485619", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "15:21:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T15:21:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T15:19:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4862745106220245, "url": "https://www.comingsoon.net/guides/news/1816902-stephen-nedoroscik-why-does-he-wear-glasses-eyesight", "title": "Stephen Nedoroscik: Why Does He Wear Glasses?", "body": "Stephen Nedoroscik recently impressed fans with his performance at the 2024 Paris Olympics. As a pommel horse specialist, his nearly flawless routine helped Team USA secure a bronze medal. During the broadcast, viewers noticed his distinctive look with his eyes closed under his glasses. Now, fans are curious to know why Stephen Nedoroscik wears glasses.\n\nHere is everything to know about why Stephen Nedoroscik wears glasses.\n\nWhy does Stephen Nedoroscik wear glasses?\n\nStephen Nedoroscik started wearing sports glasses during his time at Penn State. These glasses were a Secret Santa gift from his teammate Ben Cooperman. After performing exceptionally well while wearing them, he continued to use them, and soon, the glasses became a part of his routine. Therefore, the glasses are more for their symbolic value than any practical need.\n\nAccording to Essentially Sports, the gymnast said, \"They were a Secret Santa gift from a teammate. We joked that they must have some magic in them, so I kept wearing them. They're more for show than anything. They don't have prescription in them.\"\n\nPreviously, Nedoroscik also opened up on TikTok about having strabismus, a condition that causes crossed eyes. He reached out to doctors on the platform for more information about his diagnosis and demonstrated his experience with the condition to his followers. While the strabismus doesn't seem to affect his performance, it may influence his choice to wear glasses.\n\nNedoroscik also noted that he relies on feel rather than sight for the pommel horse. According to the Washington Post, he said, \"I don't think I actually use my eyes on pommel horse. It's all feeling. I see with my hands.\" Though he occasionally competes without them, the glasses remain a significant part of his persona. {"uri": "8249611982", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "22:02:28", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T22:02:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T22:00:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4862745106220245, "url": "https://www.forbes.com/sites/kaseynelson/2024/07/29/mission-complete-for-us-mens-gymnasts-first-team-medal-in-16-years/", "title": "Mission Complete For U.S. Men's Gymnasts: First Team Medal In 16 Years", "body": "The U.S. Men's Gymnastics Team won a bronze medal inside Bercy Arena Monday - this marks their first team Olympic medal since the 2008 Bejing Games. From the outset of the meet, the U.S. displayed an abundance of confidence and energy on their mission for a medal. They showed immense improvement from the qualifying meet, where they were forced to count falls. Today they counted no falls to tally a 257.793. Japan took gold (259.594) and China took silver (259.062).\n\nTeam USA began on rings while Japan and China both started on floor exercise. As for the scoring, each team puts up their best three gymnasts on each event and all three scores count toward the team total.\n\nTeam USA started off strong with Fred Richard sticking his double-double off the rings for a 14.033. Brody Malone kept the momentum going with a 14.166, a great start after rocky qualifications for him. Asher Hong competed third and led the way with a 14.533 after a laid-out double-double. After rotation one, the U.S. sat in fifth place.\n\nThe men kept the energy alive on vault with Paul Juda sticking his Kasamatsu 1.5 and scoring a 14.666. Brody Malone matched Juda with another stuck vault for a 14.533. Last up was Asher Hong for a sky-high vault that scored a 14.833 to lead the team once again and help Team USA surge into first place. Following Hong's vault, the crowd began chanting \"USA, USA.\"\n\nThe team headed to parallel bars for rotation three, where Brody Malone showed a great set with nice lines, including a double pike dismount for a 14.433. Fred Richard kept things going for the squad, firing a 14.566 with a double front dismount where he fought for every tenth and had to take small hop forward on the landing. Asher Hong rounded out the rotation, dismounting with a double front half out stuck to score a 14.4.\n\nHigh Bar was up next, and this was a critical event for Team USA to hit to maintain third place. Paul Juda started off with a 13.366. Fred Richard hit another routine to earn a 14.833 after a double-double dismount. The pressure was all on Brody Malone, who fell twice in qualifications. But he came up clutch for Team USA when it counted, catching all his releases and sticking his laid-out double-double dismount. After four rotations, the U.S. held onto third place.\n\nTeam USA moved to floor for rotation five out of six. Paul Juda scored a 14.2 after\n\ndisplaying a double-double, a Randi (front 2.5 twist), double-full, a 2.5 punch front full and a full-in. Asher Hong was up next and earned a 14.133 after showing huge tumbling, including a front double-full to front double front. Fred Richard led the way on floor with a 14.466 after a big 2.5 twisting double tuck. Once again, the team maintained third place heading into the sixth and final rotation and a chance at a bronze medal.\n\nThe pressure was on for Team USA to to make all three routines on pommel horse to medal. Paul Juda hit his set to score a 13.900, and Brody Malone followed up with the second hit for a 13.700, which was a great comeback day for Malone. Stephen Nedoroscik, who waited the entire competition to show his specialty, hit with a 14.866 to lead the team on the event and clinch the bronze for U.S. Men's Gymnastics for the first time in 16 years.\n\nChina and Japan added excitement going into the final rotation with China in the lead over Japan. {"uri": "8249681437", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "23:29:05", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T23:29:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T23:28:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4823529422283173, "url": "https://www.nbcnews.com/news/sports/olympics-recap-may-missed-gymnastics-skateboarding-basketball-rcna164181", "title": "Olympics recap: What you may have missed from gymnastics, skateboarding, basketball and more", "body": "The U.S. leads the Paris Games with 20 total medals while France is next with 16.\n\nDay 3 of the Paris Games gave us memorable moments in men's gymnastics, men's skateboarding and more. Here are the biggest stories from another action-packed day in France.\n\nThe United States men's artistic gymnastics team won its first medal since 2008 in a thrilling finish. Needing a strong showing in the final rotation, the men stepped up on the pommel horse to earn a bronze medal.\n\nBrody Malone redeemed himself after a difficult qualifying round, scoring a 13.7. Stephen Nedoroscik (a.k.a. Pommel Horse Guy a.k.a. Clark Kent) stole the show, however, waiting more than two hours to perform on the pommel horse and putting up a 14.866 score.\n\nNedoroscik is eyeing gold in the pommel horse final, which is slated for Saturday, while Paul Juda and Frederick Richard will compete in the all-around final on Wednesday.\n\nJapan ultimately won gold in the event, coming from behind in the final rotation to topple China, which settled for silver.\n\nCanadian prodigy Summer McIntosh won gold -- perhaps the first of many -- on Monday night in competition marked by newcomers and nations not always represented on the podium.\n\nMcIntosh easily took the 400-meter individual medley, a race the 17-year-old normally dominates and has the world record.\n\nDavid Popovici won the 200 free, becoming the first Romanian man to ever take a swimming gold. Reno native Luke Hobson won bronze. Mona McSharry earned bronze in the 100 breaststroke, delivering the first swimming medal to Ireland since 1996.\n\n\"I'm a little scared to look at my phone,\" a beaming McSharry, 23, told reporters. \"But I got to hug my family, cousins, a big group of Irish people that were down by the bottom, behind the podium, so that was great. No words were spoken but I think just a lot of smiles and happiness.\"\n\nLas Vegas native Katie Grimes and Sarasota, Florida's Emma Weyant took silver and bronze, respectively, behind McIntosh.\n\nRyan Murphy, who grew up near Jacksonville and attended UC Berkeley, won bronze in the 100 backstroke.\n\nThe U.S. women's basketball team began its quest for an eighth straight gold medal, dispatching Japan 102-76 to open group play. This game was not close. USA had a massive size advantage and exploited it at every opportunity.\n\nA'ja Wilson and Breanna Stewart combined for 46 points and 21 rebounds. Brittney Griner, playing overseas for the first time since her detainment in Russia in 2022, added 11 points and nine boards of her own.\n\nFor all the discussion leading up to the games on who was left off the team, Monday was a reminder how much talent remains on the squad in Paris. The U.S. is loaded, and it's going to be difficult for the competition to keep up.\n\nTwo American men medaled in skateboarding street, but in a shocking fashion. Yuto Horigome of Japan, the defending gold medalist, took home the top spot again. He wasn't in position to win any hardware until his final trick -- a nollie 270 to nosebluntside -- stunned the crowd and scored a massive 97.08.\n\nIt was good enough to overcome American Jagger Eaton, who finished second, only 0.10 points behind Horigome. Nyjah Huston, a 15-time X Games skateboarding gold medalist, won bronze, his first Olympic medal.\n\nEaton and Huston were trading the top two spots for most of the event until Horigome's fifth and final trick upended the order.\n\nOlga Kharlan won bronze in women's sabre, Ukraine's first medal in Paris.\n\n\"Ukraine, I love you,\" Kharlan exclaimed after the win. \"This is for you, my dear, this is for you!\"\n\nKharlan overcame a six-point deficit to defeat South Korea's Choi Sebin.\n\n\"I brought a medal to my country, and it's the first one, and it's going to be a good start for all our athletes who are here because it's really tough to compete when in your country is a war,\" she said. \"Every medal, it's like gold. I don't care [that] it's bronze. It's gold.\"\n\nKharlan was disqualified from last year's world championships because she refused to shake the hand of a Russian opponent. She was granted an exception to compete by the International Olympic Committee after backlash to the disqualification.\n\nThe U.S. women's rugby sevens team won its quarterfinal match vs. Great Britain, advancing to the semifinals in the event for the first time in its Olympic history.\n\nNeither the American men nor women have made it this far in the rugby sevens tournament. The U.S. came from behind to secure their spot, trailing Great Britain 7-0 before reeling off 17 straight points to win 17-7.\n\nIt was not only redemption for the States, who finished sixth at the Tokyo games, but revenge -- Great Britain knocked them out of the quarterfinals in 2021.\n\nThe U.S. will face New Zealand, the reigning gold medalist, in the semis on Tuesday.", "source": {"uri": Jake Jarman (84.897) and Joe Fraser (84.666) posted the top all-around scores and six-time Olympic medalist Max Whitlock provided a jolt with an electric pommel horse routine - his signature event - that left the 31-year-old looking relieved.\n\nWhitlock's 15.166 trailed only American Stephen Nedoroscik, a specialist whose 15.200 likely earned him a spot in the event finals and gave his teammates some early momentum.\n\nIt didn't last. The USWNT is always one of the bigger focuses considering they are led by perennial gymnast Simone Biles. However, the USMNT has come alive and secured a medal for the first time since 2008.\n\nMore news: France's Leon Marchand Shines While Team USA Tops the 2024 Olympic Medal Count\n\nThe USMNT won the bronze medal in Artistic Gymnastics at the Paris 2024 Olympics.\n\nThe U.S. secured bronze with an overall score of 257.793, while China took the silver with a score of 259.062, and Japan secured gold with an overall score of 259.594.\n\nChina lost out on gold by 0.532 and the U.S. by 1.801.
