{"uri": "8249774414", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "01:33:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T01:33:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T01:32:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.47843137383461, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/olympics-recap-may-missed-gymnastics-011749302.html", "title": "Olympics recap: What you may have missed from gymnastics, skateboarding, basketball and more", "body": "Day 3 of the Paris Games gave us memorable moments in men's gymnastics, men's skateboarding and more. Here are the biggest stories from another action-packed day in France.\n\nThe U.S. men's artistic gymnastics team won its first medal since 2008 in a thrilling finish. Needing a strong showing in the final rotation, the men stepped up on the pommel horse to earn a bronze medal.\n\nBrody Malone redeemed himself after a difficult qualifying round, scoring a 13.7. Stephen Nedoroscik (aka Pommel Horse Guy aka Clark Kent) stole the show, however, waiting more than two hours to perform on the pommel horse and putting up a 14.866 score.\n\nNedoroscik is eyeing gold in the pommel horse final, which is scheduled for Saturday, while Paul Juda and Frederick Richard will compete in the all-around final Wednesday.\n\nJapan ultimately won gold in the event, coming from behind in the final rotation to topple China, which settled for silver.\n\nCanadian prodigy Summer McIntosh won gold -- perhaps the first of many -- on Monday night in competition marked by newcomers and nations not always represented on the podium.\n\nMcIntosh, 17, easily took the 400-meter individual medley, a race she normally dominates and in which has the world record.\n\nDavid Popovici won the 200 free, becoming the first Romanian man to ever take a swimming gold. Reno, Nevada, native Luke Hobson won bronze. Mona McSharry earned bronze in the 100 breaststroke, delivering the first swimming medal to Ireland since 1996.\n\n\"I'm a little scared to look at my phone,\" a beaming McSharry, 23, told reporters. \"But I got to hug my family, cousins, a big group of Irish people that were down by the bottom, behind the podium, so that was great. No words were spoken, but I think just a lot of smiles and happiness.\"\n\nLas Vegas native Katie Grimes and Emma Weyant, of Sarasota, Florida, took silver and bronze, respectively, behind McIntosh.\n\nRyan Murphy, who grew up near Jacksonville, Florida, and attended UC Berkeley, won bronze in the 100 backstroke.\n\nThe U.S. women's basketball team began its quest for an eighth straight gold medal, dispatching Japan 102-76 to open group play. This game wasn't close. The U.S. had a massive size advantage and exploited it at every opportunity.\n\nA'ja Wilson and Breanna Stewart combined for 46 points and 21 rebounds. Brittney Griner, playing overseas for the first time since her detainment in Russia in 2022, added 11 points and nine boards.\n\nFor all the discussion leading up to the Games about who was left off the team, Monday's game was a reminder how much talent remains on the squad in Paris. The U.S. is loaded, and it's going to be difficult for the competition to keep up.\n\nTwo American men medaled in skateboarding street, but in a shocking fashion. Yuto Horigome of Japan, the defending gold medalist, took home the top spot again. He wasn't in position to win any hardware until his final trick -- a nollie 270 to nosebluntside -- stunned the crowd and scored a massive 97.08.\n\nIt was good enough to overcome American Jagger Eaton, who finished second, only 0.10 points behind Horigome. Nyjah Huston, a 15-time X Games skateboarding gold medalist, won bronze, his first Olympic medal.\n\nEaton and Huston were trading the top two spots for most of the event until Horigome's fifth and final trick upended the order.\n\nOlga Kharlan won bronze in women's saber, Ukraine's first medal in Paris.\n\n\"Ukraine, I love you,\" Kharlan exclaimed after the win. \"This is for you, my dear, this is for you!\"\n\nKharlan overcame a six-point deficit to defeat South Korea's Choi Sebin.\n\n\"I brought a medal to my country, and it's the first one, and it's going to be a good start for all our athletes who are here, because it's really tough to compete when in your country is a war,\" she said. \"Every medal, it's like gold. I don't care [that] it's bronze. It's gold.\"\n\nKharlan was disqualified from last year's world championships because she refused to shake the hand of a Russian opponent. The International Olympic Committee granted her an exception to compete after the disqualification sparked backlash.\n\nThe U.S. women's rugby sevens team won its quarterfinal match vs. Great Britain, advancing to the semifinals for the first time in its Olympic history.\n\nNeither the American men nor women have made it this far in the rugby sevens tournament. The U.S. came from behind to secure its spot, trailing Great Britain 7-0 before reeling off 17 straight points to win 17-7.\n\nIt was not only redemption for the States, who finished sixth at the Tokyo Games, but also revenge -- Great Britain knocked them out of the quarterfinals in 2021.\n\nThe U.S. will face New Zealand, the reigning gold medalist, in the semis on Tuesday.", "source": He's the only returning Olympian on the U.S. team. Team USA alternate Shane Wiskus, who competed at the Tokyo Olympics, also trains at EVO.\n\nSarasota resident and U.S. Olympic Team coach Sam Mikulak has worked with gymnasts at EVO for two years.\n\nEVO's MAG Foundation USA funds the gymnasts and its goal is to \"help USA return to the podium in Paris 2024 and to the top of the podium in LA 2028.\"\n\nEVO Gymnastics is located at 7188 {"uri": "8249624780", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "22:15:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T22:15:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T22:14:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4627451002597809, "url": "https://www.on3.com/teams/penn-state-nittany-lions/news/penn-state-alum-lifts-u-s-mens-gymnastics-to-bronze-at-olympics-tyler-duzansky-makes-mannelly-watch-list/", "title": "Penn State alum lifts U.S. men's gymnastics to bronze at Olympics; Tyler Duzansky makes Mannelly watch list", "body": "A former Penn State gymnast has lifted the U.S. to bronze at the 2024 Paris Olympic Games. Stephen Nedoroscik, who was an NCAA pommel horse champ in 2017 and 2018 and a 2021 world champion in the discipline, nailed his routine in the final round of the Olympics' men's teams gymnastic finals to put his country on the podium.\n\n\"I knew he had it as soon as I saw him take the podium and do his arm swings and take his warmup,\" Penn State gymnastics head coach Randy Jepson said in a news release. \"It's just all about the first circle he does and as soon as he got that I knew his tempo was right and he was off to the races. I couldn't be happier for Penn State's second bronze medalist at the Olympics.\"\n\nTeam USA finished behind China and Japan, respectively, to end a 16-year men's team gymnastics medal drought.\n\n\"What it comes down to is that [Nedoroscik's] scores on pommel horse are so much higher than everybody else on that one event that he adds a tremendous amount of potential score,\" NBC Sports gymnastics analyst Tim Daggett, a 1984 gold medalist, told the outlet. \"That one routine from Nedoroscik gives Team USA basically a full point over the next guy in line for the USA.\"\n\nNedoroscik will compete in the pommel horse finals on Saturday.\n\nPenn State second-year starting long snapper and redshirt junior Tyler Duzansky is on the Patrick Mannelly Award watch list. It is given annually to the best player at the position in college football. Chris Stoll was the last and only Nittany Lion to previously win the award. It has been given out annually since 2019.\n\n\"I would say the reason I came here, number one, obviously, to be able to play at the next level,\" Duzansky said last October. \"And, Penn State specifically has been able to produce specialists to the NFL in recent years.\n\n\"Chris Stoll and Jordan Stout, who I've played with here, and I would consider them both mentors to me. But then also just how the coaches treat players. It's not like this everywhere. And I would say that another plus that Penn State gives to recruits and players.\"\n\nDuzansky is an All-Big Ten third-team pick by Phil Steele. {"uri": "8251213917", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "19:14:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T19:14:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T19:13:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4588235318660736, "url": "https://fortune.com/well/article/stephen-nedoroscik-pommel-horse-guy-paris-2024-vision-impaired/", "title": "'Pommel horse guy' and Olympic sensation Stephen Nedroscik has two vision-impairing conditions -- but that didn't hold him back from being a champion", "body": "If you've spent any time on social media in the past 24 hours, you've probably run into the viral \"pommel horse guy\" on Team USA's men's gymnastics team, which just won bronze -- its first Olympic medal in 16 years. That guy's name is Stephen Nedoroscik, who executed a pommel horse routine that left his teammates cheering, jumping, and fist-pumping with excitement the second he planted his feet back on the ground.\n\nSeconds before he began the routine, Nedoroscik, 25, removed his eye glasses, earning him the nickname \"Clark Kent\" on social media as he transitioned into his competitive alter-ego. For Nedoroscik, however, those glasses are what keep his two vision-impairing conditions at bay: strabismus and coloboma, which he publicly addressed on social media.\n\n\"Basically I'm cross-sighted, and I can switch my dominant eye on command,\" Nedoroscik said in a TikTok he posted in August 2022, in which he was hoping to get some more info about his conditions from eye doctors online.\n\nStrabismus is also known as eye misalignment, according to the Cleveland Clinic. One eye is turned in a different direction than the other, usually as a result of problems with the muscles that control eye movement. While it's mainly found in childhood, it is possible for childhood strabismus to remain if it wasn't treated, or to come back in adulthood.\n\nAround 4% of the U.S., or around 13 million people, have crossed eyes, according to the Cleveland Clinic.\n\nComplications that can arise from strabismus include blurry vision, eye strain, fatigue, headaches, poor three-dimensional vision, and double vision. A lazy eye may also develop, which happens when the brain receives two images from eyes looking in different directions. In an effort to avoid double vision, the brain may ignore what the turned eye sees, causing poor vision development in that eye.\n\nNedoroscik's other condition, coloboma, occurs when part of the tissue that makes up the eye is missing. This happens during pregnancy, when a baby's eye does not fully develop normally.\n\nAccording to the National Eye Institute, symptoms of coloboma include vision loss or blindness, low vision, and sensitivity to light.\n\nIn both cases of strabismus and coloboma, symptoms can be treated with corrective lenses -- in Nedoroscik's case, his Clark Kent glasses.For years, Nedoroscik has been perfecting his pommel horse routine -- the only gymnastic event Nedoroscik came to Paris for (thus, the \"pommel horse guy\" was born), as he watched the rest of his teammates in the other events of the Team All-Around competition. And he did not disappoint his teammates. {"uri": "8247035848", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-28", "time": "06:13:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-28T06:13:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-28T06:12:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4549019634723663, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/2024-paris-olympics-top-usa-gymnast-brody-malone-out-of-all-around-race-after-struggling-in-qualifications-134628851.html", "title": "2024 Paris Olympics: Top USA gymnast Brody Malone out of all-around race after struggling in qualifications", "body": "Top men's gymnast Brody Malone, the reigning U.S. men's all-around champion, is out of the individual competition after struggling during qualifications.\n\nMalone fell three times -- twice on horizontal bar, once on pommel horse -- during preliminaries on Saturday to finish with a 79.598. He is now 11th in the first subdivision; the top 24 gymnasts from across three subdivisions advance to the finals.\n\nOnly two gymnasts from each Olympic committee can advance to the all-around finals. Given that Malone finished well behind teammates Frederick Richard and Paul Juda, who finished third and fourth, respectively, he will not advance.\n\nMalone underwent multiple surgeries for a gruesome knee injury sustained last year, but recovered in time to win his third national all-around title in June. Malone performed incredibly well at Team USA trials, finishing second, just behind Richard.\n\nHe struggled on Saturday, receiving a 0.3 deduction on vault and earning just a 6.033 on horizontal bar, his best event and his highest difficulty. Malone finished fourth overall in the high bar at the Tokyo Olympics in 2021, but is now unlikely to make the finals for the event.\n\nMalone's only hope for the finals is to advance on an individual apparatus. He competed well on parallel bars, earning 14.533 points and finishing fourth in the subdivision. However, only the top eight from all three subdivisions will advance, meaning that an appearance at the finals is not guaranteed.\n\nRichard and Juda, meanwhile, will move on to the next round. The former Michigan teammates competed well on Saturday, with Richard finishing with 83.498 points and Juda finishing with 82.865. With the first of three subdivisions complete, Team USA is currently second in the team result with 253.229. He has taken on the role of de facto captain, and while he wasn't at his best during qualifying, he made sure to tell his teammates to drink in the moment, as difficult as it might have been at times.\n\nMalone spent the last 16 months defying the odds, improbably coming back from a catastrophic right knee injury in the spring of 2023 to reach the Olympics for a second time.\n\nWhen the 24-year-old won his third national title in June, he looked every bit the star the Americans envisioned when he became the standard-bearer for the men's program three years ago.\n\nThe last time the United States won a gold team medal in men's gymnastics was 1984.\n\nThe last time the United States won a silver team medal in men's gymnastics was 2004. The U.S. also won silver in 1904 and 1932.\n\nThe last time the United States won a bronze team medal in men's gymnastics was 2008. The U.S. also won bronze in 1984.\n\nWednesday, July 31 - The men's gymnastics all-around final will take place starting at 10:30 a.m. CT on Wednesday, July 31. That's it. That was the only thing he had to do during these Games.\n\nSounds pretty simple, right? I mean, it's just one thing. Just come in and do some swings on the horse and you're done! Easy.\n\nBut it's not that simple at all.\n\nThink about how things go for, say, NFL kickers. Or closing pitchers in the NFL. If that kick glides just slightly to the left, you're cooked. If that curveball gets away from you just a bit, you're done. The ball is going yard.\n\nNow think about what Nedoroscik had riding on this. He didn't need to just complete his routine on the horse -- he needed to nail it. The men's U.S. gymnastics team had a whole medal riding on this. The team's first medal in 16 years.\n\nAnd guess what he did? Nailed it. LOOK AT MY BOY. He took those glasses off and turned into Superman.\n\nHe nailed it. This is so clutch. What a performance. {"uri": "2024-07-438545797", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "16:18:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T16:18:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T16:11:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4470588266849518, "url": "https://eu.indystar.com/story/sports/olympics/2024/07/30/steven-nedorosciks-ex-teammate-loves-his-fame-on-pommel-horse-at-olympics/74602446007/", "title": "Former teammate Alec Yoder of Indy loving Steven Nedoroscik's viral fame on pommel horse", "body": "Former Indianapolis gymnast Alec Yoder, with two holes to play at the Jacksonville Beach Golf Club, was intently watching a YouTube livestream of the Paris Olympics men's team final on his cellphone Monday.\n\nPerhaps more than anyone, Yoder, an Olympian on pommel horse, knew what Steven Nedoroscik could do.\n\n\"Basically just sat in my golf cart and watched Steven hit it out of the park again,\" Yoder said in a phone interview.\n\nWith a bronze medal on the line for Team USA, Nedoroscik was at his best when it mattered most. He delivered a pommel horse routine that scored 14.886 points, enough to put the U.S. men on an Olympic podium for the first time in 16 years.\n\nWhen it was over, his teammates hoisted him into the air, and he raised his hands above his head.\n\n\"It was just the greatest moment of my life, I think,\" he said.\n\nIt wasn't so great three years ago. Not for Nedoroscik.\n\nHe fell at the 2021 Olympic Trials, prompting USA Gymnastics to select Yoder for Tokyo. He was world champion in 2021 but fell again at the 2022 World Championships, where the Americans finished fifth in team standings.\n\n\"Look, Steven is unreal,\" Yoder said. \"He was when we were going to head-to-head. We had a lot of great opportunities to compete against each other. We both had successes and failures in those times as well.\"We were people who pushed each other to be the best. I could not be more proud to be sitting in that golf cart watching him getting it done for our country.\"\n\nYoder, 27, now living in Jacksonville Beach, Fla., retired from gymnastics and is social media content manager for the PGA Tour. He made the world team in 2018 and was an all-around bronze medalist at the 2014 Youth Olympics.In the individual event final at Tokyo, Yoder finished sixth.\n\nFrom 2017-21, he and Nedoroscik alternated victories on pommel horse. Nedoroscik, of Penn State, won NCAA titles in 2017 and 2018. Yoder, of Ohio State, did so in 2019.\n\nYoder said his late coach, Gene Watson, always told him pommel horse was the one event in which a gymnast could never take a break.\n\n\"It's nonstop focus for 50 seconds,\" Yoder said. \"You've got to be locked in the entire time. Those hand positions can be tricky. It's easy to lose it.\"\n\nHoosiers in Paris: Here are the Indiana athletes competing in the 2024 Olympics\n\nAfter team bronze was secured, Nedoroscik became a sensation on social media, as much for his nerdy appearance as for his gymnastics excellence. He went from a glasses-wearing Clark Kent to caped Superman.\n\nAwaiting the team final, he solved a Rubik's Cube in 9.32 seconds. It's a hobby of his.\n\nAfter years of hyping himself up, Nedoroscik said he came to learn it was better to calm himself down. Of course, he felt pressure.\n\n\"(But) I thought about it before, about how I get to be the last person that goes in the Olympics,\" Nedoroscik said. \"I put that in my head as a positive. Like, I can be the exclamation point.\"\n\nIt was an exclamation point rippling across the Atlantic, spilling onto a Florida golf course.\n\nTom Schad of USA Today contributed to this report. Contact IndyStar correspondent David Woods at dwoods1411@gmail.com. But, his parents are his biggest supporters and got him to where he is today.\n\nBorn on October 28, 1998, the Olympic gymnast had humble beginnings when his parents found out that he was climbing all over the furniture at their house. His parents called him \"Spider Monkey\" and it has stuck ever since. They eventually enrolled him at a local gym in 2003 and the rest is history. \"On the first day there, I climbed a rope all the way to the top,\" Nedoroscik told NBC News. \"After that, they invited me to join the gymnastics team. We accepted it, and that was it.\"\n\nRelated: Meet Simone Biles' biological and adoptive parents\n\nIn 2024, Stephen qualified for the Paris Olympics earlier this year, making history as the only American gymnast to qualify as a single-event specialist. Donning his famous glasses, he's been dubbed the \"Clark Kent\" of gymnastics for his stellar abilites.\n\nCheryl Nederoscik is Stephen's mother. According to her LinkedIn, she's a Client Exprience Manager at BayStateSavings Bank. {"uri": "8249936033", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "04:40:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T04:40:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T04:39:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4392156898975372, "url": "https://www.nbcboston.com/paris-2024-summer-olympics/stephen-nedoroscik-inspires-members-of-sterling-gym-where-he-once-trained/3442603/", "title": "Stephen Nedoroscik inspires members of Sterling gym where he once trained", "body": "Worcester native Stephen Nedoroscik helped bring Team USA back to the podium in the men's team gymnastics event at the 2024 Paris Olympics\n\nThey say never forget where you came from. For gymnast Stephen Nedoroscik, who helped bring Team USA achieve something it hadn't done since 2008, that's a gym in Sterling, Massachusetts.\n\nThe Worcester native pommel horse specialist did his part Monday to earn bronze in the men's team event -- America's first trip to the podium in 16 years.\n\nThe Sterling Academy of Gymnastics, where Nedoroscik was once a member, cheered him on at a watch party.\n\n\"My parents started this business in 1992 with the smallest of dreams,\" said Matt Carbone. \"But 32 years later, we now have an Olympic bronze medalist, and he's still going on to compete in event finals on Saturday. It's absolutely incredible.\"\n\n\"They see the big, giant banner on the wall, they look up to it, they want to be like that,\" boys gymnastics coach Jon Rydzefski said. \"It shows if you work hard enough, you can potentially be doing what Stephen's doing.\"\n\nIt was at the academy that Nedoroscik had his humble beginnings.\n\n\"He was a typical goofy little boy that would play around on the equipment and get in trouble at times and just had fun with gymnastics,\" Carbone said.\n\nThat free spirit turned into an unstoppable force on the pommel horse.\n\n\"A lot of athletes will look up to the legends of their sports in basketball, baseball and football and all that. These guys don't have a whole lot to look up to until the Olympics or the World Championships hit,\" Carbone said. \"And now one of their own teammates has made the world stage. He's going to be incredible for them to look up to.\"\n\nHis success is inspiring even the youngest of gymnasts as they grab the same handles as an Olympic medalist.\n\n\"He encourages me to, like, train hard,\" said fifth-grader Alec Wild. \"Work really hard. Eat healthy.\"\n\n\"They loved it, they absolutely loved it. {"uri": "8249646075", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "22:42:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T22:42:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T22:41:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4392156898975372, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/07/29/sports/olympics-mens-gymnastics-frederick-richard-team-usa-bronze/", "title": "As his men's gymnastics team is written into history, Stoughton's Frederick Richard at the center of it all, living the American dream - The Boston Globe", "body": "When a dream comes alive in every way you imagined, you let your body and brain go along for the ride.\n\nAnd yet, and yet. By the time Richard made his way beyond the medal stand, by the time he was in a media mixed zone and an official podium-placing press conference, by the time he was scratching the back of his neck as the weight of the bronze medal around it pulled against his skin, the signature effervescence had been replaced by something different.\n\n\"It's sinking in, but it still feels pretty unreal,\" he said, eyes wide. \"We're going to be written in history. All of us. That's crazy to think about. They used to have pictures in my gym of the past Olympic teams that medaled and I would look at that and think, 'Man, what if I was one of those people one day?'\n\nAnd what a way to make it happen. A total team effort, yes, but one absolutely energized by the 20-year-old Michigan undergrad who got his start bouncing off the walls of his family home.\n\nA team-high 14.833 on the high bar that nearly set Bercy Arena alight with its electricity, but more importantly, drove Team USA past the midpoint of the six-apparatus rotation with momentum that proved unstoppable. A team-best 14.466 on the ensuing floor routine, his final contribution of the contest, where he (once again) stuck his landing and then bounced his way back around the mat to join his teammates. Another team-best 14.566 on the earlier parallel bars. And a steady, strong and -- most importantly -- mistake-free 14.033 on the rings, the first routine of the night for Team USA and the perfect tone-setter.\n\nHis Olympics aren't over yet. Richard and Juda will be in the field of 24 competing in Wednesday's all-around final; one more opportunity to show off the range of skills that included side-by-side, near-perfect vaults Monday. But with the best gymnasts from the golden Japanese and silver Chinese teams earning the top four qualifying spots, that challenge is steep. (Richard finished 10th.) In coming up short on his one other goal -- make the individual event final in the high bar -- Richard could feel the competitive fire getting stoked for this team goal.\n\nSo there he was, wingspan encircled around Malone, Juda, and Hong as they stood by the corner of the pommel horse watching Nedoroscik. This quintet of men bonded for eternity by shared hope, shared pride, and ultimately, shared achievement. When Nedoroscik hit the ground with a solid, two-footed thud, no one needed to wait for the 14.866 that would later flash as the Americans' single best score of the night.\n\n\"I was jumping so high. Like, I was five feet in the air jumping,\" Richard said. \"I was incredibly thankful and just proud of us because we put a lot of work into it. And it all paid off.\"\n\nWhat a moment. A life-changing moment. A new permanent descriptor tethered to their names, written in red, white, blue, and bronze: Olympic medal winners.\n\nOnly a few days ago, Richard was asked to consider what he wanted people to say when these Olympics are done. What he wanted the American public to know about this team and about his personal journey. What the future might hold for this child of immigrants who found his passion at such a young age, who pursued his dream through endless days of practice in the gym, who followed his heart to the Big Ten and learned the true value of being part of a bigger whole. Who came to Paris with his eye on some hardware and won it.\n\n\"I want to say Team USA made a statement to the world that we're getting better and better on the men's side and we represented the country well,\" he said. \"And I want to say that the world knows Frederick Richards's name and that he's, he's going to keep getting stronger and stronger, and in 2028 he'll probably be the greatest gymnast in the world.\"\n\nThe Los Angeles Games might prove him right. That can wait. It's time to let this one sink in.", "source": {"uri": "bostonglobe.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Boston Globe"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8251601963", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "02:13:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T02:13:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T02:12:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4313725531101227, "url": "https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/general-news/olympics-2024-most-viral-moments-stephen-nedoroscik-ilona-maher-simone-biles-1235962592/", "title": "Olympics 2024 Most Viral Moments: Stephen Nedoroscik, Ilona Maher, Simone Biles and More", "body": "Bella Hadid Responds to Adidas Campaign Controversy: \"Antisemitism Has No Place in the Liberation of the Palestinian People\"\n\nThe Paris Olympics have gifted the internet with a number of fan-favorite athletes, as both new and familiar faces captivate audiences around the world.\n\nAs the games progress, fans contribute to a growing list of viral moments that celebrate the Olympics' predisposition for fantastic comeback stories, heroic displays of talent and, sometimes, just the right amount of humor.\n\nSee below for The Hollywood Reporter's overview of Paris 2024's breakout viral stars.\n\nNedoroscik headed to Paris as a specialist for the USA men's gymnastics team, there to compete in just one event: pommel horse. Just before his big moment came in the team all-around final, cameras caught Nedoroscik, bespectacled in a pair of glasses, seemingly taking a quick nap on the sideline. The athlete then ditched the eyewear and performed a near-perfect routine that clinched a bronze medal for Team USA, the sport's first in 16 years. Images of Nedoroscik have subsequently gone viral, and many celebrated his zenned-out behavior, comparing him to Superman's Clark Kent.\n\n\"Obsessed with this guy on the US men's gymnastics team who's only job is pommel horse, so he just sits there until he's activated like a sleeper agent, whips off his glasses like Clark Kent,\" one user on X, formerly Twitter, wrote.\n\nNedoroscik, for his part, told Today he loves the memes. \"I'm representing people who wear glasses well,\" he said. He also noted that shedding the glasses really does make him quite blind. \"I don't even really see when I'm doing my gymnastics,\" he said. \"It's all in the hands. I can feel everything.\"\n\nAfter struggling with mental blocks and dropping from competition at the Tokyo 2020 games (held in 2021 due to COVID-19), Biles headed to Paris with all eyes turned to her comeback. On Tuesday, she shepherded the women's team to gold in the all-around final, and the internet soon went crazy for her historic trajectory.\n\n\"Simone Biles is not a generational talent,\" one fan wrote on X. \"She's so good that they had to create a new difficulty level to score her. She has multiple moves named after her. She's not a generational talent. She's the best to have ever existed. Netflix's Simone Biles: Rising director Katie Walsh previously told The Hollywood Reporter that Biles was headed to Paris as \"a mature woman who knows what she wants and is really doing this for herself in a way that you don't always see, especially in gymnastics. It would be wonderful for her to win all the gold medals, but I think the showing up and putting herself out there has been the greatest achievement.\"\n\nMaher first rose to TikTok fame during the Tokyo games for her candid videos about life in the athlete's village. She surpassed one million followers shortly after, and has since entertained fans with educational content about women's rugby, female athletes and her journey with body positivity. Maher and her team won the bronze medal at the Paris Olympics, the first time Team USA ever landed on the women's rugby sevens podium.\n\n\"I'm a female athlete in a sport that's not very big, especially in America,\" Maher told The Guardian of her online following. \"It's not a money-making sport ... {"uri": "8251230656", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "19:28:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T19:28:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T19:27:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4274509847164154, "url": "https://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/national-international/team-usa-pommel-horse-specialist-stephen-nedoroscik-used-visualization-to-help-win-an-olympic-bronze-medal/5649937/", "title": "Team USA pommel horse specialist Stephen Nedoroscik used visualization to help win an Olympic bronze medal", "body": "Before his pommel horse routine secured USA Men's Gymnastics its first Olympic medal since 2008, cameras showed Stephen Nedoroscik seemingly napping on the sidelines.\n\nThe 25-year-old American, who was brought to Paris exclusively to be a pommel horse specialist, had his nation's hopes on his shoulders. But he wasn't resting when his eyes were closed, he was visualizing what he had to do next.\n\n\"I do it all the time,\" Nedoroscik told the Washington Post about his habit of visualizing. \"Sometimes I think I do it too much, but what else am I to do with those empty spaces?\"\n\nIndeed, the Penn State grad told the paper that he had visualized his routine \"about 100 times.\" By the time it was his turn to go, Nedoroscik didn't even need his glasses.\n\n\"I don't think I actually use my eyes on pommel horse,\" he said. \"It's all feeling. I see with my hands.\"\n\nVisualizing isn't just helpful for Olympic medalists. Neuroscientist and executive coach Tara Swart previously told CNBC Make It that visualization can be a useful tool to help people achieve their goals.\n\n\"You would be surprised how many high-powered executives secretly have action or vision boards at home or saved on their computers,\" Swart said in 2019.\n\nVision boards can help because there's not much difference to your brain between a strongly imagined vision and an actual experience. She said it's important to visualize what it is already like to have accomplished what you want to achieve rather than see it as a goal.\n\nPut your vision board somewhere you will regularly see it, such as next to your bed or in your closet, so that you constantly encourage yourself to make decisions and take steps towards reaching your goals.\n\nKeeping your goals top of mind, she said, can help remove some of the stress of taking action to achieve them.\n\n\"It cannot just be that you create a fantasy image of your ideal life and wait for your life to magically change,\" she said. {"uri": "8247853182", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-28", "time": "20:04:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-28T20:04:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-28T20:03:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4274509847164154, "url": "https://www.nbcolympics.com/news/preview-first-set-gymnastics-medals-line-mens-team-final", "title": "Preview: First set of gymnastics medals on the line in men's team final", "body": "The first round of Olympic medals for artistic gymnastics will be awarded at the conclusion of the men's team final. In the absence of the reigning Olympic team champions, the Russian Olympic Committee, China and Japan are undoubtedly the favorites for gold.\n\nThe two teams went head-to-head during the qualification round where China got the bragging rights, edging out Japan by over two points. In the team final, it will hope to turn those bragging rights into a gold medal.\n\nHowever, expect Japan to be hot on China's heels after not performing up to its own expectations during qualifications.\n\nNotably defending Olympic all-around champion Daiki Hashimoto had a rough day - falling on floor exercise and high bar (where he won the gold medal in Tokyo). With Daiki performing at full-strength, Japan has all the ingredients to win gold. The pressure will be on China to be clean and deliver another performance like it did during qualifications if it wants to come out on top.\n\nThe format for the team final is three athletes up, all scores count. The scores from qualifications do not carry over so all eight teams will start from scratch.\n\nBoth China and Japan have a built in cushion from the rest of the field thanks to the difficulty in their routines, meaning a few mistakes here or there shouldn't impact the gold and silver positions. However, both teams have made it clear they want gold. The little details will make a difference in the competition between themselves.\n\n\"In Tokyo we got a silver medal (in the team competition) with a little margin,\" Kaya Kazuma said after the qualification round. \"So it was frustrating, but we kept practicing every day for success today. Next time, in (the team final), I want the gold medal.\"\n\nJapan last won the Olympic title in 2016. China won the title in 2012.\n\nThe battle for bronze will be just as exciting as the battle for gold.\n\nGreat Britain finished third in qualifications, Ukraine finished fourth and the United States finished fifth.\n\nHowever those placements don't bring much comfort.\n\n\"A lot of people have asked me that question in terms of 'how does it feel to be above the USA?' Max Whitlock said after the competition. \"To be honest, take that with a pinch of salt ... I think it's really important to kind of just think about our job, our job only.\"\n\nAll three teams are capable of landing on the medal podium if the cards align. All three teams also enter the team final with the confidence of knowing there is still room to improve.\n\nFor the U.S. team, that improvement could come from three-time U.S. national all-around champion Brody Malone, who had fallen on pommel horse and high bar. Follow along.\n\nCoco Gauff in action for Olympic tennis\n\nAmerican women's tennis star Coco Gauff has started her third round match against Donna Vekic of Croatia. Hill lost by split decision, 3-2.\n\nNBC is airing and streaming the Paris Olympics from all angles: Peacock is streaming every sport and event live as it unfolds; NBC, USA Network, CNBC and E! are carrying various live events and replays throughout the day. Here are 6 tips and tricks for getting the most out of Peacock during the Olympics.\n\nLedecky, 27, is undefeated in the 1500 in her professional career, having won five world titles and the first-ever Olympic gold medal in the event at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics.\n\nBecause of the length of the race and the endurance it requires, the 1500 free preliminaries and final will be held over a two-day span, with heats being held Tuesday. -- Steve Gardner\n\nMen's triathlon postponed due to Seine pollution levels\n\nPARIS -- Pollution in the Seine river forced Olympic organizers on Tuesday to postpone the men's triathlon event, threatening to derail a centerpiece of the Paris Games where a massive, $1.5 billion clean-up effort aimed to allow athletes to compete in the notoriously dirty waterway that runs through the heart of the city.\n\nA statement issued by Paris 2024 and World Triathlon said tests showed the water quality in the Seine was still below an acceptable standard for a race day. The men's race has been postponed to Wednesday at 10:45 a.m. local time (4:45 a.m. ET), immediately following the women's event, which is scheduled for 8 a.m.\n\nBoth triathlons remain subject to water tests complying with the established World Triathlon thresholds for swimming, and the original contingency competition day of Friday, Aug. 2 also remains in place, the World Triathlon statement said. -- Kim Hjelmgaard\n\nOlympic swimming today: What to watch\n\nIn the pool, American Bobby Finke is the reigning Olympic champion in the men's 800-meter free. In Paris he likely will be challenged by Australia's Samuel Short and Ireland's Daniel Wiffen.\n\nOlympic gymnastics today: What to watch\n\nIt's the day of the women's team final and the Americans have had this one circled on their calendars. In Tokyo, Simone Biles withdrew from the team event after struggling on vault. The Americans went on to win silver behind Russia (or ROC as the team was called). It was the first time since the 2010 world championships that the Americans did not win the team title at a worlds or Olympics. For the Paris Olympics, Russia is not allowed to compete as a team. Led by Biles, the U.S. won the gold at the 2023 world championships followed by Brazil (silver) and France (bronze).\n\nHow Stephen Nedoroscik delivered on pommel horse to seal US gymnastics' Olympic bronze\n\nPARIS -- Hours before the men's gymnastics team final at the 2024 Paris Olympics, Stephen Nedoroscik solved a Rubik's Cube in 9.32 seconds. It's a hobby of his. And that time, for context, is quite impressive. \"Good omen,\" he wrote on Instagram.\n\nIt was indeed.\n\nIn arguably the most pressure-packed situation that one could imagine in men's gymnastics - the last routine of the last rotation of the Olympic final - Nedoroscik delivered in a big way Monday night, putting together a smooth, confident showing on pommel horse that wrapped up the bronze medal for the U.S. men's gymnastics team. -- Tom Schad\n\nThe Olympics are always among the most talked about events in the world every four years, and with such attention comes an abundance of entertaining content from the masses.\n\nAmong them is the social media account @ArtButMakeItSports. -- Austin Curtright\n\nThe USA TODAY app gets you to the heart of the news -- fast. The event was marked by extraordinary performances, culminating in an exciting finale. KXAN's Jala Washington caught up with Team USA after the competition.\n\nGymnast Stephen Nedoroscik, who delivered a final performance on pommel horse, recalled the decisive moment. \"Yeah, I mean, the last step in the whole competition, the pressure was on. Right before I went, these guys told me, 'We trust you, we have your back.' It's all I needed to hear. I went up there. I knew what I had to do. So I just went out there and did it. And as soon as I landed, that dismount and stuck it. I couldn't get the smile off my face man. That's a moment I'll never forget.\"\n\nWhen asked about the pressure, gymnast Frederick Richard said, \"I would say obviously you have pressure, but I think there was a big thing looming over us and that was opportunity. And we wanted to take that opportunity. We knew we worked really hard to seize the moment, seize the opportunity, and then that's what we did today.\"\n\nGymnast Brody Malone commented on the crowd's energy, \"Oh yeah, it felt kind of. I mean, we just fed off of it and we just made it happen, and it was awesome.\"\n\nAsher Hong described his role, \"I'm always the hype, man. I just wanted to give all my energy for my boys. I mean, if I'm not competing, I'm usually cheering for my boys. A terrible pommel horse routine for Tokyo 2020 all-around winner Daiki Hashimoto looked to have put paid to Japan's challenge early and China established a comfortable lead.\n\nBut Hashimoto stepped up to deliver a brilliant high bar routine and capitalise on Su's huge mistakes to give Japan the gold by a narrow margin - just 0.532 separated the top two nations.\n\nGreat Britain were consistent throughout, with some encouraging performances - particularly an upgraded pommel horse routine for Whitlock - that give hope there may still be medals for them in the individual finals.\n\nWhitlock, 31, appearing in his fourth and final Games, had been seeking to add to his six Olympic medals.\n\nHe will bid to win a third successive pommel horse gold on Saturday and has a chance to become the first gymnast to win medals on the same apparatus at four successive Games.\n\nHis team-mates also still have opportunities for individual medals, with Jarman reaching the all-around, floor and vault Canada early in Olympic men's artistic gymnastics qualifying | CBC Sports", "body": "Canadians 3rd with team total of 247.794 points after first of 3 subdivisions in Paris\n\nBuoyed by F\u00e9lix Dolci's seventh-place standing in the all-around event of artistic gymnastics, Canada placed third in Olympic men's gymnastics qualifying in the first of three subdivisions Saturday in Paris.\n\nThe 22-year-old's best disciplines for placing were the floor exercise and horizontal bar in which he was fifth, scoring over 14 points in each.\n\nLast October, Dolci was the first Canadian to win Pan Am artistic gymnastics gold since Wilhelm Weiler in 1963.\n\nDolci made an impact at the 2022 Commonwealth Games, earning silver in the team event and floor exercise while placing fourth in individual all-around.\n\nA year earlier, he brought home vault silver and bronze in team, all-around and floor from the Pan Am Championships.\n\nIn 2018, Dolci represented Canada at the Youth Olympics in Buenos Aires, Argentina, where he was the first Canadian to win a gymnastics medal (silver in rings).\n\nThe following year, he became the most decorated athlete in Canada Games history in 2018, compiling 11 medals over two appearances.\n\nWATCH | Dolci collects individual all-around Pan Am gold in 2023:\n\nCanada had two other athletes crack the top 10 in all-around, with Ren\u00e9 Cournoyer of Repentigny, Que., ninth (80.798) and Samuel Zakutney 10th (79.698) behind Dolci (81.498) at Bercy Arena.\n\nGreat Britain surged to an early lead with a team total of 256.561 to finish ahead of the United States.\n\nThe Americans, who finished third at the 2023 world championships ahead of Great Britain, dealt with issues on high bar and pommel horse to finish second at 253.229.\n\nCanada was third with 247.794 points, highlighted by a 42.699 performance on parallel bars.\n\nThe U.S. arrived in Paris believing it had a legitimate chance to medal in the team competition for the first time since earning a bronze in Beijing 16 years ago.\n\nThere is work to be done after the British put on a largely mistake-free clinic across six rotations. Jake Jarman (84.897) and Joe Fraser (84.666) posted the top all-around scores and six-time Olympic medalist Max Whitlock provided a jolt with an electric pommel horse routine -- his signature event -- that left the 31-year-old looking relieved.\n\nWhitlock's 15.166 trailed only American Stephen Nedoroscik, a specialist whose 15.200 likely earned him a spot in the event finals and gave his teammates some early momentum.\n\nQualifying continues later Saturday, with longtime rivals and gold medal favourites Japan and China competing in the second of three subdivisions. In rotation one (of six) Max and his colleagues will have first use of the pommel horse alongside competitors from Ukraine. Jake Jarman and Joe Fraser wil lalso go in the pommel.\n\nNext for GB will be rings, then vault, then parallel bars before horizontal bar and, finally, the floor.\n\nWhitlock described his \"crazy\" relief after the double defending champion successfully negotiated the qualifying round for the Olympic men's pommel competition at the Bercy Arena in Paris.\n\nWhitlock, who is competing at his last Games, scored 15.166, placing him second behind Stephen Nedoroscik of the US after the first qualifying rotation, a result that means his place in next Saturday's eight-man apparatus final is effectively assured.\n\nThe 31-year-old, who won the pommel title in both 2016 and 2020 but has struggled with injury since reversing a retirement decision in the wake of his success in Tokyo, believes he is still capable of plenty of improvements.\n\n\"The relief is crazy,\" admitted Whitlock, who also did his bit to help the team with routines on horizontal and parallel bars. \"I had to wait a while to present that routine, so I was mega pleased.\n\n\"Of course there's some increases I can make, some bits that I can clean up a little bit, difficulty I can increase on. But it's a huge relief to come out and do it successfully.\"\n\nA successful team performance saw Great Britain top the standings at the top of the first rotation ahead of the US and Germany, with Jake Jarman top-scoring on floor and Harry Hepworth leading the way on vault with a score of 14.766.\n\nThe results should be good enough to ensure at least one individual final for all five of the men's team, and leave them in with a shout of landing their first team medal since their bronze at London 2012.\n\nJoe Fraser, the former world parallel bars final whose all-around score of 84.666 was only eclipsed by team-mate Jake Jarman in the first rotation, paid tribute to his team's ability to deliver under pressure.\n\n\"Me and the team really just gave it our all out there,\" said Fraser. \"We really put our necks on the line and just gave it our all.\n\n\"We weren't really focusing too much on the finals, it was more about trying to put out our best work today. And I think we did as much as we could. It was also the last routine on the last rotation of the day for the Americans, meaning he had to sit in anticipation of the event for hours.\n\nIn the end, Nedoroscik scored a massive 14.866 in the final routine of the day for Team USA. At that point, the celebration was on with teammates hugging one another and waiting for it to go official that they'd be standing on the podium.\n\nBut with athletic competitions come off the field happenings as well. Brazilian swimmer Ana Carolina Vieira was banished after sneaking out of the village.\n\nAccording to Tom Balogun of the Daily Mail, Vieira, 22, snuck out to meet up with boyfriend and fellow swimmer Gabriel Santos without authorization. When questioned, Vieira was reportedly disrespectful and challenging.\n\nSantos was also disciplined but allegedly apologized for leaving and breaking the rules.\n\nNot only that, but other countries noticed the absence of basketball superstar Caitlin Clark from the Olympics.\n\nAhead of the matchup between the United States and Japan in Paris, a Japanese fan brought in and raised a sign that said 'You need Caitlin Clark to beat us'. {"uri": "8249471056", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "19:36:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T19:36:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T19:36:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.3921568691730499, "url": "https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/olympics/2024/07/29/stephen-nedoroscik-us-mens-gymnastics-paris-olympics-medal/", "title": "U.S. gymnast Stephen Nedoroscik is at the Olympics for one reason. He delivered.", "body": "PARIS -- There's pressure all over this city. It will live here for two weeks during these Olympics, at every venue and inside the thumping hearts of athletes in every medal-deciding moment. It's inescapable, and after more than two hours on the sideline during the men's gymnastics team final, American Stephen Nedoroscik finally had his turn under a career-defining spotlight.\n\nHe's a specialist, here because he excels on a single event: pommel horse, an apparatus so fickle that one misstep can derail an athlete's rhythm and send the routine into disarray. And in the waning moments of Monday's final, Nedoroscik had to deliver for the United States to clinch its first Olympic team medal since 2008. He leapt onto the apparatus and began swinging, floating through each element and maneuvering his hands with precision. His teammates watched with their arms around each other, and as soon as he dismounted, the celebration began.", "source": {"uri": "washingtonpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Washington Post"}, "authors": [{"uri": "emily_giambalvo@washingtonpost.com", "name": "Emily Giambalvo", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stephen_Nedoroscik", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Stephen Nedoroscik"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gymnastics_at_the_2020_Summer_Olympics_\u2013_Women's_artistic_team_all-around", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Gymnastics at the 2020 Summer Olympics \u2013 Women's artistic team all-around"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pommel_horse", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Pommel horse"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gymnastics", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Gymnastics"}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Track_and_Field/Athletes", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Track and Field/Athletes", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Multi-Sports/Modern_Pentathlon", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Multi-Sports/Modern Pentathlon", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Disabled/Mentally_Challenged", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Disabled/Mentally Challenged", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Shopping/Sports/Olympics", "label": "dmoz/Shopping/Sports/Olympics", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/EI5S2DN4L2722PHZJ3PK443HG4_size-normalized.jpg&w=1440", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9768598", "eventUri": "eng-9768598", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.1058823529411765, "wgt": 100, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8249737908", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "00:43:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T00:43:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T00:43:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.3882353007793427, "url": "https://www.cbssports.com/olympics/news/2024-paris-olympics-breakout-stars-ilona-maher-stephen-nedoroscik-creating-moments-memes-at-summer-games/", "title": "2024 Paris Olympics' breakout stars: Ilona Maher, Stephen Nedoroscik creating moments, memes at Summer Games - CBSSports.com", "body": "Also on the list: Frenchman L\u00e9on Marchand, who's turning swim meets into rock concerts on his way to taking gold Getty Images\n\nWithout fail, every Summer Olympics provides breakout stars that capture our attention and make this quadrennial global sporting extravaganza so much fun. In some instances, there are athletes who quite literally help market their sport exponentially purely through athletic achievement and/or vibes.\n\nWe've got a few such candidates here in 2024.\n\nWe're but a few days into the Paris Games and it's already looking like this year's Olympics could be an all-timer for memorable breakout stars. If you've been watching the action and/or following on social media, you've seen some of the fresh new faces that are amping up these Olympics. To make it easier on you, I'm packaging them all in one post. Best of all: This story will update as we continue to get more stars as the Olympics moves on into August.\n\nIlona Maher: Rugby sensation, social media star\n\nWomen's Rugby Sevens is getting an overdue glow-up at the Paris Games, thanks in large part to Team USA's push to the semifinals. The biggest reason? Maher, who is a force of nature and an irresistible watch. The Vermonter is playing in her second Olympics with Team USA, but she had her first mega-viral moment over the weekend when she channeled Derrick Henry and Marshawn Lynch en route to this score in the United States' 36-7 win over Japan.\n\nHell yeah, that's the stuff.\n\nMaher's far from the only reason to watch women's rugby sevens -- Massachusetts' Kristi Kirshe and North Carolina's Sammy Sullivan are also awesome -- but her uncommon combination of size and power makes Maher a phenomenal watch. With the increasing (and overdue) rise in women's sports popularity in recent years, Maher's emergence for Team USA has given American sports yet another reason to champion its amazing female athletes.\n\nBeyond her on-field dominance, the 27-year-old Maher is ultra-savvy with social media. She has amassed more than 1.5 million Instagram followers and is even more popular on TikTok, where she frequently speaks on body positivity and encouraging women to be comfortable in their own skin. She's also recruited the recently retired Jason Kelce to endorse women's rugby for Team USA.\n\nView this post on Instagram\n\nA post shared by Ilona Maher (@ilonamaher)\n\nMaher's personality and potent power is a breath of fresh air.\n\nAfter bruising past Great Britain, 17-7, on Monday, Maher and Team USA will play vs. New Zealand at 9:30 a.m. ET on Tuesday in the semifinals. Not bad for a program only making its third Olympics appearance in history -- and going for its first medal.\n\nStephen Nedoroscik: Bespectacled gymnast getting superhero comps\n\nWhen the glasses come off, the competition is ON.\n\nThe United States men's gymnastics team almost never medals. In the previous 19 Summer Olympics, they'd made it to the podium only twice.\n\nBut on Monday, a 16-year drought ended when Team USA took bronze, comfortably out-performing Great Britain and Ukraine in order to clinch third place; Japan won gold and China got the silver.\n\nAs the team got closer to its rare reality, the cameras panned to a nerdy-looking pommel horse specialist named Stephen Nedoroscik, who hadn't competed on any of the other disciplines (parallel bars, high bar, floor exercise, rings, vault). Watching Brody Malone's insane athleticism was one thing -- and Malone is himself a star in the making, to be sure -- but NBC's framing of Nedoroscik's lead-up to the horse set the stage and turned him into a viral sensation.\n\nThe guy's got serious Clark Kent aura, you know?\n\nNedoroscik was brought across the Atlantic Ocean for one reason and one reason only: to throw his body around a pommel horse in a lithe-yet-powerful fashion. He nailed it, and in doing so, he clinched the bronze for the United States.\n\nNedoroscik will get another big moment on Wednesday, when he'll compete in the individual pommel horse competition.\n\nL\u00e9on Marchand: French swimmer goes supernova in home country\n\nSwimming has a new superstar, and this time, it's not an athlete from America or Australia.\n\nBy pretty much every account, L\u00e9on Marchand's gold medal-wining 400-meter individual medley performance Sunday at La D\u00e9fense Arena was a once-in-a-lifetime type of event. The hometown kid, just 22, stepped onto the platform as the overwhelming favorite, then proceeded to cruise to first by touching the final wall in 4:02.95, beating Michael Phelps' 16-year Olympic record in the process.\n\nWith thousands on hand to cheer on the Frenchman, they synchronized their \"Al-lez! L\u00e9-on!\" cheers so that Marchand would hear them as he bobbed his head out of the water on the breast stroke and butterfly. Pretty cool, that. For a few moments, a swim meet took on the din and rhythm of a soccer match.\n\nWe'll be getting more of Marchand this week. He's set to compete for the podium in the 200m breaststroke, the 200m butterfly and the 200m IM.\n\nThe greatest venue ... ever?\n\nIt's not just humans who are emerging as breakout stars. And, fine, it's not like the Eiffel Tower doesn't consistently get its due.\n\nBut check this view of the beach volleyball venue in Paris. This is ... the best sporting backdrop in the history of our species?\n\nA phenomenal vista, and the picture-perfect iconography for these Olympic Games. (A shoutout to the fencing venue as well, which is also a breathtaking sight to behold.)\n\nWe knew beach volleyball would have its moment in the sun (and under the stars), but the images are even better than expected. Paris, which last hosted the Olympics in 1924, is a place beautifully built for the Summer Olympiad. It's images like this that all but ensure it won't wait another 100 years before the City of Light gets to host the Games again.", "source": {"uri": "cbssports.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBS Michael Phelps stands behind Katie Ledecky in support of her after criticism from fans\n\nIn a thrilling turn of events at the men's gymnastics team final this Monday at the Summer Olympics in Paris, all eyes were not only on the athletes but also on the stands. Brody Malone's fianc\u00e9e, Serena Ortiz, stole the spotlight as she passionately cheered for the 24-year-old American gymnast, adding an extra layer of excitement to the competition.\n\nMalone, hailing from Tennessee, delivered an epic routine on the horizontal bar, igniting hopes for a medal among fans. One enthusiastic supporter tweeted, \"The USA is having its best final in over a decade here at #Paris2024.\n\nHorizontal Bar: Paul Juda was very good (13.366). Fred Richard was magnificent (14.333). Despite a rocky start in the individual competition with an untimely fall on the pommel horse that scored him 12.100 points, Malone showed resilience.\n\nThough his routine on the horizontal bar, his strongest event, was marred by missed releases and a poor catch, earning him 12.233 points, he didn't let it dampen his spirits.\n\nMalone's perseverance shone through as he helped secure Team USA's spot in the team finals. With China and Japan as heavy favorites, the American team's chances for gold were slim. However, Malone's toughness and determination kept their medal hopes alive.\n\nIn the end, all the hardships were worth it. The US Men'sGymnasticsTeam captured their first Olympic medal in the team event since the 2008 Beijing Olympics, capturing a bronze with consistent performances from all five members. Japan won gold and China won silver.\n\nAs the team final unfolded, the atmosphere was electric. With Ortiz's heartfelt support and Malone's relentless drive, the narrative of their journey captivated fans and added a personal touch to the Olympic drama. {"uri": "8249431440", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "18:58:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T18:58:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T18:57:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.3254902064800262, "url": "https://brobible.com/sports/article/stephen-nedoroscik-pommel-horse-nerd-team-usa-gymnastics/", "title": "'Pommel Horse Nerd' Goes Viral After Steven Nedoroscik Hits Incredible Routine To Earn Team USA Unlikely Team Medal", "body": "The USA Men's Gymnastics Team has long lived in the shadow of their dominant female counterparts, and for good reason. They seem to never get it done when it matters most and find a spot on the podium at major competitions.\n\nBut, that all changed on Monday evening in Paris. Considered an underdog to medal in the Men's Artistic Gymnastics Team Final, Team USA hit their first seventeen routines, meaning all Pommel Horse specialist Steven Nedoroscik had to do for the team to earn their first team medal since Beijing 2008 was stay on the Pommel Horse.\n\nNedoroscik is at the Olympics for one thing and one thing only, as the Pommel Horse is the only event of the six events that he competed during the team final. And, the way the draw worked out, he would be the last routine of the entire competition for the USA, meaning he would have to sit and wait for over two hours while his teammates competed.\n\nThe commentator team on the NBC broadcast kept bringing up how it could come down to Nedoroscik, who wears glasses and takes them off only right before he is about to do his routine. \"Gymnastics nerd\" or \"Pommel Horse\" nerd went viral on social media as people awaited his crucial routine.\n\nFinally, it was time for the Penn State alum and 2021 World Champion to have his make-or-break moment. And, he made it a memorable one.\n\nNedoroscik scored a 14.866, plenty enough to get the USA on the podium, and social media went wild.\n\nNedoroscik will look to get back on the medal podium on Saturday in the Pommel Horse final, as he qualified tied for first for the final But, everyone will always remember the \"Pommel Horse Nerd\" coming through in the clutch for Team USA.", "source":
